HEADLINE: Albany Battles Acid Rain Fed By Other States

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 1

 BODY:
The New York State Legislature today completed passage of a bill that seeks to reduce the amount of air pollution that drifts into New York from coal-burning power plants in Midwestern and Southern states.
The measure would stop New York companies from keeping the money they make by selling pollution credits, earned by cleaning their own smokestacks, to major polluters in the Midwest and the South. The credits are now sold on the open market to utilities with older power plants that find it cheaper to buy such credits instead of modernizing their plants and cutting their emissions. 
 The action is the first by a state that directly challenges a major provision in the federal Clean Air Act of 1990: setting up a marketplace in which companies can trade the right to pollute, in the form of credits, as a commodity. Some New York utility companies immediately threatened a court challenge to the new legislation, saying the law could violate constitutional protections for interstate commerce.
It is not clear the degree to which the legislation will reduce pollution and acid rain in New York State, in large part because polluters in the South and the Midwest could turn to other companies in other states to buy their pollution credits. But experts say the legislation will ultimately limit the amount of pollution credits available to polluters in the Midwest and the South and thereby force up the price of such credits.
The federal Environmental Protection Agency, which administers the credit program, said it supported New York's attempt to regulate pollution credit trading by companies within its own borders.
Kim Rubey, a spokeswoman for the agency, defended the credit trading program. But, she added, "We are also in favor of providing maximum flexibility to states like New York in our common effort to protect public health and the environment."
Federal regulations permit a company that cuts pollution below federal levels to sell credits it has earned to a company unable or unwilling to meet those federal emission levels. The goal is to reward companies that reduce their toxic emissions below the federal standard, while forcing companies that exceed the standard to buy the right to continue polluting.
Over all, the free-market approach has resulted in cleaner air nationwide. But there has been a glaring glitch, according to environmental experts. Major polluters in the South and the Middle West have found it cheaper to buy pollution credits instead of cutting toxic emissions that have blown downwind into New York and contributed to the state's acid rain problem.
The legislation adopted today is intended to help correct that problem, essentially penalizing power companies in New York when they sell pollution credits to coal-burning power plants in the Midwest and in the South, whose pollution is a major cause of acid rain in the state.
The measure essentially calls for the state to seize all proceeds that a utility would receive from such polluters as part of a transaction for pollution credits. The bill allows state regulators to impose a fine equal to the amount of such a sale; the fine would be used to promote development and use of nonpolluting energy sources like solar power.
John F. Sheehan, a spokesman for the Adirondack Council, an environmental group, said the measure could help protect regions of the state that have been ravaged by acid rain, most notably tracts of wilderness in the Adirondacks. He said government studies estimated that in fewer than 40 years, half of that region's nearly 3,000 lakes and ponds would be too acidic to sustain the fish and plants that now live in them if the acid rain problem continued unabated.
"It makes no sense for New York to clean up its own smokestacks and then hand the right to pollute to its neighbors," said Mr. Sheehan, whose group played a major role in pushing the bill through the Legislature. "This legislation puts an end to New York's squandering of the benefits of its own responsible actions toward clean air."
The measure drew harsh rebukes from representatives of the state's powerful utility industry, who said it potentially violated the interstate commerce clause of the Constitution prohibiting states from enacting laws that restrict trade outside their borders. Proponents of the measure say companies still have the ability to sell credits to whomever they want but run the risk of incurring penalties when the credits go to out-of-state companies that contribute to New York's acid rain problem.
Carol E. Murphy, executive director of Independent Power Producers of New York, said she expected utility companies to sue the state over the measure. "Either you have a national trading program or you don't," she said. "I haven't talked to anybody who doesn't think this law is unconstitutional."
In all, New York utility companies have sold roughly 700,000 credits between 1995 and 1998 to polluters in the other states, according to a recent report issued by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. The credits now cost about $140 each and allow polluters to emit one ton of sulfur dioxide, a major contributor to acid rain and smog. New York's pollution credits account for roughly 4 percent of all the sulfur dioxide emitted in the United States, government and private estimates indicate.
The bill was passed by the Republican-controlled State Senate by a 59-to-0 vote early this afternoon. The Assembly, which has a Democratic majority, passed the bill by a 129-to-15 vote earlier this year. The measure now goes to Gov. George E. Pataki. He has expressed support for such legislation in the past, but aides said today that he wanted to review the measure carefully.
Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat who is the bill's primary author in the Assembly, said the measure did not diminish the need for federal legislation that would force plants in the Midwest and the South to reduce pollution that caused acid rain in New York. "The legislation we passed is self-help for New York," he said. "But it also focuses attention on the need for the Congress to meet us halfway by stopping other states from dumping on us."
Carl L. Marcellino, a Republican who is the legislation's main sponsor in the State Senate, said the state's action should send a message to Washington that the current system had allowed utilities in regions like the Midwest to burn high-sulfur coal at the expense of states like New York. "At the very least, I believe this legislation will force Congress into action and ultimately require the federal government to reduce acid rain," he said.
The pollution credit trading system was approved by Congress at the urging of economists and some environmentalists, who said it would bring about pollution reduction with the least amount of government intervention and the most efficiency. The act gave New York utilities a windfall of pollution credits because a New York State law had forced those companies to cut emissions in the 1980's to levels below what the federal law requires.
The legislation adopted today seeks to prohibit power companies from selling their pollution credits to companies in 10 Southern and Midwestern states by providing for fines against utilities making such sales. Those states are Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, West Virginia, Ohio, Michigan, Illinois, Kentucky, Indiana and Wisconsin. It also prohibits sales to four neighboring states: New Jersey, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

HEADLINE: Sports of the Times;
Leafs Carry The Beacon For Canada

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

 BODY:
THE Toronto Maple Leafs have their own burden of failure, their personal cross to bear, without taking on an entire country's as well. Thirty-three years without a Stanley Cup or even a trip to the finals is well along the road to other droughts of lore, but there can be no getting around the inescapable and nationalistic truth.
The drying-out of Canada as a once bottomless well of National Hockey League champions illuminates the Leafs as the last team from north of the border not to go south before the second round of the playoffs. 
 This is not to confuse Edmonton and Ottawa, the only other qualifying Canadian teams this season, with those erstwhile outfits from Winnipeg and Quebec that have actually emigrated deep into Nielsen Land, or any others trying to resist the bottom-line urge. But those teams are also part of the wagon-train reality of N.H.L. 2000, the slow and sad expatriation of the Canadian game.
"Sure, there is a more nationalistic approach around us because the economics have affected the ability of the Canadian teams to compete," said Pat Quinn, the Maple Leafs' coach, before the Devils wasted his team, 5-1, last night at Continental Arena in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference semifinals the Devils now lead, 2-1. "You just hope your players don't feel it."
It's doubtful the Leafs are feeling anything more than the frustration of the Devils shutting them out for five straight periods, or until it didn't matter last night. While there was no trademark contrast of styles on a night the Devils opened up and embarrassed Toronto at its own game, there remains the obvious polarity of what and whom these franchises represent.
If, as Quinn contended, the Leafs are as important to English-speaking Canada as the Yankees are to baseball-worshiping America, then this particular series symbolically boils down to Canadian Yankees versus YankeeNets, the pride of a nation against the identity-challenged, sellout-deprived boys from the 'burbs. It is another battle in the failing holy war to prevent the sport from being ripped from its roots, for the sake of better arena and television deals.
If the Leafs don't rally, this will be the seventh consecutive year that the Stanley Cup has not spent the off-season on Canadian soil, a record. The six years from 1936 to 1941 matches the current streak, one obliterated by Canada's domination between 1956 and 1990, when it captured 26 of 35 cups.
Summers up north have been getting colder and drier, with nothing to drink from. After Montreal won in 1993, Quinn's Vancouver Canucks became the last Canadian team of the decade to reach the finals, in 1994.
"Interest does wane," Quinn said, describing the malaise that overtakes Canada as it watches the playoffs sink deeper into America's Sun Belt. It's as if the Expos were playing the Blue Jays every October, and if no radical restructuring of the game's finances is done, Quinn agreed the possibility exists that Toronto and Montreal, the original Canadian two, could eventually be the only two left.
In Vancouver, the 1994 run to Game 7 in Madison Square Garden already feels as dated as it does in New York (for different reasons). "They've had staggering losses over the last two years," Quinn said. "What can you do? The players get a disproportionate share of the money. It's not their fault. We give it to them."
With more Americans and Europeans in the N.H.L., there is less sentiment for smaller Canadian markets. Even Garry Valk, the Leafs left wing who grew up in Edmonton and deplores the negativism he hears every summer at home in Vancouver, said he doubts many Canadian players would resent more teams relocating to the States.
The players have become conditioned by the owners and the league marketing gurus who pose as front-office visionaries and measure the soul of a sport by the dollar it turns.
"You can't compare what Calgary can offer to what an Anaheim can," Valk said. "It's that way in baseball, and it's that way in hockey."
For what it's worth, Valk and Tie Domi said they and their teammates pulled for Montreal and Vancouver as those teams made unsuccessful late-season playoff runs. "You want to see as many Canadian teams as possible because they need the postseason revenue," Valk said. "It's good for hockey."
Unfortunately, what players root for bears little consequence to what they'll sign for. American cities with little hockey orientation have greater revenue potential, foretelling a day when Canada's string of cup-less years could be as long as the Leafs'.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Cable Dispute Halts Service To Time Warner Customers
Millions of television viewers in major markets, including New York and Los Angeles, found themselves without access to "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" and many other popular TV programs as Time Warner and Walt Disney fought over how much Disney should be paid for its cable programming.
The dispute also involved issues concerning the distribution of news and entertainment programming, the growing competition between cable and satellite companies, and Disney's opposition to the proposed merger of America Online and Time Warner. ABC asked the Federal Communications Commission to restore programming. Page A1. 

Actors Stop Work on Commercials
The Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists went on strike and called on their membership of about 135,000 actors to stop working on all television and radio commercials until an agreement could be reached with advertisers. Actors rallied in Los Angeles, New York, Chicago and San Francisco. C2.
 
Mexico Revamps Bankruptcy Laws
The Mexican Congress has passed legislation to replace bankruptcy and loan-guarantee laws dating to the 1940's. C4.
 
Stocks Climb in Calm Session
Major market gauges remained in positive territory in a session devoid of volatility. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 77.87 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,811.78. The Nasdaq composite closed at 3,958.08, up 97.42 points, or 2.5 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.82 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,468.25. C14.
 
Lehman Brothers Is Named in Suit
Lehman Brothers, a source of financing for lenders catering to customers with less than perfect credit, was named in a class-action suit filed against First Alliance, a national mortgage lender that filed for bankruptcy protection in March. C10.
 
Rexall Agrees to $1.7 Billion Deal
The Dutch vitamin maker Royal Numico N.V. agreed to buy Rexall Sundown Inc. for about $1.7 billion, bolstering its No. 1 position in the American vitamin and nutritional supplement market. Numico, best known as Europe's top baby food maker, entered the vitamin market last year. Shares of Rexall Sundown rose $4.1875, to $23.4375. C4.
 
Reports Suggest Economy Is Strong
A picture of a strong economy emerged from figures released by the National Association of Purchasing Management on growth in manufacturing in April, along with a government report of a surprising 1.4 percent rise in construction spending in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of $765.2 billion. C8.
 
Realism in Fast-Food Advertising
Cliff Freeman and Partners, known for offbeat commercials like "Where's the Beef?" for Wendy's, is serving up a television campaign for Church's Fried Chicken that tries to depict working families realistically. The spots at first appear to be film clips rather than commercials. Advertising. C12.

HEADLINE: Deal Places Mohawk Casino At Kutsher's In the Catskills

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
In another round of billion-dollar poker involving a proposed casino for the Catskills, the world's largest gambling company announced yesterday that it had signed an option to buy Kutsher's Country Club, the oldest resort in the Catskills, to create a 1,400-acre entertainment complex and gambling hall that would be owned by the St. Regis Mohawks tribe.
The resort would sit on Anawana Lake in Sullivan County, five miles north of the site at Monticello Raceway that federal officials approved last month, after a four-year-long application for a $500 million casino and entertainment complex for the Mohawks. 
 But the leaders of the Mohawk tribe recently abandoned that plan and signed an unusual agreement with Park Place Entertainment, which owns 28 gambling operations in New Jersey, Nevada, Mississippi and overseas. The agreement grants Park Place the right to develop and manage Mohawk casinos throughout New York.
That new agreement is being viewed with increasing skepticism by political and governmental officials who helped gain support for the original plan.
The announcement yesterday by Park Place appears to be another attempt to outmaneuver the tribe's original partners in Monticello, Catskill Development, and seize control of a project that the developer estimates could generate more than $1 billion a year. Some gambling analysts doubt that Park Place truly wants a hall in Monticello that would undercut its three casinos in Atlantic City. The company said yesterday that it would build a resort hotel with up to 2,000 rooms in addition to the casino. The project would rival the Foxwoods casino in Connecticut and employ 4,500 people in a county whose resort industry has been slowly dying for 30 years.
"We intend to build a destination resort on the site of Kutsher's," said Clive Cummis, general counsel for Park Place. "We'll build a hotel and casino, upgrade the golf course. This would be a giant step forward in the rebirth of Sullivan County."
Mr. Cummis said Park Place believed it would inherit the federal approval granted to the original Mohawk project and proceed quickly, but officials at the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the National Indian Gaming Commission, which oversees management contracts between casino operators and tribes, said the company would have to file a new application for Kutsher's, a process that could take two to four years. Kutsher's resort was built in 1907.
For that reason, Senators Charles E. Schumer and Daniel K. Inouye and other supporters of the tribal casino were bewildered by the tribe's sudden alliance with Park Place, just when the long-sought Monticello Raceway casino seemed assured. They had supported Catskill Development's plan to put 30 acres in trust for the tribe under a seldom-used provision of federal law. The trust would establish a sovereign Indian territory for a gambling hall and bypass New York's prohibition on casinos.
"I was surprised and not prepared for this sudden change," said Senator Inouye, vice chairman of the Senate Indian Affairs Committee. "I am certain that those of us who have been trying to assist the St. Regis Mohawk tribe would like to hear directly from them about what has happened, or is happening."
Local officials in Sullivan County told four Mohawk chiefs at a meeting Friday night at the Town Hall in Thompson, Sullivan County, that they would not look kindly on a casino at Kutsher's, or a delay in the county's long-awaited casino project. The chiefs said they wanted to put a casino at the raceway, according to two people who attended the meeting, but were also considering another location, which the two men presumed to be Kutsher's.
"It is extremely important that it be located at the Monticello Raceway," said Anthony P. Cellini, supervisor of the town of Thompson. "If they change locations now, there'll be very little support from local people. Our residents have had this golden carrot dangled in front of them for too long. To delay this for another two to four years is not acceptable."
There is widespread speculation among gambling analysts, Sullivan County officials and some dissident Mohawks that Arthur M. Goldberg, chief executive of Park Place, is intent on delaying and derailing a Sullivan County casino to protect his Atlantic City casinos, which generate 30 percent of the company's profits. Other analysts say that Mr. Goldberg wins whether he gains control of the casino project in Monticello or whether it is delayed, perhaps forever, by regulatory reviews and lawsuits.
Mr. Cummis struck a deal on Friday with Mark Kutsher, the head of the family that owns the country club, under which Park Place agreed to buy 50 acres within 60 days and a five-year option to acquire the remaining 1,350 acres. Park Place, which said it would transfer the 50 acres to the Mohawks, agreed to hire the Kutsher family, as well as its employees, and to continue to use the Kutsher name in some manner.
"Arthur Goldberg is a builder, not a blocker," Mr. Cummis said. "We're going to get this built and done, just as we did with the Paris in Las Vegas, on time and on budget."
The Mohawk chiefs, who did not consult the lawyers they hired to work on gambling ventures before they signed the Park Place deal, granted Park Place broad casino development rights on April 14 in return for a $3 million loan to bolster the tribe's financially crippled Akwesasne Casino at the reservation in Hogansburg, N.Y., and 70 percent of the profits. Fearing problems in Monticello, the tribe turned its back on Catskill Development and made the deal with Park Place, which will almost certainly cause a lawsuit by Catskill Development.
Robert A. Berman, a partner in Catskill Development, has called the Park Place deal "the greatest rip-off of an Indian tribe since the Dutch grabbed Manhattan for $24." If Park Place eventually has a casino in Sullivan County, it may have to strike a deal with Catskill Development, which has vowed never to do so and has begun talks with other tribes for a casino in the area.
The Mohawks have not notified federal officials or Catskill Development that the tribe has abandoned the project at Monticello Raceway.
"I can't imagine that the tribe, or anybody who recognizes how long it takes to get land into trust for gaming, would want to undo four years of work," said Rick Chiff, deputy chief of staff at the National Indian Gaming Commission. "We're proceeding with the Monticello contract because that's the one that's before us and that's the one that's greenlighted."
Many residents of Sullivan County have viewed gambling for decades as a way to revive the county's economy. But a series of efforts to legalize gambling failed, so the major gambling companies, real estate developers and many politicians paid little attention.
In recent years, however, Gov. George E. Pataki has said that he favors Indian casinos in former resort areas like the Catskills and western New York. And then, while federal approval of the casino at the Monticello Raceway was inching forward in Washington last year, real estate developers, who had contributed thousands of dollars to Mr. Pataki and the Republican Party, began snapping up large tracts in Sullivan County for hotel projects.
Mr. Goldberg of Park Place got involved in talks with the tribe last fall, as did the company's consultant, Alfonse M. D'Amato, the former senator. Donald J. Trump and other casino operators in Atlantic City who feared the competition lobbied against the project in Albany, while Sen. Robert Torricelli of New Jersey lobbied vigorously against it in Washington, and, as recently as April 7, he warned that the Mohawks would bring crime to the Catskills and northern New Jersey.
But Mr. Torricelli has had a change of heart. The senator, who is friendly with Mr. Cummis and Mr. Goldberg and has received thousands of dollars in political contributions from executives at the gambling company, said he now recognized that the battle against Indian gambling has been lost.
"I think gaming in Monticello is probably an inevitability," Mr. Torricelli said. "It seems to me that Park Place is offering a good deal."
The emergence of Park Place has made Governor Pataki's next step more uncertain. He had chastised Mr. Torricelli last summer for opposing the New York casino, and both critics and supporters of gambling said that he had seemed to be lining up to approve a Monticello casino.
The role of Park Place "adds to the long list of questions surrounding this whole situation," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Governor Pataki. "Every day seems to bring another new development."

HEADLINE: 2 Microsofts: The Right Thing?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Remedy for Microsoft" (editorial, April 28): You applaud the spectacle of government lawyers using laws developed over the last 100 years to throttle this country's leading high-technology company. It's hard to imagine a greater farce. 
 Bill Gates has done more to make personal computers cheap and powerful, and more to help the new economy, than all the world's bureaucrats put together.
 
CHRISTOPHER M. SCHNAUBELT
Santa Maria, Calif., April 29, 2000

INTERNATIONAL A3-16
 
TV Confession in Iran At Jew's Espionage Trial
The first of 13 Jewish men charged with spying went on trial in Shiraz, and Iranian television showed him making an admission that he had spied for Israel. The public confession came after the government refused to allow family members, human rights groups or the public to witness the opening of the trial. A1 

Few Takers on China Visit
Only two congressmen undecided on whether to vote to give China permanent normal trade relations accepted an administration invitation to let a Cabinet officer lead them on a trip to China to gauge trade and human rights conditions. A1
 
European Opposes U.S. Plan
The foreign policy chief for the European Union, Javier Solana, said European officials were concerned about possible damage that the Clinton administration's plan for a missile defense system could do to Europe's security ties with the United States. A16
 
May Day Mass With the Pope
Pope John Paul II, pre-empting the trade unions' traditional hold on May 1, presided over a workers' rally that combined a solemn Catholic Mass with a raucous rock concert dedicated to third world debt relief. But the day was less about the Vatican or pop music than about the changes it showed taking place in Italy. A6
 
Dispute on Red Cross Symbols
Concern is spreading among international relief organizations that the American Red Cross may be on the verge of withdrawing from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies because the umbrella organization has not agreed to admit an Israeli contingent under a Star of David flag. A8
 
Philippines Hostages Examined
A doctor made the first visit to a group of 21 hostages held by armed rebels of the Islamic separatist group Abu Sayyaf. The hostages were suffering from hunger and diarrhea and some pleaded for water, as 50 to 70 rebels guarded the area. On a nearby island, another group of Abu Sayyaf rebels escaped with their 27 hostages when government troops overran their mountain base over the weekend, the military said. A5
 
Turkey Leader Lacks Votes
Parliament failed for a second time to muster the two-thirds vote necessary to elect Ahmet Necdet Sezer, the reformist candidate for president favored by the leaders of all five parties, although Mr. Sezer finished far ahead of other candidates, with 314 votes. The next ballot is set for Friday; in that round, just a simple majority of 276 will be necessary. A12

NATIONAL A18-25
 
Some Big Corporations Are Forsaking Soft Money
Soft-money donations are on a pace to set a record, even though many big corporations have stopped making them because executives are disillusioned with the process and feel there are better ways to spend their companies' money and still stay politically involved. But other corporate interests, senior executives and unions are increasing their unrestricted gifts to political parties. A1
 
McCain-Gore Meeting
Senator John McCain and Vice President Al Gore met for 20 minutes on Sunday. Mr. Gore said they discussed changing campaign financing, Mr. McCain's signature issue and one that Mr. Gore is also advancing. Mr. McCain is to meet with Gov. George W. Bush next week. A24
 
Document Request Rebuffed
The White House said it would invoke executive privilege and lawyer-client privilege, as it told the House Government Reform Committee that it would not surrender some documents subpoenaed in an inquiry about missing e-mail messages. The action prompted an angry reply by the committee's chairman, Dan Burton. A23
 
Challenging Asylum Case
Elian Gonzalez was pressured by "distant" relatives to sign a political asylum claim that he neither wanted nor understood, a lawyer for his father said in federal court papers. A22
 
Ruling on Retroactive Law
The Supreme Court overturned a Texas man's sex abuse conviction on the ground that a change in state law had made it easier for the prosecution to prove its case than at the time the crime was committed. A24
 
Judge Mediates Settlement
Lawyers said a tentative settlement had been reached in a 16-year-old case involving accusations that Baltimore public schools had woefully neglected physically and mentally disabled students. The settlement was reached through the mediation of a federal judge, a procedure thought to have been used only once before, and then unsuccessfully, in the Microsoft antitrust case. A18
 
Retiring 6.2% of National Debt
The government said it would pay off $216 billion of the $3.5 trillion national debt by Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year. In February, the projection was $167 billion. The Treasury secretary said the bigger payment resulted from the booming economy and a growth in tax revenue. A23 

NEW YORK/REGION B1-10
 
State Challenges U.S. Law In Bid for Cleaner Air
The Legislature gave final passage to a bill intended to reduce air pollution drifting into New York from coal-burning power plants in the Midwest and South. The measure would stop New York companies from keeping money they make by selling pollution credits, earned by cleaning their own smokestacks, to major polluters elsewhere. The action is the first by a state that directly challenges a major provision of the Federal Clean Air Act of 1990. A1
 
Postponing 'Monologues' Role
Donna Hanover will not take the lead in "The Vagina Monologues" on May 30 because of "family circumstances." Her husband, Mayor Giuliani, has disclosed he has prostate cancer. B1
 
Catskills Casino Plan
Park Place Entertainment signed an option to buy Kutsher's Country Club, the oldest resort in the Catskills, to create an entertainment and gambling complex that would be owned by the St. Regis Mohawks. B1

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: AS POLITICAL GIFTS SET A RECORD PACE, SOME STOP GIVING

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Soft-money donations to the political parties are on a pace to set a record this year, but more and more large corporations have quietly stopped giving them.
In some cases, senior executives say they want to distance themselves from what they describe as the capital's unseemly culture of cash and influence, while others acknowledge that their companies are simply not getting much in return for the money. 
 Thirty-one corporations that in each previous election cycle since 1993-94 contributed at least $100,000 in soft money -- unlimited and largely unregulated gifts to the parties -- have not donated any soft money in the current cycle, covering the last 15 months, according to a computerized study of Federal Election Commission records. The list includes prolific past contributors like Revlon, Advanced Micro Devices, Miramax Films, and Starwood Hotels and Resorts.
None of the 31 companies have made statements announcing an end to their soft-money contributions, and many still make much smaller, federally regulated donations through political action committees. But some executives confirmed, although not for attribution, that their companies had adopted, or were weighing, a permanent ban on writing soft-money checks.
Only a few large companies -- General Motors, Monsanto, AlliedSignal, Time Warner, none of them among the most recent 31 -- have formally announced in recent years that they have sworn off soft money.
Few corporations have followed suit, in at least some cases because they do not want to risk angering legislators in Washington. "There are more and more companies out there who are refusing to give money, but they are not advertising their decision," said Charles E. M. Kolb, president of the Committee for Economic Development, an association of corporate executives fighting for a campaign finance overhaul that would outlaw soft money. "I suspect that there are more and more companies asking themselves if this is really worth it. What's just as interesting, though, is the fact that companies are scared to tell people."
Several executives said their corporations had stopped giving soft money because they had found better use of their resources, like lobbying, contributing to political action committees and acting as hosts for fund-raising events. Others have stopped giving because they believe that soft money plays an unhealthy role in the political process.
While more companies quietly join the ranks of those forgoing soft-money donations, other corporate interests, senior executives and labor unions are redoubling them. Since January 1999, the Democratic and Republican Parties have raised $160.5 million in soft money, according to data compiled last week by the nonpartisan watchdog Common Cause. That was nearly double the $84.6 million in soft money raised by the parties in the first 15 months of the 1996 election cycle. By November, the parties will have raised nearly $500 million in soft money, some experts predict, as against $262 million in the 1996 cycle.
But the addition of 31 companies to the roster of those turning their backs on giving soft money does add muscle to the effort of two organizations of corporate leaders that are pushing for a soft-money ban.
The effort began in 1995, when Jerome Kohlberg, a founder of the leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, created Campaign for America to fight for an overhaul of the nation's campaign finance system. Mr. Kohlberg is being assisted by Warren E. Buffett, the acclaimed value investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway. Last fall, Campaign for America reported that 121 companies that had given at least $100,000 each in 1994 or 1996 had since stopped contributing soft money.
The other group, Mr. Kolb's Committee for Economic Development, has an even larger number of corporate executives, although not all of them have persuaded their companies to stop giving soft money.
A senior vice president at one company that has stopped giving soft-money donations said that "there was not much benefit" to them, especially inasmuch as membership fees of the parties' most elite donor clubs had jumped to $250,000 from $100,000.
"What happens is by the time you give the base amount to the House Republicans, Senate Republicans, House Democrats and Senate Democrats, it costs the company a total of $60,000 and you find you don't get a lot of action for it," this executive said. "As companies go through cost-cutting measures, it's an expense that is harder to justify."
This executive's company, which stopped giving soft money in late 1998, has since found no negative ramifications in its dealings with lawmakers. "When we were giving $10,000 or $15,000," the officer said, "it was never enough; you are constantly asked for more. The no-money pledge is better than the some-money pledge."
Some longtime fund-raisers and political strategists say they have seen recent signs of what they call "donor fatigue," especially among corporate executives who are bombarded with solicitations for the parties' elite donor clubs and almost weekly black-tie dinners and political retreats at resort hotels. The fund-raisers say the fatigue is the fault of both parties' enormous appetite for soft money.
"Just in the last few weeks, I have had several clients of mine say they are getting out of this soft-money business," said Lanny J. Davis, a lawyer and lobbyist at Patton Boggs.
"Both political parties have gotten so excessive in trying to beat the other in the soft-money hunt," Mr. Davis said. "I'm part of the problem, and I've never seen such disgust with the practice in all my years here. It has reached critical mass."
In past election years, the Democratic National Committee and the Republican National Committee were the most aggressive soft-money solicitors. This year, however, the Senate and House fund-raising committees of each party are also pushing hard to collect big soft-money checks. With the battle for control of Congress intensifying, many donors are being solicited by multiple party committees at the same time, exhausting some supporters.
Other fund-raisers, however, play down the danger of donor exhaustion, noting that more corporations are writing larger checks than ever.
Last week, for example, the Republican National Committee brought in $21.3 million -- the most ever raised in a single event -- at its gala in Washington saluting the party's apparent presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush. The Republicans received six-figure contributions -- and fund-raising assistance -- from Philip Morris, AT&T and the National Rifle Association, all three of which are among the most generous soft-money contributors to the party this year. The Democrats hope to raise a similar amount at a tribute to President Clinton later this month.
One longtime Republican lobbyist predicted that more corporations would shun soft-money giving if they learned that competitors were doing the same. "I think we are going to see a rush to the exit, if not a stampede," the lobbyist said. "People are beginning to say it does not make sense in the context of our budgeting and our giving."
Mr. Kolb, whose Committee for Economic Development has enlisted more than 250 executives and retired executives to endorse a soft-money ban, said an interesting question would be whether companies that had stopped giving believed that their interests were given short shrift by Congress as a result.
General Motors, which stopped soft-money giving in 1997, thinks not. Bill Noack, a G.M. spokesman, said the company had found that its decision had not affected relations with Congress at all.
"There are so many issues that affect us -- the environment, safety and trade -- there is something every day," Mr. Noack said. "And I can't say our decision has made an impact at all."
(The company, through its political action committee, still makes regulated donations, with a $5,000 legal maximum, to federal candidates.)
Like G.M., Monsanto, which had given $88,700 in soft money during the 1995-96 election cycle, stopped giving it in 1997. And like G.M., St. Louis-based Monsanto, which merged in April with Pharmacia & Upjohn, found that relations with Congress were unaffected, a spokeswoman said.
"Before we gave -- and after we stopped giving -- we always had wonderful relationships with the members in Congress who represent our company in Missouri," said the spokeswoman, Linda Fisher, Pharmacia's vice president for government affairs. "We support them through our PAC and fund-raisers, and we have found that to be the most successful way to have our voice heard."
Among the 31 companies that have most recently abandoned soft-money giving -- identified through a computerized check for The New York Times by the nonpartisan Campaign Study Group of Springfield, Va. -- some, of course, may find reason to make such a donation before November.
Further, among these companies, some top executives have stepped up their contributions. The Spanos Companies, for instance, contributed $295,000 in soft money in 1997-98, and none in the last 15 months. But its chairman, Alex G. Spanos, gave $250,000 to the Republican National Committee in March 1999, records of the Federal Election Commission show.
And while neither Revlon nor its chief executive, Ronald O. Perelman, has given any soft money this cycle, Mr. Perelman has given a total of $7,000 in federally restricted contributions to various candidates.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Landlords Seek Rise In Rents, Up to 15%

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Landlords of the one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City yesterday proposed a rent increase of 9 percent for a one-year lease and 15 percent for a two-year lease. They cited higher operating costs, notably the price of fuel oil for heat and hot water.
"Significant inflationary pressures are building," said Jack Freund, vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a landlords' group. It will detail its position at a hearing today before the city's Rent Guidelines Board. The board has scheduled a preliminary vote for Monday on the maximum rent increases on stabilized apartments for leases renewed in the year starting Oct. 1. 
 The debate over rent is intensifying this year, after a long period of modest increases. For five of the last six years, the board has approved increases of 2 percent for a one-year lease and 4 percent for a two-year lease.
But last week, the board released its annual study of the landlords' operating costs, showing a rise of 7.8 percent. At the same time, the board's chairman, Edward S. Hochman, proposed changes in the rent formula that could result in increases of 8.5 percent for a one-year lease and 12 percent for a two-year lease, although he said he did not expect those numbers to be adopted.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who appoints the rent board, called those numbers "very, very high" and stressed that no decisions had been made. BRUCE LAMBERT

Bid to Keep Printers in City

HEADLINE: Wined, Dined, Wooed on Trade: Just 2 Lawmakers Travel to China

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, May 1

 BODY:
Measured on a per-vote basis, it was probably one of the more expensive lobbying efforts ever undertaken by the Clinton administration.
Hoping to sway legislators who remain undecided on whether to grant China permanent normal trade relations in a vote set for this month, President Clinton set aside money earlier this year to fly wavering lawmakers to China where they could gauge trade and human rights conditions for themselves. 
 But, in the end, only two undecided congressmen showed up.
Two trips had originally been proposed, one led by Commerce Secretary William Daley and another by Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman. But these quickly became political no-flight zones for politicians worried about coming under attack by organized labor lobbyists who argue that permanent trade status would erode human rights in China and cost American jobs.
So Secretary Daley's trip, which was to have included a dozen legislators, was "consolidated" with that of Secretary Glickman's. And when Mr. Glickman lifted off last week from Andrews Air Force Base in a C32-A, the Air Force version of the civilian Boeing 757, he had only two undecided congressmen in tow -- and administration officials were refusing to identify them until the flight had left, lest they be pressured at the last minute to drop out.
And so began the education of Representative Gregory Meeks, a New York Democrat, and Representative Ruben Hinojosa, a Texas Democrat, neither of whom had been to China before. They were treated royally in Beijing, where they met with a deputy prime minister and watched the sun rise over the Great Wall.
In Shanghai, they had a private audience with China's chief negotiator with Taiwan. And in Hong Kong, they met with the chief executive of China's newly reclaimed territory and dined with its business elite at the exclusive China Club.
About a dozen administration officials accompanied them, as well as two congressmen who support making China's trade status permanent, Greg Walden, an Oregon Republican, and Norman Dicks, a Washington Democrat. And dozens more people chaperoned the men from place to place on the ground.
Congressmen Meeks and Hinojosa seemed bemused by so much attention, sometimes falling behind the throng that moved through a program meant to show them how much the United States would lose if it did not grant China the permanent trade status. China's favorable status has been subject to annual review by Congress since the suppression of pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square in 1989, though it has always been approved.
Mr. Meeks appeared particularly suspicious of the over-orchestrated show, and skipped a supermarket visit in Shanghai in order to meet with common folk. With a consular official translating at his side, Mr. Meeks trudged up the stairs of a middle-class apartment block and along the dirt paths of a migrant worker neighborhood in his gray summer suit, addressing startled Chinese along the way with his big American hello.
"Do you like China?" he asked a young migrant from Anhui province who invited him into her barren, whitewashed room.
"Of course, I do," she replied, "I'm Chinese!"
Mr. Meeks questioned everyone he met about human rights ("I've never had any trouble," one elderly man replied in a typical exchange) and what they thought about China joining the World Trade Organization ("Well, of course you should support it; we want to compete with the rest of the world," said Cui Qian, a middle-aged businesswoman).
Between stops, he fought to reconcile what he had heard from the labor unions in Washington with what he saw in China. He detected none of the repression or exploitation so often talked about.
"The Chinese seem to think that economics are more important to them than whatever form of government they have right now," he concluded.
Mr. Meeks was uncertain what advantage labor unions could expect if Congress does not grant China permanent trade status when it votes on the measure later this month. "That's something I'll have to ask them," Mr. Meeks said, noting that the issue is muddled even in his own district, the borough of Queens.
United Parcel Service, which has a large operation at Kennedy International Airport, supports permanent trade status and China's membership in the World Trade Organization because the company is lobbying for a cargo route to China. The Teamsters support the company in that bid, which would create union jobs, but are nonetheless lobbying against permanent normal trade relations, or P.N.T.R.
Mr. Meeks and Mr. Hinojosa watched workers unload sacks of American soybeans from barges in Shanghai. China is the biggest buyer of American soybeans and is importing $700 million worth of them in the current season.
"There's a lot of demand for imported soybeans in China and if we don't give them P.N.T.R. that demand will go to the Argentineans or the Brazilians," said Philip Laney, who represents the American Soybean Association in China and was on hand to lobby the congressmen.
China has said it will apply to enter the World Trade Organization regardless of the Congressional vote, and the United States is unlikely to stand in its way -- in part because such a move would infuriate Taiwan whose membership is being held up until China joins.
China's entry does not require the support of Congress. And although President Clinton promised China during the negotiations that the annual Congressional review of its trade status would end, a Geneva-based trade official said, "China can come in regardless of what Congress votes, provided that the U.S. representatives in the General Council and the Working Party approve the conditions, along with the other member governments."
While no one is sure exactly what would happen if Congress votes against permanent normal trade relations, China could join and then invoke Article XIII of the Marrakesh Agreement that established the trade organization, allowing Beijing to withhold from the United States commitments it makes to other organization members.
"If the United States misses this opportunity it will actually lose the tremendous market of China and will be giving away the opportunity for participating in this market to its competitors," China's trade minister, Shi Guangsheng, said last month. "In that case, the United States, especially U.S. companies, will suffer the most."
That has many American business people in China worried.
"China's government has no qualms about rewarding political cooperation with economic opportunity," said Jeffrey Bernstein, founder of Emerge Logistics, which handles distribution of foreign products on the mainland, an industry likely to open most dramatically to foreign participation if China joins the trade organization.
"Jeopardizing American companies' natural advantage in distributing products provides a wonderful opportunity for our European, Asia and Australian friends," he said.
Larry Wortzel, director of the Heritage Foundation's Asian Studies Center says more than 200,000 American jobs are directly related to China trade.
The House of Representatives will vote on China's trade status during the week of May 22. Legislators familiar with the vote say it is still 10 to 15 votes short of passage.
The White House has been working with Representative Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat, on "parallel legislation" that would set up a watchdog Congressional commission to review Chinese trade and human rights policies and perhaps recommend sanctions against Beijing within the limits of organization rules.
Mr. Meeks and Mr. Hinojosa, for their part, remained undecided as they headed home this weekend.
"You do get a different feel once you have been here," Mr. Meeks said. "Theory and practice are two different things."

HEADLINE: Bergen County Sheriff Halts Jail Construction, Saying Project Is Over Budeget

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 1

 BODY:
The Bergen County sheriff blocked construction at the new county jail today, saying he would not allow work to resume until county officials explained why the project was over budget and running late. County officials countered that the sheriff was waging a misleading, partisan battle to divert attention from what they called his own poor performance.
The sheriff, Joseph L. Ciccone, a Democrat, held a news conference in a vacant cell block of the new jail on River Road to cite an analysis published last month by The Record of Hackensack, which asserted that the projected cost of the project was $16 million over budget, after an initial estimate of $45 million. 
 Sheriff Ciccone, who unseated the Republican incumbent for sheriff in November 1998, said that the county executive, William P. Schuber; the county administrator, Charles A. Nurnberger; and the Republican-dominated Board of Freeholders had ignored his requests for information on the overruns.
"Sixteen million dollars over the original price tag," Mr. Ciccone said. "If that happened in the private sector, someone would be fired."
The first phase of construction was completed in March, and last month more than 600 inmates were moved into the new building.
Mr. Ciccone said he would not allow the start of construction on the project's second phase -- adding administrative space to the new building and renovating part of the old jail for 300 more beds -- because it involves the same project manager, the Gilbane Construction Company of Mercerville, N.J. And with 150 beds now vacant in the new jail, Sheriff Ciccone said he also questioned whether the work on the old jail was necessary.
County officials acknowledged there had been delays, but added that the sheriff's cost figures were all wrong. Officials said an architect estimated that the project would cost the county $45 million, but that was in 1993, three years before the project was sent out for bids. The estimate also failed to include the expense of hiring a construction manager, which cost $4.3 million.
Mr. Nurnberger said the actual initial cost was more like $53 million, including the cost of the project manager, by the time bids were solicited in 1996. Inflation had increased the cost as the county fought and won a lawsuit brought by the City of Hackensack in 1993 seeking to prevent the jail from being constructed on the site, which is along the Passaic River. There were also change orders totaling $2.7 million, making the total cost to the county about $56 million, Mr. Nurnberger said.
Scott Chilcote, Gilbane's project executive, confirmed that the first phase was completed 11 months late. He said the delays included the discovery of huge concrete slabs buried deep underground that had been part of a defunct sewage treatment plant.
"Every time you put a shovel in the ground, you don't know what you're going to find," Mr. Chilcote said.
Anthony Cassano, the chairman of the seven-member Board of Freeholders, said the sheriff was trying to divert attention from his own problems.
"It's a smoke screen," Mr. Cassano said. "His performance has been incredibly lackluster."
He cited three escapes from the old jail this year. He also said the sheriff had already exhausted his overtime budget for the year.
The number of beds, Mr. Cassano said, had been dictated by a court order stemming from a 1990 lawsuit by the state public advocate seeking to ease crowding at the old jail.
Mr. Cassano said the county was seeking a court injunction to allow the work to continue. Judge Sybil R. Moses of the State Superior Court is to meet with both sides on Tuesday in her chambers at the Bergen County Courthouse.

HEADLINE: Placing Hopes In the Net;
Indonesia Entrepreneur Tries To Redeem Business Dynasty

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
South of a park called Dreamland on an abandoned airfield surrounded by slums, Edward Suriadjaya is testing the Internet's powers of redemption.
In a country dominated by corporate dynasties, Mr. Suriadjaya is famous as the scion who broke his family's bank and cost his family the car company his father founded in 1957, Astra International. 
 Now, Mr. Suriadjaya (pronounced sir-ya-JAI-ah) has returned to the corporate stage as a high-technology entrepreneur planning to build a stable of dot-coms and turn Jakarta's old airport into Indonesia's Silicon Valley. In the process, he wants not only to resurrect a fallow property investment but also to prove at last that he was an unwitting pawn of politics and to help restore his family's position.
"I'm putting my future at stake," he said in a recent interview. "I believe that information technology, as an enabler for the Indonesian nation, is in line with the development of technology in the world and has a very good future."
His vehicle is PT CyberCity Indonesia, a holding company with what he calls a "bag of goodies" he hopes will attract $76.5 million in new investments with a stock offering set for year-end. Inside the bag are stakes in an Internet service, two Web portals, an incubator for Net-related businesses, a multimedia academy and a 7.5-acre sliver of a 109-acre piece of overgrown airport that he hopes to turn into a high-technology commercial and residential sanctuary.
"Clicks and bricks," Mr. Suriadjaya intoned in his sonorous Indonesian drawl. He says he already has a heavy list of backers, including the governments of Indonesia, Malaysia and Japan as well as Microsoft.
There is no shortage of naysayers. Many point to Mr. Suriadjaya's reputation. "I'm always skeptical about whatever Edward does," said Manggi T. Habir, president of the credit-rating agency Pemeringkat Efek Indonesia.
While the Suriadjayas' influence with Indonesia's new government has produced criticism, some skeptics wonder about Mr. Suriadjaya's high-technology connections. They question the seriousness of a project that despite claiming to have set up at least five different ventures, has yet to establish a corporate Web site. CyberCity, they say, is more about bailing out a $50 million project Mr. Suriadjaya was in charge of developing on the site of the old Kemayoran domestic airport before the colossal failure of the bank he ran, Bank Summa, in 1992.
Mr. Suriadjaya is not the only Asian tycoon to become a pioneer of the new economy. Though brash unknowns have won many of America's new fortunes, the high-technology start-up scene in Hong Kong, the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand is dominated by the rich and powerful. Skeptics say it is a sign of how much buzz surrounds the Internet; in Asia, as elsewhere, there is nothing like an Internet play to give an old-economy stock a new shine. Others say it is a symptom of economies in which wealth is still tightly concentrated and local capital markets are developing too slowly to fuel the speedy growth of the new economy.
"There are a lot of entrepreneurs who want to start up but don't have resources," said Vasant Chatikavanij, executive vice president of Loxinfo, a Thai Internet service. "They end up selling themselves cheap. They sell to companies like us."
Indonesia may seem an unlikely locale for dot-com mania. Most bankers and economists will not even discuss its Internet potential. This, after all, is a country with a government that still depends on the International Monetary Fund to make ends meet; a country where a personal computer costs nearly twice the average annual income. Only 4 of every 1,000 Indonesians use the Internet, according to the International Data Corporation, compared with 14 of every 1,000 Asians over all. Most people do not even have a phone.
But analysts and Internet entrepreneurs like Mr. Suriadjaya say such statistics highlight the promise. Indonesia, the world's fourth-most-populous nation, already has more Internet users than Singapore, and millions of wealthy urban residents with money to spend online. New and cheaper ways of connecting to the Internet, like TV set-top boxes and mobile phones, they say, will quickly extend the Net to more of Indonesia's 200 million people.
"There's a large market coming out of the crisis that has spending potential," said Jonathan Morris, 26, a Bostonian who dropped out of the Harvard Business School a year and a half ago to start Indonesia's most popular Web site, astaga.com.
Mr. Suriadjaya, 51, comes to the Internet world with more business experience -- and, some say, more baggage. The eldest son of William Suriadjaya, a respected businessman who built Astra from a small importer of diesel generators into a $2.4 billion automotive giant, Edward Suriadjaya started out as a salesman at an Astra unit. He then ventured into finance, first with a bank in Germany and later a finance company in Hong Kong.
In 1988, he bought a small Indonesian bank, renamed it Bank Summa and expanded rapidly through the Summa Group. By 1991, Bank Summa was among the country's largest private banks, with about $1 billion in assets, most in loans to Summa companies and much of that for property investments.
One such investment was the $50 million Jakarta International Trade Fair Corporation, a joint venture of Mr. Suriadjaya's Griya Nusantara Pratama, the Indonesian State Secretariat, Jakarta's city government and a group of Japanese investors. The corporation was to develop 109 acres of the old Kemayoran airport, which had closed in 1985.
But in mid-1990, Indonesia adopted a tight fiscal policy, and Summa's world began to unravel. The property market sank, and Bank Summa was faced with $303 million in losses in 1991. Mr. Suriadjaya's father moved in to bail out Summa, removing his son as chairman and pledging Astra shares against the bank's obligations. The more he struggled to prop up the bank, the lower Astra's share price sank and the deeper Bank Summa's hole grew. By late 1992, the central bank closed Summa amid a depositor run. To help meet the bank's $690 million in liabilities, the Suriadjayas relinquished virtually their entire 76 percent stake in Astra to several businessmen close to President Suharto.
That is only half the story, according to a version of events that Mr. Suriadjaya said could be told only now that Mr. Suharto has fallen. The government set him up, he said, by encouraging him to lend, only to later impose restrictions and then remove government pension funds from Bank Summa to precipitate its collapse. He said his father would eventually spell out who was behind the intrigue in a tell-all biography. "I blame ourselves for being naive," Mr. Suriadjaya said. "We refused to be a crony."
Mr. Suriadjaya suggested he was victimized because his first wife, who died of cancer the year the family lost Astra, was the daughter of President Sukarno, whom Mr. Suharto ousted in 1965. Astra had long been uncharacteristically independent of the Suharto clan. And Mr. Suharto was reportedly less than appreciative when, in mid-1990 Bank Summa built a network of banks for rural Muslim communities with a powerful cleric named Abdurrahman Wahid.
Now, Mr. Wahid is Indonesia's president, the Suhartos are fending off prosecutors, and the Suriadjayas are rebuilding. In 1998, Edward Suriadjaya was reinstated as a board member of Jakarta International Trade Fair. Last December, his father was named chairman.
The family's comeback has forced President Wahid to counter accusations that the Suriadjayas have become neocronies. Last month, the president sold his stake in the Muslim finance company he set up with Edward Suriadjaya in mid-1990 after it bought a stake in Mandiri Inti Finance, a company Edward Suriadjaya took control of last January.
Mandiri was trying to raise funds for a last-minute bid to buy back the Suriadjayas' stake in Astra -- it was on the block after being seized from the indebted cronies who had bought it seven years earlier -- before the government sold it to a Singapore-led consortium.
Mr. Suriadjaya denies trying to capitalize on his presidential connections. "If I were doing it, why didn't I do it before, when we were fighting for our existence?" he said.
Last month, Mandiri Inti Finance changed its name to Siwani Trimitra and said it would start raising funds for CyberCity. But most of Mr. Suriadjaya's Internet deals have so far been conducted by L & M Group Investments, a financially troubled engineering company in Singapore, which Mr. Suriadjaya's younger brother, Edwin, ended up controlling after taking over a different Singapore company.
Edwin Suriadjaya remains listed as L & M's deputy chairman, and his father is chairman; Edward Suriadjaya became a member of the board last year and, after slowly building up his stake in the company, was named chief executive last month.
Underscoring the tangled shareholdings and cross-shareholdings that make Indonesian business so nebulous, L & M owns part of CyberCity together with Jakarta International Trade Fair and Edward Suriadjaya's own Griya Nusantara Pratama, which still owns part of Jakarta International. Just how much of CyberCity each owns, Mr. Suriadjaya said, is "now being arbitrarily decided." CyberCity, in turn, owns only a portion of the five Internet-related ventures it is involved in.
Nevertheless, investors are using L & M's stock as way to bet on the project. It rose 20 percent in November when L & M announced that MyWeb Inc.com, an American set-top box maker, would take a 10 percent stake in CyberCity and help build an Internet service in Indonesia, then fell 8 percent when the deal fell apart a month later. Soon afterward, when L & M said it was in talks to replace MyWeb with Microsoft, the stock rose more than 40 percent.
L & M's share price has drifted down about 28 percent this year, tracking the decline of Asia's stock markets. But L & M has also been dogged by concerns about whether partnerships will materialize. The company has announced that SingNet, Singapore Telecommunications' Internet unit, was considering a 30 percent stake in CyberCity, and that Detecon Marketing Consulting, a unit of Deutsche Telekom, would buy 10 percent. On Friday, L & M said it had signed a memorandum of understanding with SingTel to help develop CyberCity but gave no details. Detecon said it was in talks but that no deal had yet been reached.
In February, L & M finally signed a deal with Microsoft -- not to take a stake in CyberCity but rather to help build a news and information Web site in return for a share of the revenue the site generates. The site is scheduled to start this month. The only CyberCity venture that appears to be up and running is the Jakarta Multimedia Academy, which L & M established with Malaysian Technology Development, a government-owned venture capital concern.
"We support CyberCity fully, but we're still waiting for something to be realized," said Pandji Choesin, executive director of the Indonesian Association of Internet Service Providers.
Mr. Suriadjaya wants to sell a 50 percent stake in CyberCity for $26.5 million by June 28, when he plans to officially introduce it at an Internet trade show at Kemayoran. He hopes to raise another $50 million by the end of the year, despite the fact that there are still no revenue projections for the group. "From June 28 onward, I trust that the price tag of our company will be in excess of $100 million," he said.
Such a big capital buildup might not be unusual for an Internet start-up, but it would represent an especially neat turnaround for Jakarta International Trade Fair's original airport investment.
Property analysts say prices in Jakarta have fallen at least 50 percent the last 10 years, though with no sales anywhere in two years it is hard to tell. Mr. Suriadjaya said CyberCity was valuing its 7.5-acre property at $5 million, a price that would make Jakarta International's entire 109-acre spread at Kemayoran worth around $73 million -- a 46 percent paper profit.
Mr. Suriadjaya rejects criticism that his high-technology vision is a property deal in disguise, though he does not deny that CyberCity could be good for the local real estate market. "We know we have to push it as a cyberinitiative because that's where most of the funds are basing their decisions," he said. "We're not cheating anybody."

HEADLINE: Actors Strike Against Radio and Television Advertisers

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 1

 BODY:
For the first time in 12 years, the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists called on their combined membership of about 135,000 actors to stop working on all television and radio commercials at 12:01 a.m. today until an agreement could be reached with advertisers.
Residual payments for commercial work are at the heart of the disagreement between the actors -- who rallied here today and in New York, Chicago and San Francisco -- and television and radio advertisers. For years, actors in commercials used on network television have received payments every time an ad runs in a practice known as "pay per play." For commercials on cable television actors receive a flat rate. 
 A placard stating "Please Don't Squeeze the Actor" summed up the attitude of an estimated 2,000 actors as they marched down Wilshire Boulevard today.
Frank Simmons, an actor who marched, said the disparity between the two sides could be vast. For example, he cited the residual payments he received for working in a recent General Motors commercial. Over a three-month period on cable, he said he received a flat fee of $1,100, although the commercial was shown several times a day.
During the same period on the networks, he said the commercial brought him nearly $40,000.
"This is about as good as economic times are going to get and by suggesting to get rid of residuals they're basically asking for a pay cut," said Greg Krizman, a spokesman for the guilds.
Commercial advertisers want the flat rate used by cable to be adopted across the board while the unions want to see pay-per-play extended to cable advertising.
Under the advertisers' most recent proposal, the lead actor's fees for unlimited use of a commercial on cable in a 13-week cycle would increase 60 percent.
Actors' representatives say that times have changed since they negotiated the flat-rate portion of their contract. In those days, cable was a struggling enterprise and unions across the country were making concessions during hard economic times.
But in today's booming economy, with cable television well entrenched union representatives say it is time to share the wealth.
"They boast of record profits," said Todd Amorde, a Screen Actors Guild board member and joint chairman of the unions' strike committee. "We want our fair share. It's very simple."
Advertisers counter that with the decline in network viewership and an audience dispersed over a greater number of networks, they must show a commercial more often to reach viewers. They have contended that the unions' demands would increase the cost of cable television commercials by 350 percent.
"We think the use of the concept is obsolete particularly with the exploding venues for watching television," said John A. McGuinn, chief negotiator for the Association of National Advertisers Inc. and the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the two major industry trade groups.
He noted that the per-use concept was born in the 1950's when the three networks delivered 90 percent of the television households. The three network now deliver less than 50 percent of the audience, he said.
Talks between the two groups broke down in mid-April and attempts in recent days by federal mediators to bring the two groups back together were unsuccessful.
Screen Actors and American Federation representatives, who have said they would try to shut down production on television and radio commercials made after the strike began, said they knew of no production going on today.
Richard E. Posell, an entertainment lawyer who represents production companies, said he knew of no companies that were shooting today and predicted they would not work, at least in the United States, during the strike.
"The loss of commercial business is an enormous blow to the entertainment community and the economy at large particularly Los Angeles and New York," Mr. Posell said.
He noted that commercial production is estimated to represent about 60 percent of Screen Actors Guild income, or about $720 million annually.
"It's a lot of money," he said. "It's going to effect not only the production business but I think the economy of Southern California."

An article in Business Day on May 2 about a strike by actors in television and radio commercials misspelled one striker's surname and referred incorrectly to his comments about the pay disparity between cable and network television. The actor is Frank Simons, not Simmons. He said he would have earned $40,000 if his commercial had run as often on the networks as on cable. He did not say that that occurred.
