HEADLINE: Lush Wine From A Pacific Breeze

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV 

DATELINE: LOMPOC, Calif., May 2

 BODY:
The Santa Ynez Valley stretches west through central Santa Barbara County, reaching toward this small city and the Pacific Ocean beyond. It's a land of relaxed beauty, where narrow roads curl through the knobby, windswept Santa Rita Hills, through rows of walnut trees and strawberry fields, past acres of cabbage and broccoli and, here and there, a few sparse vineyards. It's certainly not Burgundy, where grapevines are planted everywhere, right to the edge of the highway, or Napa Valley, where the wineries are as densely packed as a suburb full of split-levels, but make no mistake: this is wine country.
And in the last few years, the Santa Barbara wine region has grown astonishingly. Since 1997, the amount of land planted with grapes has shot up to more than 18,000 acres, from about 10,000, and the number of wineries in the county has almost doubled in the last decade, to about 50. Most of that acreage was planted by big wineries like Beringer, Robert Mondavi and Kendall-Jackson, which, recognizing the quality of Santa Barbara grapes and the relative affordability of the land, bought up huge tracts in the Los Alamos Valley and the Santa Maria Valley to the north. 
 But the true measure of excitement here is focused a little farther south, on the western Santa Ynez Valley, where smaller parcels of land, ranging from just a couple of acres to a few hundred, have been planted with pinot noir and chardonnay grapes. Growers expect these Burgundian varietals to flourish in the cool climate that is moistened by fogs blowing in almost daily off the Pacific Ocean, and the first wines, made from vines planted three years ago, show excellent potential. The chardonnays are almost crisp with citrus flavors, while the pinot noirs, flamboyant in their youth, should achieve elegance as the vines mature.
"You're going to see some brilliant wines coming out of Santa Barbara," said Alan Phillips, the winemaker and general manager of both Foley Estate and LinCourt Vineyards, which have planted about 250 acres, mostly of chardonnay and pinot noir, on undulating slopes facing south and west. "The cool climate wines are absolutely stunning."
Equally exciting are the passionate young winemakers like Steve Beckmen, 31, of Beckmen Vineyards and Andrew Murray, 28, of Andrew Murray Vineyards, who have seized on Rhone varietals, particularly syrah, and have planted new hillside vineyards in the warmer central part of the valley.
THE best Santa Barbara syrahs are rich and complex wines, layered with nuances as in the northern Rhone Valley of France, syrah's home territory, rather than lightly likable, as so many California syrahs have been.
"When I started making syrah, I think there were four other people in the state who were doing it," said Bob Lindquist of Qupe, who made his first syrah for Zaca Mesa in 1982 and who saw the potential for Rhone grapes early on in the Santa Ynez Valley. "Now, I think there are 25 syrah makers in Santa Barbara County alone."
Santa Barbara is not the only booming region in California. San Luis Obispo County, the Monterey Bay region and Sonoma County have all experienced similar rapid development. But this sleepy county about 100 miles north of Los Angeles may be the most unlikely California region to be joining the top echelon of wine producers. It's far better known for the relaxed city of Santa Barbara, for its beautiful hills that have offered refuge to the likes of Ronald Reagan and Michael Jackson and for its 18th-century adobe missions. In fact, the missions were the first in the county to make wine, a sweet and sturdy beverage that no doubt had its secular as well as its sacramental uses. Wine was made in the county right up through Prohibition but seemed to die out after World War II.
Not until the late 1960's and early 70's, well after the California wine industry began to take off, did Santa Barbara again try its hand at grape growing and winemaking. Pioneers like Firestone Vineyards, Zaca Mesa and Sanford & Benedict arrived, with little idea of what grapes to plant and where.
Many early arrivals planted cabernet sauvignon in areas ill suited for the grap, producing weedy, vegetal wines. Others planted chenin blanc and riesling, noble grapes that have never achieved much popularity in California. But some got it right almost immediately. The 130-acre Sanford & Benedict vineyard, the first planted in the western part of the Santa Ynez, has been a superior source of pinot noir and chardonnay grapes for 25 years, while the 900-acre Bien Nacido vineyard, first planted 30 years ago, graces the labels of many of the county's finest bottles.
By the mid-80's, acclaimed wineries like Au Bon Climat, Qupe, Babcock Vineyards and Sanford Winery were firmly established, soon to be joined by others like Foxen Vineyard, the Lane Tanner Winery and Fess Parker Winery and Vineyard. Big organizations like Beringer had begun to make inroads, but the winemakers were largely a small, close-knit community, many of whom had learned their craft together, and the county reflected their irreverence.
By most accounts, Jim Clendinen of Au Bon Climat, an iconoclastic winemaker who wore long, shaggy hair after it had been stylish and a goatee before goatees came back, worked feverishly to draw attention to Santa Barbara wines, traveling the world to tout their quality. In Santa Barbara County, he and Mr. Lindquist of Qupe had a cooperative agreement to share production facilities at the Bien Nacido vineyard, an arrangement that has set a collegial standard for the county.
"Jim Clendinen has been huge, as far as his ambassadorial role in bringing attention to the area and paving the way for others to follow, and to illustrate what the potential of Santa Barbara County could be," said Greg Brewer, 31, of Brewer-Clifton, one of the county's hottest winemakers today. "In the late 80's and early 90's, he was a larger-than-life figure here."
Though they had eked out a reputation for seductive, elegant pinot noirs and ripe yet nicely acidic chardonnays as well as a few good syrahs, Santa Barbara wines were still largely a footnote in California.
BUT that made Santa Barbara all the more attractive to wealthy wine lovers in Southern California, who saw greater opportunities to make an immediate mark in the wine industry nearby, rather than in Northern California, where they would be greeted with yawns, if they were noticed at all. That and the fact that prime Santa Ynez vineyard sites are a relative bargain, under $20,000 an acre, compared with $35,000 to $45,000 an acre in the Carneros district of Napa Valley, by one winemaker's estimate.
Ron Melville, who owns a securities firm in Los Angeles, actually bought land in Napa Valley before settling on several hundred acres in the Santa Rita Hills, where he built Melville Vineyards and Winery. He hired Mr. Brewer to oversee his operations. Melville will release its first bottles, from the 1999 vintage, later this year. The families of both Mr. Beckmen and Mr. Murray moved up from Los Angeles, choosing Santa Barbara over Northern California to build wineries. Fess Parker, the Hollywood actor who played Davy Crockett and Daniel Boone in the 50's and 60's, opted for elbow room and wide open spaces in Santa Barbara County in the late 80's, over densely populated Northern California.
Like many in the county, Mr. Parker points to great untapped potential in the region, and with recent purchases in both the western Santa Rita Hills and the central Santa Ynez, he is doing his best to tap it. He owns hotels in Santa Barbara and in Los Olivos, a quiet town of cafes, galleries and wine-tasting rooms, where Mr. Parker is trying to develop a world-class restaurant.
"My goals here are not modest," he said. "I want this to be the French Laundry of Santa Barbara County. Napa Valley wasn't any fun until the restaurants came in."
Mr. Parker's winery, a sprawling ranch-style building with a rambling veranda, is on Foxen Canyon Road, a winding country lane of stunning vistas of hills and valleys, sprawling coastal oak trees and wildflowers, with hawks and vultures drifting overhead. While most of the small wineries on this route that links the Santa Ynez Valley with the Santa Maria Valley welcome visitors, Mr. Parker's is one of the few equipped to handle big groups, complete with a large tasting room, a smiling staff and a gift shop where you can buy wines, local foods and of course, coonskin caps.
Such an operation sends cold chills through many in the county, who see wineries as harbingers of the kind of large-scale development they detest. Traffic jams are unknown in Santa Ynez, short of the tourists who slow to gawk at the twirling windmills in the town of Solvang, where the main draw is not wineries but a quaint and kitschy Scandinavian theme with plenty of clogs and shoppes.
"This is kind of where Napa was 25 years ago," said Gary Burk, a marketing and production executive with Au Bon Climat and Qupe, who incidentally makes very good pinot noirs and chardonnays under his own label, Costa de Oro. "Are we going to stay a little country place that makes wines, or are there going to be wine trains and bed-and-breakfasts all up and down Foxen Canyon Road? I don't know if everybody wants that. Some people will welcome that, I think especially the newer people. The older people prefer making wines in a more casual environment."
In an effort to slow development, the county has put up numerous regulatory hurdles -- "the madness," Mr. Phillips, the Foley winemaker, calls it. Well-financed concerns like Foley Estate can battle their way through the obstacles, but some smaller winemakers are opting out.
Brewer-Clifton, which makes minute quantities of pinot noir and chardonnay from purchased grapes, is moving its winemaking operation to a warehouse in the city of Lompoc, which is within the county lines but is not bound by its rules.
"Lompoc is a funny town that's screaming for business," Mr. Brewer said. "Santa Barbara County is very resistant to more wineries going in. There are all kinds of regulations, permits and delays. It's a long, arduous process."
Though the regulatory tensions are bound to continue (the latest debate was over a rare salamander that received an emergency listing as an endangered species, grinding several winery projects to a halt), one thing the wineries seem to be figuring out is to how to use the climate for the maximum advantage of each particular grape.
THE Santa Ynez Valley is blessed with long growing seasons with plenty of sunshine, offset by natural, fog-induced maritime air-conditioning, a product of the east-west valleys that are a peculiar feature of the jutting coastline below Santa Barbara. "It's a unique combination," said Mr. Lindquist of Qupe. "We're far enough south so that we don't get hit by the rains that come down from the northwest, and yet because the coastline is turned around we have this tremendous cooling effect. The soils are important, but not nearly as important as the climate."
That moderate climate, Mr. Murray of Andrew Murray Vineyards said, is what gives the Rhone varietals such potential in the central Santa Ynez. "Too warm and you might get a more insipid-style syrah," he said. "Too cool and it might be too lean. Somewhere right in the middle, you get your darkest, richest wines, full-bodied but still elegant."
Other places in California make good syrahs, too, Mr. Murray admited, but he believes that the long Santa Barbara growing season is a definite advantage. "We were picking syrah at the end of November," he said. "That's when you can really eke out not only those fruit flavors, but those flavors of earth and spices and violets, the real pretty side of syrah, which you find often in the syrahs of this area."
The California wine boom has sent the demand for grapes soaring, forcing many winemakers to seek new supplies or to grow their own. Chris Whitcraft, who has been buying grapes to make small quantities of pinot noir and chardonnay since 1985, had to get his pinot noir from Sonoma County in 1999. When the demand exceeds the supply, the small winemakers are the first to lose out, one of the reasons that Mr. Beckmen of Beckmen Vineyards feels more secure with his own supply of grapes.
"Believe me, having 80 acres of syrah, I get calls every day asking if I have syrah grapes available to sell," he said.
Some fear that the expansion can be too rapid, and that a fall will be inevitable. "Will there be a home for all these grapes, especially if the economy takes a dip?" Mr. Lindquist asked. "Both '98 and '99 were small crop years. But in '97, there were more grapes than we could handle. A lot of winemakers have short memories."
As far as the wines themselves are concerned, a Santa Barbara signature has been elusive. The future looks very good for syrahs, which can be spicy, nuanced and elegant. Some optimistic winemakers even expect that the eastern end of the Santa Ynez, the warmest part of the valley, will one day produce good Bordeaux varietals like cabernet sauvignon and merlot, grapes that have failed miserably in other parts of the valley.
But most people agree that the county's greatest successes have been its richly textured, sweet pinot noirs and its chardonnays, some of which resemble Chablis in their blend of citrus and mineral flavors.
 For some like Mr. Brewer, who can sound almost mystical discussing how Brewer-Clifton wines reflect the soil from which the vines emerge, this is a noble challenge. Others like Richard Dore, an owner of Foxen Vineyards, seem to say, slow down and catch your breath.
"We've been doing this for 30 years, and we're just figuring out where to plant stuff, let alone how to make it," Mr. Dore said. "In Burgundy they've had 3,000 years to get it right."

HEADLINE: The Euro's Value

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In your April 29 editorial "Decline of the Euro," you note the "dashed" hopes of those Europeans who, when the euro was born 16 months ago, "boasted that it would challenge the dollar for international supremacy." The problem, though, is not that the United States is growing faster than Europe, but that the single currency is gradually replacing 11 and that the European Central Bank has failed to mop up the surplus liquidity.
As old contracts in marks, francs and lire expire and are replaced by euro contracts, individuals and enterprises are running down their old currency balances. Instead of selling assets from its portfolio, the European Central Bank has been trying to stop the decline by raising interest rates. This only further reduces the need for liquidity and puts more in surplus. 
 The euro can indeed challenge the superiority of the dollar, but only by using the euro price of gold as a market signal of Europe's liquidity needs.
 
JUDE WANNISKI
President, Polyconomics
Morristown, N.J., April 29, 2000

HEADLINE: New Flurry of Economic Data Shows Little Sign of Slowdown

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family houses soared in March to their second-fastest pace on record and an index of growth expectations rose, suggesting the record economic expansion still has legs.
Sales of new single-family homes unexpectedly rose 4.5 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 966,000 units after falling 0.6 percent in February. The sales rate was the largest since the 995,000 units reported in November 1998. 
 "Higher interest rates are doing nothing to slow consumer spending," said Joel L. Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
The index of leading economic indicators, a gauge of economic performance for the next six months, rose 0.1 percent in March after a 0.3 percent decline in February. The gain reflected rising stock prices, low levels of unemployment claims and higher orders for consumer goods.
The reports come just two weeks before the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Open Market Committee meets again to decide interest rate policy. Although the Fed has lifted the overnight bank lending rate five times since June 30 -- from 4.75 percent to 6 percent -- the housing report in particular suggests buyers are finding ways to skirt higher borrowing costs.
Analysts had expected new-home sales to fall in March to an annual rate of 900,000 units. Home sales have averaged 940,000 units at an annual rate in the first three months of the year, the fastest pace since the fourth quarter of 1998, when the rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 6.76 percent, according to Freddie Mac.
Rates on the 30-year mortgages have remained above 8 percent since February. The median price of a new home rose 3.1 percent, to $165,000 in March from $160,000 a month earlier.
The report on leading indicators by the Conference Board, an industry research group, showed five of the index components were positive contributors and five were negative.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Long-Term Treasuries Lower; 30-Year Yield Now at 6.01%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of United States Treasury securities were mixed yesterday.
Treasuries with shorter maturities were higher as investors moved money out of stocks, which were declining, for the favorable return on interest-bearing instruments. The price of longer-term Treasuries was lower, however, amid concern that the Federal Reserve would move to raise interest rates, driving bond prices down.
 By late in the day, the benchmark 30-year bond was down 10/32 , to a price of 103 11/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, increased to 6.01 percent from 5.99 percent on Monday, exceeding 6 percent for the first time in six weeks. 
 The mixed feelings about the Fed's next move have created some consternation in the bond markets. Michael P. Maurer, a fixed-income strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons, said.
"Strong economic data forced the reassessment of conventional market wisdom last week as the consensus for the Fed funds target rate became less certain," he said.
Market participants, he added, are divided between expectations of a quarter-percentage-point increase and a rise of half a point. Until recently, it had seemed fairly certain that the central bank would continue its pattern of gradual rate increases.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, is among those who say that many market participants expect a half-point tightening at the May 16 meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee, as economic growth led by strong consumer spending continues.
"The Fed seems poised to move aggressively in its pre-emptive strikes against inflationary forces," he said. "Simply put, the risk of economic momentum being sharply curtailed by an aggressive move to a less accommodative posture is considerably less at this juncture than the risk of having an undesirable inflationary bulge result from a somewhat sluggish monetary policy."
Mr. Maurer of A. G. Edwards said, "There are several major announcements due this week, which could shake up the markets." The data include the Treasury's quarterly refunding on Wednesday, first-quarter productivity and cost figures on Thursday, and April employment figures on Friday. Expectations are for nonfarm payrolls to rise 350,000 and for the unemployment rate to drop to 4 percent.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Companies increasingly turn to corporate jets, thanks to the economy and airline hassles.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; Business Travel appears each Wednesday. Joe Sharkey's e-mail address is jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WE fly higher and faster," said Bill Wagner, a pilot. "We can get from Des Moines, Iowa, to Washington, D.C., in about two hours with no delays. And we've never lost a piece of luggage."
But hold on before inquiring where to book your next business trip on this astonishing airline. Mr. Wagner flies an executive jet for the Townsend Engineering Company of Des Moines, one of more than 11,000 American companies that own corporate aircraft. To take a business trip on Townsend's Cessna Citation X, an eight-passenger mid-size executive jet, or its six-passenger Piper Cheyenne propeller plane, you generally have to be an employee or a customer of the company, which manufactures processing machines for domestic and foreign meat packers. 
 The corporate-jet business has abandoned the defensive crouch it went into for years after the shareholder revulsion generated by the celebrated business excesses of the mid- to late 1980's, when legendary corporate Champagne Charlies like F. Ross Johnson of RJR Nabisco presided imperially over fleets of expensive jets that could be dispatched on a whim, say to fetch a pet.
The business has come back at full throttle, thanks to a booming economy, a reaction against the delays and frustrations of commercial airlines, and a pronounced change in attitudes as corporate managers justify the expense of a company plane as a business tool. It is seen as a productive way to transport not only top executives, but also the middle-management teams that are increasingly spanning out on ever-wider business trips.
Corporate jets are "very expensive -- so they'd better provide a return on that investment of significant value or you cannot realistically own one," said Ted Townsend, the president of Townsend Engineering. Some big companies, like Wal-Mart Stores, operate big fleets of aircraft for a variety of business reasons, but even smaller operations like Townsend Engineering use planes for functions besides transportation, including things like shipping spare parts to outlying areas.
Though he admits to fervently loving his jet, Mr. Townsend says that its value is strictly practical for a company like his, a machinery maker whose sales and service staffs have to be quick-footed, wide-ranging and happy on the job. "With our location in the central part of the country, we can go anyplace in the United States and still come home for dinner," he said.
The number of companies owning jets and other turbine-engine aircraft increased more than fivefold over the last 30 years, to more 11,000 by 1998, according to the National Business Aviation Association. American companies now operate about 6,200 jets, 5,100 turbo-prop planes and 5,000 helicopters.
But the climb wasn't steady. After a steep ascent through the 1970's, sales of business aircraft flattened in the late 1980's. In 1992, manufacturers delivered 348 new business jets and turbo-props, according to the General Aviation Manufacturers Association. Last year, the number was 778.
It was a long haul to change the corporate jet's image as a toy for pampered executives, industry experts say. "To a certain extent, the community brought this upon itself many years ago when they emphasized the tremendous comfort, luxury and special privilege of a company airplane," said Jack Olcott, the president of the National Business Aviation Association, a trade group that represents corporate aircraft owners. "The excesses of the '80's were really only very limited examples, but they received tremendous media attention."
Even corporations with big corporate fleets depend heavily on commercial aviation for most of their business travel, he noted. "The enlightened company uses the airlines when appropriate, and business aviation when appropriate," he said.
One of the fastest-growing areas in business aviation is in companies that operate corporate jets for charter and for use by clients who purchase fractional shares of a plane or a group of planes, allowing them to have an aircraft available when they want it. The number of companies with fractional-ownership deals doubled, to 1,125, from 1997 to 1998, according to the business aviation trade group.
Not only is the corporate jet back, but it's getting bigger. The Boeing Company is now marketing its new Boeing Business Jet, which has an 807-square-foot interior -- about twice the space of other top-line corporate jets. The plane costs about $38 million, with another $8 to $12 million for accessories and other options. So far, Boeing has orders for 56 of them.
Fred Kelley, a spokesman for the Boeing Business Jet division, described the plane as "basically a hybrid 737," with modifications, including bigger fuel tanks that give it a flying range of about 6,200 miles, similar to the Gulfstream V and twice the range of the Boeing 737 aircraft used domestically by many commercial airlines. The appeal of having a "global presence" accounts for the longer range, Mr. Kelley said. The size reflects a demand for flying more people, including management teams, and equipping them to work in flight with "all the things you would have in a normal office," he said.
Mr. Kelley and other Boeing executives recently returned from a 40-day barnstorming trip on one of the new planes through Europe and the Middle East. Negative public attitudes toward business aircraft remain especially entrenched in Europe, where "if you have a private jet, you don't talk about it," Mr. Kelley said, adding: "We're trying to convert people's thinking into seeing it as a business tool, rather than it being an excessive perquisite for the C.E.O., the royal barge kind of image."
Mr. Kelley said the trip was productive. "I flew 150 hours, 48,000 miles, in 40 days," he said. "I wouldn't want to even think about doing that on commercial flights."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK 

 BODY:

Scholarships for Future Scientists
EUGENE M. LANG broke new ground in philanthropy in 1981 by offering all sixth graders at East Harlem's Public School 121 a college scholarship if they graduated from high school.
Last Friday, Mr. Lang was at it again, this time at the American Museum of Natural History, where a group of inner-city seventh graders were shouting aloud with him, "I will be a scientist." 
 He has given $1 million to make the 10 youngsters the first members of a museum science team.
The students will spend many Saturdays in the coming years in the museum's research program, working closely with curators. Those who complete the program will get a college scholarship and each year another 10 seventh graders will be added.
 
Rutgers Picks Chief of Arts School
Rutgers University has chosen GEORGE B. STAUFFER, chairman of the music department at Hunter College, to become dean of the Mason Gross School of the Arts at Rutgers in August.
Dr. Stauffer, an organist and Bach scholar, will replace MARILYN F. SOMVILLE, who is retiring as dean of the 700-student arts school. Founded in 1976, it offers graduate programs in music, theater and visual arts, and undergraduate programs in those disciplines plus dance.
Dr. Stauffer said one of his top priorities was to build up an independent, multimillion-dollar endowment for the school. Another is to attract more students from around the country; more than 90 percent are now from New Jersey.
Before arriving at Hunter, Dr. Stauffer taught at Yeshiva University and at Columbia University, where he was university organist and chapel music director for 22 years.
 
New York Schools in Need of Repair
A new study by the National Education Association, the nation's largest teachers' union, put New York State at the top of the list of states that need to repair their schools or modernize them with new technology.
The study, released today, said the total repair bill for the nation's schools should be $322 billion.
Of that total, $51 billion is needed in New York, $32.9 billion in California, $25.1 billion in Ohio and $22 billion in New Jersey, the study said.
The $322 billion is 10 times what states are now spending, the report said.
"We often fail to realize that where our students learn can have a dramatic impact on what they learn," said BOB CHASE, the association's president.
 
University Moves Graduate Students
After 24 years at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, Long Island University is moving its Westchester campus for graduate students to the State University at Purchase.
At Purchase, the students will have a 15,000-square-foot space with 14 classrooms wired for the Internet and two computer labs. The two institutions will remain separate, but students will be able to share library access online.
 
Economics Chair at Manhattanville
Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., will create the first endowed professorial chair in its 159-year-old history with a $1 million contribution from SERGIO DANGUILLECOURT, a director of the board of Bacardi Ltd. The chair will be known as the Ryan-Bacardi chair of economics, after Bacardi and Prof. EDWARD W. RYAN, who has taught at Manhattanville for 42 years.
Mr. Danguillecourt, who lives in Miami, graduated from Manhattanville in 1990 with a degree in economics. MICHAEL POLLAK

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 973 words

HEADLINE: Win Now, or Lose Forever

BYLINE: By Neal Gabler; Neal Gabler is the author, most recently, of "Life the Movie: How Entertainment Conquered Reality."

DATELINE: AMAGANSETT, N.Y.

 BODY:
For now the doomsday clock has stopped ticking. ABC is back on the air, at least temporarily, while Time Warner and Walt Disney, the parent company of ABC, restart talks over whether Time Warner's cable systems will carry ABC programming. Some 3.5 million cable subscribers will no longer be deprived of "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," "Dharma and Greg" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue."
A national crisis has temporarily been averted. 
 Yes, it's easy to be sarcastic. On its face this is a dispute about money. In exchange for letting it carry ABC programming, Time Warner says Disney is insisting that the cable operator convert the Disney Channel from a premium service to a basic cable service and that it add two Disney-owned channels to its systems -- and that it pay what it believes is an extortionate fee for doing so. Thus the Orwellian "Disney Has Taken ABC Away from You" sign that had appeared on cable screens in the affected communities.
For its part, Disney insists that the pending AOL-Time Warner merger has changed the negotiating context and says it wants the same access to new, highly profitable interactive technologies that Time Warner's own channels feature.
But while money is certainly at issue, it is not the whole story or even the main story -- at least not the relatively small amounts being quibbled over. This is about hegemony. The brinkmanship demonstrates that media companies are no longer rivals jockeying for position, but behemoths locked in a deadly power struggle to become the lone king of a rapacious world.
Rivalry among media giants is nothing new. Back in the 1920's, for example, when the movie companies were integrating production, distribution and exhibition, Paramount, Fox, Warner Brothers and Loew's, the parent company of MGM, were all building or buying theaters -- the movie equivalent of cable -- to deliver their films to the public.
Fierce battles often ensued. Companies even instigated labor troubles at rivals' sites and promoted disinformation campaigns charging that a rival's theater was carelessly constructed and the balcony would collapse. Paramount was so enthusiastic in its efforts to subvert its competitors that the Federal Trade Commission even opened an investigation of its practices.
But once the construction dust settled, the movie companies realized that not only could they co-exist, they could make money from one another. Why fight? A Loew's first-run theater could show a Warner Brothers movie and a Warner Brothers theater could show an MGM film if the theater's location and the situation warranted it.
Before the Depression, the idea was that the movies were an ever-expanding pie with plenty for everyone. After the Depression hit, the idea was that the rivals had to find ways of dividing the pie, profiting off one another. In either case, there was a grudging collegiality.
As the dispute between Time Warner and Disney illustrates, the days of cooperation, grudging or otherwise, are long gone -- the casualty of two factors. One is the Internet, which has created unparalleled opportunity and uncertainty in equal measure. Everyone assumes that eventually hundreds of billions of dollars will be made off Internet technology, which is why America Online could acquire Time Warner in the first place, but no one knows exactly how this windfall will be reaped. Each company sees the unprecedented chance to be the Internet Almighty and thus reduce opponents to irrelevance -- the fear that Disney has expressed in the wake of the AOL-Time Warner merger.
In this situation, there is no ever-expanding pie to be divided but only one to be eaten whole by the company that gets the jump on the Internet and the billions of dollars that go with it.
That leads to the second factor that has turned media competition into hostility: a monopolist mentality.
The old movie moguls may have been megalomaniacs but they didn't think like monopolists. They thought like heated competitors trying to be the biggest and the best, but never believing that they could be the only one. They knew they couldn't.
Kept in check in part by the threat of government antitrust actions, Louis B. Mayer, the chieftain of MGM, realized that the 50 or so films his studio made each year couldn't satisfy some 80 million weekly viewers. In effect, he needed the other studios to keep slaking the movie-going habit, just as they needed him. Together they constituted a film industry that could never have been congruent with just a single company.
Today's media conglomerates, however, have an opportunity that those old movie companies didn't have. Microsoft notwithstanding, the government seems less zealous in enforcing antitrust law, and the financial system encourages vast new economies of scale and the mergers that help provide them.
 The new media companies are full-service entertainers that can provide everything an audience might want -- not only movies but television, videocassettes, CD's, books, interactive games, theater and, yes, the Internet.
When you can provide for every entertainment need an audience might have, the industry and the company can be congruent, which creates an entirely different mindset, as we can see from the Time Warner-Disney dust-up.
Competitors are no longer an unavoidable part of doing business; they have actually become an impediment to doing business.
In a sense, then, the skirmishes among Time Warner, Disney, Fox, Sony, Bertelsmann and the other pretenders to media pre-eminence have less to do with traditional economics than with dynastic politics. These companies are modern warriors that don't believe they have to live with one another. As they see it, the world may be big enough for only one of them -- one king of the media hill and a group of vassals.
Meanwhile, we still have Regis.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1747 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Business-School Boom;
What Jacobs Wrought, in a Quarter-Century, at Kellogg

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Donald P. Jacobs jumps into a swimming pool every day at 6:30 a.m. and spends 45 minutes doing laps. During rainstorms, he sometimes dashes without an umbrella between buildings on the Northwestern University campus here, even as the wind off Lake Michigan musses his hair. When he gives public speeches, he often wears a sweatshirt. And when he finds something funny, he throws his head back, crosses his arms over his chest and guffaws.
Mr. Jacobs has a rather loose style for a business school dean, especially one who passed the traditional retirement age seven years ago. But nothing is frivolous about his accomplishments: No one has had a greater effect on management education in the United States than he has, say his peers at schools around the country. 
 This spring, Mr. Jacobs is celebrating his 25th anniversary at the helm of the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern. He has held his job longer than any current major university president or other business school dean, higher education experts say. When he took over, Cal Ripken Jr. was playing high school baseball and Pope John Paul II was still Karol Wojtyla, archbishop of Cracow.
Along the way, Mr. Jacobs created the prototype of the modern business school, management experts say. Well before many of its rivals, Kellogg interviewed all its applicants, published students' evaluations of its professors' teaching skills and encouraged students to help design the curriculum.
In other words, Kellogg caters to its students as if they were customers. It unabashedly considers the teaching of skills like teamwork and social networking as central to its mission, and seeks students who agree. "If you think you are that kind of person, you fit," Mr. Jacobs recently told a group of accepted applicants. "If not, this is the time to get the hell out," he added, to much laughter.
Thanks to the changes -- many of which once seemed heretical in the world of higher education -- and to the recruitment of ambitious young professors, the school that once had little respect on its own campus steadily climbed the national rankings, securing a solid spot in the top five and forcing more prestigious schools to imitate it.
Professors say Mr. Jacobs is the symbol for the business school boom that over the last quarter-century has tripled, to 100,000, the number of M.B.A.'s awarded each year.
"No one has quite done what Don has done," said Rajat Gupta, the managing partner of McKinsey & Company, who sits on advisory boards at Kellogg, Harvard and the Universities of Chicago and Pennsylvania. "Which is to transform an average school into a top five school and keep it there for some time."
In a business world that craves speed and flexibility, Mr. Jacobs, jovial and blunt-spoken, has also become something of a model manager himself, colleagues say. Kellogg, with a relatively small administrative staff, relies on its version of factory-floor employees -- its students -- to study many of its problems and suggest solutions. Unlike many academic institutions, it acts quickly, putting in place pilot programs and deciding later whether they deserve a permanent place in the curriculum. "He pushes constant change," said Robert Duncan, a professor of leadership who has taught at the school since 1970.
Last summer, for example, reacting to student criticism that Kellogg had not devoted enough attention to the Internet, Mr. Jacobs and a few faculty members drew up plans for an e-commerce major that covers 16 courses. It is already the third-most-popular major at the school.
At the core of Mr. Jacobs's strategy has been a strengthening of the ties between the ivory tower and a business world that sometimes views intellectuals as eggheads. Over the skepticism of other Northwestern officials, he built an executive education center 20 years ago that now brings in $93 million a year and has inspired similar versions at Stanford, Pennsylvania and other schools. He was also among the first deans to encourage professors to make international trips a part of actual classes.
He continues to teach, both the full-time day students and the executives who pass through. Between 1975 and 1979, he served as the chairman of Amtrak and has also been a director for First Chicago, Commonwealth Edison and Hart Marx, the high-end clothing company. (One of his board stints, on a meat-packing company, even turned him into a vegetarian, he said, after he had learned the details of the industry's operations.)
A competitive man whose sometimes fiery temper has cooled only recently, friends say, and who needs little provocation before lobbing insults about the nearby University of Chicago, Mr. Jacobs says Kellogg makes a legitimate claim to be the nation's top business school. More removed experts call that wishful thinking, if only barely. Given the choice, most students enroll at Harvard or Stanford over Kellogg, for example. And after building a top-notch faculty, Kellogg has lost a few stars to rival schools in the last three years and has not replaced them with researchers of the same rank, professors say.
Most management experts agree, however, that few graduate schools of any kind have come as far over the last 25 years, and few institutions bear the mark of their leader as much as this one. "His personality really infuses the place," said Mike Miles, the former chairman of Philip Morris who heads the school's advisory board.
In fact, some students and professors worry that Kellogg's biggest problem is that Mr. Jacobs has not surrounded himself with strong candidates to replace him, even though he plans to retire in a few years and spend more time teaching. "There's nobody that is a natural successor to Dean Jacobs within the school right now," said James Schlesinger Jr., the former editor of the student paper, who will graduate this spring.
Mr. Jacobs grew up as the son of bakers on the far west side of Chicago, three blocks from the suburb of Oak Park that Frank Lloyd Wright was making famous. Until junior high school he suffered from what doctors would now call dyslexia and, he said, is still terrible at remembering names. He enlisted in the Navy at 17, just weeks before Japan surrendered in World War II. He returned home and attended Roosevelt University in Chicago, where an economics professor encouraged him to take up the subject. Mr. Jacobs eventually earned a doctorate in economics at Columbia. "I never, ever thought of being anything but a professor," he said.
His first job was at City College in New York. Northwestern's business school offered him a post in the 1950's, but the dean at the time, Richard Donham, son of the founding dean of Harvard Business School, asked him to promise to teach in the executive education program, a forum that many faculty members deemed intellectually weak. Dr. Donham "wouldn't have hired me if I wouldn't do it," Mr. Jacobs said.
The experience changed his view of business education and, eventually, remade Kellogg.
Over the next two decades, Mr. Jacobs taught finance and, in 1974, found himself on a search committee to find a replacement for John Barr, the former chief executive of Montgomery Ward who was then stepping down as head of Northwestern's business school. The committee offered the job to a French diplomat and to administrators at both Princeton University and the University of Pennsylvania. All three said no.
"And then the search committee," said Professor Duncan, another committee member, "almost in desperation, said: 'Enough is enough. Somebody's got to be dean.' " Mr. Jacobs, as the senior faculty member on the committee, was the choice, and he set aside his academic career to accept the post. "He wasn't thrilled about it," Professor Duncan said. "I don't know that anyone was thrilled about it."
But Mr. Jacobs threw himself into the job almost immediately. On his first day, a Monday, he told the outgoing dean that he wanted the school to focus, in part, on the teaching of business people who were in their 30's and 40's and no longer interested in attending school full-time. By Friday, he was meeting with James Allen, a founder of Booz Allen & Hamilton, to pitch his idea to build a separate executive education center for weeklong and monthlong classes. The following Monday, Mr. Allen agreed to finance much of the project, and the planning began.
Mr. Jacobs's idea was hardly met with unanimous enthusiasm. "The university thought he was crazy," said Meyer Feldberg, now the dean at Columbia, who was the center's first director. More prestigious schools like Harvard already had thriving programs, and with the economy in an inflation-induced funk, companies were not rushing to make large new investments.
But when the center, named for Mr. Allen, opened in 1979, the corporate landscape was changing. Globalization of markets and acceleration of technological change had made doing business more complicated. The Allen Center had little trouble filling its seats, and Northwestern professors soon had the advantage of being in constant contact with their core audience.
"Our faculty were good theorists," Mr. Jacobs said, "but they honestly understood the problems businesses really faced. It was one of the things that made us different."
The Allen Center also became an unofficial advertisement for Kellogg, as the school became known in 1979 after a gift from relatives of the cereal company family who were largely unconnected to the business. After a few weeks of study in Evanston, executives went home more willing to consider Northwestern graduates as well as the Harvard, Pennsylvania and Chicago M.B.A.'s that they had long hired.
Robert Hamada, dean of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, offering a rare compliment for the local competition, said, "He was the first of the major deans -- and he wasn't even a major dean at the time -- to think in terms of marketing." In fact, after years of ignoring the market, Chicago itself began offering executive classes a few years ago.
Mr. Jacobs's big headache now is how to exit gracefully and allow a smooth transition. It is a problem the students in his corporate governance classes study in detail but that he says is difficult to solve at a university, where a successor is chosen by a committee rather than groomed.
"The question of succession drives me crazy," Mr. Jacobs said. "A well-run organization probably would have gotten rid of me by now."

HEADLINE: Revolt of the Business Class

 BODY:
The American political scene has always been enlivened by protests. But there are not many parallels to the recent rebellion among wealthy businesses tired of being hit up by Democrats and Republicans for campaign donations. As Don Van Natta Jr. reported in The Times this week, at least 31 corporations that have given big soft-money contributions in recent election cycles appear to be boycotting the process this year. Most are backing off quietly, but a few have stepped forward to say that swearing off soft money has not brought retaliation from the political establishment. Their disgust with the excesses of fund-raising could be another impetus to enactment of campaign finance reform this year.
Late last year Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and other foes of the McCain-Feingold bill that would ban the unlimited donations to political parties known as soft money never tired of saying that this was an issue of little interest to American voters. Then the reform cause was energized by Senator John McCain's primary campaign, and by a Democratic race in which Vice President Al Gore declared that enactment of the soft-money ban would be one of his highest priorities as president. 
 Now business support for reform is growing. Senator Mitch McConnell has contended that businesses give money in order to "participate" in the political process, with no expectation of anything in return. But business leaders from the Committee for Economic Development and the Campaign for America, led by the investor Jerome Kohlberg, have characterized the campaign finance system as a shakedown operation. Many big businesses like General Motors, Time Warner and Allied Signal have concluded that the money they were spending on political contributions is better spent elsewhere.
But of course many businesses and special interests still give to get something in return for their donations. Philip Morris and the National Rifle Association, two of the biggest givers to the Republicans, have gotten politicians to oppose efforts to regulate guns and tobacco. The question is whether the public wants big questions like a patients' bill of rights, the creation of Social Security investment accounts and policies on software, telecommunications and Internet companies to be decided by who can give the biggest donations to whom.
Unfortunately, Gov. George W. Bush has so far joined Mr. Lott as an obstacle to reform. He says he favors a ban on corporation and union contributions to parties, but he would leave open a wide loophole by allowing unlimited donations to parties from individuals. Like other opponents of reform, he calls it a free speech issue. But Congress set limits on individual donations to candidates in 1974 after the Watergate scandals, and the legislation before Congress would simply extend those limits to donations to parties, which have been used to undermine the old reforms.
Mr. McCain is to meet with the presumptive party nominee in a few days to talk about issues. He needs to press Mr. Bush to support his campaign finance legislation in the Senate, where it commands majority support, and Mr. Bush ought to sign on to real reform. Americans want it. Most in Congress want it. Now even the donors want it. Mr. Bush and Mr. Lott should not stand in their way.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE MONEY ISSUES;
Spate of Numerical Sparring Highlights the Fiscal Focus of the Presidential Race

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Aides to Gov. George W. Bush fought back today against accusations that his fiscal proposals are risky, saying that the growth in the economy over the past six months meant that there would be enough money to accommodate comfortably the governor's spending and tax cut proposals.
Mr. Bush's advisers released a new analysis of his budget plans after days in which Vice President Al Gore has sharply criticized Mr. Bush on fiscal issues. Mr. Gore has asserted that Mr. Bush's large tax cut proposal and plan to push for a portion of Social Security payroll taxes to be put into private investment accounts would return the nation to the era of deficits. 
 Mr. Gore went on an advertising offensive on Monday against Mr. Bush, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, through a series of interviews and television appearances, charging that Mr. Bush would continue "multitrillion-dollar debts." Campaigning today, Mr. Gore called Mr. Bush's Social Security proposal "bad for America's future and bad for America's economy."
The battle over numbers underscores how much the presidential campaign -- the first one waged in the new era of federal surpluses -- will be fought over economic policy and the related question of how to shore up Social Security. The Gore campaign considers the economic prosperity of the Clinton years one of its greatest assets.
The figures released by Bush aides today addressed a weakness in earlier calculations. With the annual spending battle stepping up on Capitol Hill, the Bush campaign stopped assuming Congress would make large reductions in domestic spending, instead assuming discretionary domestic spending would grow.
At the same time, Mr. Bush's advisers argued that the growth in the economy over the past six months means the federal surplus will be larger than previously forecast. They said that under their new calculations the estimated federal surplus across 10 years -- after $2.2 trillion is set aside for Social Security -- will amount to $1.8 trillion.
That is roughly $1 trillion more than the Gore campaign estimates and about $500 billion more than the Bush campaign's earlier projections. Mr. Gore assumes a higher rate of spending and a less robust economy.
Mr. Bush's aides said his cut would use 1.3 trillion surplus dollars, allowing $512 billion for other programs.
"The bottom line is clear," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, the Bush campaign's chief economic adviser. "Governor Bush's plan takes care of Social Security first, provides America's working families with a tax break and does it all within the context of a balanced budget."
The Bush campaign's new calculations were released less than 24 hours after Mr. Gore's aides held their own session with reporters and released an array of numbers they said showed that to accommodate his tax cut, Mr. Bush either had to make "cuts in core areas of government that are unimaginable" or risk a return to deficits.
Mr. Gore's aides were still critical of Mr. Bush today.
"Last month he claimed that his tax cut and spending increases were paid for," said Elaine Kamarck, policy adviser to Mr. Gore. "Today, after finding more money, Bush still can't pay for his promises for a huge tax cut, increased spending and privatization of Social Security."
The Gore campaign said Mr. Bush was underestimating spending, and Mr. Bush's advisers refused to disclose how much Mr. Bush's embrace of a national missile defense system and prescription drug program would cost, while saying the proposals fit in their spending plan.
The most serious dispute between the two campaigns is the true cost of Mr. Bush's tax-cut proposal. Mr. Bush's aides said the tax cut would cost $1.3 trillion over 10 years from 2001-2010. Over just five years they said it would cost $460 billion, slightly less than their original estimate of $483 billion. And they pointed to an analysis from the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation backing them. The committee is controlled by Republicans.
The Gore campaign argued that it was more appropriate to examine the tax cut through 2011, since the tax cut does not go into effect until fiscal 2002. Mr. Gore's aides said that once that extra year is added in, as well as lost interest costs, the tax cut costs $2 trillion.
Another looming battle is over debt reduction and Social Security. Mr. Gore has made eliminating the public debt the centerpiece of his economic agenda. He says that Mr. Bush's proposal for putting some Social Security money into individual retirement accounts will carry a huge cost because it will require using part of the federal surplus that would otherwise go toward eliminating the national debt.
Mr. Bush's aides counter that by giving individual workers their own retirement accounts, which can be invested in financial markets, they decrease the government's long-term obligation to pay benefits out of tax revenues. This itself, they say, is a form of debt reduction.
The retirement system is projected to start paying out more in benefits than it is taking in through payroll taxes starting in 2015.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Across the Atlantic, the Microsoft Case Attracts Curiosity

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, England, May 2

 BODY:
This university town has been transformed in the last decade by the arrival of companies like Microsoft, along with a bevy of start-ups hoping to follow in its footsteps. Now it is watching intently to see whether Microsoft's path will be divided.
"For us, Microsoft is viewed as the archetypical high-tech success story," said John Cornish, director of product marketing for ARM Holdings, a designer of microchips for hand-held devices based in Cambridge that itself has become a hometown success story. "The antitrust issues are a function of antitrust laws based on U.S. history, which differs very much from the U.K. and Europe." 
 In Britain and on the Continent, the latest chapter in the Microsoft tale -- the government's proposal last week to break the company in two -- has received prominent attention in the media. The French daily newspaper Liberation has even set up a forum on its Web site for Parisian readers to weigh in with their views.
"We're a bit further removed, but I think there is as much interest here as there is in the States," said Derek McAuley, the assistant director of Microsoft's research lab in Cambridge, Microsoft Research Ltd. "When I talk to my friends at the pub, there is an understanding of the principles of antitrust, but there is some confusion as to why this litigation is being brought to bear against us."
Indeed, for many of the new-economy start-ups in Europe, Microsoft has served as the ultimate example of an entrepreneurial success story. William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, has achieved a celebrity status in Europe that rivals the Spice Girls. And while most Europeans have watched the breakup of state-owned monopolies through deregulation, most have never seen the breakup of a self-made company.
But the European Commission, the executive unit of the European Union, has kept a careful eye on Microsoft's practices, working with the Justice Department in some instances to curb the software giant's behavior. The Brussels-based commission is investigating Microsoft's integration of certain server-related software technology that has been integrated or bundled into Windows 2000. The European Commission is also examining Microsoft's agreement to acquire 29.7 percent of Telewest, the British cable TV operator, from MediaOne.
"This is not a competition between antitrust authorities," a spokeswoman for the European Commission said. "At this stage, we trust the Justice Department. Obviously, the bottom line is that we're talking about a global marketplace and whatever happens in the U.S. will have an impact everywhere."
In 1995, the European Commission and the United States Justice Department cooperated in an antitrust investigation that Microsoft settled by changing contracts with personal computer producers and eliminating some restrictions on software makers.
Today, neither party is willing to settle, and this time around the stakes are much higher. And so is the attention the company is getting across the Atlantic.
"Microsoft has used its operating system as a marketing vehicle to the disadvantage of the customers," said a column in the German business daily Handelsblat. "At a time when the trend goes toward software that is integrated into servers on the Internet, a voluntary or a forced split-up would offer the chance for a new beginning."
Readers of Liberation have been posting messages to its Web site about the Microsoft case all week. "The dismantlement of Microsoft is not a cure-all to break the monopoly of Windows, but at least it sheds light on the general contempt for Microsoft's practices," wrote a user identified as Erion.
Not many companies in Europe compete head-on with Microsoft. More often than not, the high-tech companies in Europe that have prospered have been allied with Microsoft. From computers to hand-held devices to set-top boxes for digital television, it is hard to find a European version of Sun Microsystems or Oracle, two American companies that have lobbied hard for a breakup of Microsoft.
Even British Telecommunications P.L.C., the once state-owned telephone monopoly, has several alliances with the software maker.
"On one hand it does seem strange to try to break them up because they are the ultimate start-up made good," said Peter Bonfield, chief executive of British Telecom. "But who am I to judge the Justice Department? In terms of a company, we deal with them. We don't feel threatened by them at all."

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Keep to Torrid Pace Even as Loan Costs Rise

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 2

 BODY:
Rising interest rates, a volatile stock market and higher gasoline prices were expected to be slowing the American economy by now, especially the highly cyclical auto industry. Yet the stampede into the showrooms continues across the country, with every big domestic and foreign automaker announcing today that sales last month exceeded even last year's brisk pace.
The buyers are people like Frank DiBernardino, a 52-year-old human resources consultant in Glen Mills, Pa., who bought a huge, indigo blue GMC Yukon for $42,300 last month. Interest rate increases did not affect him, he said, because he wrote a check for the entire cost of the full-sized sport utility vehicle, using the proceeds from stock he sold in February. Nor was he troubled by the high price of gasoline. 
 "There's a certain size requirement we needed for the family," he said, noting that his three grandchildren frequently visit him and his wife.
Economists and auto executives have been predicting for the last several months that sales would soon slow significantly. That has not happened. Sales did dip very slightly in April from the record-setting pace of the first quarter of this year. But after adjusting for seasonal variations, they were still up 10.5 percent from the extremely strong levels of April last year. In fact, last month was the auto industry's best April ever, according to Ward's Auto Infobank, a data service.
Other economic indicators are also showing surprising strength: the Commerce Department said today that new-home sales leaped 4.5 percent in March, while the Conference Board in New York announced today that its index of leading indicators rose a tenth of a percent in March after edging down in February.
The auto sales report is a clear sign that robust economic growth continued into the second quarter. Auto executives and economists said the biggest reason was that buyers were still feeling confident about the economy and still had plenty of money to spend.
"Real wages are really strong and it's hard to stop this train," said Diane C. Swonk, a senior vice president and chief economist at Bank One in Chicago. "You don't need any more gains from the stock market."
Another reason for the booming business at dealerships is that automakers are still piling on rebates, discounted interest rates and other incentives in a frantic struggle to increase or maintain market share. They are using their enormous profits to subsidize prices and keep monthly payments from rising for the 80 percent of their customers who obtain loans or leases instead of paying cash.
"The fly in the ointment is that the incentives for everybody are very tough," said James Holden, the president of the Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler. "With interest rates escalating, trying to hold payments constant is getting expensive."
Paul Ballew, general director of global market and industry analysis at General Motors, said that his company actually hoped that sales would slow soon, because factories were struggling to keep up with demand, and the torrid sales now might hurt future sales.
"We would like and expect to see some moderation -- it's not in our interest to have an exaggerated cycle," said Mr. Ballew, who was the Federal Reserve's top expert on the auto industry in the 1980's.
There are a few signs that the sweltering pace of sales might be cooling. Frank Ursomarso, a car dealer with many franchises in Wilmington, Del., said he had noticed a slightly slower tempo lately. He has charted a pattern over the last 44 years in which his sales trends tended to precede the overall industry's increases and declines.
"The floor traffic has been trending down a little each month," he said. "At least in this market, there's beginning to be a slower pace."
DaimlerChrysler said on Friday that it was cutting production slightly of the Jeep Grand Cherokee, which faces ever-growing competition from other midsize sport utility vehicles. Mr. Holden said the company had decided that it was better to lose a little market share than to keep increasing incentives.
William Lovejoy, G.M.'s group vice president for vehicle sales, service and marketing, also complained about the discounting. "Some of the incentives really are, we believe, extreme," he said.
G.M.'s market share was 28.3 percent in April, down from 30.6 percent a year ago. But almost all of the decline came from the company's continued weakness in the unprofitable small-car market, in which it faces competition from low-cost Korean imports. G.M. has gained share in sales of profitable full-sized sport utility vehicles, as recently redesigned models like the Chevrolet Suburban and Mr. DiBernardino's Yukon have enjoyed vibrant sales.
G.M. reported the smallest sales increase among the big automakers last month: a 2.2 percent gain overall as a 7.1 percent rise in sales of sport utilities, pickup trucks and vans more than offset a 2.5 percent decline in car sales.
G.M.'s archrival, Ford Motor, reported a different pattern. Its 15.4 percent increase in car sales led the company to an overall sparkling increase of 12.1 percent, while its sales of light trucks -- sport utilities, pickups and vans -- rose 9.9 percent.
Mr. Ballew said that this might be the first full year in which light trucks inched ahead of cars. That so far has happened only for a few months during the last three winters, which invigorated the sales of four-wheel-drive vehicles.
Market share gains for light trucks have slowed sharply from the mid-1990's, and are increasingly a result of rising sales of all-wheel-drive wagons, like the Chrysler PT Cruiser, which the auto industry chooses to classify as light trucks because of preferential regulatory treatment for such vehicles.
DaimlerChrysler's sales rose 5.3 percent, led by ever-popular sport utilities, pickup trucks and Mercedes cars.
Among other automakers announcing results today, Asian companies thrived last month, with Honda's sales rising 14.7 percent from a year ago; Toyota's sales, up 15.7 percent; Nissan's, up 31.8 percent; and Mitsubishi's up 55.2 percent.
European automakers also prospered, with BMW posting a 12.1 percent increase, while Volkswagen reported a gain of 19.3 percent.
Jamie Jameson, DaimlerChrysler's vice president for sales and marketing, said that with 25 to 30 percent of customers now leasing their automobiles, sales would not drop too quickly.
"Those people are coming back to the dealership every two or three years and they don't walk home -- they drive home in a new vehicle," he said.

HEADLINE: As Charter School Closes, Debate on Innovation's Limits

BYLINE: By KATE ZERNIKE 

DATELINE: EGG HARBOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 2

 BODY:
When they opened a charter school in a deserted warehouse here, Michael and Sarah Rennick had a clear vision of what it could be: a place where kids who did not fit the mold -- the geeks, the dropouts -- would flourish, a place where students might start their days later to accommodate their teenage sleepiness, a place where they would call teachers by their first names, and skateboard or play paintball in lieu of gym class.
The Regional Experiential Academic Charter High School, also known as Reach, would engage these students like no other school had, giving them trust and responsibility and getting hard work and respect in return. 
 But where the Rennicks saw potential, the state of New Jersey saw chaos. Given the freedom to learn the way they wanted, students were not learning anything at all, the state found. That was presuming students actually showed up at school, and many simply did not.
The school so threatened the students' education, officials said, that they shut it down barely eight months after it opened, just more than a year after granting Reach a charter that should have allowed it to stay open for five.
The closing last month left the Rennicks and parents complaining the state stifled its own experiment. The state set up the charter school law to reward innovation, but then refused to allow it, parents say. What looked disorganized was just different, and given time, they insist, the children and the school would have blossomed.
"We saw the opportunity for true innovative reform," said Mr. Rennick, 41. "They didn't want to hear about real reform."
The closing highlights an essential tension in the charter school movement. By definition, charter schools are alternative public schools, so they are often started by and attract parents who feel the traditional public school model is not working for their children. Many are based on unconventional ideas of how children learn best.
But as the Reach case shows, one person's alternative is another person's flaky. The case raises a host of questions. At what point does the experiment stray out of bounds, as state officials said it did here? Given that taxpayers are financing these schools, how far is the state obligated to indulge parents' ideas for innovation? And who decides whether the experiment works, and when?
These questions will come up again and again in the next few years as the first round of charter schools in 32 states come up for renewal.
"The states have got to think really carefully about how to allow meaningful experimentation," said Bruce Fuller, a professor of education at the University of California at Berkeley. His forthcoming book "Inside Charter Schools" looks at six experiments across the country.
"In the private sector," he added, "the government has tried to regulate businesses in a way that balances allowing them to be entrepreneurial and the interests of the consumers. Whether it's health care or the airlines, or schools, we're still struggling with what that balance is."
Sarah Rennick had run a small private school near this blue-collar shore town for seven years before she and her husband decided to apply for a charter under the law New Jersey approved in 1996.
They culled their ideas from reading the works of popular educators and management consultants. Taking the idea of a Harvard education professor, Howard Gardner, that students learn in a range of "multiple intelligences" -- some, say, spatially, others logically -- the Rennicks came up with a core group of courses, from performance arts to agribusiness, that would capitalize on each student's learning style. Students would learn through hands-on projects rather than textbooks or in a classroom where the time was rigidly divided among subjects like English or math.
To measure whether the school succeeded, the founders insisted that students would have to pass the state's standardized tests -- and prove fluency in Spanish and sign language, skills they felt were necessary for a new global economy.
Reach attracted 300 students in grades 9 to 11 from high schools that ranked in the bottom third statewide in standardized test scores. Most were from working-class families and spanned a range of ethnicities and races. But the school's disagreements with the state started months before any students even arrived.
The first dispute was over starting times. The Rennicks, citing recent research suggesting most teenagers are not alert in class because they need more sleep than most adults, wanted to allow students to start their mornings at 9:30 instead of 8 if they chose. Anne O'Dea, director of the Office of School Choice for the New Jersey State Department of Education, told the Rennicks that staggering start times would disrupt the busing schedule.
Parents describe a school that transformed monosyllabic, withdrawn teenagers into chatty students who looked forward to going to school.
"It wasn't that rigid, 'Here, read these three chapters, we'll be tested on this,' " said Deborah Roe, whose son Kyle was a freshman. "It was something a little more unique. But they were pulling a strength from these kids. These were the quirky kids or geeky kids. This was a place where they fit in. They were blossoming."
A student, Jennifer Unger, 15, said: "I was learning what I have never understood, because of the way the teachers taught. Instead of the teacher just standing in front of the class and talking nonsense, they actually came up to each student and talked about the assignment."
But starting the first day of school, Ms. O'Dea said she got calls from parents complaining about courses that were promised and not offered. State requirements say students have to devote a certain number of minutes to each subject, but Reach could not account for students' time, and neither could state officials who visited the school.
"We had a lot of kids who were not engaged in learning," Ms. O'Dea said. "There were periods during the day where the students were just in a multipurpose room, not engaged at all."
The school complained it was not getting its state money from the public schools to which students would have ordinarily been assigned, which by law are required to forward the charter schools 90 percent of the per-pupil costs for each student.
But Ms. O'Dea said this was another symptom of the disorganization. In drawing up its budget, the school counted students who never enrolled at the school, but no one realized this because Reach kept such sloppy attendance records. Some students, she said, were apparently absent 40 or 50 times between September and April.
Parents insist the school should have been allowed to stay open at least until the first round of statewide tests, to give it a chance to prove whose version of the school was more accurate -- the state's or the founders'.
But with the disputes with the state escalating, the school's board of trustees voted out the Rennicks in February. By late last month, about 100 students had left, too, although the Rennicks say the students left pre-emptively because the state made it clear that it intended to shut the school.
Mrs. Roe pulled her son out two weeks before the school closed. Her voice broke as she described how she had hoped to send her other son to Reach, as well.
"This was the last-chance school for a lot of these kids," she said. "I just feel like the state just really beat it up, they wanted so much conformity. They couldn't control that uniqueness of how this school wanted to educate."

HEADLINE: Floyd Flake to Take Post With Education Company

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, the Queens minister and former congressman who has been widely talked about as a potential candidate for mayor of New York City, plans to announce today that he is joining Edison Schools Inc., the largest for-profit school-management company in the country, education industry officials said yesterday.
Mr. Flake is to head the company's charter school division. 
 Edison has been one of the most aggressive entrepreneurs in the mushrooming field of charter schools, publicly financed schools that operate free of much of the authority of local school districts. Mr. Flake has been a supporter of the schools, as well as an advocate of giving parents vouchers to send their children to private schools.
Mr. Flake, a Democrat who has been a leading black supporter of conservative causes, particularly in education, will continue to serve as senior pastor of the Allen A.M.E. Church in Jamaica, Queens, the officials said.
H. Christopher Whittle, the founder and president of Edison, and Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the chairman, are expected to announce the appointment of Mr. Flake this morning at a news conference at Edison's headquarters in Manhattan. Neither Mr. Flake nor Edison officials would comment yesterday.
The appointment is expected to remove Mr. Flake from the list of potential candidates for the mayoral election in November 2001. Though he is a Democrat, Mr. Flake had been courted as a mayoral candidate by state Republican leaders, who saw him as someone who could attract African-American voters to the party through his support of education reform. And he has long been familiar to Republican leaders, having endorsed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in their campaigns for public office. Mr. Flake had told friends, however, that if he ran it would be as a Democrat.
Although Mr. Flake endorsed Al Gore for the Democratic presidential nomination in February, he has criticized the vice president's education policy, which opposes vouchers. Last October, Mr. Flake gave a warm introduction to George W. Bush, whom he referred to as "my homeboy," at a meeting of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a conservative advocacy group, at which Governor Bush outlined his education proposals.
One education industry executive who spoke on condition of anonymity said Mr. Flake's job with Edison would not be merely a ceremonial one. Although both Mr. Whittle and Mr. Schmidt are familiar figures in both business and political circles, Mr. Flake is expected to become the company's most prominent public figure, promoting Edison's management program and curriculum to school board officials and talking about the benefits of charter schools to state and federal lawmakers.
Edison operates 79 public schools with a total enrollment of 38,000 students in 16 states and 36 cities. Most are schools for which Edison has been given a management contract by a school district concerned about a history of poor student performance. But about one-third of those are charter schools, in which Edison is accountable to a community sponsor chosen to start a school free of standard district rules.
In November, Edison announced its largest contract to date, with the Dallas Independent School District, to serve 6,500 students next school year. Edison is scheduled to open its first charter school in New York State this fall, in Rochester.
Edison is one of the largest publicly traded education companies, and its revenues have been growing quickly. They totaled $132 million in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1999, up from $69 million the previous year. In the six months that ended Dec. 31, revenues grew to $102 million from $60 million in the same period a year earlier. But profits have been harder to come by; the company recorded net losses of $51 million last year and $21 million in the first six months of the current fiscal year.
Mr. Flake's extensive contacts on both ends of the political spectrum testify to his philosophy of using his political power with both parties to gain economic clout for his church. The Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, which says it has 12,000 members, is one of the largest churches in New York State, occupying a cavernous $23 million cathedral, which opened in 1997, on Merrick Boulevard in southeastern Queens.
Although he runs only a small religious school, with 500 students from prekindergarten through 8th grade, Mr. Flake has vast business experience through Allen A.M.E.'s wide-ranging interests. The church has more than a dozen affiliated corporations, some of them operated for profit, with interests in housing, transportation and financial services.
In 1997, Mr. Flake retired from Congress after 11 years, saying he wanted to spend more time tending his congregation. He has since been active in political circles as well as in education, and already has an association with Edison as well as some of its rival charter school companies.
In March, he was appointed to an Edison advisory board. He also serves on a similar board for Victory Schools Inc., a small for-profit operator of charter schools in New York City. Mr. Flake is a director of the Children's Scholarship Fund, the philanthropic venture started by Ted Forstmann, the financier.
Mr. Flake had recently considered starting his own charter school company to apply for the right to open new publicly financed schools in New York. As part of those deliberations, industry executives said, Mr. Flake was approached by Mr. Whittle about working for Edison.
George Arzt, a Democratic political consultant and friend of Mr. Flake's, said that although many people in both major parties had asked Mr. Flake to explore a mayoral candidacy, he always said that if he ran it would be as a Democrat.
"But he found at the end of an exploration period, after some time thinking about it, that he just didn't want to do it," Mr. Arzt said.
