HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Sather's Oiler Contract an Obstacle in Rangers' Path

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS 

 BODY:
If Glen Sather is indeed willing to listen to overtures from the Rangers about taking over control of the team, it may come after a long wait.
Sather acknowledged recently that he had a window of opportunity to leave Edmonton, where he is president and general manager. But Cal Nichols, the chairman of the Edmonton Investors Group, which owns the Oilers, said yesterday that opportunity to leave the Oilers takes place in mid-July. The window, which Sather had written into his contract, is believed to be two weeks. "There is a time limit," Nichols said, declining to elaborate. 
 Nichols also said that Sather's status with the Oilers was tied to their payroll, and how competitive that payroll was with the rest of the league. "It's tied to our player budget," Nichols said. "It has to meet a percentage of the league average."
By that he meant that the Oilers' payroll must remain within a certain percentage -- he would not say how much -- of the league average. If it does not, Sather is free to leave during the escape window. Sather had that clause written into his contract to protect his interests in case the cash-poor Oilers began slashing the payroll by trading top players.
It is no secret that the Edmonton ownership group, made up of 37 partners, is strapped for cash, and Nichols acknowledged their economic concerns. "I don't know where the league is going," Nichols said, alluding to salaries. "We know where we're going to go. And we're not going to try to keep up with the league. We will have a player budget that we can afford."
A person in hockey familiar with Sather's thinking said that because of the Oilers' current budget situation, he may be less inclined than ever to stay in Edmonton, where he has worked with the Oilers for 24 years.
If Sather is unable contractually to use the escape clause, the Rangers could presumably try to negotiate with the Oilers for his services. When asked if the Rangers would need to contact the Oilers before talking to Sather, Nichols said: "They certainly have to talk to us. Otherwise, it would be tampering. He has two years left on his current contract. We intend to fulfill our part. If he decides to leave, that will certainly be his decision."
When reached on the golf course near his Palm Springs, Calif., home on Monday, Sather had no desire to reveal the contents of the clause. "I have zero comments to make," he said.
According to Alan Adams, a hockey expert who writes for The National Post of Canada, the Oilers had a payroll this season of $25.2 million, 22nd in the 28-team league. The Rangers, who missed the playoffs for the third straight year, had a payroll of $61.2 million, tops in the league by almost $14 million.
The dilemma for the Rangers, of course, is that if they wait until mid-July to begin speaking with Sather, they will likely miss out on some of the other candidates they may be interested in, and who may be interested in the job. Without a general manager until mid-July, the hiring of a coach would have to be delayed until late summer, as well. Training camp begins in early September.
The Rangers have been without a general manager and coach since the Madison Square Garden president Dave Checketts fired Neil Smith and John Muckler on March 28. The Rangers have two possible in-house candidates for the general manager's job to fall back on should they wait in vain for Sather. They are the assistant general manager Don Maloney, who is basically serving as the interim general manager; and John Davidson, the longtime television analyst. Both Maloney and Davidson played for the Rangers, as did Sather, which makes all three all the more attractive as candidates to Madison Square Garden.
The more likely scenario, then, is the Rangers' asking for permission to speak with Sather before his window of opportunity opens. If so, the Rangers would have to work out some sort of deal with the Edmonton ownership group involving any possible package that would include money, draft picks and players.
Checketts was not available for comment yesterday. When asked if the Rangers have already asked for permission to speak with Sather, Nichols said, "No, they have not."
But Nichols did not rule out the possibility that he would listen if the Rangers came calling. "It can happen," Nichols said, when asked if the Rangers could seek permission before mid-July. "But we're not inviting it."

HEADLINE: Two Men Charged in Killing Of New Jersey Rabbi's Wife

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May, 2

 BODY:
Two New Jersey men who the authorities said were paid to kill the wife of a prominent rabbi in Cherry Hill were formally charged today and ordered held in bail, officials said.
Prosecutors said that both men had confessed to their roles in the murder of Carol Neulander, 52, who was bludgeoned to death in her living room more than five years ago. 
 Until yesterday, Rabbi Fred J. Neulander, 59, was the only suspect charged in his wife's murder, a crime that has profoundly shaken his former congregation, the largest in southern New Jersey.
Investigators have said they believe the rabbi wanted his wife dead so he could continue his affair with a woman who had a radio talk show in Philadelphia. The woman, Elaine Soncini, was pressuring him to end his marriage, and prosecutors say he feared divorce proceedings would bring out allegations of infidelity, threatening his position as leader of M'Kor Shalom, the synagogue he had founded 20 years earlier.
As in the past, Rabbi Neulander's lawyers said today that Ms. Neulander, the owner of two local bakeries, was killed during a robbery, and that their client was not connected to her death.
Rabbi Neulander, who is free on $400,000 bail, had been facing trial next month on murder and conspiracy charges. With the new revelations, Dennis Wixted, one of Rabbi Neulander's lawyers, said he would ask the judge for more time.
The two men arrested yesterday, Leonard Jenoff, 54, of Collingswood, and Paul M. Daniels, 26, of Pennsauken, are being held at the Camden County Jail on charges of murder and conspiracy to commit murder.
An unsparing confession by Mr. Jenoff, a friend of Rabbi Neulander's, added a new dimension to a crime already brimming with lurid detail. An account of the confession was reported today by The Philadelphia Inquirer.
Mr. Jenoff, who worked as a private investigator, said he believed he was being paid to kill an anti-Israeli terrorist, according to prosecutors. Rabbi Neulander, Mr. Jenoff told them, had said that such a crime would be forgiven by God. In addition to a promised payment of $30,000, the rabbi, he said, offered to help find him a job with Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency. Only after hearing a news account of the crime the next morning did he learn the true identity of his victim, he said.
Although both men were charged with murder, Mr. Jenoff did not actually carry out the crime as intended. At the last minute, paralyzed by fear, he offered $7,500 to Mr. Daniels, his roommate at the time, to do the deed.
Mr. Jenoff's lawyer, Francis J. Hartman, said his client had confessed because he was overwhelmed by feelings of guilt. "He knew the rabbi's trial was coming up and he was afraid he might be acquitted, which he thought would be wrong," Mr. Hartman said. "This clearly was a spontaneous thing."
As of this evening, details about Mr. Daniels's life remained unclear. At today's arraignment, he told Judge Linda Rosenzweig of State Superior Court that he was unemployed, suffering from mental illness and living on disability payments. Mr. Daniels, who did not have a lawyer at the hearing, was ordered held on $400,000 bail. Mr. Jenoff's bail was set at $200,000.

HEADLINE: Administration Steps Up Effort For Support of China Trade Bill

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
President Clinton and his top aides, acknowledging that they still lack the votes to pass a decisive China trade measure later this month, increased pressure on Congress yesterday by arguing that the decision is as much about global leadership and the fate of Chinese reformers as it is about the interests of American business.
The emphasis on national security issues reflected a growing feeling within the administration that the economic arguments in favor of elevating trade ties with China, while strong, have proven insufficient for wavering lawmakers. Labor unions have subjected those lawmakers to an intensive campaign, as have other groups opposed to granting China permanent normal trade relations. 
 "From a national security point of view, it would in my view be a very, very unwise and precarious move to say that the United States doesn't care whether they're part of the world community or not," President Clinton told a group of independent insurance agents meeting in Washington.
Just three weeks before Congress is scheduled to vote, the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, visited New York and gave a detailed examination of the security issues at stake in the trade bill, calling it the most important chance the United States has had in a generation to help shape China's future. Mr. Berger said a rejection would threaten to set off a "downward spiral" in bilateral ties that he likened, without using the exact words, to a second cold war.
"Rejecting permanent normal trade relations would be the worst possible blow to the best possible hope we have had in 30 years to encourage positive change in China," Mr. Berger said during a lengthy address at Columbia University. If the two sides start thinking of each other as adversaries, he said, "we will find ourselves confronting each other across Asia and across the world."
The warning comes as the Clinton administration begins a final push to persuade undecided members of Congress to vote in favor of granting China the new trade status, which would allow United States companies to benefit fully from a market-opening trade agreement that paves the way for China to join the World Trade Organization. Congress is being asked to sacrifice its annual review of China's trading rights and to treat Beijing as it does most other members of the world body, based in Geneva.
Administration officials and Congressional supporters estimate that they are still about 10 votes shy of the 218 votes needed for majority approval in the House. Mr. Clinton and five members of his cabinet have focused their lobbying efforts on about 30 lawmakers, most of them Democrats, who they say will make the difference between a narrow victory or defeat. Approval by the Senate appears more certain.
On Capitol Hill yesterday, opposing sides both claimed that the momentum was shifting their way after the two-week House recess. But there were signs that both sides were nervous about the final vote.
Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, which has jurisdiction over the China trade bill, warned business leaders yesterday that the outcome remains in jeopardy.
"I'm more concerned about getting a majority of votes today than I was four weeks ago," Mr. Archer said. "Failure to pass this would create an unworkable trade environment that will slop over to the rest of the world."
Administration officials said yesterday that President Clinton has allotted a large block of his own schedule in coming weeks for lobbying members of Congress.
The president is planning a visit to a farm community to advertise how the trade agreement might benefit farmers, who potentially could export more grain and meat. White House officials are also considering inviting former presidents and cabinet secretaries to the White House to highlight the fact that a bipartisan coalition of former national leaders favors the measure.
Last night, Mr. Clinton invited a dozen members of Congress to join him at the White House residence for a discussion on China. Mr. Clinton arranged for Martin Lee, a prominent Hong Kong opposition leader who favors granting China the new trade privileges, to attend and speak to the lawmakers.
But the president has so far declined to accede to Republican demands that he arrange a prime time, nationwide television address on China, a step Republican supporters of the trade measure argue is necessary to line up enough Democratic support. Administration officials said privately that the president does not wish to commit to such a speech unless the national networks agree to put it on the air, a tough sell during "sweeps" month, when the networks compete fiercely to attract viewers.
Opposition to granting China elevated trading rights is dogged. Labor unions as well as religious, consumer and environmental groups have put heavy election-year pressure on Democrats to vote no.
Unions have argued that the trade agreement will encourage United States companies to shift production to China, where, union officials say, low wages and lax labor standards make for unfair competition. About two-thirds of House Democrats are expected to vote no.
Most Republicans, reflecting overwhelming business support, say they will vote yes. But a minority of hard-liners in the party accuse the Clinton administration of appeasing Beijing, awarding it long-sought trading rights even as they say the nation steps up repression at home and threatens to become more belligerent abroad.
China is likely to join the World Trade Organization, a regulatory body, even if Congress decides not to grant permanent normal trade relations. But United States companies would not get many of the benefits unless Congress agrees to give up its annual vote.
Administration officials argue that the trade agreement with China is a bonanza: The Chinese made all the trade concessions, while Congress just has to agree to treat it like other trading partners. But as the lobbying campaign enters the final stretch and union opposition has proven effective, the administration is increasingly relying on national security arguments to sway uncommitted lawmakers.
Mr. Berger said yesterday that the agreement is so beneficial to United States companies that want to do business in China -- and requires so many concessions by China's Communist Party-controlled bureaucracy -- that Beijing would view rejection of permanent normal trade relations as a seismic shift in United States strategy. "The Chinese government and people simply will not believe we rejected it for economic reasons," he said. "They will suspect that rejection is a strategic decision to pursue a course of confrontation, contention and containment."
Failure to pass the accord would rebound to the advantage of numerous hard-liners in Beijing who have opposed World Trade Organization concessions all along, Mr. Berger said. In such a scenario, he said, he considers it likely that China, already mired in a high-level debate about ties with the United States, would turn inward, become more repressive and adopt a more militant stance toward Taiwan.
He also said rejection would be a slap in the face to America's Asian allies, especially Japan and South Korea, both of which have urged Congress to elevate trade ties with China. He said Asian allies would view a no vote as a sign that America has become an "unreliable, unilateral" nation that has lost its capacity to lead.
In a boost for supporters of the bill, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat who has opposed granting China trade privileges in the annual votes, said yesterday that he would support permanent normal trading status. Another Democrat who had been uncommitted, Lois Capps of California, also declared her support.
But over the recess, two supporters of the annual vote said they would vote against the bill. They are Representative Steve Buyer, Republican of Indiana, and Representative Bill Luther, Democrat of Minnesota.
In a sign that the administration and its Congressional supporters need more inducements to recruit fence-sitters, Mr. Archer, the House Republican, reversed his earlier position and said he would consider parallel legislation to the trade bill.
Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat in the House, has proposed creating an executive body that would have powers to monitor and report on China compliance with international labor and human rights standards, as well as its adherence to trade agreements.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Blessed Are the Weak

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
So this is the way the euro begins: not with a bang but a whimper.
Many enthusiasts for Europe's new unified currency, introduced only 16 months ago, expected the euro to quickly become a powerful rival to the dollar; they also expected the euro to be a very strong currency, largely because of its international role. This never made much sense if you thought it through; but anyway, it hasn't happened. Introduced at a value of roughly $1.17, the euro has been more or less steadily declining ever since; last week it briefly fell almost to 90 cents before staging a modest recovery. 
 As it happens, when it comes to the euro I am an ugly American. That is, I am one of those naysayers who was never convinced that a unified European currency was a particularly good idea, and always suspected that Europeans were enthusiastic about monetary union because it gave them an excuse not to think about other problems. So you might expect me to be gloating over the euro's slide.
But the truth is that the weakness of the euro is not a sign of economic malaise. European economies are actually doing somewhat better than most outsiders, myself included, expected. And the currency's decline despite that good news says more about the rationality of markets than about Europe's monetary experiment.
Europe's three fundamental problems -- the problems that monetary union gave Europeans an excuse to ignore -- are jobs, jobs and jobs. An old joke among economists is that the European definition of a boom is a year in which the unemployment rate rises less than usual. Behind this poor employment performance lies the phenomenon of "eurosclerosis": a labor market so clogged with government rules and regulations that European companies have had little incentive to create new jobs -- especially the low-wage jobs that in the United States provide the young and minority groups with a first step into the world of work. Europeans have, of course, been caustic about the American model. And this rhetoric, whose implications we ugly Americans in turn tend to ridicule as a policy of no jobs at good wages, continues unabated.
But if you look at what is actually happening in Europe, you discover that in the last couple of years quite a lot of job creation has in fact taken place -- and much of it involves the creation of precisely the kind of low-wage employment that European governments supposedly oppose. The telltale sign is what is happening to output per worker; in the countries where employment is expanding fastest, like Spain, productivity is actually declining. This is, believe it or not, a good sign, an indicator that marginal workers are finally finding jobs.
What naive Americans failed to understand, it turns out, was the talent of at least some European societies for creative hypocrisy. The government of France, for example, continues to talk the talk of horror at the brutal American model of capitalism. In reality, however, even as the French government introduces seemingly anti-market policies like a mandated reduction in the workweek, it has quietly allowed companies to exploit loopholes in the system -- using the shortened official workweek as an excuse to scrap old rules about worker scheduling, employing vast numbers of part-time workers, and so on. The result is that while unemployment in much of Europe is still extremely high by U.S. standards, and especially so among the young, it is finally starting to come down.
Does this mean that the weakness of the euro is unjustified, that markets are not giving Europe enough credit? In a word, yes. Look at the interest rates: 10-year euro bonds yield about 5.2 percent, not much less than the 6.1 percent yield on dollar bonds. So anyone who buys a dollar bond instead of a euro bond is in effect forecasting that the euro will be worth barely more 10 years from now than it is today. This is just not plausible when you bear in mind that the United States is running a huge trade deficit -- and has inflation that, while not severe, is significantly above the rate in Europe.
The weakness of the euro, then, is not a verdict on the European economy. It's just one of those things that markets do now and then; and it, too, shall pass.

HEADLINE: Ethics Inquiry Sees No Breach In Pataki Trips

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The New York State Ethics Commission has found that Gov. George E. Pataki and his aides did not violate the law in allowing a nonprofit trade group largely financed by companies lobbying his office to pay for trips he took to Hungary in 1995 and 1996.
The commission concluded that the trips did raise "ethical concerns" because the nonprofit group, the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce U.S.A., raised money from the companies specifically for the trips. 
 The commission, which is controlled by the governor's appointees, said its inquiry had determined that the governor and his aides were not aware that the group was soliciting money from the companies, which included Philip Morris, Pepsico and two pharmaceuticals giants, Pfizer and Bristol-Myers Squibb.
"There is no evidence -- either from the witnesses interviewed or the documents reviewed -- that anyone in the governor's office (or elsewhere in state government) knew that H.A.C.C. was soliciting funds for the trips," the commission's executive director, Donald P. Berens Jr., wrote in a letter released yesterday in which it announced its findings.
"Accordingly," the letter said, "the commission has concluded that neither the governor nor any state officer or employee violated the state ethics law or sought to circumvent the law in connection with H.A.C.C.'s funding of the governor's trips."
In the letter, which was sent to three advocacy groups that filed a complaint about the trips, Mr. Berens noted that one of the governor's aides had asked the commission before the first trip whether the administration was required to examine the chamber's finances, and the commission had responded that it was not. Mr. Berens said that when Mr. Pataki's predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, had accepted a trip from the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the panel had not required him to request information about that group's backers.
Still, Mr. Berens added, the commission would change its rules to require that Mr. Pataki and his successors, when taking trips financed by outside groups, ask whether the groups are raising funds for the trips and from whom.
"Where such a solicitation occurs, the potential for improper influence is heightened," Mr. Berens said. "A corporation may respond to the solicitation in the hope of currying favor with the state and thereby advancing its own private interests."
During its investigation, the ethics panel learned that once Governor Pataki decided to take the first trip, his senior economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano, asked the group to pay for it. According to tax records and the commission's findings, the group had little if any money at the time.
Mr. Berens did not say whether Mr. Gargano asked the chamber if it could afford the trip. Right before the trip, the chamber received a total of $40,000 from the companies it solicited.
The chamber, Philip Morris and some of the other companies indicated in interviews last fall that the donations to the chamber were not tied to the trips. The commission said it had determined that they were but had decided not to take action against the chamber or the companies.
Under state ethics rules, companies with interests before the governor are barred from paying for his travel. In this case, the companies financed the trips, with donations of $5,000 to $20,000, by funneling the money through the chamber.
The commission had allowed the chamber to pay for the trips because the chamber did not have business in Albany.
Walter Ayres, a spokesman for the commission, said it believed that it would not be appropriate to penalize the chamber and companies because the commission had never explicitly banned such arrangements.
Philip Morris's links to the trips helped to renew scrutiny of the company's activities in Albany, where it has long been a lobbying force. But after disclosures about its efforts to court the governor and legislators, the company suffered several defeats in the state capital.
Its chief lobbyist was fined and banned for violating disclosure rules, and the state nearly doubled the cigarette tax. Last month, the Legislature completed passage of a bill over the tobacco industry's objections that would require that cigarettes be made less likely to cause fires. The bill now is before the governor.
The ethics panel opened its inquiry last fall after The New York Times published several articles about the financing of the trips, which were a combination of trade mission and family vacation in the homeland of Mr. Pataki's paternal grandparents.
At the time, Mr. Pataki said no one in the administration knew anything about the chamber's backers, and that the ethics rules had been strictly followed. He declined to disclose the cost of the trips and the amount the chamber paid.
In response to the commission's findings, Mr. Pataki's spokesman, Michael McKeon, read a statement yesterday: "As we have said all along, what we did was right and proper. The commission has now verified that we followed the advice and guidance that they provided us, which were the same practices used by the previous administration."
Blair Horner, legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group, one of the three advocacy groups that filed the complaint, said that if the administration was to be believed, it was startling that no Pataki aides had scrutinized the chamber's finances.
"This shows that the administration was ethically tone deaf when this deal was first being put together," Mr. Horner said.
The commission has five members. The governor appoints the chairman and two other members, and the state comptroller and state attorney general each appoints one. The current chairman is Paul Shechtman, a former criminal justice adviser to Mr. Pataki.
When asked about the trips last fall, the chamber's president, Monika Szarka-Elling, said she did not know why Philip Morris and the other corporations contributed to the chamber, which was founded in 1992 and is based in New Jersey.
Executives at Philip Morris, the world's largest tobacco company, said at the time that its donations had nothing to do with the trips.
Ms. Szarka-Elling did not respond to two messages at her office. Peggy Roberts, a spokeswoman for Philip Morris, declined to comment.
Philip Morris said last fall that it gave $10,000 to the chamber a week before the first trip, $10,000 a few weeks before the second, and another $10,000 a year later. (In its report, the commission said the company gave $20,000 before the second trip.) A senior company executive also attended a reception in Hungary on the first trip.
Mr. Berens said the panel had determined that before both trips, Ms. Szarka-Elling sent letters to Philip Morris and the other companies asking for money; the letters "referred to H.A.C.C.'s seeking funds for the governor's proposed trip," Mr. Berens said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Tougher Stance On Safety of Biotech Food

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN and MARC LACEY 

 BODY:
The Clinton administration plans to announce today that it is strengthening its policy on regulating the safety of genetically engineered foods, an administration official said last night.
Under the plan, biotechnology companies would be required to talk to regulators at the Food and Drug Administration about the safety of the foods before they are sold, the official said. Under the current policy, that discussion is voluntary, leading critics to say that regulators may not even know about all of the genetically engineered foods being sold. 
 The nation's largest food companies had asked the administration for the change to help calm the growing consumer fears about the safety of such foods, which are now included as ingredients in most processed foods sold in American supermarkets.
"The goal is to increase consumer confidence in the food supply," said the official, who would speak only on the condition of not being named.
But some consumer groups criticized the plan last night, saying that it did not go far enough. The groups have demanded that such foods be labeled and tested for safety before they are approved for sale.
"Talking is not testing," said Andrew Kimbrell, director of the Center for Food Safety, a nonprofit group in Washington. The center has filed a lawsuit against the F.D.A., contending that its current policy on genetically engineered foods is illegal.
The nation's largest trade group of food companies quickly praised the administration's plans.
"We believe the steps as they have been outlined to us are appropriate and responsive to the discussions that we've been having with F.D.A. officials and other government officials over the last few months," said Gene Grabowski, vice president for communications at the trade group, the Grocery Manufacturers of America.
Dr. Jane E. Henney, the food agency administrator, is expected to announce the changes at a news conference that may also include Dan Glickman, the secretary of agriculture.
The administration is also expected to ask for comments on new guidelines for food companies that want to label their products as being free of genetically engineered ingredients. Without those guidelines, regulators can easily challenge companies that try to label their foods.
The administration has repeatedly assured consumers that all genetically engineered foods now being sold are safe to eat. But officials are under pressure to do more to reassure consumers because of a growing global debate over the safety of genetically engineered plants and the foods that are harvested from them.
European countries no longer buy corn grown by America's export-dependent farmers because of the concerns. And consumer fears are now spreading to Asian countries like Japan, and more slowly to the United States.
A few American food companies, worried that consumers could boycott their products, have decided to avoid genetically engineered ingredients. Frito Lay, for instance, has asked the farmers that supply it with corn not to plant genetically engineered varieties.
Genetically engineered crops, first sold in 1995, have quickly become a success. Farmers have bought up the altered seeds, which can save them time and boost productivity.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1554 words

HEADLINE: Albany Accord on Debt Plan Clears Way for Passing Budget

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 2

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and state legislative leaders announced an agreement today to restrict the state's much-maligned borrowing practices, clearing the way for final passage of one of the timeliest state budgets in recent years.
Mr. Pataki had refused to sign off on a final budget deal until a debt reform package was agreed on. The proposal hammered out today would for the first time impose a cap on the amount of debt that the state can carry at one time. The deal on debt limits means that the Legislature will be able to begin passing budget bills in the next few days. 
 The debt issue is critically important to Mr. Pataki, a Republican, in large part because he has been facing sharp criticism from conservative groups and independent budget analysts for expanding the state's overall indebtedness, even as the state has amassed multibillion-dollar budget surpluses from year to year.
New York's debt has grown by more than 30 percent in the six years since the governor took office, bringing the total to more than $37 billion, the largest for any state in the country. The debt is one of the major reasons that the state's credit rating on Wall Street is among the poorest in the nation. It is also forcing the state to spend nearly $4 billion a year on debt service.
The budget that Mr. Pataki and the leaders agreed upon calls for spending $77.5 billion to provide hefty spending increases for education, health care, transportation, public colleges and universities and other programs. The finished product reflects the state's continued economic prosperity by relying heavily on the surging tax revenues that are largely generated by huge profits on Wall Street.
The budget also provides a bounty of new tax cuts that would save New Yorkers $1.3 billion a year when fully phased in over the next four years. The biggest part is $330 million to cut a tax on utility companies that is passed on to consumers each month. The package also establishes tax deductions for college tuition costs, provides tax credits for low-wage workers and gives new tax breaks to married couples who are paying higher income taxes than if they were single.
At a news conference today at the State Capitol, Mr. Pataki said the budget struck a balance among new spending for education, tax cuts and larger cash reserves to balance future budgets. He also said the plan to restrict the state's rapidly growing borrowing would help place the state on firm financial footing.
"This budget includes the most fundamental debt reform in the history of New York State," Mr. Pataki said.
The state budget was due on April 1, but for the 16th consecutive year, the Legislature and the governor failed to meet that deadline.
But the agreement reached today almost certainly means that the governor and the leaders will complete their work this year earlier than they have in recent memory. Last year, for example, the budget was adopted on Aug. 4 -- 126 days overdue.
To breach the gap between the deadline and this week's action, the Legislature had to pass contingency budgets that kept spending at last year's levels. While the delay does not cost the taxpayers more, it does impose hardship on localities, particularly school districts that need to know the amount of state money to expect so that they can determine their own budgets.
Mr. Pataki's aides said the state's general fund budget, which consists of revenues from state taxes and fees that are not committed to specific purposes, would rise by about 4.7 percent, or nearly $1.8 billion more than last year's $37 billion. The governor had proposed a 2.3 percent, or nearly $1 billion, increase in general fund spending.
But this year's total state spending would increase by about $4.1 billion, or 5.7 percent, to $77.5 billion, according to another calculation. That calculation includes federal money that passes through the state budget and other money that is not included in the general fund. Mr. Pataki had proposed an increase of 5.5 percent, or $3.9 billion, in total state spending.
Mr. Pataki's budget officials could not be specific about a third calculation that is used to measure the budget, known as state funds. But officials said they expected that figure -- which includes the general fund, debt service, capital projects and several special dedicated revenue funds -- to be significantly higher than the $49.8 billion that it was last year.
Mr. Pataki and the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, and the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, predicted today that the entire budget would be passed as early as this week by the Legislature.
The biggest spending increase in the budget goes to education. It provides a record $1.2 billion, or 8.7 percent, rise in state aid to public school districts statewide, bringing the total amount spent on education to about $13 billion. New York City is expected to receive about $400 million of the total increase.
The budget also requires the state to continue the planned expansion of its program to provide prekindergarten classes to all 4-year-olds, and to reduce class sizes in the early grades, at a cost of nearly $200 million. That program was included at the insistence of Democrats who control the Assembly.
The budget also contained initiatives sought by Republicans who control the Senate. They include expanding a program that subsidizes prescription drugs for the low-income elderly, at a cost of about $180 million.
The agreement also adds $750 million in a reserve fund to hedge against an economic downturn and to make up for revenue lost to future tax cuts that the governor and the Legislature had enacted in previous years. Mr. Pataki had insisted that the money be placed in reserve.
At Mr. Pataki's insistence, the lawmakers also agreed to pass a law that would, for the first time, impose limits on state debt, to be phased in over the next 10 years. Ultimately, it would restrict the state's outstanding debt to no more than 4 percent of New York residents' personal income.
Now, the state's $37 billion debt load is more than 6 percent of total personal income, whereas most other states have a debt load that is about 3 percent of personal income, said Colleen Woodell, the director of public finance for Standard & Poor's, the debt rating agency.
Ms. Woodell said it was encouraging that state leaders were taking action to restrain future borrowing and to reduce the state's existing debt. "It's a good thing that they are adopting this," she said. "But the question is, can they live with it?"
New York has the largest debt of any state, and analysts have urged Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders to use the state's recent series of budget surpluses to make early payments on some of that debt, thereby reducing the principal and lowering future interest payments.
But the state's debt has ballooned since Mr. Pataki took office in 1995, when the total indebtedness totaled $28.2 billion. The state now spends nearly $4 billion, or 5 percent of all state revenues, to make payments on that debt. The median among the states is 3.5 percent, according to budget experts.
 
THE HIGHLIGHTS
What the Budget Agreement Calls For
 
Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature have reached agreement on a state budget of $77.5 billion, a 5.6 percent increase over last year. The largest share is devoted to education and transportation. The legislators accepted some of Mr. Pataki's plan for debt reform but rejected his proposals to build a new prison and expand the lottery to include Powerball.
 
TAX CUTS -- The budget would cut $1.3 billion in taxes, with the bulk of the cuts phased in over the next four years. About $330 million would come from reducing a state tax on electric power. The state would also become the first to allow parents to deduct college tuition -- up to $10,000 per student -- from their income taxes. And the budget plan would eliminate the "marriage penalty," under which married couples often pay more in income tax than two single people.
 
EDUCATION -- State officials plan to increase school aid by $1.2 billion over last year, directing about $190 million to a program that provides prekindergarten classes to all 4-year-olds and reduces class sizes in the early grades. The Legislature also adopted Mr. Pataki's plan to recruit more teachers for public schools.
 
TRANSPORTATION -- Lawmakers agreed to spend $17.1 billion over five years on mass transit projects and an additional $17.1 billion for improvements to bridges and highways. The transit money includes money for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to plan a Second Avenue subway line that runs the full length of Manhattan.
 
HEALTH CARE -- A program that subsidizes prescription drugs for the elderly would be expanded at a cost of $180 million. The budget also contains a 5 percent increase in revenue sharing for local governments to help pay for a new program that would provide medical coverage for as many as one million uninsured New Yorkers.
 
DEBT PAYMENT -- The budget would triple, to $750 million, the size of a two-year-old fund used to repay the state's $37 billion debt, and adopt a series of fiscal measures that restricts borrowing and places a cap on future debt.

HEADLINE: Euro's Anemic Showing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
For those of us living in countries that are contemplating joining the euro, the currency's performance is ominous ("Decline of the Euro," editorial, April 29). The euro's decline is a reflection of the structural weaknesses of Continental economies (extremely high taxation, inflexible labor markets, protectionist trade policies) that will continue to inhibit euro-zone economic growth. 
 The euro is a solid currency, but it is not dynamic, for although the countries that use it are wealthy and happy, they are also expensive and inefficient compared with Britain and inert compared with the United States.
 
J. EVERETT BOATRIGHT
St. Andrews, Scotland, April 29, 2000

LENGTH: 1310 words

HEADLINE: Behind Korea Meeting, a Million Troops in a Standoff

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: PANMUNJOM, Korea

 BODY:
For American and South Korean soldiers stationed in the demilitarized zone that divides the two Koreas, days begin with a blast of martial music and Communist propaganda blaring from gigantic loudspeakers that North Korea has erected just across the heavily fortified border.
The monotonous diatribe, which urges "one and all to join the workers' paradise," is often broken by jarring explosions that send the soldiers scrambling to determine whether North Korean troops or wild animals are invading nearby minefields. More often than not, the intruders are mule deer. But sometimes they are North Korean infiltrators who incite deadly gun battles. 
 This is the front line of the tense demilitarized zone, a fiercely armed no man's land of barbed wire and big guns, where well over a million opposing troops are locked in a highly combustible standoff in a place that President Clinton once called the "scariest" on Earth.
As the leaders of the two Koreas prepare for their first summit meeting since their countries went to war 50 years ago, the soldiers whose sole mission is to defend against a North Korean attack say the danger of another all-out conflict remains high.
"With such a heavy concentration of manpower and weapons located in this relatively small area, there is great potential for fighting to break out at any time," said Lt. Kwon Byung Su of an elite South Korean front-line unit on border patrol.
A half-million South Korean soldiers guard the border, backed up by 36,000 American service members and some of the most advanced military hardware available. Their assignment is widely considered one of the most difficult military postings, because the hard-line North Korean government, which has amassed one million troops along the border, seems determined to reunify the peninsula by force.
The demilitarized zone, a 150-mile-long three-mile-wide stretch of rolling hills, craggy mountains and farmland, was formed by the 1953 armistice. The village of Panmunjom, which straddles the demarcation line that runs down the middle of the zone, was destroyed by tank fire in the war. But it now serves as the site of truce talks. The northern and southern borders of the zone are lined with high fences crowned with barbed wire.
Although most clashes in the zone resemble a game of a cat and mouse and are nothing more than saber rattling, they sometimes turn deadly. More than 1,000 South Koreans, 50 Americans and numerous North Koreans have died in skirmishes along the border since the armistice officially ended the fighting.
Perhaps the most notorious incident involved the ax killings of two United States soldiers by a gang of North Koreans in 1976 in a dispute over tree pruning. In a gunbattle in 1992, three North Korean soldiers were killed and two South Korean soldiers were wounded after the North Koreans had crossed into the southern part of the demilitarized zone. Last year, a naval skirmish resulted in the sinking of a North Korean boat and the deaths of at least 20 North Korean sailors.
Underscoring the threat posed by North Korea, the United States recently distributed 14,000 gas masks to dependents of American soldiers and embassy workers in South Korea. That is because military intelligence officers have determined that North Korea has thousands of tons of chemical and biological weapons that the experts predict would be used in storming the border and taking Seoul, the South Korean capital, 30 miles away.
Some soldiers said they hoped that the anniversary of the start of the Korean War, which began on June 25, 1950, would remind the world that the conflict had not been resolved.
"I think most people don't know very much about the Korean War, and they take freedom for granted, or they just don't realize the costs," said Phillip McNeal, 21, an Army specialist from Chicago.
In his two years on the line, Chung Eup, 24, a South Korean lieutenant, has never encountered a North Korean soldier. But he said that possibility was always in the back of mind.
"Yes, it's stressful, but we think it's every Korean man's duty to serve his country here," Lieutenant Chung said as he inspected fences for signs of infiltration.
Military officials said 1 of every 100 South Korean soldiers have had at least one encounter with a North Korean counterpart in his mandatory service of two years and two months. Many encounters occur on special patrols beyond the southern boundary. Soldiers told of tense, almost surreal, encounters with North Korean troops in grassy fields of the demilitarized zone late at night.
In those situations, the soldiers said the opposing troops often confronted each other face to face, arms drawn, in a stare down. Usually the soldiers back away from one another and continue on their ways. In one case fraught with symbolism, the soldiers exchanged cigarettes before moving on. Not all such encounters end so amicably, and there have been numerous casualties in late-night gunfights that were not made public.
Although North Korea has publicly sought to improve its diplomatic relations in recent months, senior United States and South Korean military officials said Pyongyang had also been busy beefing up its military, acquiring advanced weaponry and conducting rigorous exercises.
"North Korea remains the major threat to stability and security in northeast Asia and is the country most likely to involve the United States in a large-scale war," Gen. Thomas A. Schwartz, commander of the American forces in South Korea, testified to the Senate in March.
Echoing that, a spokesman for the South Korean Defense Ministry said that although his agency supported the summit meeting, scheduled for June 12 to June 14 in Pyongyang, it still considered North Korea "a very dangerous and aggressive enemy."
In the past decade, as North Korea suffered a devastating recession and severe shortages of food and fuel, its ability to attack the South with conventional armed forces was widely thought to have declined. But South Korean and American military officials now say that despite economic woes and widespread famine, North Korea has replaced much of its obsolete weaponry, and its troops are well prepared to go to battle.
In his testimony, General Schwartz said that over the last year, North Korea had done more to arrest a decline in readiness among its troops and to improve its military capability than in the last five years combined. The general said North Korea had greatly improved its ground forces, including the deployment of large numbers of long-range multiple-rocket launchers and self-propelled guns near the demilitarized zone.
General Schwartz said North Korea had installed antitank barriers; taken new combat positions along major routes between Pyongyang, its capital, and the border; strengthened its coastal defenses; procured fighter aircraft; and taken steps to increase its missile range.
There is some growing concern in the South Korean military that new draftees have a weakened sense of North Korea as an enemy.
"We have noticed that some younger troops don't have the same contempt for North Korean troops as past generations," said Lieutenant Kwon, a public affairs officer. "They know that we are enemies. But they also realize that we are same people. It's not like we are Iran and Iraq."
Kim Myong Won, 22, a recruit who had just finished basic training and was about to begin his first tour on the front line, said: "We will fight to defend ourselves. But we really don't consider them enemies. Especially with the summit talks, there is the possibility of reunification."
Lieutenant Kwon said that with a little ideological training and field experience, he expected Mr. Kim would eventually see things differently. "Nothing has changed," Lieutenant Kwon said. "We teach our soldiers to shoot to kill."

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1034 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Changes in the earned-income tax credit are a success in the effort to fix welfare, but there's room for improvement.

BYLINE: By J. Bradford DeLong; This column appears here every Thursday. J. Bradford DeLong is a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley and co-editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Four economic analysts -- Professor DeLong, Jeff Madrick, Virginia Postrel and Alan B. Krueger -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
THE 1990's began with a burst of intellectual and political energy in support of genuine welfare reform. By the beginning of the decade mainstream political opinion had finally coalesced around the idea that the welfare system based on Aid to Families With Dependent Children -- cash payments to nonworking single mothers -- was a failure. Welfare recipients remained very poor, the incentives the system gave them were horrible, and the lessons implicitly taught about responsibility and opportunity were destructive.
It seemed better, according to the consensus of opinion makers, to make a big push to shift people from welfare to work. The idea was to bolster the wages of low-skilled workers, to provide training programs so that long-term A.F.D.C. recipients could build enough skills to escape the system and to offer job-search assistance so that they could find employers who would pay for those skills. Such an extensive welfare overhaul would be more expensive for the government than would simple cash grants to nonworking single mothers, but to many liberals and conservatives it seemed worth the price. 
 The 1996 welfare reform of Newt Gingrich, Bob Dole and Bill Clinton, however, largely dropped the ball. Instead of making a big push on training and job searching, it basically gave each state a blank check -- roughly equal to the money the federal government had formerly spent on welfare -- to spend as it saw fit. A few states have used their money to do remarkable and innovative things. But a lot more have paid lip-service to the goal of reform, and used large chunks of the federal money for programs that the state budget used to pay for, reducing rather than increasing the total amount of money spent to help the poor.
True, the number of people on welfare has dropped significantly. But in spite of a booming economy, the incomes of the poor have not risen significantly. Very little money has been spent on building skills. Little has been devoted to providing assistance in finding jobs. No one knows but everyone fears what will happen to America's single-parent poor when the boom ends and the next recession begins.
One piece of the original welfare reform program, however, was quietly put into place in 1993, as part of President Clinton's deficit-reduction program. And unlike the 1996 law, it may prove to be the most enduring and effective antipoverty instrument the federal government has ever devised.
The instrument is the earned-income tax credit. While already in existence, in 1993 the government significantly expanded the program so that it now gives a family with two children a 40-cent payment from the Internal Revenue Service for every dollar of income earned up to $9,500. A part-time $8-an-hour job thus becomes, after taxes, an $11.20 an hour job for the working poor.
The tax credit means that a two-child family with a full-time minimum-wage worker is lifted -- just barely -- above the poverty line. Two economists at the Economic Policy Institute (epinet.org), Max Sawicky and Robert Cherry, have found that more than five of six families eligible for the tax credit actually collect it, and that the credit manages to push more families above the poverty line than any other government program.
Is the earned-income tax credit perfect? No. But, like democracy, it is better than any of the alternatives.
There are three standard criticisms of the program: It is a subsidy to low-wage employers, and low-wage employers should be discouraged; it penalizes working-class two-earner families; and it is overly bureaucratic and complicated.
The first criticism seems completely wide of the mark. If we want to raise the wages of the working poor, we want to see a lot of employers competing to hire them. To provide subsidies to employers of low-wage labor is to raise their numbers and so increase the bargaining power of low-wage workers in the labor market.
The second criticism has a point. As the income of a two-child family increases from $12,500, to $30,850, it gradually loses its $3,816 tax credit. When this reduction is combined with the 15.3 percent Social Security wage tax paid by both employee and employer and the payment of income tax at a 15 percent rate, the burden on American families earning $28,000 ends up with them paying the highest marginal federal tax rates of anyone.
An easy way to make the earned- income tax credit a better program would be to reduce the speed with which the credit is phased out as income rises. But that takes money. Politicians are almost always more excited about seeing their signature on some new initiative than about improving effective but existing programs. Moreover, the political leaders who made the credit their signature initiative -- former Senators Russell Long and Lloyd Bentsen in particular -- are mostly long gone from Washington.
And the third criticism has a point as well. The earned-income tax credit is a social insurance program administered by the Internal Revenue Service, an agency whose core mission does not involve lifting the incomes of the working poor. Moreover, the tax credit's details are unnecessarily complex: the family as defined by the earned-income tax credit is not necessarily the family as defined by the rest of the tax code, and the income concept that determines whether you qualify for the program is not necessarily the income that appears anywhere else on your tax form.
But this flaw could be overcome with relatively modest changes. Mr. Cherry and Mr. Sawicky have made a proposal to fix it by simplifying the tax credit and combining it with other child-centered tax provisions into a universal unified child credit.
Most important of all, even if nothing is done to improve the program right away, the validity of these criticisms should not blot out the tax credit's broad success: $32 billion a year channeled to 15 million working poor and lower-middle-class families to increase their real wages and make work pay.
I wonder whether the training and skill-building and job-search components of the original 1990's welfare reform dream would now be regarded as equal successes, had they been undertaken, too.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Interest Rates Move Upward As Fed Cites Wage Gains

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Interest rates shot higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve reported that wages were rising across the country and investors wondered if that news would make the central bank more aggressive in its effort to slow economic growth.
The report on economic conditions in Federal Reserve Districts around the country said that "there were more frequent reports of intensifying wage pressures as shortages of workers persisted in all districts." 
 The Fed report also said economic growth was moderate to strong across the country. That assessment was re-enforced by the report that factory orders jumped a higher-than-expected 2.2 percent in March.
The new information on inflationary pressures comes after the report of a surprisingly sharp jump in consumer prices, excluding food and energy, in March and an increase in total worker compensation in the first quarter. Together the reports have increased speculation that the Federal Reserve may decide to raise its short-term interest rate target by a half of a percentage point when policymakers meet May 16.
William C. J. McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, noted the rise in inflation in March in a speech yesterday and said "we have to keep especially alert now."
In the Treasury market, the investor concern was reflected in a jump in the yield on the two-year note, which is sensitive to expected policy moves by the Federal Reserve. The yield rose to 6.74 percent, from 6.68 percent Tuesday, and is the highest it has been in five years. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 5/32, to 99 9/32.
This was a sharp rise in yield given the fact that the Treasury announced yesterday that it would reduce its issuance of two-year notes as part of its program to cut government borrowing as the budget surplus grows. A cut in issuance normally encourages buying.
The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 6.39 percent, from 6.30 percent on Tuesday. The price fell 21/32, to 100 26/32. The yield on the 30-year bond climbed to 6.11 percent from 6.01 percent on Tuesday.
Until now most forecasters had said they thought the Fed would raise its interest rate target just a quarter of a point, which would be the sixth such move since June. That would bring the Federal funds rate, the overnight rate on loans between banks to 6.25 percent.
Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at PNC Financial in Pittsburgh, said if Fed policy makers were meeting today, "knowing what they know today, they would probably go half a percentage point."
William Dudley, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, did not want to predict the size of the next Fed move. But he did say that the strength of the economy and the new signs of inflationary pressure would force the Fed to push interest rates higher than he had thought.
"I don't want to stake my reputation on predicting the May move," he said. "But I want to stress that the Fed has a lot more work to do."
Yesterday he raised his forecast for how high the Fed will have to push the federal funds rate. Mr. Dudley is now predicting that it will be up to 7 percent by the end of the year, a quarter of a point higher, and at 7.5 percent in 12 months.

HEADLINE: Missile Defense, Then and Now

BYLINE: By Robert C. McFarlane; Robert C. McFarlane was national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan from 1983 to 1985.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As President Bill Clinton prepares to decide whether to deploy a ballistic missile defense system or to wait for further testing to be completed, it may be useful to recall the history that has brought us to this point.
When President Reagan came to office almost 20 years ago, the Soviet Union had a huge advantage -- 3 to 1 -- in highly accurate ballistic missiles that had developed over the previous 10 years. Our ability to deter a first-strike attack with an adequate force of survivable counterstrike weapons -- the concept of mutual assured destruction -- had become tenuous in the minds of sensible American leaders, both Republican and Democrat. 
 Mr. Reagan had considered but was unimpressed by the theory of mutual assured destruction. He believed strongly that keeping the peace through a threat to annihilate humankind was immoral, and he came to office with the hope of starting work on a defensive system. His vision was morally inspired and deeply felt.
Despite his passion for a defensive system, however, nothing was done for two years. It was reported that neither the uniformed military nor Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger initially believed Mr. Reagan's goals to be achievable.
In 1981 and 1982, we had tried and failed to maintain the viability of offense-based deterrence. Congress had rejected deployment of the MX missile, and it became clear that we had to find a new way to deal with a growing Soviet superiority in first-strike systems. If we couldn't do it offensively, with the MX, then our only alternative was to explore relying on defense.
That led me, as deputy national security adviser, to ask several leading scientists whether technology had advanced far enough to warrant another look at a defensive system. The answers from men I respected, like Dr. John Foster at TRW, were encouraging. I then took the idea to Adm. James Watkins, the chief of naval operations, since any such concept would need the support of the military to pass muster with Congress.
Admiral Watkins, a cerebral and devoutly religious man, identified with President Reagan's moral motive and was very supportive. The other chiefs of staff fell into line, seeing the president's strong devotion to the concept and the scale of potential funding involved.
In the ensuing years, neither the president nor the team of scientists who focused on strategic defense nor I believed it would be achievable during his term. But all of us came to believe that we needed to begin exploring defense to deal with the current, as well as foreseeable, threats.
I also believed that by investing in America's comparative advantage in high technology, we would be competing more sensibly than we had for the previous 40 years. Conceivably, the burden that competing with the Strategic Defense Initiative would impose on the Soviet economy -- when combined with the expense of modernizing the country's conventional forces -- might lead the Soviets to reduce their offensive systems, ultimately eliminating the need to deploy large-scale, space-based S.D.I.
It was in that context, in December 1984, that I stated in a background session with journalists that because we wouldn't be able to deploy the system in Mr. Reagan's term, it might be called "the greatest sting in history." But it wasn't a ruse at all. And my statement in no way suggested any lack of support for the program. Indeed it was my responsibility to make it succeed.
Obviously, that the Strategic Defense Initiative might lead the Soviets to make concessions was a hope without guarantee. But trying it was worth the risk, because we would begun research and development on a system that someday we would need for a different, but foreseeable threat.
That day has come. The threat is substantially different and not as large, but North Korea and soon two or three other rogue states will present a serious nuclear threat.
Seventeen years of research has allowed us to cover a lot of ground on missile defense. Still more work is needed before a decision on deployment is made. Research on both the Navy's Aegis sea-based system and its land-based counterpart should be pursued more aggressively than current financing allows.
A delay will also provide useful time in which a new government in Washington can engage with the new Russian government and reach a mutually beneficial basis for modifying the outdated ABM treaty. My recommendation would be to share our technology with them so that they could use it too -- as President Reagan intended to do. Once testing and the bilateral negotiations are completed successfully, a decision can be made.
At that point Congress should finance deployment of a robust missile-defense system. Thanks to President Reagan's vision and determination, the means of our defense are within reach.

HEADLINE: Rural School Is Now Wired to the World

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: KAYCEE, Wyo., May 2

 BODY:
The day began as it always does in Mrs. Wetherbee's third-grade class at Willow Creek Elementary School, and it proceeded routinely, from the Pledge of Allegiance through reading, writing exercises, math, science, geography and phys ed.
But the class itself was unusual in a striking way: Nine-year-old Diamond Forbes is the only pupil Kathy Wetherbee is teaching this year in the one-room school in a remote part of the nation's least populous state. 
 Nonetheless, Diamond has a powerful tool in the classroom -- an iMac computer for class work, homework and e-mail to help her keep pace with schoolmates in larger, more privileged districts here and across the country.
Unlike most states, Wyoming has not taken a big bite of America's booming economy. Faced with sluggish job growth and a steady exodus of college graduates to other states, state officials focused on Internet access in the classroom as a critical component in equalizing educational opportunities and developing job skills. As a result, Wyoming this academic year became the first state to wire all its public schools -- even those as small and remote as Willow Creek, here in central Wyoming. And there are quite a few others: Among Wyoming's 234 elementary schools, 19 have fewer than 10 students this year. The state average is about eight students for every computer.
"Every child in Wyoming now has the opportunity to develop to his or her own potential," Gov. Jim Geringer, who began the push for statewide Internet access in schools more than five years ago, said in an interview. "By finding a way to touch every school, the next great leader from business or government could come from that one place."
Given Wyoming's rugged terrain and the isolation of many schools, it has been an ambitious and expensive project, $25 million for the first five years. But in financing the connections, state leaders recognized a desperate need to keep Wyoming children competitive or watch the state's economy fade and the population continue to slip, as it has since 1996 to the current level of 479,602.
The state Legislature approved for every school not only Internet access but also a two-way interactive video system that maximizes teacher skills by allowing, for example, a Russian language instructor to address students in his own classroom as well as those at distant locations at the same time. By next month, all the state's 78 high schools will be connected to the video system. Legislation does not require installation in the middle and elementary schools.
The combination of technologies, Mr. Geringer said, also demonstrates how businesses seeking to expand or relocate in Wyoming could take advantage of a skilled but far-flung work force.
It is hard to imagine a school that would benefit from the wonders of telecommunications more than Willow Creek, a one-room, cinder-block school that sits 22 miles off the nearest interstate along a winding gravel road that cars share with cows and sheep. The antelope and llamas apparently know enough to keep their distance. The school mailing address is Kaycee, a town of 400 that is 20 miles away. The nearest city is Casper, more than 80 miles away.
In planning for the academic year, Mrs. Wetherbee expected to teach three pupils, Diamond and two younger children. But the parents of the other children decided at the last minute to send them to kindergarten in Kaycee, leaving the iMac to Diamond, who has found it immensely helpful on her two big projects this year -- one on the Basque region of Spain, the other, which is near completion, on Scotland. Today, she searched the Internet for recent sightings of the Loch Ness monster. She found nothing new, only pictures from the 1930's she had seen before. "There she is," Diamond said, assuring Mrs. Wetherbee that the monster is female. "That's why they call her 'Nessy.' "
For Diamond, whose mother, Gloria, moved to the area from Casper last year to marry a local rancher, Skip Forbes, the Internet has become an invaluable tool. The computer she uses at home is not linked to a telephone line. "I learn a lot of card games there," she said. But it is clear from her time on the iMac that she has mastered more than that, navigating the World Wide Web with speed, dexterity and confidence.
As part of each day, Mrs. Wetherbee requires her to consult The Casper Star-Tribune's Web site to chart daily weather and read at least one story. Diamond found the weather easily and was drawn to a story about the ABC television dispute with Time Warner that included a photograph of the ABC studio in Times Square. Mrs. Wetherbee told her that millions of people live in New York City, compared with fewer than a half-million in all of Wyoming.
Diamond looked puzzled. "That doesn't make sense," she said.
Mrs. Wetherbee, 54, a veteran elementary school teacher who plans to retire after this school year, said she volunteered to work at Willow Creek this year, attracted by the remote location -- she earns an extra $55 a month in what the state calls "isolation pay" -- the class size and the living conditions. Adjoining the classroom is, effectively, a one-bedroom apartment that includes a small kitchen, living room and bathroom. Grazing cows and deer sometimes wander past the huge satellite dishes that serve the computer and Mrs. Wetherbee's television to peek inside her windows.
She lives at the school through the school week and travels to Casper on weekends to stay with friends, shop and buy food for the week ahead. After school ends in June, she said, she plans to move to Modesto, Calif., to live with her sister and plan what to do next.
"To me, it has been a gift to be here, and I think it goes both ways," she said of working with Diamond. "I needed some space after the typical teaching situation. It was not as much fun anymore, teaching to test. Everything had become so structured. But this is a dream. For the first time in my life, I am not managing children's behavior. I'm truly teaching."
And Diamond, she added, has vastly improved her learning skills this year, especially in reading, which she regards as her favorite subject "after recess."
Next year, Diamond will have a new teacher at Willow Creek and, in all likelihood, classmates, a change that Mrs. Wetherbee said would enhance Diamond's social skills and improve her confidence, which is considerable already. Without classmates, she sees old friends and cousins on occasion but spends most of her free time with her horse, Smokey, and five dogs.
Guiding the cursor across the iMac screen in search of the Loch Ness monster, Diamond said she would prefer that Mrs. Wetherbee return in the fall. But even with a new teacher she will still have her old iMac, even if she has to share it.
"I know Diamond doesn't look at it this way, but with the computer, she has not just been stuck in the little world of a ranching community," Mrs. Wetherbee said. "The Internet gives her the opportunity to see a world she doesn't see at home. I think that's a real blessing."

In an effort to help students compete, all of the state's public schools are hooked up to the Internet. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dominican Town Fears For Its Cabdriving Sons;
New York Killings Are Too Local a Story

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE DE LAS MATAS, Dominican Republic, May 1

 BODY:
The coffins of livery-cab drivers, shipped back to this country from from New York nearly once a week during the city's recent spate of killings, have badly shaken this poor mountain town of 55,000, which for decades has sent its young men to drive the streets of New York in pursuit of a decent, if dangerous wage.
Families here have exacted promises from sons, brothers and fathers in New York not to work at night, to install required partitions or get out of the business. And those planning to leave for New York are being told to steer clear of the livery cab industry. 
 "I have two teenage sons who want to join my brother Paulo driving livery cabs," said Rosario Vargas, "but I and a lot of other mothers have put down this rule: Go if you have to, but driving livery cabs is out of the question."
San Jose de Las Matas, 120 miles north of the capital, Santo Domingo, is perched amid sharp, razor-backed peaks, floppy royal palms, arching plane trees and banana groves. Along with the surrounding villages and hamlets, it has long fueled the livery cab industry in New York. Indeed, drivers from San Jose de Las Matas have come to dominate many of the car services in Manhattan. Town officials estimate that over $100,000 a month is sent back from New York.
The work has always been dicey and killings part of the trade. But not for a decade, when a previous series of New York City shootings left many Dominicans dead, has there been such widespread apprehension in places like San Jose.
The value of plastic partitions is as widely debated over domino games as the weather. And street names and neighborhoods from the Bronx, Washington Heights and Brooklyn are discussed as if they were across town. A neighborhood in Queens is called Sabana Iglesia after the rolling hills that spread out from San Jose de Las Matas.
"The Dominicans were quick to fill the hole left in many parts of New York when the yellow cabs abandoned high crime areas around 1984," said Jaime Vargas, who for 13 years was the director of the Livery Cab Owners Coalition, now known as the Federation of Livery Cab Drivers. "We created the industry. There is great pride here about this. But it has always been risky."
The poverty in this remote region drove hundreds of Dominicans to the city in the early 1960's when all they needed was a work permit. Many stayed, and slowly relatives and neighbors followed, often packing themselves into the same apartment buildings in Washington Heights, the Bronx and Brooklyn. The exodus over the years has, in fact, left small villages in the area wiped out, as subsistence farmers gave up to work in the city.
The appeal of New York, and the dollars that driving its streets at night can yield, remain powerful, and the economic pipeline and the support networks have been solidified over the years. Over the last few decades, San Jose de Las Matas has in large part been built off the earnings of livery-cab drivers and bodega owners. Cabdriving remains one of the few ways a young man with no skills can make money. And nearly everyone has a cousin or a friend willing to let them camp out on the floor, introduce them to car service owners and feed them until they find work.
And so with regularity, lithe young men, adorned with thick gold chains, designer jeans and wads of dollar bills, return here after taking their first cracks at driving livery cabs or stocking the shelves of bodegas in New York.
They are called "the Dominican Yorks," and in their moments of returning glory, they saunter down the rutted back alleys where they grew up and, for a brief, sweet moment, are somebody. It's part of the modest payback for months of drudgery and danger.
"They flash their chains and show off their money," said Santiago Bueno, 38, who worked in a bodega in New York for many years. "It's a ritual, but people long ago figured out how they really live, what their lives are really like."
He meant that New York is often not glamorous, its perils great. And so even here, where the average income is about $70 a month, the concern is beginning to outweigh the lure. While none of those killed in New York this year are from this town -- six of the nine killed since January were from the Dominican Republic -- many expect, given the high numbers of drivers from the area, that it is a matter of time. Nearly everyone here has a friend or relative who has had a close call, or even been killed.
"My cousin Rene Rodriguez was shot dead seven years ago this March rushing to help another driver that was being held up," said Elena Estevez. "His widow lives up the street with his three children. After he died, my brother bought his car and began doing the same job. He's still driving in New York, but none of us like it. We all wait for the phone to ring."
San Jose de Las Matas is a town where poverty and underdevelopment are obvious. The last stretch of road leading here from Santiago, for instance, is dirt, much of it washed out, and cars and trucks slow to a dusty crawl.
But the evidence of New York-generated income is obvious, too. Many houses are no longer made of wood, but concrete painted blue, ochre and white and topped with red tiled roofs. Station wagons, the vehicle of choice for bodega owners, and pickup trucks, many shipped down from New York, lie parked in driveways.
Antonio Rodriguez sat in a plastic chair with Rafael Urena under the shade of a corrugated tin roof, their taxis parked on the street.
"We all ask what is happening?" said Mr. Rodriguez, whose brother drives a livery cab in New York. "Is it part of the racism against Latinos? Why is it always a Dominican or a Latino that dies?"
Mr. Urena has two brothers in New York who drive livery cabs.
"I am getting ready to go but my brothers tell me it is too dangerous," Mr. Urena said. "They tell me to try and find other work. But suppose there is no other work? What can I do? If the only way I can make some money is to drive, I will drive."
Jose Antonio Roman, who ran a car service in New York, went home and on July 4, 1994, a date he chose deliberately, opened the town's first radio dispatch service. He has 24 cars and employs his son, Fausto, whom he has dissuaded from going to New York.
"Here I am middle class," he said, after barking orders over the radio, powered by a 10-volt car battery on the porch. "What am I there? Here, we find a drunk and the police call us to take him home to his wife. In New York a couple of drunks get into your car and you do not know if you are going to get out alive or with your money."
He stopped to comfort a driver over the radio whose passengers had been picked up by a rival driver nicknamed Torpedo because of the way he barrels to locations.
"The city has a powerful pull," he said. "It hovers over us. The fact is, if you are willing to work like a dog, you can come back in a few years with enough to build something. I learned how to run a dispatch service in New York, but it was not much of a life."
