LENGTH: 642 words

HEADLINE: Ambitious Plans for Transit

 BODY:
With the first major expansion of the city's transit system since the 1930's set to go forward, this is a promising moment for public transportation in New York. The scheduled projects are a Second Avenue subway on Manhattan's Upper East Side, a Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal and extension of a rail line to La Guardia Airport. To build these links, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is embarking on a $17 billion capital program that has been criticized as financially unsound and unduly influenced by Bear Stearns & Company as a financial adviser. The capital plan is important to the region and deserves to go forward. But Gov. George Pataki, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and legislative leaders must take steps to ensure that it does not force undue fare increases in the future, and the M.T.A. should recruit an independent adviser to review the financing scheme and the role of Bear Stearns.
Thanks to a booming economy, transit improvements and a new fare structure, commuter and transit riders have increased 40 percent in five years. The M.T.A. has made two sound choices in pushing initially for the L.I.R.R. connection to Grand Central and for the Second Avenue subway from 125th Street to 63rd Street. This page continues to be skeptical about the priority given to the La Guardia link. The M.T.A. may find that extending the No. 7 line from Times Square to Pennsylvania Station and the far West Side makes more sense. 
 But, as reported in The Times earlier this week, concerns have been raised about the M.T.A.'s financing plan because it was recommended by Bear Stearns, a financial firm that stands to make tens of millions of dollars if the plan goes through. The M.T.A. has reinforced the suspicions by the secretive way it has put the financing together. Before proceeding, the agency should hire a new financial adviser, using competitive bidding, to undertake a thorough review. Any underwriting business should also be awarded by competitive bid, rather than going automatically to Bear Stearns.
Criticisms of the financing center on the fact that it includes both the refinancing of old bonds and issuing of new bonds, which together would push debt service costs to 24 percent of the operating budget in 10 years, compared with 15 percent today. The resulting squeeze could curtail future improvements and force fare increases if alternative sources of financing are not found. The M.T.A. argues, however, that long-term debt repayments for major projects make sense because the new lines will be in use for decades.
The M.T.A. is taking a calculated risk that by putting forward an ambitious and much needed plan it will generate sufficient pressure on city and state elected leaders to ensure its financing. It was a good sign that recently the Legislature and Mr. Pataki agreed to plug a $2.4 billion hole in the M.T.A.'s budget over the next five years with $850 million in new funds. They also authorized a $3.8 billion bond issue on the ballot in November, with 40 percent of it earmarked for the M.T.A.
But more financing will be needed from other sources. With its own big surpluses, New York City may be able to increase its support of the transit system. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, where the directors from the two states are in an unseemly fight over allocations, could also be a source of financing for the city's mass transit needs. Most important of all, the federal government is a possible source of increased financing for mass transit.
A healthy transit system is essential to the economic, environmental and physical well-being of the New York region, justifying considerable subsidies from taxpayers to supplement fare revenues. The M.T.A. is right to proceed with its plan and enlist government leaders on all levels to battle for full financing.

HEADLINE: New Day on the Docks: They're Hiring Brains, Not Brawn

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 3

 BODY:
Like the proverbial rising tide that lifts all boats, the bustling economy that has buoyed activity in New York and New Jersey ports over the last three years has now brought an effort to hire additional longshoremen for the first time in nearly 30 years.
But those jobs will call more for brain power, like computer and technical skills, than for the brawn the work demanded decades ago. 
 "This is not Marlon Brando's waterfront anymore and never will be again," said Ira Womack, a 62-year-old docks foreman who has worked at the port for 43 years. He recalls the days depicted in the movie "On the Waterfront," when a cargo hook and a pair of gloves were standard gear for stevedoring, and their work was called the buggy-lugging of cargo bales. "They used to say that this was a place where the men were made of iron and the ships were made of wood," he said. "Now the only way most of us get exercise is by going to the health club."
The hiring of nearly 500 longshoremen will be the subject of the first of two hearings Thursday by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, the agency created by New York and New Jersey in 1953 to root out the mob influence and corruption that plagued the ports and threatened their viability.
The two-member commission must investigate and approve all who perform the work at the docks, from the lowliest stevedore to the largest shipping companies, and so is being asked by both the industry and the union to allow and supervise the new hiring.
With the exception of a trickling of emergency hiring in the last three decades and occasional temporary hiring to meet seasonal needs, new admissions into the ranks of the unionized longshoremen have been all but cut off since 1969. That was when the International Longshoremen Association, which had 27,000 members then, signed a contract to permit labor-saving mechanization and increased container shipping in exchange for a guaranteed annual income for its members, whether they worked or not.
Today, after attrition and retirements, there remain only 2,700 active longshoremen -- too few, industry experts say, to handle the growing volume of cargo in and out of the port efficiently. The workers conduct computerized checks of inventory, direct the 10-story cargo cranes that load and unload containers, and drive the gangly straddle carriers that glide around the yards, looking like legs without torsos.
The changes have cut the time and labor it takes to unload a 900-foot-long cargo ship to 24 hours and 10 men today, from three months and 500 men in 1969. But there is still a need for more workers to run the machines.
To be sure, the new hiring plan suggests that the economy is strong, but even economic health will not bring back the bustling docks that live on in workers' memories to a waterfront where human sounds and sweat have been replaced by the roar of motors and diesel fuel.
"The camaraderie is gone and won't come back," lamented Joe Garcia, 60. "Now we're all like our own bosses, sitting in a rig or a crane or carrying a portable computer, and alone. I'm glad some things about those days are gone, but I still think about them."
John Bowers, president of the union, said the new hiring was necessary not only because of the increased activity at the port, but also because of the aging of the union's membership. In the last contract, he said, the union agreed to a two-tiered system in which any new longshoremen would receive $14 an hour for their first three years rather than the $24 an hour that longer-serving workers got.
"This wasn't a popular move with our people," Mr. Bowers said, "but it helped the port become more competitive."
Carmine Cardone, the executive director of the Waterfront Commission, said that in the past the industry had to wait until there was a labor shortage on the docks and then petition the commission for the authority to hire a few emergency or temporary workers. That was the only method for new hiring allowed by the law creating the commission.
But both New York and New Jersey adopted laws in September allowing workers to be hired for projected needs, not just current shortages, and by the shipping companies rather than the unions, so that workers could be selected for the specialized skills needed.
The Waterfront Commission will still have to investigate any hired workers to see if they have criminal records or organized crime links before they can start working.
Lillian Borrone, the director of port commerce for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, noted earlier this year that cargo activity had increased 7.3 percent from 1998 to 1999.
But there are still places on the docks where brawn and numbers count for more than mechanization. At the Red Hook Terminal in Brooklyn, Sal Catucci is the owner of American Stevedoring, which moves the bales of cocoa, streaming in daily, that have made New York the largest handler of cocoa in the world in the last two years.
Mr. Catucci said the new hiring of longshoremen was "long overdue," because he had often gone days without enough workers to unload ships.
"My work force's average age is 62 years old, the oldest in the port," he said. "I'm losing men each month, and I have customers screaming because I don't have the labor to handle their ships."

HEADLINE: To Aid Trade Bill, Democrat Creates Plan for Rights Panel

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
With supporters of a China trade bill scrambling for every vote, a Michigan Democrat in the House is planning to introduce legislation this week that he predicts will rescue the Clinton administration's top remaining foreign policy goal from potential defeat.
The legislator, Sander M. Levin, said today that he is putting the final touches on a proposal to establish a commission with powers to review human rights, labor policies and development of the rule of law in China. After weeks of test-marketing in Congress, Mr. Levin said his proposal for parallel legislation to the trade bill could recruit enough fence-sitting Democrats to tip the balance in favor of the administration. 
 The bill would set up a commission consisting of nine members of each house of Congress, five presidential appointees and a full-time staff. The body would study China issues and advise both Congress and the White House on legislation or administrative steps, including United States policy on lending by the World Bank. That would keep pressure on Beijing to comply with its trade commitments and improve human rights, Mr. Levin said.
Opponents of extending permanent normal trade relations have dismissed Mr. Levin's proposal as a fig leaf, saying the commission would have no real powers of enforcement. Both the Clinton administration and the Republican Congressional leadership had kept their distance.
But Democrats, Republicans and administration officials are now saying that the Levin proposal attracts more votes for elevating China trade relations than it loses, especially among uncommitted Democrats. House vote counters said the Levin commission had helped recruit at least 15 Democratic yes votes, badly needed ones if the administration is to reach the minimum 70 Democratic supporters it claims it must have.
Republican leaders say they can produce 140 to 150 votes for the trade bill, but will rely on Democrats to push the total over the 218 necessary to pass the House. The House vote is scheduled for late May. Approval in the Senate is seen as certain.
"I think the Levin proposal will be responsible for 15 votes and maybe more," said Robert T. Matsui, the California Democrat who is leading the effort to round up Democratic votes in the House. "It gives me what I need."
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, who is leading the administration's lobbying effort on the bill, today called Mr. Levin's proposal "an extremely good plan." Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, also spoke favorably about the idea at hearings on China trade.
The China trade measure also got a lift today when House and Senate negotiators agreed on details of a bill to give African and Caribbean countries wide-ranging trade benefits aimed at helping their ailing economies. The House could vote on the compromise as early as Thursday.
As many as half a dozen House Democrats have suggested that they would not vote for the China measure until the House first passed the Africa trade bill.
Meanwhile, the Clinton administration announced plans to beef up the team the government employs to police compliance with trade accords, with special emphasis on china. Mr. Daley said the administration would ask for $22 million in extra spending for trade enforcement and export promotion. Some of that money would pay for new personnel who would focus specifically on whether China meets its market-opening obligations after it enters the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Levin designed his proposal to resemble the Helsinki Commission, a joint commission of Congress and the White House set up in 1976 to monitor human rights in the Soviet bloc. The idea is to give members of Congress sway over China policy even if it agrees to sacrifice its annual review of that nation's trading rights, a step that's necessary if American companies are to benefit fully from concessions China made in its bid to join the W.T.O.
"This is something that should be an important part of our trade policy - a way to shape globalization," Mr. Levin said.
House Majority Leader Dick Gephardt had his own plan for setting up an investigation and enforcement body for trade with China with the authority to mandate sanctions if China failed to live up to its trade obligations or to international labor standards. But the Clinton administration firmly rejected any proposal that would have the power to mandate sanctions, calling that inconsistent with America's obligations under W.T.O. rules. Mr. Gephardt has said he will vote against the China trade bill.
Critics say Mr. Levin's proposal is a watered down version of Mr. Gephardt's and does not deserve broad support.
But it has elicited enthusiasm among some Republicans. Representative Doug Bereuter, a Nebraska Republican who has been working closely with Mr. Levin, said he planned to present it to the House Republican leadership for their blessing. He said the commission could sway several undecided Republicans to vote for the China bill.

HEADLINE: Two Reports Show Strength In Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
New orders to American factories rose 2.2 percent in March, a much sharper rise than expected, led by the largest jump in demand for electronic equipment in more than two years, the Commerce Department said today.
In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said today that its latest review of the economy showed "moderate to strong" business activity in most areas around the country in March and part of April. 
 "Factories were running near capacity in some areas as overall manufacturing activity was strong," the Fed said in its report, known as the beige book. Retailing and commercial construction were also brisk, adding to the economy's growth.
The Fed survey, compiled from reports from its 12 regional banks, also said "there were more frequent reports of intensifying wage pressures as shortages of workers persisted in all districts."
But even against this backdrop, consumer prices remained relatively well behaved, the Fed said.
Though surging energy prices meant fuel surcharges or higher costs for certain materials for some companies, in few instances were the increased costs passed along to consumers as higher product prices.
The survey, based on information collected before April 24, will be used when Fed policy makers meet on May 16 to review the central bank's stance on interest rates.
In its report, the Commerce Department said manufacturers' orders rose to a seasonally adjusted $383.2 billion after showing no change in February and declining in January.
The 2.2 percent increase in factory orders in March was the best showing since a 3.8 percent gain in December and was stronger than the 1.7 percent rise that many analysts had anticipated.
Orders for electronic and electrical equipment, including household appliances and communications equipment, posted the largest gain in March, rising 10.2 percent, to $45.2 billion. That was the biggest jump since August 1997 and the eighth increase in the last 10 months. These orders rose 9.9 percent in February.
Also contributing to the strength in total factory orders in March was a 4.1 percent increase in orders for transportation equipment, which rose to $48.5 billion. In February, such orders fell 9.4 percent.
Excluding the volatile transportation category, factory orders grew 1.9 percent in March after rising 1.5 percent the month before.

HEADLINE: College Education Seen as Essential

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
In a shift that experts attribute to the changing economy, higher education is increasingly seen as the ticket to the middle class, with 87 percent of Americans saying "a college education has become as important as a high school diploma used to be," a new study has found.
Seven years ago, a majority of Americans believed that too many people were going to college rather than directly into technical trades like plumbing or computer repair; now, 3 out of 4 think the country could never have too many college graduates. The study shows that 77 percent of Americans believe college is more important now than a decade ago. 
 "The market demands it," a woman from Old Bridge, N.J., said in one of several focus-group discussions held around the country as part of the study. "Before, you could get a good job with a high school graduation. Now, you need a college degree, a master's or even a Ph.D."
More than 60 percent of parents of high school students see a college education as "absolutely necessary" for their children. Even more noteworthy are the views of minorities, whose enrollment in higher education lags behind that of whites. When asked to choose the single factor that most determines success, 67 percent of Hispanic parents and 45 percent of African-American parents picked a college education, compared with 35 percent of parents over all.
"There has been this coalescing of opinion in this country around the notion that college is critical to opportunity," said Patrick M. Callan, president of the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, a research group in San Jose, Calif. "It isn't just a piece of paper. It's a necessary factor for middle-class life."
The $315,000 project on attitudes about education was financed by three groups that study education policy, and conducted by Public Agenda, an organization in New York that conducts in-depth research on various issues. It began with telephone interviews of 1,015 adults -- particularly parents -- in December, and included in-depth discussions with groups in six cities.
The strong support for higher education among minority parents, experts said, belies the oft-stated view that one barrier to black and Hispanic enrollment is the low priority those ethnic groups placed on college. Only 20 percent of Hispanics ages 18 to 24 are enrolled in college, compared with 37 percent of non-Hispanic whites, yet more than twice as many Hispanic parents (65 percent) as white ones (32 percent) believe a college education is necessary to be successful in today's working world, according to the new poll.
"This is a pattern that we've been waiting to see emerge," said Robert Zemsky, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania and director of the Institute for Research on Higher Education. "It now follows other groups that have seen higher education as a means of transformation. The Jewish community, the Italian community, the Asian community -- now we're seeing it in the African-American and the Hispanic community."
When asked what students should gain from attending college, those surveyed emphasized job-related skills rather than the traditional tenets of the liberal arts. Sixty percent said computer proficiency and specific expertise in a chosen career were "absolutely essential" outcomes, while just 32 percent gave that level of importance to "exposure to great writers and thinkers" in literature and history. At the top of the list were basic skills in living, including a sense of maturity and an ability to get along with diverse people.
"All of us in the academic world like to think that the purpose of higher education is to master the great philosophies and read the great books," said Stanley O. Ikenberry, president of the American Council on Education, which represents 3,500 colleges and universities. "But the public, throughout this past century, has really seen education in very instrumental, very practical terms."
While 71 percent of those polled think paying for college is more difficult than it was a decade ago -- and 4 out of 5 say students have to borrow too much money to pay tuition -- an overwhelming 93 percent of parents are confident that they will find a way to work out the cost of higher education. Still, 69 percent of parents worry about meeting college expenses and 61 percent say they "should have done more" to prepare financially.
Asked about various forms of financial aid, more of those polled favored tax credits and work-study programs than loans or direct grants to students. Fewer people (47 percent) believe there are many qualified applicants who lack the opportunity to attend college now than who believed so in 1993 (60 percent).
"If the desire is there, you make a way for your children," a Philadelphia parent said in a focus group.

HEADLINE: Federal Regulators Give Approval to Viacom's Buyout of CBS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
Federal officials today approved the largest broadcast merger in history -- Viacom's $30 billion acquisition of CBS -- just a day after two other media giants resolved a dispute that was, in large part, a byproduct of consolidation in the broadcasting and cable industry.
The decision by the Federal Communications Commission to approve a merger that will give Viacom control of 35 percent of the broadcasting market represents the high-water mark of a Clinton administration policy of promoting consolidation in a number of industries as a way of encouraging competition. It was immediately hailed by top executives of the company. 
 Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman and chief executive of Viacom, said that the acquisition would be completed on Thursday morning and that CBS's ticker symbol would never again be trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"This has really worked perfectly," an ebullient Mr. Redstone said in an interview this afternoon. "We basically got everything we had wanted."
The administration's policy of permitting consolidation in the telecommunications industry will be on display again later this month, when the F.C.C. is expected to approve a staff recommendation to permit AT&T to complete its acquisition of MediaOne, giving it control of more than a third of the cable industry. Many experts expect that the Justice Department, which is reviewing that deal for antitrust issues, will also approve it.
The policy is rooted in the notion that a few corporate behemoths battling over control of the market can be both more efficient and more competitive than any regulation and control from bureaucrats in Washington.
"We don't think big is per se bad," said Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division. "We analyze mergers in terms of relevant markets."
But such mergers do not always come without a price. The policy helped both the Walt Disney Company, ABC's parent company, and Time Warner grow into formidable broadcasting and distribution companies in recent years. But this week, some 3.5 million customers of Time Warner cable television lost their ABC signal for almost two days as the two companies wrangled over retransmission agreements.
The consolidation has created bottlenecks that have made it easier for one company to block the access of another. Moreover, government officials and industry analysts say negotiations between Time Warner and ABC had grown more strained after Time Warner's announcement that it intended to merge with America Online.
Moments after approving the merger of Viacom and CBS, the F.C.C. ruled that Time Warner had violated a regulation that prohibits a company from removing a network's signal during the sweeps rating month and said it would consider what penalty to impose. The fine will be symbolic, as the agency can only penalize the company $7,500 for each violation each day.
But consumer groups say the larger lesson from this week's events is that further consolidation of the cable and broadcast industries will lead to similar disputes and blackouts, as the survivors struggle to control both the content and distribution of what appears on television and the Internet.
As the number of dominant players in telecommunications and other industries dwindles, some regulators are also beginning to question how much further the government should go in approving large pending deals.
"Quite often the best consumer competition comes from big companies fiercely competing against each other," said Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. "But in some sectors of the economy, we are running out of big companies."
Mr. Pitofsky declined to discuss his agency's review of the proposed merger of America Online with Time Warner. But other government officials said today that Time Warner's decision to remove ABC this week from its cable systems had undermined the companies' repeated pronouncements when the merger was announced that they would never try to shut out others from using their enormous Internet and cable backbone.
In approving Viacom's acquisition of CBS, the regulators gave the companies a year to come into compliance with a rule that prohibits a television network from having an ownership interest in a second network. Viacom holds an interest in the fledgling UPN, and some experts predict that the agency may relax the dual network rule over the next 12 months.
Viacom will also have a year to meet the national television ownership cap, which prohibits a company from controlling more than 35 percent of the broadcast market. The combined reach of CBS and Viacom is now more than 41 percent. As part of the regulatory order, the companies will have six months to sell some radio and television stations in the Los Angeles, Chicago, Baltimore, Dallas-Fort Worth and Sacramento, Calif., areas.
But those divestitures are relatively small pieces of the deal, which involves the transfer of 38 television stations and more than 160 radio stations.
With a few exceptions, regulators during the Clinton years have signed off on big mergers, many of which would have been unimaginable a generation ago.
"In merger law, the Clinton administration has a great deal in common with the Reagan and Bush years," said John Shepard Wiley Jr., a law professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. "The analysis has become bipartisan."
By contrast, in the 1960's, the Justice Department successfully blocked one deal that would have resulted in a grocery store merger that would have resulted in a company controlling 7.5 percent of the industry.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE INFIGHTING;
Jabs Fly in Presidential Ring Over Social Security's Future

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO with FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
In a sharp exchange that gave the presidential campaign the intensity of a day in late October, Vice President Al Gore accused Gov. George W. Bush today of devising a "secret plan" that could bankrupt the Social Security system. Hours later, Mr. Bush tartly questioned the vice president's honesty and predicted that Mr. Gore's attacking style would soon backfire.
Echoing a theme he has repeated often in recent days, Mr. Gore used a speech to union officials in New Jersey to assert that Mr. Bush, the likely Republican nominee, was quietly developing a "risky" plan to allow individual investment accounts in Social Security that would jeopardize millions of taxpayers' savings. 
 "How does the Bush plan propose to deal with the bankruptcy of Social Security that his privatization scheme would cause?" Mr. Gore told a gathering of A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials in Atlantic City. "He doesn't even bother to provide an answer. He just smiles and goes on with the smug assumption that there's no need to share with you the details of what he wants to do."
Responding to Mr. Gore's cascade of attacks, Mr. Bush spent much of a plane flight this afternoon from Austin, Tex., to Palm Springs, Calif., telling reporters that the vice president had flatly misrepresented his record on a host of issues, ranging from the Texas budget to his positions on China and Russia to his crime-fighting policies.
"Someone running for the highest office of the land should stick to the facts," Mr. Bush said. "I think it is a pattern to say things, to stretch the truth. He's the man who said he invented the Internet."
Asked whether Mr. Gore's aggressive campaigning might work as well against him as it did against former Senator Bill Bradley during the Democratic primaries, Mr. Bush said he planned to respond faster and more forcefully than Mr. Bradley.
"It's not going to work here," he said.
In fact, rather than being aggrieved by his opponent's attacks, Mr. Bush seemed somewhat amused by the constant salvos from the vice president, suggesting that Mr. Gore's strategy was self-defeating. "Pretty soon, it's going to have a corrosive effect on his campaign if he's not telling the truth," Mr. Bush said of Mr. Gore during the 78-minute airborne news conference. "The fact that he relies on facts -- says things that are not factual -- are going to undermine his campaign."
He added: "The more outrageous he gets, the more outrageous allegations he makes against me, the more skeptical people will become."
Mr. Gore's aides clearly disagree. Privately, they contend that the slashing strategy they employed during the primaries will work again in the general election, provided they avoid the appearance of attacking Mr. Bush personally.
They have done that, they argue, by focusing on issues like Social Security, tax cuts, health care and gun control.
"The primaries showed that voters believe that vigorously debating your opponent on issues is considered fair play," said one adviser to Mr. Gore.
Mr. Gore also used his Atlantic City speech to discuss his own proposal for keeping the Social Security system solvent.
Under that plan, he would use the system's surplus to pay down the national debt, which in turn would reduce the federal government's interest payments. Those savings would then be put back into the Social Security trust fund, keeping the system solvent for an additional 13 years or more.
"I will devote all interest from debt reduction to shore up Social Security," Mr. Gore said. "I think it is wrong to cut benefits, raise the retirement age or risk your retirement savings in a game of stock market roulette."
But that description amounted to one brief passage in a 35-minute speech that was devoted mainly to attacking Mr. Bush on a variety of fronts, particularly Social Security.
Under the proposal floated by Mr. Bush's aides in recent days, taxpayers would be allowed to invest a small part of their Social Security payroll taxes in the stock or bond markets.
Mr. Bush's aides argue that such a plan would help taxpayers take advantage of the stock market's historic growth.
But Mr. Gore asserted today that the plan would make the system vulnerable to huge market fluctuations that could hurt millions of retirees. And as he has repeatedly done in recent days, he suggested that Mr. Bush was charting a course that was "reckless" and "irresponsible."
"To me, Social Security is more than a government program," he said. "It is a solemn compact between the generations." Governor Bush, he added, "seems to believe differently."
Mr. Gore asserted that Mr. Bush had "left the door wide open" to raising the retirement age for Social Security as a means of bolstering the system.
That approach, he argued, would be harmful to people who do strenuous manual labor and physically cannot postpone retirement. And he accused Mr. Bush of wanting to cut Social Security spending to pay for a tax cut that Mr. Gore argues would favor the rich.
"What about the waitress who's carrying a heavy tray, what about the longshoreman, what about the steelworker and the auto workers?" he asked. "When they get to the current retirement age, they don't want to be told that in order to finance some risky tax scheme for the wealthy, they are going to have to keep on working until they are 70 years old."
Mr. Bush's aides acknowledge that he has not ruled out raising the retirement age. But they note that he has not formulated a detailed plan yet, only the general principles for one. Those include not increasing Social Security taxes, not cutting benefits and setting aside the Social Security surplus in a "lockbox" to make sure it is used only on Social Security.
It was Mr. Bush's lack of a detailed plan that caused Mr. Gore to accuse the Texas governor of devising a "secret plan" today.
"He wants to spring it on you after the election," Mr. Gore said. "Well, I think he may be underestimating the capacity of the American people to figure out for ourselves what the details of his secret plan would mean for each and every American."
But if Mr. Gore's barbs were meant to rattle Mr. Bush, they failed. Indeed, what was extraordinary about today's exchange was the almost delighted mood that Mr. Bush brought to his end of it.
Mr. Bush was on his way to California for several days of campaigning, including a fund-raiser in Palm Springs tonight for the Republican Party that was expected to bring in about $1 million.
On the flight, Mr. Bush revealed a few more glimmers than usual of his obvious distaste for what he seems to see as Mr. Gore's desperation to be president.
Usually, Mr. Bush does a more thorough job of pulling his punches when he is asked what he thinks about Mr. Gore as a person.
After a reporter told Mr. Bush that Mr. Gore, whose first grandchild was born on the Fourth of July, sometimes says to Hispanic audiences that he hopes his second grandchild will be born on Cinco de Mayo, Mr. Bush muttered, "Totally pathetic."
At another point, talking about his own desire for the presidency, Mr. Bush said: "I'm willing to work for it. What I'm not willing to do is sell my soul to become the president."
Asked if Mr. Gore would do that, Mr. Bush arched an eyebrow and said, "That's for you all to figure out."
Mr. Bush did not use the word "lied," and when reporters did, he corrected them, coyly repeating again and again that he was simply setting the record straight and expressing his "disappointment" in Mr. Gore's behavior.
But he did use the words disappointment or disappointed at least half a dozen times.
"The vice president said I've never submitted a budget as governor of Texas" said Mr. Bush, reciting the comments by Mr. Gore that he deemed untruthful. "He talked about recidivism rates that were totally inaccurate numbers."
"He said I called China and Russia enemies," Mr. Bush added. "Have I ever referred to China and Russia as enemies?"
Mr. Bush shook his head and veered toward what he clearly intended to be a kind of emotional and moral high ground.
"I just am disappointed and I think Americans will be disappointed when they find out the truth," he said.
 
In Their Own Words
 
VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE
 
Remarks at a convention of the New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. held yesterday in Atlantic City, N.J.:
"Now we face a basic choice. Will we use our prosperity to lift up our working families and meet our responsibilities to our parents and to our children and make sure that no one is left behind? Or will we go back to where we were eight years ago?
Will we roll the dice in the same casino economics that devastated our economy and hurt working families? Does anyone in this room think we should go back to the union-busting, job-destroying, budget-busting policies of the Bush-Quayle years. I don't think so. . . .
There are deep and profound differences between Governor Bush and me. Not personal differences, but real differences on the issues. I believe America has to put its fundamental responsibilities first. We have to pay down our debt, we have to save Social Security, we have to lift up working families.
George W. Bush believes instead that our top priority should be a reckless $2 trillion tax giveaway lavishing more on those who already have the most. . . .
His tax plan is bigger than anything Newt Gingrich ever dreamed of proposing. That may be why Governor Bush does not set aside a single penny for Medicare. And I believe his approach to Social Security is even more irresponsible."
 
GEORGE W. BUSH
 
Speaking yesterday aboard his campaign plane en route to California:
"The vice president said I've never submitted a budget as governor of Texas. He talked about recidivism rates that were totally inaccurate numbers. . . .
The more outrageous he gets, the more outrageous allegations he makes against me, the more skeptical people will become. I will respond. But I'm going to respond in a way that doesn't allow him to drag the process down. One of our jobs in this campaign is to make clear what the facts are."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: FUND-RAISING;
At $500,000, Democrats Gala Ticket Tops Record

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3

 BODY:
For its annual gala here on May 24, the Democratic Party is offering tickets ranging from an affordable $50 to a platinum price of $500,000, the highest amount either party has charged for admission to a fund-raising gala.
The donors and fund-raisers who give or collect $500,000 will be given a package of perks that includes an invitation to a private dinner with President Clinton at a Washington restaurant on the eve of the gala and front-row seats, in the so-called "platinum section" of the MCI Center, for the gala's entertainment. The comedian Robin Williams leads the list, along with the musicians Stevie Wonder and Lenny Kravitz. 
 The gala is a tribute to Mr. Clinton, led by his close friend Terry McAuliffe, who offered last year to put up $1.35 million of his own money for the Clintons' house in Chappaqua, N.Y. The event features the widest gulf in donor levels ever seen at a political fund-raiser here.
Prolific fund-raisers and generous donors will also be invited to attend a private reception with Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore before the gala.
S. Daniel Abraham, the chairman of Slim-Fast Foods of West Palm Beach, Fla., recently wrote a check for $500,000, which the national committee deposited on May 1, party officials said today.
At its black-tie gala last month, the Republicans raised a record-shattering $21.3 million, a sum composed mostly of large, unregulated checks of $100,000 or more. Nearly 50 Republican fund-raisers gave $250,000 each. And the Republicans have a big-money club of donors, known as the Regents, who each pay $250,000. The Democrats have their own big-money club: members of Leadership 2000 each give or collect $350,000.
The sharp escalation of campaign contributions, or "donation inflation," as some fund-raisers call it, has alarmed many who advocate changes in the campaign finance system, and they reacted with outrage today at the $500,000 fund-raising level established by the Democrats.
"The spiraling obscenity of craven campaign finance efforts will not stop unless either the public's outrage starts being felt or corporations and special interests become sickened themselves and balk at paying these absurd amounts of money," said Peter Eisner, managing director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit public watchdog group.
Fred Wertheimer, the president of Democracy 21, a public policy group that advocates campaign finance reform, said, "This is crazy greed, and it would be shameful if there was any shame left in this city."
Democratic Party officials objected to the portrayal of the gala as a soft-money event.
"This is a different kind of event meant to bring people from all walks of life to rally around the Democratic Party and the issues we stand for," said Jenny Backus, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee. "It's very disappointing for these reformers, who know better, to try and put a pox on both of our houses, when it is very clear that the Democratic Party is the party that wants to reform the campaign finance system."
Mr. McAuliffe says he is trying to open the gala to thousands of young Democrats, who he says will pay $50 or $100 for tickets. The Democrats want to sell 14,000 arena tickets at prices from $50 to $1,000. And they have contrasted their event, which they say will encourage guests to wear blue jeans and cowboy boots, with the Republicans' black-tie affair last month in tribute to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the party's presumptive presidential nominee.
But both have one thing in common: many checks of soft money, the large, unregulated contributions.
The Republicans received large checks and fund-raising assistance from Phillip Morris and Wayne LaPierre, the executive vice president of the National Rifle Association.
In recent months the Democrats have received $350,000 from SBC Communications, the telecommunications giant, and $250,000 checks from both Marc Andreessen, the founder of Netscape, and Mark B. Nathanson, a cable television mogul.
"The money for this event is unbelievable," said one Democratic fund-raiser. "It's all because of Terry. He could raise $25 million, or even $30 million, in one night. It will be the most successful Democratic event, by a factor of three."

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Pass Budget and Adjourn

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 3

 BODY:
Connecticut lawmakers put the finishing touches on a $12.3 billion state budget today, ending this year's legislativesession on an unusual note of bipartisan amity.
Before the clocks struck midnight, ending this year's 12-week session, the General Assembly had unanimously passed the state budget for the 2001 fiscal year and allocated this year's approximately $250 million surplus to several projects, including a bailout of the state's largest hospital and giving $34 million extra to cities and towns. 
 All 187 lawmakers voted for the budget, which includes a 7-cent-a-gallon cut in the state gasoline tax and an exemption on sales tax for up to $300 in back-to-school clothes, as it sailed through Connecticut's House of Representatives and Senate Tuesday evening.
"I cannot remember a unanimous budget in both chambers," said Kevin B. Sullivan, the State Senate president pro tempore, who has been in office since 1986. "This is the most clear demonstration of consenus that I have ever seen, ever."
Indeed, with their big bills out of the way and a near-perfect spring day beckoning from outside, lawmakers seemed usually giddy today, like college kids in their final class before spring break. Several times, House and Senate leaders had to stop and scold their colleagues for chattering and not paying attention to the matter at hand.
"I'm going to ask once again to please keep the noise level down," Lieutenant Governor Jodi Rell, the Senate president, told Connecticut's 36 state Senators, sounding more like a lunchroom monitor than the state's second-ranking executive. After they quieted down, she warned, "If I have to ask you again, I may have to ask you to leave the chamber."
Their exuberance was perhaps understandable. On Tuesday, after three days of squabbling that nearly sank a $771 million construction and redevelopment package for downtown Hartford, the Democratic-led House and Senate passed the bill and Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, quickly signed it.
Leaders of both parties hailed the project, the state's largest urban construction project in nearly 40 years, as the advent of a new era in a city with persistent economic problems.
The bill allocates $529 million in public funds -- most of it from state bonds -- to build a hotel and convention center, college football stadium and luxury apartment tower along Hartford's long-ignored riverfront. Last Friday, disagreements between labor unions and the project developer, the Waterford Group, threatened to scuttle the 33-acre project, known as Adriaen's Landing.
Last-minute negotiations Monday saved the deal, which includes about $230 million in private investments. The deal assured that Hartford and East Hartford, its impoverished neighbor across the Connecticut River, where the new University of Connecticut football stadium will be built, will be clogged with construction cranes for at least two years, starting next spring.
"Adriaen's is the toughest thing I've ever had to deal with," Mr. Sullivan said. "It will never make Hartford into what Baltimore is," he added, contradicting some of the more lofty predictions heard at the Capitol lately, "but it might make Hartford into what Providence has become."
Tony Caruso, the executive director of the Hartford Downtown Council, a business group, said Adriaen's Landing was "a great start for the next millennium."
The budget agreement includes Governor Rowland's top fiscal priority: a 7-cent reduction in the state's 32-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, the highest in the nation, beginning July 1.
The new budget also includes much of the Democrats' wish list. It increases the price of clothing exempt from the state's sales tax from $50 to $75 per item and creates another tax exemption for up to $300 worth of clothing and shoes bought at any one time in August, before school resumes.
Other major items this session included a bill that authorized a referendum in November, on whether to abolish the state's sheriff's system. One sheriff faces charges of carrying an assault rifle into a courthouse; a sheriff's deputy faces charges of firing a gun at motorists after a traffic dispute.
Governor Rowland signed a bill that tightens the rules limiting who may collect a finder's fee for arranging investments of state money.
The measure was prompted by the case of a former state treasurer, Paul Silvester, who pleaded guilty in September to charges of racketeering and money laundering. He admitted accepting kickbacks from finder's fees paid by companies with which he invested state pension money.

HEADLINE: 2 Stock Exchanges in Europe To Merge, With Nasdaq Link

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 3

 BODY:
The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges announced plans today for a merger as well as an alliance with the technology-heavy Nasdaq stock market of the United States. London and Frankfurt hope to build a pan-European trading heavyweight and a 24-hour global market in new-economy stocks -- both unthinkable prospects only a few years ago.
The British-German exchange would be Europe's biggest by far and the world's fourth largest. 
 The announcement offered the most significant evidence to date of a sea change in European markets. The shift has been driven by a clamor among investors for less expensive trading systems, a challenge from Internet-based and electronic trading systems, and a perception that Europe has become a single investment arena since the introduction of a unified currency -- the euro.
The development also showed how far Frankfurt has progressed in its challenge to London as Europe's prime financial center. Page C1.
Just six weeks after the exchanges in Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels announced a rival European combination called Euronext, the London Stock Exchange and the Deutsche Borse, which operates the Frankfurt exchange, said their merged company -- called the iX, for International Exchanges -- would have its administrative headquarters in London and would carve the European market into two parts. Blue-chip stocks would be listed in London, while a market in high-growth technology stocks linked to the Nasdaq would be run from Frankfurt.
And Eurex, the Deutsche Borse's market for derivatives -- complex financial contracts whose values are derived from underlying assets like stocks, bonds, commodities and currencies -- would continue to be run from Germany as part of the combined exchange. The role of Eurex, the world's biggest derivatives market, in the pan-European exchange could effectively isolate the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange, a chief rival.
Participants said the Frankfurt-London merger would be completed by the fall, but the replacement of London's trading system with Germany's advanced technology is not expected until at least some time in the first half of 2001.
Frank Zarb, the chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the Nasdaq market, told a news conference today that the opening of a Nasdaq subsidiary in Tokyo next month would enable investors to connect with both European and American markets, offering "a 24-hour clock for the high-growth companies."
"The markets," he said, "will follow the sun for the biggest companies."
The alliance with the Nasdaq will bring together London's techMARK and Germany's Neuer Markt, technology-heavy exchanges that list newer stocks, as the core of a new high-technology exchange. Nasdaq and iX are to be equal shareholders in that venture, which will be incorporated in London and operated from Frankfurt. Mr. Zarb indicated that the deal had pre-empted the Nasdaq's plans to set up a separate European trading system.
The negotiations on the Frankfurt-London tie-up had been going on almost two years.
While the rival Paris-dominated Euronext market will trade stocks valued at some $2.2 trillion, the iX will group equities with a combined value of $4.29 trillion. By way of contrast, the New York Stock Exchange trades shares valued at $11.24 trillion, while the Nasdaq's equities are valued at $6.23 trillion, and Tokyo's are about $4.46 trillion, according to the International Federation of Stock Exchanges.
In Europe, the iX would clearly dominate, the partners said today, particularly because smaller markets in Milan and Madrid also want to join it.
Without Milan and Madrid, the iX said it would still control 53 percent of European equity trading, 81 percent of the market in high-growth stocks and 56 percent of the European derivatives market.
"This is the first step to an integrated pan-European market," said Don Cruickshank, the newly appointed chairman of the London Stock Exchange, who will be chairman of the iX. He is expected to hold talks with both the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange and Euronext on expanding the Frankfurt-London combination.
Caroline Denton, a spokeswoman for London International Financial, said the exchange would not reject an approach from the iX out of hand but also felt it could survive on its own.
And Euronext shrugged off the new combination, saying it proved "we took the right decision," according to Olivier Lefebvre, president of Brussels exchange.
The new company will be owned 50-50 by the London and Frankfurt exchanges and will eventually use Xetra, Germany's advanced technology for carrying out transactions.
Werner Seifert, the chief executive of Deutsche Borse, will be chief executive of the iX.
"What belongs together finally comes together," he said. "London is the largest cash market in Europe, and we bring in the largest derivatives market worldwide."
The management lineup reflects both the national sensitivities underlying the merger and the increasing weight of Frankfurt at the heart of the 11-nation euro-zone; Britain is not one of the 11.
With the biggest of Europe's stock markets and a reputation as Europe's financial capital, London would once have automatically regarded itself as the senior partner in any European business combination. But Frankfurt's fast-growing and technologically advanced exchange earns more as a business than does the London Stock Exchange, bolstering its ambitions to displace London as Europe's financial hub.
"Is this transaction a blow to the ambitions of finance center Germany? The answer is no," said Rolf Breuer, the chairman of the Deutsche Borse, who is also chief executive of Deutsche Bank. Indeed, some British bankers said the merger represented a German takeover because of the use of German technology and the appointment of Mr. Seifert as chief executive.
One investment banker said it was noteworthy that high-growth and new companies would be listed in Frankfurt, in effect making it the new-economy center of Europe.
The banker, who insisted on anonymity, added that the differing ownership structures of the London and Frankfurt exchanges meant that shareholdings in the merged company would be heavily weighted toward the big German banks that dominate the Deutsche Borse. Ownership of the London Stock Exchange is shared by over 290 members who voted earlier this year to make the exchange a publicly owned company, while ownership of the Deutsche Borse is much more restricted.
Mr Seifert said the iX's long-term goal was to go public with an initial public offering.
Others said the move was inevitable considering the changing profile of the marketplace.
Michael Marks, executive chairman of Merrill Lynch Europe, Middle East and Africa, called the merger and tie-in with the Nasdaq exchange "a significant step forward in the creation of a broader, deeper, more liquid marketplace."
"The investors have moved on, and they want one stock market to reflect that," he said.
Both the German and British governments welcomed the deal, and the European Union said the merger was unlikely to encounter regulatory hurdles.
The participants made their announcement today with more emphasis on grand visions than on detail. It remains unclear, for instance, precisely when and at what cost Germany's Xetra technology will be rolled out for British investors, or what savings may benefit investors.
Mr. Seifert said conversion to Xetra should be possible some time in the first six months of 2001. London traders work on the SETS system and "people are going to face conversion costs that have not been spelled out," one trader said.
Similarly, the number of possible layoffs is unclear.
Britain's position outside the euro-zone also means that London-listed blue chips, including giants like BP Amoco, will be quoted in both euros and pounds. Some bankers expressed concerns about the costs of clearing and settlement in the merged market.
The Deutsche Borse owns 50 percent of the Luxembourg-based Clearstream settlement system, which is not included in the merger. Clearstream said today that it was in talks with CrestCo Ltd. of Britain. Both companies will provide settlement services to the merged exchange, but a Clearstream spokesman said a merger between them was "quite a long way down the line."
Much of the impetus for the deal came from the rapid pace of events beyond the control of traditional exchanges, notably the proliferation of smaller and more nimble electronic trading systems like Tradepoint in Britain, which allow investors to bypass traditional brokers. Tradepoint, which is supported by big American and European banks, plans to start a pan-European trading system in July and says it will offer investors lower costs.
The challenge presented by such organizations emerged anew today when Mr. Breuer, the Deutsche Bank chief executive, was asked whether his organization would withdraw from Tradepoint in favor of the iX. His answer was less than a ringing endorsement for the merged exchanges. "Both systems have still to show whether they'll perform," he said. "So let's wait and see."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
The King Of the Mile

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: RABAT, Morocco

 BODY:
The photograph is wedged into a corner above the fireplace. It is unlike the other framed items in Hicham el-Guerrouj's room, the autographs of 16 other men who have held the world record in the mile, the magazine cover proclaiming him the mile's new king, the fist-pumping joy at winning his second world championship in the metric mile. These are all tokens of victory. What el-Guerrouj keeps on equally prominent display is a reminder of forlorn defeat.
Entering the final lap of the 1,500-meter race at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, he collided with the eventual winner and fell to the track. He got to his feet and continued to run, but he finished 12th, dead last in a race that he believed he would have won. He began to cry and a photographer caught his agony, producing the picture that el-Guerrouj keeps in his room at the Moroccan track and field institute: his left hand to his face, eyes closed, lower lip drooped in a disconsolate sob. 
 "I thought it was the end of my career," said el-Guerrouj, who was 21 at the time. "This photo gives me the power to work very hard, to break the world record, to win the gold medal."
Ten minutes after the race, King Hassan II of Morocco reached him by cellular phone at the Olympic Stadium. "You are the best," said the king, who died in 1999. "For us, you are the winner."
The Moroccan news media treated el-Guerrouj's fall in the same understanding manner, and Nike, his sponsor, even paid the $50,000 bonus it had promised for a gold medal, he said.
"The king is responsible for all Moroccans, and for him to say that I was still the best gave me a lot of confidence," he said. At that moment of the phone call, he said, "it was as if another el-Guerrouj was born."
A month later, el-Guerrouj defeated the Olympic champion, Noureddine Morceli of Algeria, and in the following years he took Morceli's world records, running the 1,500 in 3 minutes 26 seconds and the slightly longer mile in 3:43.13. He has lost only one race since Atlanta, and he will be a clear favorite to win the metric mile at the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia. He will turn 26 on Sept. 14, a day before the Olympics begin. He looks younger, with his boyish haircut and long thin face. God willing, he said, kissing his hands and putting them to his face, a gold medal would be a remarkable birthday present.
El-Guerrouj is the most accomplished athlete in this north African constitutional monarchy, which has long challenged Kenya and Ethiopia for distance-running supremacy on the continent. He is also a symbol of possibility for the young in a nation where 70 percent of the 30 million residents are under 30, where half the population lives on less than $50 a month and the illiteracy rate is 50 percent. He is considered the most visible ambassador of Morocco, which is using sport -- including a revived national tennis program -- in hopes of increasing its international prominence and is seeking to be host to the 2006 World Cup of soccer as a means of reviving its sluggish economy.
For decades, Morocco has had trouble with its international profile in sports. When Nawal el-Moutawakel became the first Arab woman to win a gold medal by taking the 400-meter hurdles at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, and the great Said Aouita followed with a victory at 5,000 meters, many people confused Morocco with Monaco, said Aziz Daouda, the technical director for the Moroccan track and field federation and the business manager for its top runners. With the accomplishments of el-Guerrouj, he added, one kingdom is no longer mistaken for the other.
"We are a country of Lilliputians," said Brahim Boulami, who finished seventh in the 3,000-meter steeplechase at the Atlanta Olympics. "We are not big and famous. Hicham for us is like NASA and Boeing are for the United States. It is good to be first in the world at something."
 
The Stringent Life Of a Runner
 Rabat was unseasonably hot in mid-March, the temperature reaching 97 degrees, so el-Guerrouj decided to spend a few more days training in the mountain resort of Ifrane, above the heat and humidity and pollution of the oceanside capital. This was el-Guerrouj's 40th consecutive day in Ifrane, living with other runners in a converted hotel, training on a local track and in the cedar forests outside of town.
In a year, he will spend four months at altitude, for the quiet and the increased benefits in oxygen-carrying capacity. The rest of his training is done at sea level in Rabat. He is one of 92 athletes, men and women, in Morocco's elite training program, which provides for the athletes with 17 coaches, 3 doctors and 5 physical therapists. Nutritionists take care of the meals, the federation serves as his business manager and the training centers in Rabat and Ifrane both contain small mosques where el-Guerrouj, a devout Muslim, prays five times a day.
"He's one of the few people in the world blessed with unbelievable talent, he works incredibly hard, he's got a good support system and excellent coaching," said Steve Holman, America's top miler. "They take care of everything. He doesn't have to worry about anything but training as hard as possible, and clearly he does."
If it is an athletically pampered life, it is also one of austere isolation. El-Guerrouj dates a university student. They plan to marry after the Sydney Games, but they see each other only once every month or two, according to his coach. He owns a villa and a spacious apartment in Rabat, but he prefers to live in one well-appointed room at the national track and field center, a curtain separating the bedroom from the living room. He makes $2 million a year, according to Moroccan officials, but prefers to drive a tiny Honda sports utility vehicle, rather than the Mercedes that some of the other top athletes drive.
Mostly he lives the stringent life of a runner, training twice a day and sleeping and watching tapes of his races on television. He takes only three weeks off from training a year, although he took more time before this season after undergoing surgery for hemorrhoids that bothered him last summer.
"In my mind, if I don't do the same things as before, if I don't stay in my environment, I won't be as good," el-Guerrouj said. "I want to be close to the people, to live a simple life. In my country, there are many poor people. You can't be bigger than the others."
He trains with a small group that includes his coach, Abdelkader Kada; his brother Fethi, who is 20; Mohammed Amyn, one of the world's top 1,500-meter runners; and Hocine Benzriguinat, Morocco's military cross-country champion. The others are there to challenge el-Guerrouj with their legs but not with their egos. El-Guerrouj is the undisputed leader and it is their job to pull him along, to make sure that his needs are met.
He and his entourage are inseparable. The others train with him, cheer him at the track, eat their meals with him, go to the movies with him, travel around Rabat with him, bring him coffee and tea, help him with his tie, answer his phone. Kada, too, serves as a buffer between el-Guerrouj and the stream of Moroccans who approach him daily for a handshake, an autograph, a plea for financial aid. Privately, his coach and training partners say, el-Guerrouj is generous with them, giving them money or assisting with a new car.
"He is Mr. Peace, always so easy," Benzriguinat said.
Morocco has been winning Olympic medals in distance running for 40 years, ever since Rhadi Ben Abdesselem finished second to Abebe Bikila of Ethiopia in the marathon at the 1960 Rome Olympics. After el-Moutawakel and Aouita earned gold in Los Angeles in 1984, Moulay Brahim Boutaib won the 10,000 meters at the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea. Khalid Skah followed with a victory at 10,000 meters at the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain.
"With his records and great performances, Aouita made us dream for decades," said el-Moutawakel, who is now a member of the International Olympic Committee. "He was like Muhammad Ali. He would say something and do it the next day. El-Guerrouj makes us dream, too. On every corner of the street, they know his records, his split times. He is breaking barriers, making our dreams come true, making us so happy that you lose your mind."
This day in Ifrane would be el-Guerrouj's last before he returned to Rabat for several weeks. After a morning jog, his evening workout began near dusk, under a gunmetal sky and a fingernail moon in the cedar forests. At this mile-high altitude, he would run 20 times 350 meters in 53 or 54 seconds, up a grade of 12 to 15 degrees to build strength and endurance. Amyn paced him through the first 300 meters, then stopped as el-Guerrouj kept running up the hill, carried by the elegant explosiveness in his legs, which begin with narrow ankles and build to a grapefruit bulge in his calves and a long wedge of muscle in his thighs.
Kada, his coach, did not bother counting each of the runs up the trail. He knew that el-Guerrouj would do what he had been instructed to do. "He needs a coach to tell him he is doing too much, not too little," Kada said.
After 15 repeats, the sky was dark and the lights of el-Guerrouj's Honda were turned on so the top of the trail would be visible. They kept running, invisible at the start now, their presence announced by the scuff of shoes on dirt and the exertion of their breathing. Finally, they became silhouettes as they neared the lights of the Honda, then Amyn stopped at 300 meters, doubled over, gasping for air, as el-Guerrouj kept running up the trail, briefly visible in his shirt and tights as he passed through the beams of headlights.
"He is a very serious professional runner," said Salah Hissou, the 1999 world champion at 5,000 meters and an occasional training partner of el-Guerrouj's. "He doesn't want to be a normal athlete. He wants to be a great athlete. He could do 20 competitions a year, but he only does 7 to 10, so they will always be high level."
 
'In the Hearts Of All Arabic People'
Such is the pervasive suspicion about performance-enhancing drugs in track and field that any great performance brings immediate skepticism. There are rumors, never proved, that el-Guerrouj uses EPO, a drug that increases oxygen-carrying capacity. He vehemently denies this. There is no way to know the truth, because there is no approved test for EPO. The International Olympic Committee has fallen so far behind in drug research and testing that the innocent cannot prove their innocence.
"It is work, not doping," el-Guerrouj said. "People who say that are not big athletes. I don't think they are training 11 months a year, or running in the dark with the headlights on. I train very hard, until I am sick. Sometimes I train like a foolish man who has no mind."
After the night training run, el-Guerrouj returned to the athletes' hostel, where he was greeted by two men who wanted a photograph taken with him. Earlier in the day, two women had approached the hostel, wanting money to buy a sheep for an important Arab festival.
"He is in the hearts of all Arabic people, a symbol for our young," said Abdulkarim Titi, the president of a soccer club in the city of Tiflet and one of the men waiting for a photograph. "He is a simple person. He runs for his country, his people, his flag."
El-Guerrouj sent word that he would pose for a photograph in the morning. He had to attend a dinner at the nearby apartment of Abdelkader Mouaziz, the winner of the 1999 London Marathon. Mouaziz's new condominium was decorated with traditional Moroccan rugs, and Arabic music played on a stereo, but Mouaziz is a runner, after all, and a Nike swoosh had been welded into the door of his wood-burning stove in the living room.
A group of a dozen runners gathered around the dinner table, and el-Guerrouj proclaimed, "Real Moroccan food!" as Mouaziz brought in a huge salad and a platter of tagine, a dish of beef and beans whose sauce is sopped up with spongy bread.
Among the runners at the table was Patrick Ndayisenga, the national record-holder in the marathon from the central African nation of Burundi, who had come to Ifrane to train with the Moroccans. He said he had been amazed to see el-Guerrouj, a miler, training like a marathoner, running 13 to 15 miles in an hour and a half. El-Guerrouj also trains like a sprinter, running sometimes with a weighted jacket, dragging a tire, and he does bounding drills to increase the propulsion in his ankles. The mile has come to resemble the brutal pace of the 800 meters and el-Guerrouj better than anyone has perfected the grueling training for speed and endurance.
"When he presents himself at the start, the other athletes in their minds are running for second place," Ndayisenga said.
After dinner, el-Guerrouj sat with his coach, Kada, who served as translator, and he spoke of his upbringing in Berkane, a citrus-growing region in northeast Morocco, near the closed border with Algeria, where his father ran a small restaurant. He had been a soccer goalkeeper as a boy, but he came home dirty every day and, with seven children, his mother struggled to keep his clothes clean.
"She told me not to play anymore," el-Guerrouj said.
When he was 14, he entered a cross-country race and finished second. A year later, he won his age group at the national cross-country championships, left school and went to the national training center in Rabat. His mother, Fatna, disapproved. "I told her I was able to be Aouita, or better," el-Guerrouj said.
Six years later, at 21, he was preparing to take the lead in the Olympic 1,500-meter race when he fell. As he stumbled to the ground, he felt as if he were in a dream, and he could hear the crowd groaning as he hit the track. The collision with Morceli was an accident, nothing more, el-Guerrouj said. Four years later, he is prepared to run again, and this time he believes he will win.
"He needs this medal," said Daouda, the technical director of the Moroccan track federation. "He is the world record-holder. He can't miss this. If he does, it will be a big problem. Psychologically, it will be the end of his career."
Back at sea level in Rabat, el-Guerrouj ate lunch in the national training center, where there is a six-foot-high photograph of him in the lobby. There is a metal globe in the middle of the cafeteria, atop a fish pond, the globe symbolizing that the runners who eat here are the best in the world.
He told a story from his youth. When the family was out of bread, they sent him to his father's restaurant. It was a mile away, he said, and the family would tell him, "Run fast, Hicham; you have seven minutes until the bread is cold." When he returned home, he said with a laugh, his brothers and sisters would clap as if he had just crossed the finish line of a race.
 
Following His Faith By Helping the Needy
 El-Guerrouj dressed in a suit for a meeting of Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, and for three hours he sat and watched slides and listened to a discussion about the plight of Morocco's children. The infant mortality rate is way down, but children as young as 6 are in the work force, and 50 percent of the girls still do not go to school in rural areas.
El-Guerrouj is president of an association in Berkane that sends doctors into the countryside and provides scholarships for children. He recently purchased 130 wheelchairs for disabled youth and, during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, he and another man paid for his father to cook for 400 people each evening in his hometown. Helping the needy is one of the five pillars of the faith of the Koran. El-Guerrouj, along with el-Moutawakel, is one of four goodwill ambassadors to Unicef in Morocco.
"There is so much fatalism in the villages; people say, 'I'm poor, I will stay poor forever,' " said Olivier Theo Degreef, the Unicef representative in Rabat. "But he is an example of, 'If I fight, this is what I can become.' "
Sitting still had made him stiff and tired, but el-Guerrouj insisted on his evening track workout. He would run 10 times 1,000 meters, or two and a half laps, in 2:32 or 2:33, with two minutes' rest between. Benzriguinat, the military cross-country champion, would pace him through the first 600 meters, and el-Guerrouj's brother Fethi and Amyn, his other training partner, would follow at their own comfortable speeds. It was dark now, and pale illumination came from street lamps around the track. In the backstretch, el-Guerrouj was hardly visible, except for the flash of his spikes. He is taller than his listed height of 5 feet 9 1/2 inches, 6 feet at least, and there is the grace and power of incessant stalking in his long strides.
Four, five, six times, he repeated 1,000 meters, and the others could not keep up, doubled over, agony in their breathing. Another pacemaker was brought in, but none of the other runners could finish all 10 repeats. They were reduced to cheering for the world champion, yelling at him in French and Arabic, "Come on, Hicham, go, go," and he sailed through his 10th repeat in 2:29 with a satisfied sweat on his neck. Benzriguinat kissed him on the head.
"That's why he is the champion," Benzriguinat said. "You see how he has killed us in the training. Three people, we are all finished, and he is still strong."
The closer Sydney gets, the farther away Atlanta seems. But of course, he can never forget. Every time he breaks a record or wins an important race, the television shows him falling in Atlanta and the newspaper articles refer to his disappointment in 1996. "I think it is a part of me," el-Guerrouj said. But he has made a promise to himself. If he wins in Sydney, he will remove the crying picture from above his fireplace.
"I will put up a photo of Sydney," he said.
A photo of victory.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
TSAO, JOSEPHINE

 BODY:
TSAO-Josephine, C.P., age 39, died peacefully on Wednesday, April 26, 2000 at the University of Pennsylvannia Hospital in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania after a courageous battle with cancer. A native of Michigan, Josie held a B.A. in economics from the University of Michigan and a J.D. from the University of Michigan Law School. After moving to New York following law school, she became a specialist in executive compensation and employee benefits, with emphasis on compensation and benefits issues in mergers and acquisitions. She was an attorney at the law firms of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom; was Vice President, Executive/International Compensation and Benefits, at J.P. Morgan; and finally, she served since September 1996 at IBM Vice President, Compensation and Benefits, at corporate headquarters in Armonk, NY. Josie was a member of the American Bar Association, the Conference Board Council on Execuitve Compensation, and the Cato Institute Project on Social Security Privatization Business Council. Josie is survived by her husband, Michael S. Katzke of New York, NY; her parents, Chia Kuei and Ying Lan Tsao of Ann Arbor, MI; three siblings, Anna Tsao of Bowie, MD; Marilyn Tsao of Ann Arbor, MI; and John Tsao of Ann Arbor, MI; and by three nieces and three nephews. A memorial service and burial was held on Sunday, April 30 in Ann Arbor, MI. The family asks that remembrances be made in the form of donations to the Make-A-Wish Foundation of Metro New York, 85 Old Shore Road, Port Washington, NY 11050, Phone: 516-944-6212.
