HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Unemployment Rate Declines to a 30-Year Low
The Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate fell below 4 percent in April for the first time in 30 years, as employers hired tens of thousands of census takers, restaurant employees and temporary workers and the robust economy showed no signs of letting up.
There was little evidence in the numbers -- a total of 340,000 new jobs last month and a 3.9 percent unemployment rate -- that the record nine-year-old expansion might be weakening in response to the Federal Reserve's attempt to slow the economy by raising interest rates five times since last June. Page A1. 

Stock Gauges Rise in Light Trading
Stocks rose on the lowest trading volumes of the year as investors seemed to ignore the decline in the nation's unemployment rate. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 165.37 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,577.86. The Nasdaq composite index finished up 96.58 points, or 2.6 percent, to 3,816.82, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 23.06 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,432.63. C3.
 
Concerns Guilty in Price-Fixing Case
Four drug companies agreed to plead guilty and pay $33 million in fines for taking part in an international conspiracy to fix vitamin prices. The companies -- two American and two German -- are the latest to plead guilty in the Justice Department's investigation of the vitamin industry. C2.
 
BMW Raises Doubts in Rover Deal
BMW of Germany raised new doubts about the likelihood of a deal with the Phoenix Consortium of Britain, which is supported by labor unions and the British government, to rescue BMW's ailing Rover Cars operations at one of the biggest auto plants in Britain. C2.
 
Phone Companies End Merger Talks
Talks about a merger between two leading European telecommunication companies -- Royal KPN of the Netherlands and Telefonica of Spain -- broke down. The companies said that a majority of the Telefonica board backed the deal but that opposition "by an important minority group within the board" undermined KPN's confidence in the chance for success of the new company. C2.
 
Cisco In Stock Deal for ArrowPoint
Cisco Systems agreed to buy ArrowPoint Communications in a stock swap valued at $5.7 billion. The deal will give Cisco, the maker of network equipment, the technology it needs to compete in the fast-growing market for devices that can distribute Internet content intelligently. C2.
 
Oil Is Found in a Big Caspian Field
A consortium of nine foreign energy companies has found oil in a huge Caspian Sea field and has resumed drilling to determine just how much exists. It will be at least another month before the drilling establishes if Kashagan has commercial volumes of oil. C2.
 
ADC to Buy Fiber Optic Makers
ADC Telecommunications, a provider of technology that speeds the transmission of voice, data and video signals, said it would buy two European fiber optic component makers. ADC, based in Minnetonka, Minn., will pay $872 million in stock for the Swedish laser maker Altitun and will pay roughly $80 million in cash for Ibsen Micro Structures of Denmark. C3.

HEADLINE: Board Bars Member's Bid for Chancellor

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Irving S. Hamer Jr., the Manhattan member of the Board of Education, was barred yesterday by his colleagues on the board from his last-minute pursuit of the chancellorship of the New York City schools.
But in response, Dr. Hamer told associates that he would continue to withhold his support from the current front-runner, Harold O. Levy, the interim chancellor, effectively paralyzing Mr. Levy's candidacy. 
 The day of fast moving and often shifting events began as William C. Thompson Jr., the board president, told Dr. Hamer that he would not be allowed to join a list of six candidates selected by the board on Wednesday morning, because he had missed the deadline. Mr. Thompson said the board decided not to rethink its deadline because there was no consensus around Dr. Hamer's candidacy.
Mr. Thompson turned down Dr. Hamer's bid after consulting with board members and finding that they were split, 3 to 3, on whether to reopen the nominating process, short of the 4 votes needed for an affirmative decision. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's two appointees and the delegate from Staten Island favored allowing Dr. Hamer to be nominated, while Mr. Thompson and the delegates from Queens and the Bronx did not.
"It wasn't me making a decision on my own," Mr. Thompson said yesterday. "I was one of the other board members who expressed an opinion."
The chain of events put Mr. Thompson in the uncomfortable position of blocking the ambitions of a colleague he had worked harmoniously with for the last two years, while Mr. Giuliani's appointees -- who are philosophically opposed to Mr. Hamer on many issues -- were advocating his candidacy.
But in a sign that the behind-the-scenes politicking was more byzantine than it might appear, Mr. Giuliani jumped into the fray for the first time yesterday, hinting that while he had had some differences with Mr. Levy, he did not rule out supporting him as permanent chancellor.
The mayor said he had been disappointed by Mr. Levy's reluctance to push for individual merit pay for teachers, but suggested that now that the permanent job was no longer his for the asking, Mr. Levy might be more open to compromise.
"I have an open mind," Mr. Giuliani said of Mr. Levy's candidacy. "I haven't closed, closed my mind at all to Harold. And I don't know enough about Irving Hamer."
Asked if he would consider any other candidate for chancellor, Mr. Giuliani indicated that he would rather not. "I can just focus on the two of them," the mayor said. "I have an open mind with regard to the two of them."
The possibility that Mr. Levy might be open to compromise on merit pay clearly discomfited Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, who aggressively pushed his selection as interim chancellor, over the opposition of Mr. Giuliani.
"He is independent from the mayor, he's independent from us, he's a very independent man," Ms. Weingarten said. "He's not going to go and take their position."
Meanwhile, the mystery of why Dr. Hamer asked to be added to the list of candidates at the 11th hour, after headhunters had spent weeks compiling resumes, deepened yesterday. Confidants said Dr. Hamer, who had provided one of the four votes for Mr. Levy's selection as interim chancellor, was now dissatisfied with Mr. Levy's leadership, but they could not explain why. And for the second day in a row, Dr. Hamer avoided the media -- refusing to return telephone calls from reporters and turning down an invitation from the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, to appear with her at a news conference on the latest developments in the chancellor search.
Allies of Mr. Levy said he had agreed to seek the permanent chancellorship in mid-April only after four members of the board -- including Dr. Hamer -- assured him that he could count on their votes.
But at her news conference yesterday, Ms. Fields said that the board president had been warned two or three weeks ago that Dr. Hamer's support for Mr. Levy was not a sure thing. She said she had spoken to Dr. Hamer yesterday, and he was still "not prepared to vote for Harold Levy."
Asked if Dr. Hamer was maneuvering to become the next president of the board of education, Ms. Fields did not answer yes or no, saying, "You can't believe all the things that have come up in the last 48 hours."
Mr. Levy's allies at the board were dismayed at the confusion Dr. Hamer's would-be candidacy had caused. "The mayor is happy as hell," one board official said.
Indeed, Mr. Giuliani seemed both baffled and tickled by the turn of events. "I think it's good that there's a debate," Mr. Giuliani said, referring to Dr. Hamer's bid. "I don't know where I come out on it."
One possible outcome, education officials said, is that Mr. Levy could remain indefinitely as interim chancellor. Another is that Dr. Hamer will capitulate, throwing his vote behind Mr. Levy. "In the end, there's no place else for him to go," one education official said.
Meanwhile, the board released its list of six candidates for chancellor. Apart from Mr. Levy, all of them are notable mainly for their obscurity, and for the fact that they all come from outside New York City.
The others are: Jerome Clark, chief of staff and vice president for institutional advancement at Bowie State University in Bowie, Md.; James P. Gallagher, president of Philadelphia University in Philadelphia, Pa.; Joan P. Kowal, former superintendent of schools for Palm Beach County, Fla.; Richard T. LaPointe, president and publisher of Laubach Literacy and New Readers Press in Syracuse, N.Y.; and Anthony J. Trujillo, director of district and school services and head of the America's Choice Program at the National Center on Education and the Economy.

HEADLINE: THE JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 3.9%; LOWEST SINCE 1970

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate fell below 4 percent in April for the first time in 30 years, the Labor Department announced yesterday, as employers hired, among others, tens of thousands of census takers, restaurant employees and temporary workers in a boom that showed no signs of letting up.
Indeed, there was little evidence in the employment numbers -- a total of 340,000 new jobs last month and a jobless rate of 3.9 percent -- that the nine-year-old expansion, the longest period of uninterrupted growth in America's history, might be weakening in response to the Federal Reserve's attempt to slow the economy by raising interest rates. 
 "Everywhere you look, you see the supply of people available for work continuing to shrink pretty rapidly," said John Youngdahl, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. "Although there is not much pressure yet on companies to raise prices, the inflation rate has begun to creep up and the Fed must think about where we will be a year from now."
The economy may be in its best shape since the 1960's, but the Fed's great fear, often expressed by its chairman, Alan Greenspan, is that job shortages will eventually give workers enough bargaining power to push up labor costs ahead of productivity gains. While wage gains remained relatively modest and many of the latest jobs -- including those created by the Census Bureau -- are temporary, employers may still respond to the tight labor market by raising prices to cover the higher costs -- or simply because the strong economy allows them to.
Wall Street reacted as if the Fed would be successful in containing any inflationary threat, even if that meant it would have to be more aggressive in raising interest rates. Stock prices shot up, instead of plunging, as they often do in reaction to a strong employment report. The Dow Jones industrial average gained more than 165 points to close at 10,577.86, the Nasdaq rose 2.6 percent and bond yields edged up modestly. Page C3.
Just a week ago, the consensus among analysts and brokers was that the Fed's policy makers would probably raise the short-term interest rates they control by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 6.25, at their May 16 meeting. That would be the sixth such increase since last June. The new consensus apparent in polls taken after yesterday's job numbers were released is for an increase of half a percentage point in rates this month. Wall Street's exuberance seemed to reflect a view that half a percentage point in midmonth should be sufficient to make a dent in the robust economy.
"God only knows why the markets are doing what they are doing," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI. "All I can figure is that they figure the Fed is going to do a half-point, and that will be it. Get the tightening over, and they can go back to business as usual."
Still, Mr. Wyss and other economists noted that a booming stock market complicates the Fed's task by encouraging the all-out consumer spending that has kept the economy booming. "The stock market certainly did not help the Fed out," Mr. Youngdahl said.
April's employment report was striking for the evidence it offered that the pool of people still available for hire is shrinking. That pool fell by 426,000 men and women, falling below 9.9 million last month, the lowest level since the Labor Department began to track it in 1994. Mr. Greenspan pays particular attention to this statistic because with fewer people available, existing workers, in theory at least, are in a better position to demand and receive strong wage increases.
With the unemployment rate falling from 4.1 percent to 3.9 percent -- the lowest since January 1970 -- the pool now consists of 5.5 million people labeled as officially unemployed because they are actively looking for jobs, and 4.4 million others who tell Labor Department surveyors that they want to work, but are not currently looking.
"There is clearly some evidence of accelerating wages and prices," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute, noting that labor costs, by several measures, are growing at an annual rate of at least 3.6 percent, and inflation is rising at a similar pace.
But he wondered whether wages were pushing prices, or the other way around. "If you track this month to month," he said, "it looks more like tight labor markets are allowing workers to press for wage gains to keep up with prices that reflect the rising cost of oil."
Whatever the cause and effect, the average hourly wage of production workers rose 6 cents last month, to $13.64, up 3.6 percent over the last 12 months. That is roughly in line with the gains recorded month after month for more than a year. But broader measures, covering benefits as well as wages, show a recent jump in company payments for health insurance.
Reflecting the administration's concern that an overly aggressive Fed could damage the economy in an election year, Alexis M. Herman, the secretary of labor, argued that labor productivity was rising quickly enough to offset rising wages. "In the midst of this debate over interest rates," she said, "we must keep the focus on the nation's strong productivity to absorb any pressure on wages."
President Clinton, pointing to the social benefits of a strong economy, called attention to "the lowest unemployment rate for blacks and Hispanics ever recorded." For Hispanics, unemployment dropped to 5.4 percent from 6.3 percent in March, and for blacks the rate edged down to 7.2 percent from 7.3 percent.
While spread broadly across business and government, job creation was particularly strong at the Census Bureau, which added 73,000 part-time census takers last month on top of the 115,000 added in March. But that hiring should taper off quickly. To count the population, the bureau has hired 500,000 workers this year, and now is up to full strength, a spokesman for the bureau said.
Over all, the employment gains of 340,000, while strong, were down from an even stronger 458,000 advance in March. But job creation in the private sector remains robust, averaging 222,000 a month since January, up from 198,000 a month last year. Total employment rose to 131.1 million in April.
Restaurants made the biggest contribution, adding 80,000 jobs, while temporary-help agencies added 46,000 jobs. "Companies cannot find people, so they turn to the temp agencies, which are luring the elderly back into the work force, kids into part-time work and housewives into work," Mr. Wyss said.
The percentage of the population now holding jobs edged up last month to a record 64.9 percent, from 64.7 percent in March. Only one major industry lost ground: construction jobs fell by 55,000 after having risen by 90,000 the month before.
Manufacturers also increased their rolls, but by only 11,000 jobs, although the workweek in manufacturing rose by nearly half an hour, and overtime pay also increased.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
300 U.N. Peacekeepers Are Held in Sierra Leone
Rebels now hold more than 300 United Nations troops hostage, and contact has been lost with some peacekeeping units, officials said. A1
 
War and Censorship in Sri Lanka

New Effort on Ulster

Swiss Banks Holocaust Offer
Representatives of Swiss commercial banks and Holocaust survivors are expected to present final details of a $1.25 billion restitution settlement to a federal judge next week, after two of the largest banks agreed to give the survivors' lawyers access to databases containing information on 2.1 million Nazi-era accounts, the lead lawyer for the survivors said. Turkey Names President

HEADLINE: U.S. Giving a Lift to Salmon, But Future of Aid Is in Doubt

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: LOWER GRANITE DAM, Wash.

 BODY:
For roughly half of the millions of salmon born on the Snake River that set out each spring for the Pacific Ocean, the journey past four federal dams is an arduous and often lethal one. They can be whacked to death by giant blades of the dam turbines, knocked out from collisions with concrete spillways, or succumb to a fatal condition not unlike the bends.
The other half of the salmon have a much simpler trip: They get to take the boat. 
 But this annual free ride, by which the United States Army Corps of Engineers loads the young fish on barges and totes them around the dams, is coming under scrutiny like never before. And for scientists, lawmakers, farmers, fishermen, American Indians, barge shippers, environmentalists and a breathtaking array of other interested parties, the assessment is most likely the key to a momentous decision that will ultimately fall to the Congress: whether to take down the Snake River dams altogether.
The job of protecting the baby salmon, so they can mature and breed, is a remarkable feat of engineering and an expensive -- critics say outlandish -- accommodation to man's demands for electricity.
Thousands of fish a day are diverted to a channel leading to a pipe that runs into troughs downstream of this dam, the first of the four, which is near the Idaho border. Standing by the troughs, a busy assembly line of seasonal workers briefly anesthetizes the salmon and then injects a computer chip the size of a rice grain into their bellies so they can be tracked over the years. They are barged for a 36-hour, 300-mile trip, bypassing the dams on the Snake and four more on the Columbia River. More salmon are collected at two other dams on the Snake and one on the Columbia.
It is all part of the government's bid to keep both salmon and dams -- "to find a way to have our cake and eat it, too," said Jim Anderson, a fisheries professor at the University of Washington.
But with the river's coho salmon already declared extinct, and every other species of Snake River salmon and steelhead now listed under the Endangered Species Act, the once-unthinkable idea of breaching the dams has emerged in several federal studies as the action with the best chance of restoring healthy salmon runs. The Corps of Engineers is to recommend by the end of the year whether to propose such a step.
Breaching the dams is bitterly opposed by many people as an assault on the area's agricultural economy, and the proposal has already emerged as a hot-button issue in the Northwest in this year's presidential race. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas vowed in the primary campaign here never to allow the dams to be breached, while Vice President Al Gore, part of an administration that is intensely debating the issue, has taken no public position.
Breaching the dams would mean removing the earthen parts and restoring a 140-mile section of the Snake to its wild, free-flowing condition, thus making salmon barging both impossible and unnecessary. It would also mean that the 4 percent of the electricity the dams provide in the Northwest would have to be supplied by other sources.
The cost of the 20-year-old barging program for juvenile salmon, known as smolts, is just part of more than $3 billion the government has spent over that period trying to save salmon on the Snake and Columbia Rivers.
The barging program is derided by critics as a "techno-fix" that harms fish, interfering with their natural migration rhythms, causing them to die early, and perhaps interfering with their fabled and mysterious ability to find their way back home to spawn in their native river after spending years and traveling thousands of miles in the Pacific Ocean, as far north as Alaska.
Supporters of barging defend it as a kind of magic solution that could allow the salmon and the dams to coexist. And the National Marine Fisheries Service, one of several federal agencies that must weigh in on the fate of the dams, recently said that a decision on breaching could be put off for 5 to 10 years if barging was continued and other aggressive conservation measures undertaken.
So far, however, the results are hardly encouraging. While a corps brochure boasts that the barging system is "custom-made to make the trip as safe and comfortable as possible," and while 98.5 percent of smolts survive the trip, the salmon themselves remain in decline.
In most recent years, just 0.5 percent to 1 percent of all Snake River salmon have made it out to the ocean and all the way back, jumping through a ladder system that bypasses the dams, to their original spawning grounds. That is much less than the roughly 4 percent that scientists say the salmon stocks would need to recover fully.
Researchers are unsure what percentages of barged and nonbarged fish are making it back, a question that the microchips implanted in recent years are supposed to help answer. (Some fish implanted with the chips are caught years later by fishermen, and ultimately served in restaurants; corps biologist said the chips are implanted in a part of the fish that is not consumed by humans.) But for many environmentalists, the numbers suggest that the barging efforts are not enough.
"In a way, this issue about the difference in survival of transported fish versus fish that migrate through the river is a red herring," said Rob Masonis, regional director of hydropower programs for American Rivers, a conservation group. "The fundamental question is whether either of those classes of fish are making it back to the Snake River at levels that would lead to survival or recovery. And the answer is clearly no."
Still, there is no scientific consensus on how large a culprit the dams are in the salmon's decline. Other factors are cyclical ocean conditions, commercial fishing and erosion of habitat all along the rivers where the salmon spawn, which is caused by construction, run-off from farms and other factors.
At this point, the dams on the Columbia are not candidates for breaching.
And early counts indicate that the Snake River may this year see some of the highest numbers in recent years of returning adult chinook salmon, a result that would not take them off the endangered listing, but might lead supporters of barging to argue for more time to see if the program can work.
Moreover, no scientist can guarantee that taking the dams down would revive the salmon runs the explorer William Clark found in the Snake River two centuries ago, when he wrote in his diary that the river was "crouded with salmon."
At that time, biologists estimate, about two million adult salmon a year completed the epic journey back to their spawning grounds; in most recent years, that number has been measured in the thousands or only the hundreds for some types of salmon.
There is no question that, compared with those fish that have to navigate through the dams, a much higher percentage of salmon survive the barge trip, which drops them off just downstream of the Bonneville Dam on the Columbia River, the last man-made impediment before the fish can reach the Pacific.
But as the tugboat Umatilla made its way down the Snake the other day, pushing a barge loaded, by the government's count, with 254,317 smolts, corps biologists said they were still gathering data on whether barging contributed to a much higher rate of what they termed "delayed mortality" among salmon transported that way.
"With one big caveat, if I were a fish, I'd rather be here than there," said Doug Arndt, chief of the regional fish management division for the corps, standing aboard the barge and pointing to the dam on the river.
"And that caveat is disease transmission," Mr. Arndt said. "Is this program enhancing disease in these fish? We just don't know enough about it."
Jim Baker, the Northwest salmon campaign coordinator for the Sierra Club, said there were many ways in which barging could be harmful to fish, despite the fact that such high percentages survive the short trip itself.
"For one thing, these barges are running on a human schedule, rather than the fishes' schedule," Mr. Baker said. "There's a great deal of evidence that these fish are released too soon below the Bonneville Dam, so that they enter a salt water estuary too early in their development."
Professor Anderson of the University of Washington says that there is not enough research to show if barged fish die in much greater numbers than others.
"There are a lot of hypotheses and no real ways to measure the mechanisms that might be producing this extramortality," Mr. Anderson said. "So people are really making arguments on things for which we don't have enough information yet."
The fish transportation program started on an experimental basis in 1968 with trucks, and has been in full operation with barges since 1981.
While the fisheries service is expected to recommend waiting for several years before a decision is made, the federal Environmental Protection Agency told the corps recently that the four dams harmed the river's water quality, endangered the salmon and might have to be breached to comply with the federal Clean Water Act. (Under the 1972 act, the E.P.A. has the power to enforce water-quality standards.)
Opinions remain impassioned on both sides. The Columbia River Alliance, representing other commercial users of the river, said the breaching proposal was "an economic dark cloud hanging over these communities that depend on dams."
But at a hearing on dam breaching in Seattle this winter, one fisherman said he did not want delays or stop-gap measures or "Army Corps of Engineers Rube Goldberg barges." The solution, he said, was to "let the Snake River flow."

HEADLINE: Paying for a Trip, Ethically

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki got a mostly favorable ruling this week from the New York State Ethics Commission on the controversial financing of his two trips to Hungary in 1995 and 1996. The commission found no violation of the state's ethics law in allowing the Hungarian-American Chamber of Commerce, a nonprofit trade group largely financed by companies lobbying the governor's office, to pay for his trips, which were combined trade missions and family vacations. The panel said its "extensive inquiry" supported the governor's claim that neither he nor anyone else in his administration knew that the chamber was soliciting funds for the trips from companies with significant business pending in Albany. These included Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, Pepsico and two pharmaceutical giants, Pfizer and Bristol-Myers Squibb.
Still, the commission's finding does not exonerate the governor for his poor judgment in having his senior economic adviser, Charles Gargano, contact the Hungarian-American Chamber and request that it pay for the travel. The chamber had few resources of its own and thus had to go out and raise the money. 
 Even a five-member ethics panel with three gubernatorial appointees felt compelled to express "ethical concerns" about the indirect financing of the trips by four companies disqualified under state law from directly providing such benefits. Citing the potential for companies' gaining improper influence in such cases, the commission announced that in the future, state officials would be required to ask proposed sponsors if they would be soliciting money to pay for the trip, and if so, from whom.
That is progress, but it would be even better if state law simply barred officials from accepting free travel from any individual or group. Meanwhile the commission's verdict still leaves Mr. Pataki with some unfinished business. Now that he can no longer claim ignorance about the unsavory role of the lobbying companies in underwriting his Hungarian excursions, the only honorable course is to return the chamber's money. That portion allocable to state business can be paid by the government. The rest should be paid from his own pocket.

HEADLINE: The E-Mail Virus Is Telling Us Things

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A Disruptive Virus Invades Computers Around the World" (front page, May 5):
The latest virus invasion, particularly through the Microsoft Outlook program, illustrates yet another aspect of the problems of monopoly. In effect, the Windows monopoly is a computer monoculture with all the same problems of other monocultures. 
 In agriculture, one of the worries of the widespread planting of monoculture crops is higher susceptibility to insects and disease, since specialized bugs can rapidly increase their numbers. We might well want to encourage diversity in our computer software not just for economic reasons but to avoid future outbreaks of disease and bug infestation.
 
RICHARD C. LANZA
Cambridge, Mass., May 5, 2000
 
The writer is a senior scientist, nuclear engineering department, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Pataki Calls Timeout on a Catskill Casino

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration has called a timeout in the battle to build a major Indian casino in the Catskills, where the St. Regis Mohawk tribe has signed separate deals with two competing developers.
Last month the federal Interior Department approved a long-standing plan by a company, Catskill Development, to build a $500 million casino with the Mohawks at the Monticello Raceway. Supporters hope a casino will revive the depressed resort area. But since the approval was granted, the Mohawks have turned their backs on their original partners and signed a new deal with Park Place Entertainment, the largest gambling company in the world. 
 This week, the Pataki administration, whose approval is needed for any casino project, wrote to the Interior Department saying that it was "not possible to consider taking further action until this situation is clarified," given the confusion surrounding the relationships and roles of the various parties.
Gov. George E. Pataki has advocated development of Indian casinos in former resort areas like the Catskills, and he was in the midst of reviewing the raceway proposal. He was expected to give his approval to the raceway casino if the tribe settled its land claims with the state, said tribal advisers and state officials. But the emergence of a second deal with the Mohawks has muddled the situation.
"We don't think it's appropriate to move forward until we get clarification as to what's happening," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Governor Pataki. "We've got all kinds of lawsuits, all kinds of questions being raised. The feedback from Washington is that the governor's tack is the right way to go."
A spokeswoman for the Interior Department said officials there were just as confused by the casino battle. "We still haven't heard anything from the tribe," said the spokeswoman, Stephanie Hanna. "But the governor has apparently chosen to stop the clock for now."
The sudden turnabout by the Mohawks, whose reservation is 350 miles north of the Catskills on the Canadian border, has mystified the tribe's supporters in Washington, angered elected officials in the Catskills and spawned several lawsuits, including one by dissident Mohawks who charge that their chiefs were duped by Park Place. The company, they say, intends to protect its three casinos in Atlantic City rather than help the impoverished tribe.
Because the Catskills are only 90 minutes from New York City, a casino there is expected to generate more than $1 billion a year.
The Mohawk chiefs have not returned telephone calls requesting comment. The Bureau of Indian Affairs and the National Indian Gaming Commission, which oversees management contracts between casino operators and tribes, said they had not been notified that the chiefs had abandoned their original agreement with Catskill Development at the Monticello Raceway.
But Arthur M. Goldberg, chief executive of Park Place, announced plans this week to build a gambling resort at Kutsher's Country Club, which is about five miles north of the raceway. County legislators, who had been working on the raceway project for the last four years, criticized Mr. Goldberg's newly announced project, saying it would take years to win the necessary government approvals.
Robert A. Berman, a partner in Catskill Development, said that his rival, Mr. Goldberg, had achieved his true goal: delaying, perhaps forever, construction of a gambling hall in the Catskills that might compete with its own casinos in Atlantic City.
"Right now, Atlantic City is probably having a champagne toast in celebration of their robbing New York State of this important economic development," he said. "In the final analysis, we believe that Governor Pataki will not be muscled in his own state by New Jersey interests."
Catskill Development, which owns the only site that already has federal approval for an Indian casino, recently began talking to other tribes about the possibility of a casino deal.
Mr. Goldberg responded Thursday to accusations that he was trying to block a casino in the Catskills with a promise. "We'll pay the tribe $100 million cash if we don't build as soon as we get approval," he said.
He and the six St. Regis Mohawk chiefs signed a secret agreement on April 14 granting Park Place exclusive rights to build and manage Mohawk casinos in New York and renouncing the original contract at the raceway. But Mr. Goldberg said this week that neither he nor the tribe had ruled out building a "temporary casino" at the raceway while his plan went through the licensing process. That prompted some gambling analysts to suggest that Mr. Goldberg might be trying to force Catskill Development into selling the raceway for a bargain price.
Federal officials said that Mr. Goldberg would have to file a new application to build an Indian casino at Kutsher's, a process that could take two to four years.
As for Governor Pataki's decision to stop reviewing the project until the smoke clears, a spokesman for Park Place said he was unfazed.
But Park Place may find it hard to win approvals from Monticello officials who wrote a letter this week asking the state attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, to look into the deal with the Mohawks.
In a different letter to the tribe, Rusty Pomeroy, chairman of the Sullivan County Legislature, said that the Mohawks had placed the entire project in jeopardy and that they should not assume that the county would support a new application.

HEADLINE: U.N. Reports Rebels Now Hold 300 of Its Troops in Sierra Leone

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ and CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
Rebels have taken more than 300 United Nations troops hostage in Sierra Leone, United Nations and Clinton administration officials said yesterday, and some peacekeeping units have lost contact with their command posts.
The 8,300-member United Nations force, composed mainly of African and Indian troops, was rapidly losing confidence as a result of the assault, a Western diplomat reached by telephone in Freetown said. He added that after the latest captures, on Thursday, the entire mission, meant to secure the peace after eight years of civil war, was in jeopardy. 
 He described the chances of an effective continuation of the mission, one the most ambitious peacekeeping efforts by the United Nations, as only "50-50."
Talks were under way in Freetown, the capital, between several commanders of the insurgent Revolutionary United Front and Western diplomats to try to stop the fighting, the diplomat said. But it was unclear what if any progress had been made.
Among the hostages was a contingent of about 200 Zambian soldiers who were taken hostage, a United Nations spokesman said. Their weapons were taken and they were stripped of their clothes, the spokesman, Fred Eckhart, said.
About a dozen armored vehicles belonging to the Zambians were also confiscated and were being driven by the rebels, according to reports from the field. Another contingent of more than 100 Nigerian peacekeepers was stripped of weapons and then released, Mr. Eckhart said.
Further undermining the morale of the United Nations effort, parliamentarians in Kenya yesterday called for the withdrawal of the Kenyan contingent of the peace force after reports that four of their soldiers were missing and presumed dead.
Under a peace accord signed last July, the rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, whose forces have terrorized the country with a campaign of chopping off hands, feet and arms, was brought into a new national government.
At the time, some American officials questioned the wisdom of bringing under the government umbrella such a violent leader, who has become rich from plundering Sierra Leone's diamond mines. It was becoming obvious, some officials said, that Mr. Sankoh was using his new government position as a temporary breather before making more war.
The timing of the assault by the rebels, who began their operation on Tuesday, seemed very precise, several Clinton administration officials said.
Mr. Sankoh's troops -- assumed by the administration to number about 6,000, many of them unemployed teenagers -- chose a window of opportunity just after many Nigerian troops had withdrawn from Sierra Leone and before the United Nations force was up to full strength.
The rebels also took advantage of a United Nations force that appeared to be ill-trained, easily intimidated and equipped with only light infantry armor, administration officials said. Some troops were not following elementary military rules such as securing the perimeters of their bases, barracks and offices, one official said yesterday.
Reports from the field in the last few days showed that some United Nations troops were so frightened by the reputation of the rebels that they abandoned their vehicles as soon as they were stopped at a roadblock by the rebels.
As the situation in Sierra Leone continued to deteriorate, senior Clinton administration officials met at the White House to assess options.
Afterward, a senior State Department official said a team of British military experts would arrive in Sierra Leone today to review the United Nations operation from "top to bottom."
"What we are continuing to do is look very carefully at whether the forces there and the reinforcements that can be brought in can have a useful effect," the official said.
The administration has said it is considering a request from the United Nations to provide transport planes to ferry some of the 3,000 Jordanian, Bangladeshi and Indian troops still scheduled to go to Sierra Leone.
There was absolutely no consideration of sending American soldiers, officials said. In similar situations in the past, though, the use of American transport planes has required United States troops to help secure the airport to insure that the aircraft and military personnel involved do not come under attack.
On the diplomatic front, Washington was asking regional leaders, including the president of Nigeria, Olusegun Obasanjo, to put pressure on Mr. Sankoh to stand by the peace agreement of last July, officials said. The State Department also asked the Rev. Jesse Jackson to ask President Charles Taylor of Liberia to call for cooperation from the rebel leader, who is a colleague.
United Nations peacekeepers were also taken hostage by the hundreds during the Bosnian war. In May 1995, Bosnian Serbs held more than 350 peacekeepers, some for several weeks, as insurance against air strikes by NATO.
At the United Nations, diplomats described how the Zambian convoy of 208 soldiers, who had arrived in Sierra Leone only two days earlier, was overwhelmed, and lost its 13 armored vehicles.
The troops were dispatched Thursday from Lungi, a port north of Freetown, to reinforce beleaguered peacekeeping troops at Makeni in the northern hinterland. But they lost radio contact with the United Nations headquarters in the capital. The Zambians passed through two rebel checkpoints and then at a third found themselves boxed in by a force of heavily armed guerrillas. The convoy's commander, faced with a battle that he felt he was sure to lose, negotiated a surrender.
In addition to the 208 Zambian soldiers, an estimated 110 other United Nations peacekeepers, military observers and civilian workers are being held by the rebels.
Under the mandate authorized by the Security Council for Sierra Leone, the peacekeepers may defend themselves but are not equipped for conventional combat.
A former United States Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, Henry J. Cohen, said yesterday that the peacekeepers should have been more robustly equipped, including with artillery, to be able to give a "show of strength." Mr. Cohen said the peacekeeping force now faced two options: "appease and lose face" or use strong force against the rebels, including helicopter gunships.
Mr. Cohen added that if the United Nations force pulled out as it had in Somalia in 1993 and several years later in Rwanda, then Mr. Sankoh's forces would "sweep into power."
In the coming days, the immediate task, according to the Western diplomat in Freetown, was to see what "you can do for the battalions that are not affected."
"The key," he said, "is to get the rebels to turn it off and to resolve some of the United Nations problems of organization and communication."
The Kenyans, who were the first target of the rebels, appeared to have encountered rebels who were "more numerous, more committed," the diplomat said. But why the Kenyan unit unraveled so quickly was not clear, he added.
Four United Nations helicopter gunships were supposed to have arrived last month, the diplomat said, but as of several days ago had still not shown up. Whether the gunships would have been useful in the clash between the Kenyans and the rebels or the Zambians and the rebels was an open question, the diplomat said.
"They are rather indiscriminate," the diplomat said of the helicopters. "As long as U.N. troops are with rebels I'd be more cautious than sending up gunships to do their thing."
One of the options being discussed at the State Department in the last several days has been charging Mr. Sankoh with war crimes and trying to remove him from the scene, several officials said. But that seemed an unlikely outcome, especially while Mr. Sankoh's forces controlled United Nations troops.
Other officials said they were concerned that if Mr. Sankoh was removed, the rebel group would become even less manageable because it would fall into the hands of a number of disparate commanders.
As part of the peace accords of last summer, Mr. Sankoh was given a position as head of a commission intended to control the flow of illegal diamond exports from Sierra Leone. The United States contributed $1 million to setting up the commission, an Administration official said.
A Western diplomat said the peacekeepers were surrounded in unfamiliar terrain by armed adversaries. "They're authorized to defend themselves but they're not required to fight to the last man," he said.
Some embassies in Freetown began evacuating dependents and nonessential people. More than 100 workers for nongovernment relief organizations were also reportedly been evacuated by United Nations helicopters.
Mr. Annan expressed concern in Paris on Thursday that the deteriorating situation in Sierra Leone might have a ripple effect in making member countries hesitate to contribute troops to a more complex peacekeeping operation being assembled for Congo.
"The efforts right now are political in nature: to get anybody who has influence on Foday Sankoh to convince him to come back into compliance with the peace agreement," Mr. Eckhard said yesterday. "If that fails, I don't want to speculate what could happen next."
The rebel leader, who remains at his residence in Freetown, continued to deny yesterday that his fighters have taken any peacekeepers hostage, asserting that they must have gotten lost.
"What happened here was that there are people missing in the area because they are not familiar with the terrain, so I ordered my commanders to try to search for them," Mr. Sankoh said, according to Reuters.

HEADLINE: New Life for Old Railroads;
What Better Place to Lay Miles of Fiber Optic Cable

BYLINE: By JANE TANNER 

DATELINE: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla.

 BODY:
Henry Flagler came to Florida in 1883 to build grand hotels in what was sparsely populated coastal scrub. Using wealth amassed as one of the Standard Oil Company's founders, he began cobbling together a railroad down the length of the state. He opened up Florida as he went, erecting posh resorts like the Palm Beach Inn, later called the Breakers, that would serve as starting points for future cities. By 1896, he had built 350 miles of track from Jacksonville to Miami.
Now Florida East Coast Industries, the holding company controlling the Flagler railroad, is using the right of way to establish itself in the new economy. Since last May, the company's subsidiary, Epik Communications, has been selling capacity to move digital information through fiber optic cables that run alongside chugging train cars piled high with crushed stone, building materials and vehicles. 
 Like most railroads, Florida East Coast Railroad had been collecting rent from giant telecommunications companies that had buried cable beside its tracks. But two years ago the company decided to jump directly into the market for bandwidth capacity. Just shy of one year into its venture selling transmission capacity to telephone companies, wireless services and Internet service providers, Epik's network covers 80 percent of Florida's population and extends west to Texas and north to Atlanta. The revenue backlog is $60 million.
"What makes it a great railroad franchise is what makes it a terrific telecom franchise," says Robert Anestis, the chairman, president and chief operating officer of Florida East Coast Industries, who came on board in January 1999 to exploit the telecommunications potential. "We're in the center of growth."
The story of how the little railroad leveraged the dirt along its tracks to leap into fiber optic communications provides a glimpse into some of the swaps and barters used to create a glass network for the streams of digital bits and bytes cycling around the globe. It also suggests how some old-economy transportation and power companies may find prosperity in a cyberage.
Railroad tracks make good paths for telecommunications cable because they offer cleared, linear routes. In fact, special railroad cars run along tracks plowing cable underground as they move. The cost of assembling such paths for conduits from scratch would be astronomical.
In the same way, energy and utility rights of way are used for fiber optics. For instance, the Williams Companies created a whole new venture by putting cables along its natural gas pipelines. Consolidated Edison's infrastructure is being used for fiber optic lines into 2,000 buildings in New York.
Southern Pacific Railroad is the textbook example of a railroad creating telecommunications companies, having spawned both Sprint and Qwest Communications International.
In this latest sweep of new entries along with FLorida East Coast are the Norfolk Southern Corporation and the CSX Corporation. "The pickings have been so good, a lot of people have been getting into this industry," says Tim Caffrey, who follows telecommunications for Standard & Poor's.
While Florida East Coast is small, it is beginning to attract attention. Since January 1999, its stock has gone from $27 a share to over $46; its market capitalization has risen from $800 million to just under $1.8 billion. In mid-April an investment group including the Texas billionaire Robert Bass acquired a 5 percent stake in the holding company, based in St. Augustine, Fla., with its railroad, trucking, real estate and now telecommunications businesses.
"It's in the nascent stages, but the company is beginning to make a major play in the telecom industry," says Andrew Hamerling, an analyst at BancAmerica Securities.
Florida East Coast was a fairly inert company until Mr. Anestis began to kick-start the assets that Mr. Flagler had put into place 100 years earlier. The company and the St. Joe Company, which held a 54 percent stake in Florida East Coast until recently, had lagged under the control of the conservative Alfred I. duPont Testamentary Trust.
But in the early 1990's, investors pressed St. Joe to start exploiting its assets for better shareholder returns. It shed operations like a paper mill, telephone company and bank to focus on its one million acres of real estate in the Florida Panhandle for resort development.
When St. Joe took a look at its 53.8 percent stake, it decided that it should put the company up for sale. But Mr. Anestis, then a consultant to Peter S. Rummel, St. Joe's chairman, convinced him that there was better way to capture the value of the telecommunications potential.
"I told him it's much better to jump into this thing proactively," Mr. Anestis recalls.
Mr. Anestis had had an eye on the company's telecommunications rights of way for some time. In the early 1980's AT&T, MCI, WorldCom and other big players installed fiber optic cables along Florida East Coast Railroad lines to reach the state's growing cities. These leases were a no-cost stream of passive revenue. The next big cable construction wave followed the 1996 telecommunications act. During this second buildup, Florida East Coast decided to get a piece of the digital action.
Mr. Anestis started as a mergers and acquisitions lawyer in Pittsburgh, then headed a railroad holding company, Guilford Transportation Industries, that a client had created. In 1984, AT&T leased right of way from Guilford on an unused line in the White Mountains to add capacity to its Boston-to-Montreal fiber link. The old line, with small trees growing in the tracks, showed Mr. Anestis how valuable such linear paths could be. Mr. Anestis left Guilford and started an investment advisory firm, still consulting with railroads and negotiating right of way leases with telecommunications companies.
In 1997, when Qwest wanted to bury cable on Florida East Coast Railroad routes, Mr. Anestis negotiated on behalf of the railroad and got Qwest to build three conduits for Florida East Coast as part of the bargain.
The next year when Williams was anxious to add Florida capacity along the railroad's right of way, Mr. Anestis brokered a deal for 36 strands of dark fiber from Williams. Dark fiber is unactivated cable.
Instead of being just a passive landlord, Florida East Coast now had telecommunication assets, but it did not know how to deploy them. "We were pretty good horse traders, but we really didn't know what to do with this," Mr. Anestis said. Soon after these deals, he was made head of Florida East Coast Industries.
Mr. Anestis hired strategic consultants at the Cambridge-based Monitor Company to determine whether 3 empty conduits and 36 strands were enough to jump-start a new telecommunications company. Each 1.25-inch conduit can hold 216 fiber optic strands. Two strands of activated cable can transmit 129,000 simultaneous telephone calls. New technology is expected to increase that number a hundredfold.
John McClellan, Monitor's head of telecommunications, concluded that the venture could work. Florida's economy was expected to grow 37 percent faster than the rest of the country over the next 10 years. The company's rights of way, conduits and fiber amounted to a base to reach the majority of the state's population.
Florida East Coast also had enough capital to invest nearly $100 million in cash to get the initial parts of the business up and running.
At the end of the consultation, Mr. McClellan decided to leave his 16-year career at Monitor to head the new Florida East Coast venture.
Now, Mr. McClellan splits his time between his home in Groton, Mass., and Epik's headquarters in Orlando. He took a two-thirds pay cut, spurred by the prospect of stock options. Mr. Anestis said Epik could go public in as few as six months, but acknowledged that market volatility could extend that timetable.
"I entered into this knowing we're in this a while trying to build a business," Mr. McClellan said.
Under Mr. McClellan, Epik has extended its reach beyond Florida in fiber and conduit swaps with Enron Broadband Services and Broadwing Communications.
"We're becoming experts in swaps and barter," Mr. Anestis said. Trade-outs allow quick geographic links without time-consuming installation. Fiber optic companies build excess capacity so they can use it as capital in future trades.
Florida East Coast and Epik officials, meanwhile, are huddling over aerial photos of the 18,000 Florida acres that Mr. Flagler accumulated and that remain under company control.
Gran Central, a real estate subsidiary, has built a portfolio of high-end office complexes and industrial buildings. Now, the company is considering the land for Telecom Hotels, high-rises intended to house equipment needed to keep data flowing smoothly. The company is also considering constructing office buildings prewired for the latest technology.
Many railroad industry executives are looking for new opportunities. Last year, Norfolk Southern created a subsidiary, Thoroughbred Technology and Telecommunications, or T-Cubed. The railroad plans to lay conduit and use its microwave towers to sell bandwidth capacity to carriers.
In March, CSX signed an agreement with Pathnet Inc., a wholesaler of bandwidth based in Reston, Va., to provide railroad right of way in exchange for equity in Pathnet. Burlington Northern Santa Fe and Colonial Pipeline also signed "right of way for equity" deals with Pathnet.
With all these new players, Mr. Caffrey at Standard & Poor's and other industry watchers say a glut of fiber capacity may be on the horizon. Mr. Anestis is not flustered by the prospect. "We assumed that this supply would cause prices to fall," he said. "Even so, with the slope of growth there's a great business here."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE: By JANET PIORKO 

 BODY:

B & B THE FRENCH WAY -- A six-night package in France offered by Country Cottages of Boca Raton, Fla., starts at $1,098 a person, double occupancy, through June 15, including bed-and-breakfast lodgings, round-trip trans-Atlantic air fare and a rental car. The package, called "Go As You Please -- Decouvrir la France," offers a choice of 500 places to stay throughout the country; all have rooms with private bath. Travelers receive vouchers for their rooms and can reserve their first night before departure; the rest are booked as they go, with a free phone call from each night's lodging. (Alternatively, Country Cottages will make the reservations for $12 per location.) The price of $1,098 is also good from Sept. 16 through Oct. 31. From June 16 to Sept. 15 and Dec. 16 to 24, it is $1,296, dropping to $899 from November to mid-December and January through March. Flights are on British Airways via London. The car is a stick-shift economy model with unlimited mileage. Reservations: (800) 674-8883. 

SAILING THE MEDITERRANEAN -- First European Cruises is offering savings averaging $1,000 a person on September and October voyages of the 1,200-passenger Mistral in the eastern Mediterranean. The ship, which entered service in July, sails round trip from Venice on Saturdays from June through October on seven-day cruises to Dubrovnik, Katakolon (for Olympia), Santorini, Mykonos, Rhodes and Piraeus (for Athens). The special rates start at $949 a person, for double occupancy in an inside cabin; from $1,110 for an outside cabin; the rate is $1,800 a person for a mini-suite with balcony. Round-trip flights to and from Venice are priced at $950 from the East Coast. The ship's management aims to carry a mix of Europeans and about 15 percent North Americans; the international dining-room staff and stewards are English speaking. There are two outdoor pools, a spa and thalassotherapy center. Information: (888) 983-8767 or www.first-european.com.
 
EL AL COMPANION FARES -- Through Dec. 31, passengers in first and business class flying round trip between the United States and Israel on El Al can buy a companion ticket in the same class for $250. From New York to Tel Aviv, the summer first-class fare is $7,754, business class $5,258. The companion tickets must be purchased directly from El Al. For more information: (212) 768-9200.
 
TOUR OF THAILAND -- Grand Circle Travel, geared to those 50 and over, has a Jewels of Thailand itinerary from October through early May 2001 that starts at $1,195 a person, double occupancy, including air fare from New York and 16 other cities, six nights' lodging in Bangkok and seven in Chiang Mai, and many meals. (The lowest price is for late April and early May, going up to $1,445 in October.) For more information: (800) 248-3737. JANET PIORKO

SECTION: Section 6; Page 58; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1180 words

HEADLINE: Morality;
The Good Lie

BYLINE: By Jane Smiley; Jane Smiley is the author, most recently, of "Horse Heaven," a novel.

 BODY:
After reading the results of this poll, you'd have to say that lying to protect someone's feelings is as American as enriching your life by having children, almost as American as not ever having done yoga, and more American than thinking you are too fat or feeling guilty about a thing or two you did when you were younger. On the other hand, lying to protect someone's feelings is not nearly as American as thinking that being American is a big part of who you are.
Myself, I would have to say that lying is not nearly as big a part of who I am as writing fiction, and in fact, I almost never lie, even to avoid hurting someone's feelings. What I do to avoid hurting someone's feelings is just keep my opinion to myself. Even so, my occasional forays into lying have made me something of a theorist of lying. (Here are the lies I told: 1. I sold a car knowing it needed new valve rings, but I really did not know that it needed a new transmission until the buyer told me about it five days after the sale. 2. I told one of my husbands that I still loved him even though I didn't know whether I did or not.) 
 There are several forms of what you might call lying. One is misrepresenting the truth. Another is keeping a secret. A third is presenting as true what you wish were true, or perhaps hope is true, but don't know for sure is true. A fourth form of lying is shorthand -- the truth is changing so quickly that to detail every shift would in fact present something as true that could very quickly become false. A fifth is being mistaken, which sometimes looks like a lie.
Let's begin with being mistaken. Everyone is mistaken almost all the time, and so almost everything that everyone says will eventually be proved wrong, and so almost everything that everyone says is untrue. The best answer to any question is, "I don't know," even to so simple a question as "How do you like these shoes I bought?" "I don't know" is a real commitment to the larger truth, because it recognizes that the passage of time makes every judgment provisional. However, people who always say "I don't know" find themselves in a double bind -- either they are considered too bland to have opinions or, if they explain why they don't know, they are told that they think too much, and thinking too much is not very American at all. So, logically, there is no truth telling, but people persuade themselves that they more or less tell the truth anyway.
A recognition of complexity makes truth telling that much more difficult. Government officials or unfaithful spouses involved in some quickly developing crisis, for example, are often subsequently accused of either withholding information or misrepresenting the partial information already available. But the supposition that the truth is known almost always leads to action, and most actions, of course, turn out to be unreasoned, wrongheaded ones. Best to put off action as long as possible, and lying to achieve this goal is a perfectly wise decision.
If the truth is almost always misrepresented, then the real moral distinctions with regard to lying have to do with motive. Most of those polled seem to feel that lying to save someone else pain is moral. I suspect, though, that they would have had a different response to the statement "Lying is sometimes necessary to protect oneself." Let us say that 60 percent might have disagreed with this statement, and yet we all know that lying is sometimes necessary to protect oneself, even when we choose not to, and fail to protect ourselves. In fact, one of the main tasks of raising children is to convince them that telling a lie does not protect them; that it in fact endangers them even more than the misbehavior that gave rise to the lie. Children understand that to tell the truth is sometimes counterintuitive, which is why teaching them to tell the truth depends very much on how much power they think Mom and Dad really possess. In my experience, oldest children hardly ever lie, but second children, well aware of the disparity between what parents think is going on and what is really going on, lie rather easily.
What constitutes self-protection? I wish the pollsters had asked a final question: "Although this is an anonymous questionnaire, I have misrepresented the truth, exaggerated things and held information back on one or more questions. Do you agree or disagree?" (See question No. 8, "Have you ever cheated just a little on your taxes or an office expense account, or haven't you?") Obviously, of the 84 percent who say they have never exaggerated their business mileage, never failed to report even a penny of cash income, never filled in the wrong amount on a blank taxi receipt, at least some are protecting their own opinion of themselves.
And how about if the pollsters had asked the question, "Lying is sometimes necessary for personal gain"? How American would it be to agree with that one? In what area of our booming economy do the sellers of goods advertise them truthfully? In what area do the buyers expect them to? In what political arena do the candidates come clean? In what political arena do the voters expect them to, or even want them to? I remember when President Carter's attempt to rescue the hostages in Iran failed. He spoke to the American people of his sense that the hostage taking posed something of a dilemma, not easily solved. As a result of his honesty and understanding of complexity, he was widely perceived as weak and summarily replaced in office by a simple man who seems never to have found himself in a dilemma.
Is it more American to keep a secret or to tell it? The person doing the choosing often has to consider the motives of the person seeking the information. Almost all Americans, for example, would have considered it extremely un-American for those hiding Jews during World War II to divulge their whereabouts. In fact, many Americans would consider it highly American for those living under tyrannical regimes in faraway places to keep and bear arms, even unlawful, secret arms.
My own feeling is that even in America, there are some to whom it is obligatory to lie. When you are going through a serious crisis, and a casual acquaintance or your mother asks how you are, it is a very bad idea to actually tell them. "Fine" is fine. It is also O.K. to lie to unsolicited telephone callers, guys who make passes and friends who like to retail gossip or offer unasked-for advice. In this category I would have to include the press too: there is never any moral opprobrium to be suffered by those who lie to the press. Reporters are in the business of selling secrets for money. They do not, therefore, have your best interests at heart. I have always admired the efforts of every single celebrity or politician who lied to the press. Just as the role of the press is to be a watchdog upon the government, the role of celebrities and politicians is to frustrate the all-seeing eye of the press and remind everyone that there are questions that should never be asked if a civil society is to be maintained.
