SECTION: Section 6; Page 78; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2854 words

HEADLINE: What Do We Talk About When We Are Paying Someone to Listen

BYLINE: By Ariel Kaminer; Ariel Kaminer is an editor at The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Are there facets of the inner life that emerge only within the framework of psychotherapy? How do patients' concerns reflect larger cultural dynamics? To discuss the secrets of the 50-minute world, we set up a conversation among six experts with a variety of professional perspectives. Our panel included:
Ethel Person, a professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia University who practices in New York and is the author, most recently, of "The Sexual Century." 
 Peter D. Kramer, author of "Listening to Prozac" and "Should You Leave?" who teaches psychiatry at Brown University and practices in Providence, R.I.
Martin S. Bergmann, a psychoanalyst who teaches psychiatry at New York University; he is the author of numerous works, including "The Anatomy of Loving."
Amy Bloom, author of "Love Invents Us," a novel, and the forthcoming collection "A Blind Man Can See How Much I Love You," who has a private practice in psychotherapy in Connecticut.
Jonathan Lear, who is a member of the Committee on Social Thought at the University of Chicago; his next book is "Happiness, Death and the Remainder of Life."
John A. Talbott, a professor of clinical psychiatry at the University of Maryland, Baltimore, who has written extensively on chronic mental illness and publicly financed treatment.
Question: If I can start the ball rolling, what are the issues that people today talk about only in the context of psychotherapy? Are there any privileged realms?
Ethel Person: I think there is one realm. I think that people do not discuss their fantasies in public as much as they do in therapy because those really tap a deeper part -- and a very idiosyncratic part. I mean, typical fantasies like I want to get rich or I want a new job, that kind of thing people will talk about, but some of the kinkier sexual fantasies don't get discussed in public. Or the fantasies about which one is embarrassed.
Q: Does the list of things that people are willing to talk about only in psychotherapy change over time?
Person: Yes. Therapy is still where people talk about their most painful feelings. But they talk about much more personal things in public now than they did 20 or 30 years ago.
Peter D. Kramer: I think it's a problem for therapy. I think that the power of therapy depends on novelty and surprise. And the enormous openness about sexuality, jealousy, violent thoughts and so on impoverishes therapy to some extent. I think therapy was probably easier to do when it was more surprising to speculate, as Freud did, that the patient may have sexual feelings of which he or she is unaware. That wouldn't shock anyone -- it wouldn't be transformative anymore.
Q: So as opposed to opening up other possibilities, you feel that having gotten those kind of basic surprises out of the way lessens the possibilities for what can be discussed in therapy?
Kramer: I think that one of the great jobs of psychotherapy is to create a place where very shameful aspects of the self can safely be revealed. So I think it lessens the force of revelation that so much is already revealed.
Martin S. Bergmann: Cultural changes do in some way affect what patients talk about. To give an example, I have had experience with patients who develop cancer or other disabling diseases and then look upon themselves as "damaged goods." Now, to me, "damaged goods" is a very typical American way to look at oneself, in commercial terms. For example, "My child is a high-maintenance kid." That is also along the same lines.
Kramer: I think it's obvious at this moment that therapy also needs to be a refuge from the commercial society. There's something about the ubiquity of value. The woman in her 50's who has just been divorced and has a sense of having no social worth -- that is the sort of thing that I think is very much at the core of a carriage-trade psychotherapeutic practice nowadays. It's discussed everywhere, but the level of pain associated with the depth of the hopelessness, I think, probably emerges in the psychotherapeutic space.
Q: And this is a recent development?
Kramer: I don't know, I think there's always a temptation to believe it's a recent development. But the role of the therapeutic space as a refuge from this tendency to value very exactly every person and activity in the culture seems very much in sharp focus at the moment.
Amy Bloom: But I think the stain of the commercial actually works both ways. I have walked into colleagues' offices in the last five years and found people with drug-company clipboards or newsletters. I'm sure they were in some people's offices before, but certainly nobody I wanted to go and have a cup of coffee with.
Jonathan Lear: There's a shift in popular culture in its relation to psychotherapy. Last decade, three popular shows on television were "Seinfeld," "Friends" and "Ally McBeal." They all shared this underlying assumption that human intimacy of the standard one-heterosexual-married-couple isn't possible. And that what there really is in the world is a conversation among one's friends or business partners or flatmates about why this more traditional idea of intimacy is just not going to work. And so it's a basically ironic stance. And then there's a shift, I think, last year, to "The Sopranos." You know, this guy is a gangster, and he has his women on the side and whatever, but he's trying to make his marriage work. He's trying to deal with the responsibilities of the office. And trying to come to terms with, in terms of what Ethel was saying, very primitive fantasies that are under the surface and got him where he is. There's a kind of earnestness. It seems to me like the nature of the refuge shifted, like irony as a defense against the kinds of anxieties that have been discussed is collapsing.
Bloom: Tony Soprano has a terribly earnest therapist as well. I mean, she seems utterly unable to marshal any sort of useful defenses.
Person: If I were to say that there was a shift, it's that people's sense of being not in control in their lives is much more paramount than it was previously. And I would tie it to this major dislocation in terms of the way success and money are regarded. I'm not sure that the therapist's office is always a refuge. It's often a place that people come in order to figure out how to be in control -- which too often means being in control financially.
Q: Can you tell me some of the ways that these economic displacements manifest themselves in the therapeutic context?
Bloom: Because most of the people I work with don't actually have a lot of money, it has seemed to me over the last 20 years that there was a significant number of people who, although they would go on having unresolved issues in their lives, most of their dramatic crises that led to really terrible outcomes in their lives would have been resolved if they had had $50,000. Now, that's not to say that they couldn't also have been avoided if they had been more resourceful and less conflicted about their ability to get help. But it does often seem to me that that point at which you find yourself out of your apartment and without a car and unable to move your furniture -- some of those things could probably be avoided.
Kramer: This may be half a step back, but I think some of the same issues that we've been talking about could be put in this different way, which is, I think the culture has become hard for melancholics. If you're in a culture where there's a great deal of social disruption, where people are expected to be extremely autonomous, where the divorce rate is high, where the form the families take is very diverse, it is hard to have those underlying personality traits that we talk about as melancholic -- that is, being deliberate, attaching very strongly, being loyal, being somewhat prone to depression, having low energy, even if you tend to use it well. And I do think a lot of what we see in our offices is related to a particular sort of social disruption. People might be helped by having greater resources, but they'd also be helped by having a more reliable standing and a more reliable set of connections in the culture.
John A. Talbott: I can affiliate myself with Peter's remarks because I think that the people I treat, who are cognitively impaired, are also clueless to some extent about what cultural changes are going on. I think there's a sense of wanting to be part of the mainstream, but the mainstream has shifted so much.
Bloom: Peter, you're saying that as the culture has shifted, it has become less accepting of certain kinds of personalities with certain sort of clusters of traits, even if the person functions reasonably well. I think that that is true. I mean, you get a great deal more leeway as a tearing narcissist in this culture than you do as someone who tends to be a little broody and little thin-skinned and maybe a little slow to speak and, you know, given to pondering. I don't think that gets you a lot of room culturally right now.
Bergmann: It occurs to me that the changing roles of women, the changing expectations of women as they affect the point of view of the man, have created new kinds of marital tensions. I think that is a very important part of our culture. Also the whole question of to what extent libidinal satisfactions are obtained outside of personal realms.
Lear: What do you mean by that?
Bergmann: Well, let's say a professional whose satisfaction is entirely in terms of her relationship to her clients. That is her personal value system. Whatever operates there is the equivalent to what one used to call love life. There is less separation between personal and professional, and for many people the professional has become the personal. So I see it in two ways: I see it in terms of the professional invading the personal to an enormous extent, and I see it also in terms of new problems created within the couple as a result of the changing position of the woman in the marriage and the inability of the man to live up to these expectations or to be able to do justice to it.
Person: You're not saying she's more consumed than male professionals, are you?
Bergmann: No. In the lives of many males, the professional was always really the dominant place where most of their ambitions, most of their love needs and most of their hostilities were expressed, so that by the time you came home at 7:00 to your family in Westchester, you know, you read The New York Times and you went to sleep. It is now also much more characteristic of women. I don't mean that it's getting better or worse.
Lear: There's a theme I hear emerging. I think the issues that are being raised in the social sphere, issues about ambition, striving, competition, both in the workplace and at home, have been undertheorized by therapists and analysts. Something strikes me -- you know, Aristotle says that philosophy begins in leisure. It's only when people are freed up from just struggling for survival that they can think about the meaning of life. And I think something's very similar in psychotherapy. This is a very wealthy society. And -- a similar point -- when people get freed up via drug therapy from the acute crisis of mental illness, they're freed up to worry about the meaning of their lives. I mean, to worry, "Am I capable of a deep, intimate relationship?" is to some extent a luxury. So it's possible that there's going to be a freeing up to be worried about the kinds of issues that psychotherapy addresses.
Bloom: Well, there'll be a freeing up, but I guess one of the questions that that raised here is, given the direction of the culture, will people worry about the nature of their intimate relationships? Or will they feel that that's the last thing in the world they would want to spend time on -- that though they have terrible relationships, they should go out and buy something?
Lear: I don't think that'll last. That's a defense that won't -
Bloom: No, I agree that it's a defense that leaks all over the place, which is why you see people with money in treatment.
Q: A number of you have started doing couples therapy, as opposed to classic one-on-one analysis. Is that part of a general profession-wide outreach? Or does it reflect some other trend?
Kramer: I think it's not a coincidence. I turned to couples therapy as a more important part of my practice partly because of the notion that there are some people who really do have different and more complete selves in a relationship than they have in isolation. I think the issue of the fragility of the couple has become extremely important and shows itself in all sorts of areas even when divorce is not an issue. In terms of the balance of power within marriage, in terms of aspirations of young women, it just seems to me that some constant awareness of the fragility of marriage permeates all sorts of aspects of therapy.
Bloom: Actually, two changes that I have observed are that I certainly see far more same-sex couples than I used to whose concerns are not either cultural homophobia or internalized homophobia. And those people tend to be, I have to say, highly committed. I think the other change is, people are more expressive more quickly of their loneliness within the marriage. It's not that they are more lonely, but they no longer feel that it's quite as much of an individual failure to admit that they are lonely within the marriage, now.
Bergmann: There is a much stronger agenda of each partner than I think there used to be. They are trying to negotiate it between the two, but the agendas are much more definite. And I would say to your same-gender couples -- of which I have had only two examples over the years, but they're important -- I think part of their determination to make it is also ideological: to prove that homosexuality is not a disease, that it can be linked to a permanent relationship. And that, of course, can add to the stability.
Bloom: That may be what drives the heterosexual couples as well.
Bergmann: But they don't have so much to prove it, you see.
Bloom: That's not clear to me anymore.
Q: I have a question that's far off topic: How and to what extent do religious issues or concerns arise in the therapeutic context?
Person: They come up in terms of the degree of someone's faith and the degree to which that faith may conflict with their wish to change their lives in any way. And it's harder for people who belong to certain faiths to enter into therapy for fear of violating some tenet of that faith.
Talbott: The Group for the Advancement of Psychiatry asked the readers of Dear Abby: If you have suffered from schizophrenia, what was the most important factor in your recovery? We got hundreds of responses. To us, the single most striking factor was the role of their own religion and spirituality. They felt, rightly or wrongly, that a spiritual connection, the ability to believe that they were going to be better through a higher power, was the most important thing. And it was really astounding to the scientists who were looking at this, because we had expected answers like medication or psychotherapy.
Bergmann: It doesn't surprise me. The ability to believe is a kind of a human capacity to create within yourself the image of somebody caring for you. And that image then does something for you. So that it's really a kind of a miraculous capacity to imagine a love object and then the love object, which has been imagined, is actually helpful.
Bloom: I have certainly had more people talk about their spiritual advisers and their spiritual counselors than I did when I first started practicing. People seem to take for granted that their religious leader is also available to offer some sort of counseling service.
Lear: There's again a general theme in which this fits, which is the possibility of living with certain kinds of intimacy. It's not just intimacy about people; it's an intimacy with certain kinds of ideals. Again, I think the ironic relationship to ideals is collapsing, and I think religious ideals are one example of that phenomenon. It's part of the wider phenomenon.
Q: So it's now possible to talk about spiritual issues and financial issues in a psychotherapeutic context. To what extent do disappointed expectations come up in the kinds of concerns that patients discuss in therapy? Is that a theme?
Person: Yes, there are disappointed expectations in their lives. I think one of the common ones now is that people who are very ambitious and make lots of money are very disappointed in the quality of their lives. It has cost them too much in other areas. They come into treatment because of the emptiness that they feel.
Bergmann: I agree. I think, Who comes to us? Always people for whom something expected did not happen. It's almost by definition prerequisite for coming to us. I think the whole enormous increase in psychotherapy after World War II was to a certain extent based on the question: After the refrigerator, after car, after washing machine, what's next? Because these things were endowed with magic that they could not deliver.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 90; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 958 words

HEADLINE: Satisfactions;
Everything Changes Money

BYLINE: By Orlando Patterson; Orlando Patterson, professor of sociology at Harvard, is the author of "Rituals of Blood," the second volume of a trilogy on race relations.

 BODY:
Of the many contradictions that make American life so endlessly fascinating, few are more curious than those pertaining to money and success. The zeal to make money drives America's globally dominant economy. It has long been observed that in the absence of an aristocracy and the other insidious obfuscations of too much history, money has been the chief maker and marker of status and power. And if my profession is certain of one thing, it is the fact that a family's income matters greatly for the welfare and development of its children.
It is odd, then, that so many Americans have always held money in suspicion. The Puritans were certain that it was the root of all evil, even as they flagellated themselves for making more and more of it. Leaders from Benjamin Franklin to Martin Luther King Jr. have warned of the dangers of materialism. 
 Today, a substantial majority of Americans insist that they do not overvalue money as a measure of their success. What's more, they also deny the influence of money in the way they or their children turn out. The puzzle deepens when we observe that even African-Americans, as well as poorer and older people, are among those most inclined to deny such influences.
What's going on? Are these people simply in denial? Or are they just misinformed?
Perhaps it's a little of both. But I think something more complex is at play, having to do with the need to reconcile our deeply held beliefs about equality with the realities of inequality in America.
America justified its declaration of independence with the startling principle that all people are self-evidently equal. Nonetheless, in the more than two centuries since this declaration, income inequality has grown, except for the period that began with the mid-1930's and ended with the late 1960's. This growth in inequality has been accompanied by an extension of democracy far beyond what prevailed in Jefferson's day. And yet, contrary to the fears of postrevolutionary leaders that a tyrannous majority would inevitably soak the rich, for most periods of American history, including our own, political power has rarely been used to reduce inequality. Why is that?
There is little support for the cynical view that Americans don't really take their egalitarian ideal seriously. They do, and what's more, nearly half consider present economic inequalities morally wrong. As someone who has known or lived with the invidious injuries of the British class system, the ostentatious iniquities of Caribbean color-class hierarchies with their "one people" cant, not to mention Brazilian apartheid with its Orwellian double-speak of "racial democracy," I'll take the dilemmas of American egalitarianism any day, racist warts and all.
Nonetheless, while most Americans genuinely endorse equality in principle, they seem unable to embrace the political means necessary to achieve it. Jennifer Hochschild, a political scientist, thinks that Americans are highly egalitarian in the domains of home, school and community, but that they reject egalitarianism in the workplace. They are uncomfortable using politics to redistribute wealth because they feel it mixes up domains.
I doubt it. Working people do not use politics to repair income inequality because they believe that the democratic process has been corrupted and that politicians are beholden to vested interests. Working- and middle-class Americans certainly desire more money. But having long given up on politicians to do anything about inequality, they have by necessity developed attitudes toward money that enable them to live with it.
Religion is one buttress. In this most religious of industrialized nations, it is religious Americans, among whom African-Americans are disproportionately numbered, who are among the most inclined to deny money's impact or its role as a measure of success.
But a majority of the less devout among us also disclaim the influence of money. They imagine that anyone can make it if they really want to. Becoming rich is a matter of choice, and if there is any virtue left, it lies in the road not taken. Many still share Emerson's view that "money often costs too much," added to which are recent developments indicating that it buys less and less status.
One effect of the vast growth of wealth in contemporary America is that the rich are no longer exalted: too many millionaires have socially degraded wealth. This is all the more true in the strange roller-coaster world of the new economy, where millionaires are daily made from market ether and traditional economic value are upended. The rich can no longer claim to earn their status the old-fashioned way. Like lottery winners, it could happen to anyone.
It may be, too, that people invest money with different symbolic meanings. Viviana Zelizer, a sociologist, has argued that money has cultural significance beyond its wholly instrumental uses. People earmark and valorize money differently, depending on how it is acquired. The same person who scrupulously saves a portion of her income for the down payment on a home will blow $1,000 won from the lottery on a fancy dress or a party. In this cultural recoinage, money ceases to be fungible. There is earned money and welfare money; clean, laundered and dirty money; breadwinner's money and pin money. And, one surmises, there is the funny money of the rich and the real, honest money of working people.
In fact, I would contend that the willingness of many Americans to accept the widening income gap, despite their moral reservations about it, grows out of a deep and abiding national conviction: whatever differences fortune may have dictated between people, where it really matters all of us are of truly equal worth.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/1411 Broadway, Between 39th and 40th Street;
In Changing Garment District, a Fashion Holdout

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE changes that have taken place in the Garment Center in recent years have been so broad and so swift -- a recent survey found that less than half the space is now occupied by apparel concerns -- that, with a nod to the revitalized neighborhood to the north, some real estate executives have begun referring to the area from 35th Street to 41st Street to the west of the Avenue of the Americas as Times Square South.
But the managers of the building at 1411 Broadway, between 39th and 40th Street, say they are intent on maintaining it as a center for the clothing trade. Indeed, they say that as more buildings in the area are being converted to general office use, the value of having a concentration of showrooms in one building is allowing them to charge premium rents to tenants who want to be near the heart of the action. 
 "Clearly, the manufacturing part of the industry has left New York," said Douglas Winshall, senior vice president for the northeast region for TrizecHahn, a Toronto-based company that purchased the property in 1997. "But the showrooms and marketing department and other front-office functions still need to be here."
Mr. Winshall said that consolidation in the apparel industry, with larger companies driving smaller competitors out of business or absorbing them, had increased the value of buildings considered to be at the heart of the district. "This is an industry building," he said. "There is a value to both the landlord and tenants to operating it as a dedicated garment-industry building."
He said that the principal advantage is that when buyers for retail chains arrive in New York for seasonal purchasing sessions, they have to go to only a few locations to see a full line of wares.
"It is imperative that we be located here," said Bobby Reiss, chief executive officer of Worldwide Apparel Resources, a designer of clothing sold under private labels and a tenant at 1411 Broadway. "When retailers come to town they want to go to one general location. If you are in a different part of town you could be eliminated from the schedule."
Mr. Reiss said the principal Garment District buildings are known worldwide in the apparel business. "If you are in Hong Kong or Shanghai and you mention 1411 Broadway or 1407 Broadway," he said, "people know what you are talking about."
Joe Harary, who rents 40,000 square feet at 1411 Broadway for his company, Jacques Moret, a producer of women's sportswear and underwear, said: "This is the heart of the Garment District today. This is a location we have aspired to be in and where I hope we can stay."
Mr. Harary said that Jacques Moret uses most of its space for showrooms and offices, with only a small amount devoted to sewing samples for display to buyers.
The influx of general office-space users such as advertising agencies, law firms and Internet-related businesses has only increased the importance of the major buildings identified with the apparel business, said Neil Weiss, the chairman of KSK International, another garment-industry tenant at 1411 Broadway.
"Places like this are more important than ever to the remaining high-end apparel companies," he said. "Buyers have told me they like the idea of going into a few buildings and seeing all the vendors."
David Winokur, executive vice president of Winokur Realty, a broker specializing in the Garment District, said that the addition of new types of tenants was pushing rent levels higher. He said that rents in the area were typically in the mid-$30's per square foot annually, "and going up from there."
HE said he felt that TrizecHahn's decision to market 1411 Broadway as an apparel center, despite the industry's overall decline, made sense. "I've always thought that the movement of other tenants into the area would make the premier garment buildings even stronger," he said.
Barbara Randall, executive director of the Fashion Center Business Improvement District, said that a recent survey confirmed that apparel tenants had fallen below 50 percent of the space occupied in the district.
"There has been a huge change in just the last two years," she said. "The change in Times Square has made the real estate community willing to look here as a place to locate their clients."
As a result, she said, apparel companies are consolidating in specific buildings, naming 525, 530 and 550 Seventh Avenue as core garment buildings in addition to 1411 and 1407 Broadway. And, she said, some design companies are moving their showrooms to side-street locations that were once populated by suppliers.
"The building at 205 West 39th Street is all showroom now," she said.
Mr. Winshall said TrizecHahn is not concentrating on luring apparel-industry tenants to much of its 8.5 million square feet of property in the New York metropolitan area, including buildings in Stamford, Conn., and Jersey City. He said the location of 1411 Broadway and the characteristics of the 1.145 million-square-foot structure made it suitable for such an approach.
"This building is 30 years old, but it is the newest in the area by 20 years," he said. "Unlike most Garment Center buildings it has rectangular floor plates, with 40,000-square-foot floors in the base and 14,000 square feet in the tower."
He said that a 200,000-square-foot TrizecHahn building at 1460 Broadway, at 41st Street, that had been largely occupied by textile tenants was being converted to office use because of its proximity to Times Square.
"We went out and found Skadden, Arps which is going to use it as a back office for 4 Times Square," he said, referring to the law firm that is one of the principal tenants of a new building at the intersection of 42nd Street and Broadway. Mr. Winshall said he had been able to empty out 100,000 square feet of the building by July 1998, with the firm scheduled to take over the rest of the building as leases expire over the succeeding seven years.
Another building in the TrizecHahn portfolio, the 600,000-square-foot structure at 111 West 40th Street, is similarly being converted from largely textile-industry use to general office space, to take advantage of its location across the Avenue of the Americas from Bryant Park. It has been renumbered as 1065 Avenue of the Americas to emphasize its location and it has attracted tenants such as Yahoo, the big Internet referral service, which has rented 50,000 square feet for its New York headquarters.
"We still have some textile/apparel tenants in the building, but it's about 60-40 office to apparel now," Mr. Winshall said. "And we're moving that toward 80-20."
Tenants at 1411 Broadway run the gamut from Jones Apparel Group, which occupies 200,000 square feet, to small producers that have a 1,000-square-foot showroom, said Bruce J. Crawford, TrizecHahn's vice president for leasing in the northeast region.
The building has more than 200 tenants who are constantly expanding, shrinking, coming and going, which makes for a lot of work, Mr. Crawford said. He said a tenant with a 1,000-square-foot showroom might suddenly need to double that space if it develops a hot line of clothing.
"If we have a 1,000-square-foot tenant who needs 2,000 square feet, we try to move him to where we have space," he said. "Most want to expand showrooms, which does not involve a lot of capital cost."
He said there are typically 40 new lease transactions a year involving about 175,000 square feet of space. "It's not like you are locking things up forever," he said.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1809 words

HEADLINE: On TV, a Loss of Independents

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
FOR more than two decades, Robert Greenwald, a prolific television producer, has owned the films he made, which gave him the leverage to do such Emmy Award-winning shows as "The Burning Bed" and "A Woman of Independent Means." But now Mr. Greenwald, and every other producer of films and series, is under powerful pressure to yield to the networks and allow them to own more and more of their shows.
"It's not about the money," Mr. Greenwald said. "We all get paid well. It's about the fact that a show you own is your viewpoint, your vision. All that is dissipated when you're a hired hand. You can have the most brilliant people in the world running networks, but it's almost a scientific impossibility for bureaucracies to be inventive and edgy. They cannot. It's their nature." 
 Until five years ago, federal regulations prevented broadcast networks from creating and owning shows, which left the job to independent production companies and studios like Warner Brothers, Fox, Sony and Universal. The thinking was that the networks were so powerful they could lock out projects by independent producers. But in 1995 the Federal Communications Commission lifted the 20-year-old restriction, freeing the networks to aggressively seek financial stakes in and ownership of films, dramatic series and sitcoms.
The question is, what does this mean to viewers? Is the television landscape, already littered with derivative shows, even more compromised if independent producers are unable to get provocative programs on the air? Or are the complaints just a Hollywood shell game -- one group of rich people getting richer at the expense of another group of rich people? Put another way, was television better 10 years ago than it is today?
The clearest proof of where the television networks are heading will be evident in New York during the week of May 15. That is when the networks, in their lavish annual presentations to advertisers, will announce their fall schedules. Most of the new comedy and dramatic series will be owned entirely by the networks, or made in partnership with producers. Inevitably -- and despite the denials of network executives -- some shows will be selected simply because they are home-grown. Cynics may recall that in recent years NBC green-lighted such in-house shows as "Union Square," "Conrad Bloom" and "The Mike O'Malley Show." Each of them died without a trace, and one can only wonder what shows failed to make it to the air because of the decision to put on those three.
The decline of independent producers is a reflection not only of increased network ownership of shows but, far more important, of the ascendancy of conglomerates like Disney and Viacom, General Electric and News Corporation, who own the networks. The result is that network executives have also lost considerable independence, further hampering creative programming.
Two or more decades ago, television was presided over by figures like Grant Tinker, Fred Silverman and Brandon Tartikoff, who held top jobs at NBC, and Barry Diller, a one-time ABC programming executive and the former chairman of Fox. Whatever their flaws, these men were more independent than their counterparts today. At Disney-owned ABC, for example, Lloyd Braun and Stuart Bloomberg, the two talented executives who run the entertainment division, work under the formidable shadow of Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company and a former ABC executive himself. The fact that Mr. Eisner weighs in on program decisions is an open secret -- and doing so is his prerogative. (Not long ago, he went so far as to personally call Peter Berg, the creator of "Wonderland," to give him script advice. The show failed anyway.) Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of News Corporation, and executives at General Electric and Time Warner are less intrusive than Mr. Eisner, but their voices are heard at Fox and NBC and WB.
As corporate owners study the bottom line, the mood is bleak. The days are over when a show is allowed to struggle and find an audience, as NBC did with "Seinfeld" in 1990. This month, ABC canceled "Wonderland," a drama set in a mental hospital, after only two shows, and NBC dropped the DreamWorks police comedy, "Battery Park," after just four outings.
"There's no free lunch anymore," said Tom Werner, who with his partners, Marcy Carsey and Caryn Mandabach, created "The Cosby Show," "Roseanne" and other gold mines. The four pilots his company is now producing are being done in partnership with networks, partly out of necessity, he said. Making 22 episodes of a series can lead to a deficit as high as $15 million before the show is sold to syndication. Partners are needed to defray the costs.
Currently, CBS and NBC have their own in-house production units and seek out (or demand) partnerships with producers as well. Fox and ABC rely heavily -- although not exclusively -- on shows produced by 20th Century Fox and Disney. Is there any question that networks favor their own shows? It is a subtle issue.
"Without a doubt, it's a factor that gets in the way," said Amy Lippman, the co-creator of Fox's "Party of Five." "When networks have material that comes from a studio they own, it can't help but weigh in the decision about what gets on the air."
Ms. Lippman said that "Party of Five," admittedly in its sixth year, was shifted out of its choice Wednesday night time slot to make room for a Fox-produced comedy, "Get Real." "Party" is produced by Columbia-TriStar. " 'Party of Five' suffered," said Ms. Lippman, whose show went off the air this season.
Steve Levitan, the creator of NBC's "Just Shoot Me," told a similiar story about "Will and Grace," which is produced in part by NBC Studios. "NBC smelled a hit in 'Will and Grace,' " he said, "and poured all their resources and advertising into that show, giving it a great time period, the 'Just Shoot Me' time period," meaning Tuesday night at 9. "It's just that they're favoring their own show. It's not like they're doing something wrong. It's not like, 'How dare they do that?' " (The fact that "Shoot Me" is in its fifth year surely figured in the decision.)
Another writer-producer, Marshall Herskovitz, said that he and his partner, Edward Zwick, the creators of "Thirtysomething," went out of their way to make a deal with Disney knowing it would give them a leg up with their series "Once and Again."
"We made a deal with Disney knowing they would be the main supplier of ABC," Mr. Herskovitz said. "What we felt was, at best, there was a statistical advantage in being with an in-house production company. By that I mean that, at some odd moment, when a decision is to be made about a show, and all the factors are equal, it would be of some benefit for a network to favor its own show." (ABC recently renewed "Once and Again" for another season.)
How this affects creative quality is difficult to assess. Network executives are hardly hacks. Aware that audiences are shrinking in favor of cable and the Internet, they are plainly struggling to come up with shows that are intelligent (NBC's "West Wing"), funny (Fox's "Malcolm in the Middle"), adult (ABC's "Once and Again") and even a bit risky (NBC's "Will and Grace"). And they insist that the demise of the independent producer -- and the rise of producing partnerships -- has not altered the creative landscape.
T HE fact that a producer is affiliated with a studio or a network doesn't mean that half of their brain died," said Mr. Braun of ABC. "Producers are better served by being with a network or a studio because the business is so economically challenging."
Mr. Braun denied that ABC goes out of its way to select Disney properties. "Certainly we'll be as aggressive as possible in building up our studios," he said. "But our mantra is to develop and put the best possible shows on the air, regardless of the source."
Similarly, Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Television, dismissed the notion that series and films have been diminished. "You think the creative aesthetic of David Kelley has changed one iota because he's under the Fox banner? Of course not."
An unfair example, perhaps. Hugely successful creator-producers like Mr. Kelley ("The Practice," "Ally McBeal") and Steven Bochco ("N.Y.P.D. Blue"), whose companies are now aligned with studios, are given creative carte blanche. Most independent producers are under seige.
Television was once dominated by powerhouse producers like Norman Lear, Aaron Spelling, Witt-Thomas-Harris, Carsey-Werner, Lorimar and others. By all accounts, some of the shows they made -- "Soap," "All in the Family," "Benson," "Maude," "Golden Girls" -- would probably not pass muster today. The lead characters would not fit snugly into the prized youth market: they are too old, too ethnic, too female. "Try doing a show today like 'Golden Girls,' about three older women," said one top network executive. "Good luck!"
Some of those producers, like Carsey-Werner-Mandabach and Mr. Spelling, still work in television, but their number has dwindled. When this reporter called Michael Jaffe, a well-known producer, and said he was doing an article about independent television producers, Mr. Jaffe replied, with some hyperbole: "You're doing a short story. There are only two of us left." Mr. Jaffe said there were probably only 10 producers making films for television, in contrast to 30 or 40 in the 80's.
But a handful of powerful producers has entered the field -- Basic Entertainment (formerly Brillstein-Grey), Regency Television and the Robert Greenblatt-David Janollari studio, among them. Artists Television Group, a newcomer, has made 12 pilots for the new season. All of which suggests that, despite changes wrought by the F.C.C. decision, there is work to go around.
Increasingly, producers are turning to the flourishing cable networks, where, as Variety reported last week, wealthy corporate parents like Time Warner and Viacom are willing to pay the costs of series and films. (A one-hour series on basic cable can cost about $1.3 million an episode, only slightly less than the $1.5 million price of a broadcast show; a two-hour cable film can cost $7 million to $10 million.)
"We embraced the new world," said Mr. Jaffe, whose company made more than a half-dozen films for cable last year. "The partnerships are somewhat complicated because it's all new business. We're paving the landscape as we go."
Ultimately, said Gail Berman, president of Regency Television, the producer of Fox's successful sitcom "Malcolm in the Middle," whether or not studios own series and films is not the issue. "The audience doesn't know, doesn't care about vertical integration," Ms. Berman said. The issue, she said, is a straightforward one. Without better programming, the viewers won't be there. "They'll just flip the channel."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 17; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 832 words

HEADLINE: A Cultural Jewel Is Gaining a New Setting

BYLINE: By E. KYLE MINOR 

 BODY:
THE intimate Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam has long been considered one of the state's brightest cultural jewels. It will soon need a new appraisal. The Tony Award-winning theater is on the verge of a $30 million expansion that will turn the quaint little town into a virtual musical-theater theme park.
"We've outgrown our current facilities," said Michael Price, Goodspeed's executive director since 1967. "This expansion will not only help us meet our growing needs but draw even more people to this part of the state than before." 
 A feasibility study is being conducted now, Mr. Price said, after which the project will be put out to bid. The expansion is expected to be completed by 2004 or 2005.
Goodspeed Opera House is known as the charming, Victorian theater where the Broadway hits "Man of La Mancha," "Annie" and "Shenandoah" were born. That original 398-seat theater will be surrounded by a new 650-seat theater and 30,000-square-foot production center.
The expansion will spill over to Main Street when nine local buildings owned by Goodspeed will be developed into retail stores, restaurants and residences for actors, designers and company members. Goodspeed will continue to own and operate the 200-seat Norma Terris Theater in nearby Chester, where new musicals are developed.
In granting Goodspeed its first installment of $2 million, the state proved its commitment to "polishing up one of our true gems," Gov. John G. Rowland recently said. "This helps create excitement in this part of the state."
Goodspeed, which sits on the Connecticut River, puts an estimated $25 million into the local economy. Once the expansion is completed in 2005, that figure could balloon to more than $60 million.
Mr. Price said that the first $2 million grant from the state will be used for buying a site for the new theater, conducting a traffic study, and commissioning a design for the venue. The money was released last month once Goodspeed raised $2 million to match the grant.
Mr. Rowland said that though there was no "magical formula," the state would add $10 million to the $20 million that Goodspeed would have to raise.
"It's been my experience that people want to be part of a success story," Mr. Rowland said. "They see project like this going up around them and they want to get involved. Tourism is up 40 percent now and the time is good to invest in the state's culture."
Mr. Rowland pointed out that the first thing he did in his administration was double spending for the arts. Other performing arts sites like the Warner in Torrington, the Palace in Waterbury, the Stamford Center for the Performing Arts and Polka Dot Playhouse in Bridgeport have benefited from the state's largesse.
"It's part of our overall plan," Mr. Rowland said, adding that he had also bolstered the schools' arts programs. "One of our calling cards is culture, so it makes sense to invest in it."
Selecting Goodspeed for expansion also has its political benefits since the demise of the Connecticut Yankee Atomic Power Company in Haddam Neck has cost the community.
"Financially, that did hurt some of the communities," Mr. Rowland said. "But that wasn't a factor in the plan to expand Goodspeed. It was Goodspeed's time.
"You look at this as investment," he said. "You're building morale. How do you value people going from Greenwich to Polka Dot Theater in Bridgeport? Everybody benefits."
The plan will allow Goodspeed to expand its production schedule. The new 650-seat theater will present four shows a season, simultaneously with the existing theater. Goodspeed presently offers three musicals in both of its theaters from April to December.
"We'll now be able to transfer shows to New York without having to redesign and build them," Mr. Price said. "The original opera house is much smaller than Broadway theaters and it is very expensive to move shows. We'll also be able to build shows for touring, which is something we've never done before."
Mr. Price said that the idea for the expansion came from a slightly wilder idea he had a few years ago. "I told the board of directors that I wanted to put a showboat in the river," he said. "The board liked the idea. Governor Rowland liked it. Then, the board thought about it and said, 'You want a showboat? Fine! We need a real theater first.' "
Mr. Price had no problem dry-docking his floating theater idea because he knew as well as anyone that the existing Goodspeed had outgrown itself.
"When I first came here it was me and a press agent. Now there's over 100 full-time employees," he said.
Many businesses undergoing expansion often lose their family feel. Mr. Price is confident that Goodspeed won't lose any of its charm.
"Theaters are by nature a mom and pop business," he said.
"They can't be run like corporations. I'm always around, keeping involved in all aspects of the business. Even though we're growing, we're still a family. We're just getting a larger house to live in."

HEADLINE: Another Threat to Nassau Residents' Taxes

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
Homeowners in much of Nassau County have already begun to dread Jan. 1, 2003, the deadline by which the county has agreed to reassess all residential property and revise tax rolls that are currently based on 1930's values. The agreement, reached in March, ended a high-profile lawsuit charging that the system discriminated against minorities.
But if near-term impact is what counts, there's another, less-publicized case that homeowners should be worrying about: a lawsuit by 38 Nassau County commercial property owners who allege they are being assessed more than their fair share of taxes. 
 If their suit is upheld -- and last month it survived a state and county effort to dismiss it -- more county taxes will have to be paid by all residential owners, steepening the 2003 tax increase in well-off neighborhoods and reducing or eliminating the post-assessment tax break expected in low-income areas.
"If Nassau County wants to reach a final resolution to its financial problems, it's going to have to resolve our case also," said one of the plaintiffs, Bennett L. Rechler, a principal of the We're Group in Jericho. "If we succeed in court, the county will lose a lot of revenue."
No court date has been set, but last month's ruling has the plaintiffs talking up an out-of-court settlement that could hit taxpayers a lot sooner than the 2003 revaluation.
Roger Tilles, co-director of the Tilles Investment Company in Woodbury and another plaintiff in the case, said one of the reasons for filing the suit was that county officials, fearing the political repercussions of revamping residential property taxes, would try to shift even more of the burden onto commercial property owners. "It's politically easier to raise the taxes on businesses that can't vote," he said.
In his decision last month rejecting the state and county challenges to the commercial owners' lawsuit, state Supreme Court Justice John DiNoto in Mineola pointed out that Nassau applied 1938 construction costs and 1964 land values to determine value when assessing residential property, but applied values derived from a 1986 revaluation when assessing commercial property. And he noted that though the county had imposed caps on annual residential property assessment increases, there were no such caps on commercial property.
"The result is that Nassau commercial property owners allegedly pay the highest effective tax rate in the state, namely $38.94 per thousand dollars of market value of property, as compared with the median for all counties, which is $25.82," he wrote. "Although commercial property represents only 16 percent of the market value of all property in Nassau County, commercial property owners purportedly pay 27.5 percent of the tax burden."
Justice DiNoto ruled that the "evidence was sufficient to raise a substantial issue as to whether the stated reason for singling out Nassau and New York City for Article 18 treatment was, and continues to be, rational."
Article 18, a state law passed in 1981 that applies only to New York City and Nassau County, allows commercial property to be taxed differently from commercial property. Delores Fredrich, special counsel for Nassau County, said that in seeking dismissal of the suit, the county argued that all it was doing was levying taxes in a manner prescribed by state law.
"The plaintiffs are not complaining that the law has been applied incorrectly," Ms. Fredrich said. "Their remedy is to change the law. If they do, we will abide by the change."
The attorney for the plaintiffs, former state Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell, said the judge had "sustained our principal contentions."
"We claim that there is no rational basis for creating a separate system and no reason to discriminate against Nassau commercial ratepayers, and the judge said we have a good claim," Mr. Koppell said. "The county and state are likely to appeal. But we think the county should consider settling with us. This is an opportune time because it has to complete its reassessment by 2003. So let's solve the whole problem and deal with the disparities of the commercial sector."
Mr. Rechler said there were various ways to correct the disparities, which he said had grown appreciably. He said commercial property owners would still end up with a greater tax burden than residential property owners, but "it would be less than what we are paying now."
A recent study by the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University found that effective real property tax rates increased in Nassau by 13.06 percent from 1997 to 1998, but declined during that period by 11.2 percent in Suffolk. Nassau's increase was the largest of the eight downstate counties.
"The residential effective tax rate in Nassau County was $18.40 per $1,000 of full value in 1998," said Thomas Conoscenti, a coauthor of the study. "That same year, the commercial effective tax rate was $44.03 per $1,000 of full value. In 1997, the residential rate was $17.45 and the commercial was $38.94. The difference between them that year was $21.20; a year later, it had increased to $26.63."
By contrast, the disparity in Suffolk was considerably less and actually declined in 1998, Mr. Conoscenti found.
Mr. Conoscenti said he believed there was merit to the assertion of Nassau's commercial property owners that they were bearing a disproportionately greater share of the tax burden in the county. He said his study found that the median effective real property tax rates for residential property owners in 1998 was $23.70 statewide, $20.17 in Suffolk and only $18.40 in Nassau.
At the same time, the median rates for commercial property owners were $27.67 in the eight downstate counties, $22.84 in Suffolk and $44.03 in Nassau.
"When you make those comparisons, you really see the striking differences," he said.
Bernard Hyman, a real estate evaluation specialist, said the tax burden on Nassau's commercial property owners had become "so onerous that it has made Nassau County a less desirable place for commercial owners to do business. The tremendous increase in the tax rate in recent years is because we have had very little new development to add to the tax base."
Mr. Tilles, whose company is one of the biggest developers in the region, said he had just put up a building in Woodbury where the taxes were about $6 per foot, fully assessed. But "just three miles down the road in Melville, I'm going to build a comparable building where the taxes will be under $3 a foot. And with the rent about $30 in both places, those in Woodbury will be paying 10 percent more. That's a huge disadvantage."
He said that because of a severe shortage in rental office space on Long Island, the higher rent had not made it more difficult to find tenants for the Woodbury property. But, he warned, "as soon as we go back to normal conditions, it will make a difference."
Mr. Hyman, managing partner of the powerful Certilman Balin Adler & Hyman law firm in East Meadow, said his firm represented nearly every major developer on Long Island and that they were all expanding in Suffolk because that county was "more amenable to development than Nassau. They are also providing all kinds of incentives. Nassau County is impossible."
But Carolyn Fahey, a business development specialist in the Suffolk County Department of Economic Development, said Suffolk was not trying to take advantage of the disparity by offering incentives different from Nassau's.
"We have a nonwritten verbal agreement that we are not going to do a direct hit on Nassau County," she said. "We're not going to raid each other's businesses. A company in eastern Nassau is as profitable to us with jobs and its whole economic impact as if it were in Melville."
And Lee E. Koppelman, executive director or the Long Island Regional Planning Board, questioned Mr. Hyman's assertions, saying that "every site that is available in Nassau County is at some stage of being developed. Fortunoff just completed The Source, Roosevelt Field is in the process of expanding, and there are proposals for new growth at the Roosevelt Raceway site. I haven't heard from any major developer who has said he is not building in Nassau because of the taxes."
He said it was natural for rents in Nassau to be more expensive than those in Suffolk because of Nassau's proximity to New York City. "With commercial development, location is everything," Dr. Koppelman said. And he added that there was more building going on in Suffolk because there was more available land there.
But he conceded that the "assessment situation in Nassau County is so anachronistic that it makes Nassau vulnerable to these suits. And the litigants have some legitimacy to their argument because the whole assessment system is out of whack. So the angels aren't just on one side of the argument."

HEADLINE: House Wine Gets Its Own Room;
And What a Room! From Big-Screen TV's to Tuscan Hardware, Cellars Are Getting Grander

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
FRED TREGASKIS, who builds wine cellars for a living, said he remembered when city restaurants were the sum total of his clientele. That was in the early 1990's. Now the West Cornwall contractor is more likely to find work at private homes in lower Fairfield and Westchester Counties.
Mr. Tregaskis, owner of New England Wine Cellars, said he built about 40 cellars last year, his biggest year ever. Design Build Consultants, a Greenwich builder of wine cellars, also said last year was its biggest. "Cellars have become the rage in new construction," Mr. Tregaskis said. "I've built several cellars in nice homes where the client wasn't an avid wine collector, but felt their home wasn't complete unless it had a wine cellar." 
 Or had a wine cellar with a wide-screen television or a spiral staircase, as some do. These cellars can also come with mood lighting, secret paneled entrances and antique decorative knickknacks.
"They want hand-forged hardware on their door and old-fashioned lighting," Mr. Tregaskis said. They also often want a medieval Italian look: "Tuscany. I hear that word all the time."
As both the cost of and demand for fine wine rise to unprecedented levels in the United States, with a record $18.1 billion of wine sold in 1999, having a place at home to store it safely has become a high priority for some.
Adam Strum, chairman of the Wine Enthusiast, a wine-accessory catalog company in Hawthorne, N.Y., said sales of its custom built cellars rose from 234 in 1998 to 397 last year. In the first quarter of this year, he said demand was more than double what it was at this time last year. Christine Hawley of Manhattan, who has designed cellars in Greenwich and the Hamptons, said the strong economy had a lot to do with it.
"The economy has been so good, people already have as many cars as they can drive, as many homes as they can go to," Ms. Hawley said. "One thing people haven't experienced is the newest pleasure left, which is wine cellars."
Once, not long ago, a wine cellar was thought of as a rack under the basement stairs. But today the trend is more in line with Tony Sanfilippo's home cellar in Westport, a 10-by-12-foot space with a tasting table, a tumbled-marble floor and a chandelier with colored glass cut to resemble a grapevine.
"It's somewhat in the eye of the beholder, but it does give me pleasure," Mr. Sanfilippo said. The cellar, which can hold close to 2,000 bottles, cost about $50,000 to build.
Matt Kramer, a columnist for Wine Spectator magazine and author of the "Making Sense" series of wine books, said the increase in cellars correlated with the rise in interest in drinking wine.
"The more people get involved with wine, the more they realize that storage matters," he said.
Paul Wyatt, a designer who runs the Fine Wine Rack and Cellar Company in San Carlos, Calif., which provides supplies for cellars around the country, said the greater New York area was one of six regions of the United States where the cellar market was strongest.
"Volume is going up every year," he said. "Periodically, I get so busy I can't see straight, so I raise my prices and volume goes up again."
Evan Goldenberg of Design Build Consultants attributed the strong demand to the rise in the stock market. Mr. Sanfilippo is executive vice president of the brokerage firm Knight/ Trimark Group of Jersey City, N.J., and among Mr. Goldenberg's other clients are many with similar connections to the world of finance.
Driving through the Round Hill section of Greenwich with Mr. Goldenberg can become monotonous as he points out various streets and calculates how many cellars he has built along each. Lawrence Calcano, a managing director at Goldman Sachs, hired Mr. Goldenberg to build a cellar with a 5,000-bottle capacity at his Greenwich home. He declined to say how much it cost, but said it provided "flexibility" in choosing wines for the right occasion.
"To me it's not that complicated," he said. "It's a real fun thing, a real social thing. It's great to be able to share your passion with family and friends."
William Driscoll, a forest-products industry executive in Riverside, a section of Greenwich, has a cellar with a 1,700-bottle capacity. Unostentatious, with a hunk of ledge rock coming out of the floor that Mr. Driscoll prizes for the added humidity, the cellar is "a great comfort," he said.
"Many times at the end of a busy day I just go in and close myself in," he said. "It's like going back to the womb."
The cellar also means that Mr. Driscoll doesn't have to rush to drink his finest bottles. "In the late 80's and early 90's, you were forced to drink California Cabernets too early because you didn't have the space to store them," he said.
Some higher-end clients want elaborate cabinets instead of racks for their bottles, creating what Mr. Goldenberg calls "a library for wine."
He said his projects tended to be expensive, largely because he works with sophisticated refrigeration equipment with temperature-sensitive alarm systems and low-voltage electronic controls.
"Things really started to pick up in 1996," he said. "Projects had been in the $25,000 to $35,000 range. Then they quickly graduated to the $45,000 to $55,000 range. I'd have clients call me to say they moved and needed a new wine cellar. I'd have other clients tell me they ran out of space and needed another wine cellar."
Perhaps the most unusual wine cellar in Connecticut is the commercial one Jed and Amie Benedict have created in Stafford. It is a former bomb shelter built during the cold war for record-keeping by Hartford banks and insurance companies. It comes with a 12-ton steel safe door, diesel generator, 3,000-gallon fuel tank, and rear escape hatch.
The Benedicts are marketing themselves to restaurants, liquor stores and private collectors willing to rent space for wine storage in the 100,000-square-foot cellar, now called Horse Ridge Cellars. Because the cellar is 15 feet underground, naturally cool and vibration-free, the Benedicts see wine storage as a natural fit. In addition, when it comes to long-term commercial wine storage, Ms. Benedict said, "there is nothing else in New England at all."
Mr. Benedict added: "This was built in 1962 for $330,000. Now if you wanted to do all this, the cost would be $2 million to $3 million. The walls, ceiling and floor are all two-foot thick steel-reinforced concrete."
So far, restaurants haven't signed up, but Horse Ridge has landed private collectors from Greenwich, Glastonbury and Avon.
While cellars can certainly be a conduit to exploring a personal passion, for others, they're a smart investment.
"They're a very hot item now," said David Ogilvy, who owns a real estate firm in Greenwich. "What sells houses are things like condition and master bedrooms, but a wine cellar is a really nice piece of cake."
Wine cellars can pay off in other ways. David Koch, executive vice president of Koch Industries, a company in Wichita, Kan., whose South Hampton, N.Y., cellar was designed by Ms. Hawley, noted that many of the wines he had stored had gone up in value three or four times since he purchased them 10 years ago. "I may get enough off these bottles to justify the original cost of the cellar," he said.
Michael Davis, head of the North American wine department at Sotheby's International, said: "A lot of people are keeping wine as an investment, and they are doing quite well. What I see is the ideal cycle of wine collecting. As wines mature, people prune their cellar. A cellar can become self-funding that way, by selecting things as they reach their level of maturity and reinvesting in young wines."
Private collectors said the economics make sense.
"All you have to do is look at the auction world," said David Pedowitz, an investment adviser from Bedford, N.Y., with a 5,000-bottle cellar Mr. Goldenberg built for $75,000. "The finest wines are now outrageously expensive because of the supply and demand curves. You have to search for the supply, and supply is only going to come from people storing wines."
Ms. Hawley said she believed that wine collecting was about more than drinking or investing. It can provide entree into a world where one becomes a "connoisseur of life."
"When you start building a cellar, a lot of things change in your life," she said. "You think about going to wine countries for vacations. You start going to wine auctions. Your friends change, because you're more focused on people who love wine. Your diet changes, because you want food that goes with your wine. It's like having a baby. I see people get so energized and focused."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Rental Apartment Tower Is Rising in Fort Lee

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: FORT LEE

 BODY:
FOR years a derelict garage was all that stood on the 4.8 acre-site along the Palisades cliffs here, a symbol of a stalled condominium development from the late 1980's.
"It basically had become an eyesore," said Fort Lee's mayor, Jack Alter. The site is one of the last large developable parcels in Fort Lee. 
 But new owners bought the site 18 months ago, with plans to turn it into a $100 million rental complex called the Palisades. It will have 438 apartments in a 29-story L-shaped building, 80 apartments in a separate 12-story building that also houses a garage, with 20 town houses on its roof. Nearly all of the one- to three-bedroom units will have views of the George Washington Bridge, a quarter of a mile to the north, as well as of the river and the Manhattan skyline beyond.
The garage will accommodate 1,000 cars, and it will be crowned by a 1.4-acre landscaped plaza. The site is bounded by River Road, Parker Avenue, Old Palisades Road and Massa Lane.
The Palisades is being developed by the Applied Development Company of Hoboken, with Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook as its financial partner. In addition to the partners' own equity, financing is coming from a consortium of five banks.
Allen F. Goldman, a senior vice president of Applied, said his company was undeterred by the site's development history.
"There is no doubt about the strength of the housing market in Bergen County in general and in Fort Lee in particular," Mr. Goldman said. "Every major condo and co-op building in the borough is filled, and there is an equally strong demand for rentals."
The project, which is expected to be completed in 18 months, will be the second large new rental complex in Fort Lee. The 351-unit Avalon Crest opened in late 1998. Its seven four-story buildings are fully occupied, said Gary Steinfield, the vice president for development at the Princeton office of AvalonBay, the developer.
Together, Avalon Crest and the Palisades are the first new rental developments to rise in the 2.5-square-mile borough of Fort Lee in 25 years.
Beginning in the late 80's, the site of the Palisades was involved in a tangle of litigation, which ended last year. Applied bought the site in July 1998 from a developer that never proceeded with its its plan to build condominiums.
That developer, Haseko (New York Inc.), owned by the Haseko Corporation of Tokyo, and the borough hammered out an agreement in 1994 after seven years of litigation over the number of units to be built on the site and where. To avoid blocking other buildings' views, the new tower, designed by Costas Kondylis, the Manhattan architect, will rise on the northern corner of the site. Mr. Kondylis had also designed the unrealized condo project but has revised the interior to create larger apartments for the Palisades.
Applied is to follow the terms of the agreement, which was the result of a lawsuit filed by Haseko against Fort Lee in 1987. Haseko contended that the borough's zoning violated the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel doctrines, which require municipal zoning to include sites for housing for people of all incomes. By the time Applied entered the scene, that agreement had been the subject of two subsequent lawsuits.
The first suit went all the way to State Supreme Court, and it was decided in favor of the development. A similar suit in Superior Court, contending that the challenge to the rezoning of the site to permit a residential tower had been improperly dismissed, ended in an out-of-court settlement last year, said Mr. Goldman of Applied. The project received final site plan approval from the borough in January.
AS part of the 1994 agreement, Applied contributed $800,000 to the borough and will also build 60 rental apartments in a separate building for tenants with low and moderate incomes, up to $69,504 a year. Construction of that five-story building on Kaufer Lane, about three blocks north of the Palisades project, must meet a timetable set out in the agreement or Applied will be subject to fines.
Looking back, Mayor Alter said: "This project is something we agreed to and will not affect the neighboring buildings, preserving their views and presumably their values."
Of its impact on schools and traffic, he said, "You can't legislate against school-age children."
Peggy Thomas, the borough's administrator, said, "Only time will tell the ultimate impact."
Certainly, the development will bring more cars. But Mayor Alter said that traffic in the borough, which he called the state's most heavily traveled community, is a persistent problem because of the bridge.
The Palisades is indicative of the renewed interest in building rental apartments in the state, where such construction has inched upward since 1995. Of the 36,600 housing permits issued in the state last year, 5,915 were for rental units, according to preliminary state figures. In 1995 there were 28,895 permits issued, of which 3,483 were for rentals.
Evidence of that increase is the spate of rental towers that are, or soon will be, sprouting along New Jersey's 18 miles of Hudson River shoreline, anchored in the north by Fort Lee.
"Despite the new construction, the rental market has tightened up big time," said Nathan Slovin, the executive vice president of the New Jersey Apartment Association, in East Brunswick. The statewide vacancy rate is under 5 percent, he said.
With New Jersey's economy strong and new businesses, and employees, coming into the state, he estimates there is a shortfall of about 10,000 rental units. The most acute shortage is rentals "for regular working people," Mr. Slovin said, noting that the scarcity and high cost of properly zoned land, as well as increasing construction costs, are pushing rents for new apartments into the luxury category.
Also spurring the demand for rentals is the ripple effect from Manhattan, where soaring rents are prompting some tenants to turn to close-in and less expensive New Jersey locations, like Fort Lee and other riverfront towns.
Mr. Goldman of Applied, an active riverfront developer, offered another reason. Some people are looking for "more flexibility in their lives and have no desire to commit to purchasing housing," he said. All those reasons and the fact "that there is virtually no rental housing in Fort Lee," he said, convinced him to proceed with the Palisades project.
The borough's rental supply is puny: of its 15,000 housing units, only about 2,300 are rentals. In the conversion frenzy of the late 70's and early 80's, 41 rental apartment buildings were converted to co-ops or condos.
Charles Oppler, a partner in Oppler-Ketive Realtors in Fort Lee, said that a high-rise luxury rental, with views, services and amenities, "could fill a niche" in the market.
At the Palisades the apartments will have 900 to 1,900 square feet of space and such features as marble-tile baths, washers and dryers and large windows to take advantage of the views, Mr. Goldman said. The tower will have a facade of red, orange and beige brick, and along with the garage and landscaped plaza, other amenities will include a children's playroom, a health club and a library.
Monthly rents have not been set, but Mr. Goldman said that if the building were completed today, apartments would rent for $30 a square foot on average. That would come to $2,250 a month for a 900-square-foot one-bedroom and $4,750 for a 1,900-square-foot three-bedroom.
Mr. Oppler said those rents would be 10 percent higher than those for existing rental apartments in the area. "What the developers are counting on," he said, "is that their project is the only game in town."
