LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
For Affordable New Houses, Go East, Young Buyers

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: YAPHANK

 BODY:
IN this still-rural enclave of Suffolk County where woods and fields have not yet given way to surburban sprawl, Uri Hason and his partner, Avi Sharabani, are carving a 76-house subdivision out of the scrub oak forest. Starting prices of $184,900 for a three-bedroom ranch and a top price of $237,900 for 2,000-square-foot, four-bedroom colonial are giving young couples buying their first homes a chance to get into the housing market.
Pinewood Manor, as the 102-acre Yaphank project is called, and similarly priced developments springing up in eastern Suffolk belie the general belief that Long Island is no longer a place where first-time buyers can afford to buy new housing. 
 These projects, which are pushing as far east as Riverhead, are reminiscent of residential developments of the 1960's when Levitt & Sons and other pioneering builders ventured out to what were then untapped areas like Hauppauge and bought inexpensive land to build housing for young families just starting out.
Over the 40 years since then, prices have increased tenfold, and young couples now usually need hefty down payments and two incomes to meet mortgage costs. And now the new frontiers are Yaphank, Middle Island, Manorville and Moriches, but the appeal is the same: three- and four-bedroom moderately priced houses in new developments.
At Pinewood Manor there is a choice of six different styles. The $184,900 ranch has 1,300 square feet of living area and a one-car garage. The largest house, a $234,900 colonial, has four bedrooms, 2,350 square feet and a two-car garage. Basements are included in the price. Also available is a three-bedroom, 1,350-square-foot high ranch priced at $189,900; its 1,100-square-foot windowed lower level can be finished at a future time.
Contracts have been signed for 45 houses since sales began less than four months ago, and of these, 40 percent are being purchased by first-time buyers, said Mr. Hason, whose company, Pinewood Development, is in Hicksville.
Marilyn Larsen, the owner of Lane Realty in Great Neck, which is handling sales at Pinewood Manor, said, "These developments are still catering to the affordable level." With a 5 percent down payment of $9,200 and taxes of $6,000 a year, a buyer purchasing the $184,900 ranch could carry the $1,880 monthly mortgage cost with an annual family income of $68,000.
Among the people buying homes at Pinewood Manor are Brian Curry, 27, a sales representative for a health insurance company, and his fiancee, Kelly O'Brien, also 27, a conductor on the Long Island Rail Road. They selected a $221,000, four-bedroom, 2,350-square-foot Victorian that will give them room for a home office and enough bedrooms for the family they want to raise.
"We both have good jobs, and we have been living in our parents' homes so we were able to build up some savings," Mr. Curry said. With a 20 percent down payment, they estimate that their monthly mortgage payments, including taxes, will be about $1,925.
"People in our situation not only can find a better deal out east, but I also love it out there," Mr. Curry said. Although his office is in Uniondale, a laptop computer, fax machine and modem will allow him to work out of his new home most days of the week.
The Beechwood Organization of Jericho, whose two principals are Michael Dubb and Leslie A. Lerner, is building 307 houses in a development called Country Pointe at Manorville. Mr. Dubb said that although Manorville may seem far out, it takes only 30 minutes to drive from there to the Melville office corridor and even less time to travel to large employers like Computer Associates International in Islandia and Symbol Technologies in Holtsville.
Two of the 10 different house styles being offered at Country Pointe, a 1,900-square-foot four-bedroom colonial costing $229,900 and a 2,100-square-foot four-bedroom colonial costing $239,900, were specifically designed for young couples starting out, Mr. Dubb said. A 1,500-square-foot three-bedroom ranch that was expected to appeal mostly to older couples with grown children is also attracting first-time buyers because of its $199,900 price. In the first month of sales, 25 contracts have been signed, and of those deals, 60 percent were by first-time buyers, he said.
Jennifer and Richard Peck, both 30, who are buying the $229,900 colonial, both work in eastern Suffolk, Mrs. Peck as a vice president of an insurance company in Holtsville and Mr. Peck as a service representative for an industrial equipment and supplies company in Bohemia. Until now, they have been renting a one-bedroom apartment in Centereach for $700 a month.
Taking on a house that will cost them close to $2,000 a month is "a bit scary," Mrs. Peck said, "but we felt it was time to move on to something that we own, and we definitely want to stay on Long Island, where we both grew up and where we have our family and friends."
Builders say that they can continue to build houses in the $190,000-to-$230,000 price range only as long as land prices in these outlying areas don't increase sharply, as they have farther west.
Prices, although still relatively modest, have gone up at last 20 percent in the last two years, said Jack and Frank Campo of Port Jefferson, two land developers who assemble approved subdivisions for sale to builders. Subdivision lots in Yaphank that sold for $50,000 in 1998 now cost as much as $65,000, Jack Campo said, "and by next year I expect prices to go to $70,000."
BUT that is still considerably below land prices to the west. For example, Lennard Axinn, a partner in Island Estates in Ronkonkoma, said he is planning to sell houses in a 45-lot subdivision called Island Estates at Historic Yaphank at starting prices of $279,000 for 2,000 square feet and four bedrooms. A similar house would have cost $100,000 more in Melville, he said, because of higher land costs.
Other developers have had similar experiences. At a subdivision called Windemere Pointe at Moriches, the Windemere Development Corporation of Hauppauge is building 90 houses priced from $219,000 for a 1,600-square-foot ranch to $259,000 for a 2,600-square-foot colonial. The lots are one acre in size. "I've sold similar houses in the Huntington area for almost twice that because land costs are so much higher there," said Eric Friedlander, Windemere's president.
The Park Ridge Organization of Ronkonkoma is building 109 houses in Middle Island at a development called the Preserve. Prices there start at $181,000 for a 1,400-square-foot three-bedroom ranch and go to $260,000 for a 2,750-square-foot colonial. One-car garages are included, but basements are optional and add $10,000 to the cost of a house. "You can no longer go to communities like Huntington, Smithtown and Commack and buy land that allows you to build at these prices," said Charles B. Mancini, vice president of the company. Eighty houses have been placed under contract or sold since sales began a year ago, Mr. Mancini said, and about 75 percent involve first-time buyers.
Developers say that they would build many more houses geared to this market if they could find land at a low enough price or if they could increase the number of houses per acre.
"That's one of the best markets to be in because it's always viable even in bad economic times," said Mr. Dubb of the Beechwood Organization.
And moderate prices bring buyers out in force. Since sales began in February at a development of attached houses in Oakdale, 50 of the 67 houses have been placed under contract, all purchased from plans and computer images.
The development called Willow Wood at Greenwood at Oakdale is being built by the Klar Organization of East Meadow on 22 acres that the company bought in 1988 when land costs were much lower. "When we bring out a development, we look at our costs and ask what can we bring it in at to make it affordable," said Steven A. Klar, the company's president.
The starting price at Willow Wood is $189,990 for a 1,800-square-foot two-bedroom town house. The most expensive is a three-bedroom town house with 2,160 square feet, selling for $229,990.
After two years of searching for a home, Kristina and Charles Poakeart found it at Willow Wood. They are buying a three-bedroom town house for $205,000. With a 20 percent down payment, their monthly costs including taxes will be around $1,850. They are currently living in a 400-square-foot one-bedroom apartment in Bethpage, "which we outgrew five minutes after we moved in," said Ms. Poakeart, 29, a network analyst for a book publisher in New York. Mr. Poakeart, 30, is the manager of a travel agency in Commack.
Because of the housing costs on Long Island, they were tempted at one time to move to Arizona, an area they had explored while on vacation. Housing costs there are so much lower -- $140,000 for a nice house and much lower taxes, Ms. Poakeart said.
But staying on Long Island won out. "I got a new job," she said, "and my husband got a promotion."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2364 words

HEADLINE: Road Rage, A New Jersey State of Mind

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
CALL it chutzpah -- if you want to keep it clean. When you think about it, most of the people who put down New Jersey drivers are New Yorkers.
Take New York cabbies, who can always be counted on to yell, "#@%&x*# JERSEY DRIVER!" That is, when they speak in English.
Not only do New Jersey's 5.8 million licensed drivers get no respect, they're made to feel guilty about using their 6.4 million vehicles. Environmentalists tell them they're depleting the ozone layer and demand that they take public transit -- something in New Jersey that doesn't always get you there from here -- and planners tell them their dream of more highway elbow room doesn't ease congestion but only contributes to sprawl. 
 Rather than being reviled, perhaps the New Jersey driver should be pitied, comforted and -- yes -- even admired for the way he or she faces a staggering number of obstacles and dangers every day, not the least of which are those fellow New Jersey drivers.
"I love living in New Jersey, where you see the state bird whenever you cut someone off on the highway," says Peggy Boyce, a stand-up comic. "There's so much road rage in New Jersey I had a bumper sticker made that says 'Tony Soprano on Board.' "
And why not? The New Jersey driver still pays the among the highest insurance rates, coughs up the most money for tolls after New York state and has to get up earlier and earlier to make the Hudson River crossings on the morning commute to Manhattan.
Other gripes: Toll increases on the New Jersey Turnpike. The 134,000 trucks that drive on the state's highways every day. Confusing and unreadable signs.
Not to mention the glacial implementation of E-ZPass. It's coming. It's not coming. It will be operational on the whole Garden State Parkway by June -- in time for the annual migration to the shore. Um, make that in time for the change of autumn foliage. (Get out a lawn chair and find yourself a spot on the median; it's going to be a long wait at the toll booths this summer.)
Congestion has become so bad -- in part because of the economic boom -- that James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, quips, "If your greatest ambition in life is to be stuck in traffic gridlock, this is a great time to be a New Jerseyan."
But perhaps the problem that most infuriated drivers was the implementation last December of a new privatized auto emissions inspection system that broke down because of equipment failures and staff shortages and left drivers fuming in inspection lines for as long as five hours.
What's a driver to do? Well, bask in the reflected glory, since New Jersey can take credit for the cloverleaf interchange, the drive-in theater and the Jersey barrier (the concrete center barrier, first erected on Route 22 in Plainfield in the late 1940's and now used all over the world, according to John Dourgarian, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation).
These days, Mr. Dourgarian noted, those cloverleafs are connecting many of the 34,000 miles of highway on which 60 billion vehicle miles travel every year. That, according to the New Jersey Almanac, is close to four times the national average.
On top of that, three reports made public in the last two months show that New Jerseyans drive more often -- and earlier in the day -- than most motorists. And, of course, they spend a lot of the time just sitting.
James P. Dolan, Jr. a stockbroker from Mahwah, in upper Bergen County, who began driving into Manhattan about 30 years ago, said there wasn't much to do when he got tied up in traffic at the George Washington Bridge. "I sat and listened to the radio," he said.
That is, listened to the radio and made plans. "The only solution was to buy a place in Manhattan or continue to move my schedule up an hour," he added. So last year, he bought an apartment on the East Side, where he often stays during the week.
A survey released last month by the North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority, which oversees federal transportation spending in the state's 13 northern counties, and the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council, showed that people in the metropolitan area -- including four suburban New York counties and Fairfield and New Haven in Connecticut, used their cars for 85 percent of their trips over an 18-month period.
People in Hunterdon County, for instance, used their vehicles for 90 percent of their trips; 89 percent in Morris County; 87 in Passaic, and 86 in Bergen and Union. At least 70 percent of all trips were made within a driver's home county. Bergen, the state's most populous county, led the state in the number of car trips, 3.1 million a day or 3.7 rides per person.
So it's a kind of "which came first" question. Maybe the New Jersey driver loves his car, or maybe he doesn't have a choice. Whatever the answer, transportation officials say the results highlight a severe need for expanded and affordable mass transit.
Last month, a report made public by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said traffic backups at bridge and tunnel crossings into Manhattan from New Jersey have started even earlier in the mornings and gotten worse in recent years, in part because of the booming economy, flexible hours, and a desire to get a jump on the day. From 1996 to 1999, traffic between 5 and 6 a.m. increased 32 percent at the Holland Tunnel, 39 percent at the Lincoln Tunnel and 42 percent at the the George Washington Bridge.
"Progressively, over the last five years, it's gotten to where there's as much traffic at 6:15 a.m. as there used to be at 7 a.m.," said Mr. Dolan, who now has to leave his home at 5:30 a.m. when he's not staying in the city. "Now when I drive in I try to be at the toll plaza no later than 6 a.m. Everybody's time frame has moved up an hour just to get to the same place."
He cautioned, "If you get there at 7 now, you're going to add another 45 minutes to your commute."
A study from the New Jersey Institute of Technology in March showed that New Jersey drivers spend an average of 34 hours a year stalled in traffic at a cost of $4.9 billion -- or $880 per driver in terms of man-hours away from their jobs. A total of 72 gallons of gas per driver a year is wasted.
The average driver in Somerset County -- recently labeled a part of Wealth Belt, where many of the expensive new homes have a BMW and a Land Rover in the driveway -- spent the most time staring out the window and breathing fumes, 74 hours each year, while his Bergen County counterpart sat fuming 62 hours. So much for a nice trip in the country.
In the life of New Jersey drivers, each one of these car trips can be transformed from the routine to the ridiculous -- from chickens crossing Morris Avenue to dogs wandering onto the Garden State Parkway in Kenilworth during morning the rush hour, knotting up traffic -- and some fenders -- for miles.
Such accidents -- 265,000 were reported in 1998 -- can play havoc with the Sunday driver or the semi operator. That was the case a few months ago when a tractor-trailer went out of control in Teaneck, overturning and blocking a busy ramp onto Interstate 95 that feeds northbound traffic onto Route 80 West. Traffic was stalled for three hours.
The largest traffic jam to occur on the parkway took place in April 1995 when a fast-moving brush fire in the Pine Barrens burned on both sides of the road near the Barnegat Toll Plaza, said Dennis Ingoglia, a spokesman for the parkway. It backed up traffic for nine miles and took about two hours for traffic to just start moving again.
"It's a nightmare," said Morgan Borin, a pharmaceutical saleswoman from Ramsey, in Bergen County. "I see an accident at least once a week on the Parkway."
Mrs. Borin, who estimates she travels 200 miles a day throughout Essex and Union, said, "I think people are driving more aggressively, and it seems there's always construction on the main roads, and that makes it worse."
But at least there is the landscaping. Sort of. Workers on the parkway say they have have found everything from beach balls to furniture, including a piano, decorating the shoulder.
And if isn't the flotsam and jetsam, it's the smell.
Mrs. Borin's husband, Frank, said he especially dislikes traveling on the stretch of turnpike around Newark and Elizabeth -- "a very difficult roadway" -- because of the unpleasant stew of cars and belching trucks going to Port Elizabeth, the airport and landfills in the area. Getting in and out of the airport is another "nightmare," he said, in part because of confusing signs and lack of parking.
"Once you pay your parking fee and you're leaving the airport, you have to know exactly where you're going, because it's confusing getting on the turnpike or 78," Mr. Borin said. "There's a lot of construction; the roads get very narrow; and it's not well lit. And it seems it's gotten progressively worse." Ms. Boyce, the comic,, says she goes out of her way to avoid the turnpike. "I had a gig at Rutgers a couple years ago, was coming home late and sort of got sandwiched in between two, huge speeding trucks and couldn't get out," Ms. Boyce said. "It's just very intimidating."
Though truck traffic is heavy on major thoroughfares like the turnpike, it has become a little less intimidating on secondary roads since New Jersey last year restricted large trucks from using many local roads unless they're making pick-ups or deliveries.
Increased truck shipments are just one result of the extraordinary economic growth, which has also contributed to 465,000 jobs in the state since 1992, Mr. Hughes said. "It has put a strain on the infrastructure that has only had minimum improvements," he said.
Oh, not that New Jersey has not tried its hand at improving the snarls and sneers and shouting and slowdowns. For one thing, officials say tie-ups at toll plazas are expected to ease when E-ZPass is in full operation -- although a sluggish start and logistical proglems have left New Jersey as the monkey in the middle of the Northeast megalopolis. It has been implemented in stages on the Parkway as far south as the Raritan toll plaza and is in operation on the Atlantic City Expressway.
How convenient it will be is one thing, but John McElligott, an engineer from Ridgewood, says he may buy an E-ZPass just for self-preservation.
"I've come out of toll booths on the Parkway after stopping to pay a toll and almost been hit by someone coming through the E-ZPass lane at 30 miles an hour," Mr. McElligott said.
Stephen G. Carrellas, state coordinator of the National Motorists Association, said a high-speed entry system for E-ZPass users was a good idea If fact, Mr. Carrellas said, if more than two-thirds of the state's motorists had the electronic cards in their cars that allowed equipment to record their passage, most toll barriers could be removed -- a notion that has been discussed for years.
"The good news about E-ZPass being delayed is it will prevent the toll increase on the Turnpike to the end of the year," said Mr. Carrellas, referring to a 20 percent percent toll increase for non-EZPass users to be enacted when the E-ZPass becomes operative on that road.
Driving in New Jersey is indeed a challenge. But isn't it true that the most challenging courses -- in golf at least -- are the most expensive? Well, same here, speedo.
William Visser, manager of Public and Government Services for AAA of North Jersey in Wayne, said drivers used to complain much more about paying among the highest automobile insurance premiums in the nation, but piped down a bit after the state imposed mandatory 15 percent reductions last spring.
More recently, Mr. Visser said, they complained about the new emissions inspection system that got off to a sputtering start last December. "We got more complaints about that than anything in recent history," he said. "Nobody likes to sit in line, and those lines never should have happened."
On Jan. 26, Governor Whitman ordered the new test stopped at 15 of the the state's 32 inspection stations. But last month, the more stringent inspection procedure was reinstituted in six stations, and is expected to be in full operation by month's end. By the way, at 9:15 a.m. last Monday at the Paramus station, the posted waiting time was 40 minutes. At the Lodi station,, it was 75 minutes.
"We had a crush at the end of the month and at the beginning of the month," said Mr. Dourgarian. "But generally speaking, last week the average waiting time was half an hour."
The next major gripe for drivers could be having to pump their own gas. Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Bergen Republican, said drivers could save five cents a gallon, gas up faster and only pay a five-cent differential for full service.
But people like Robert Hallbauer, a retired quality engineer from Edison, insists most people don't want to pump their own gas, particularly in bad weather. Mr. Hallbauer questioned the savings in terms of both time and money.
"It's more like 10 to 20 cents in other states, when you can find full-serve stations," he said. "In high-risk areas where you have a gas station where they don't trust you, you have to prepay and then go out and pump your gas. Then you go back in and stand behind somebody buying something. It's not a time saver."
Not a time saver? Then step on it. Since spring 1998, 65 miles per hour has been the speed limit on 475 miles of highway. After an 18-month study, the state found that the total number of accidents in those zones were up 18 percent. although fatalities were down 8 percent. Next step: another 18-month study.
Just last Monday, a stricter seat belt law went into effect allowing the police to stop and ticket motorists for not wearing their belts. "I think the New Jersey driver is very able to cope with situations," Mr. Visser of AAA said.
And apparently New Jersey drivers are better driver than their New York counterparts give them credit for. "Eighty-eight percent of all New Jersey licensed drivers have no points on their driving record," Mr. Dourgarian said.
You know those aggressive New Yorkers, though. They probably thought points were good.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Kirstin Boncher, David Bank

 BODY:
Kirstin Royle Boncher and David Jason Bank were married on Thursday by Homer Richardson, a magistrate, at the courthouse in the Valley, Anguilla. A Jewish ceremony was performed last evening by Rabbi David Gelfand at the Eden Rock, a hotel on St. Jean Bay on St. Bart's.
Ms. Boncher, 30, is keeping her name. She is a painter and printer whose most recent works were displayed in January at the Limner Gallery in Manhattan. She received bachelor's and master's degrees in painting from Hunter College. The bride is a daughter of Lynn Epstein of East Hampton, N.Y., and William Boncher of Tucson, and a stepdaughter of Stuart Epstein. Her mother and stepfather own Devlin McNiff Real Estate, an agency in East Hampton. Her father, who is retired, was a professor of economics at Seton Hall University. 
 Mr. Bank, 31, is a director in securities research covering telecommunications in the Manhattan office of ING Barings, an investment bank based in Amsterdam. He received a bachelor's degree in political economy from Williams College and a master's degree in public and private management from Yale University. He is a son of Sandra Bank and Gerald Bank of Brooklyn. His mother, who is retired, taught English at John Wilson Junior High School in Brooklyn. His father is a New York City housing court judge.

HEADLINE: Bringing a Town House Back Full Circle

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
JEFFERY AND FAITH LARSEN of Greenwich, Conn., have been anticipating life in an empty nest, now that their children are 14 and 15 years old. So they have decided to move to a new nest. That nest, it turns out, will be an old one, a four-story town house on East 62nd Street built in 1870 and expanded to five stories in 1919.
When the Larsens move in -- the target date is January -- they will join a small but impassioned band of city dwellers who are bringing town houses full circle back to their origins as single-family homes after decades of being subdivided into apartments. Projects like the Larsens' require stamina, determination -- and more than likely a great deal of money. 
 Mr. Larsen, the chief executive of ICor Brokerage Inc., a four-month-old company that offers business-to-business online brokerage services, said that he paid more than $2 million for the house and estimated that the renovation costs would probably hit $1.5 million.
Last month, 10 studio apartments in the building and a duplex that once housed an art gallery were demolished. In addition, the facade will be rebuilt to its original state, a step that has gotten the required approval of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
"It was really ugly, and now it will be really beautiful," Mr. Larsen said. "I want to bring it back to the look and feel of a block in a historical district."
Restoring the house to exactly what it was in 1870 is an almost impossible task, though. "Because a fifth floor was added, we can't make it look exactly is it did, so we must be innovative," Mr. Larsen said. "We are putting on a mansard roof with two dormers."
That the Larsens have seized a rare opportunity is clear, but just how rare is impossible to measure.
No definitive figures exist for the number of town houses in the city. A computer analysis of city property records by The New York Times, using descriptions that would suggest town houses, found 4,400 buildings in Manhattan and 15,200 in Brooklyn that fell within the parameters. Those figures were arrived at by counting the number of residential buildings of three to five stories on lots less than 25 feet wide. The buildings had no more than 12 units and were built before 1905, after which few town houses were constructed in Manhattan.
Other estimates vary widely. For example, figures taken from the city's Department of Finance by the Real Estate Board of New York put the total number in Manhattan at 1,386, a mere sliver of the borough's residential market, which includes 200,000 co-ops and 65,000 condominiums, according to the board's estimate. For Brooklyn, Steven Knobel, the executive vice president of Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson, an appraisal firm, said, "Our guess is that there are somewhere around 45,000 town houses."
Last year, according to the Real Estate Board of New York, 145 town houses changed hands in Manhattan. The single-family town house is experiencing a something of a renaissance, a trend that has been accelerating in recent years, brokers say, bringing back a style of gracious living in buildings that don't soar to the sky and dwarf their neighbors.
"For a time the single-family house in Manhattan became almost extinct," said Tim Desmond, a town house broker at Stribling & Associates. "In the 1920's, with the advent of big apartment buildings, apartment living came into vogue, and houses went out of favor. That left housing stock that was chopped up into 4 to 12 units."
Many of the apartments in buildings with three or more units were subject to rent control or rent stabilization, limiting the profits the landlord could reap. After 1986, they lost even more luster as investments, when federal tax laws were changed to significantly restrict their use as tax shelters. But other factors were emerging to make the single-family house a diamond on the market, although sometimes a diamond in the rough. Those factors include a soaring economy, a dwindling supply of large prewar co-ops and a growing resistance to what some prospective buyers describe as the tyranny of co-op boards.
"Now we are again in a gilded age in New York, but unlike the turn of the century, there is no vacant land, so people are reconverting these buildings," said Frederick W. Peters, the president of Ashforth Warburg Associates.
Brokers say that their clients have numerous motives. "With a different perception of safety in the city, people who might not have thought of doing it 10 years ago are today, and people who 10 years ago might not have been in a position to utilize the entire house are now," said George W. van der Ploeg, a vice president at Alice F. Mason Ltd.
"We are seeing a trend toward larger, more opulent houses," he said. "A town house is probably 5,000 square feet, bigger than most apartments, and that makes a statement. In addition, some people chafe at the concept of the co-op board having so much power, from approving the buyer to approving the renovation."
And, many brokers say, compared with the square footage of a co-op or condominium, a town house offers a bargain.
"You get a lot more bang -- or space -- for the buck," said Barbara Fox, the president of the Fox Residential Group. "Say you live in a 20-foot-wide house that is 60 feet deep. For five floors, that gives you 6,000 square feet. You would have to have an immense apartment to equal that. Plus you probably get a garden in the back, you may get a terrace, and you can improve the roof and have a sun deck. It is not cheap, but it is a lot cheaper than getting the same interior and exterior space in a co-op."
The trend seems to have no geographical limits. In Manhattan, houses are being snapped up on the East and West Sides, uptown and downtown, from Harlem to Greenwich Village.
"There are no undesirable neighborhoods for this in Manhattan," Mr. Peters said, but he did agree that there are some blocks that command special attention. "Notoriously, the most desirable street is 70th Street between Park and Lex. It is famous for some incredibly beautiful buildings."
In Brooklyn, where town houses have long been dominant in some neighborhoods, the market is surging as well. Brooklyn Heights, the oldest landmarked district in the country, commands the highest prices, $2 million to $3.5 million, said Christopher Thomas, a senior vice president and the sales director for William B. May in Brooklyn. "And we are doing a lot of business in neighborhoods we didn't go into three years ago, like Fort Greene and Clinton Hill," he said. In Fort Greene houses are going for $700,000 to $1 million.
Melinda Magnett, the president of the Corcoran Group in Brooklyn, said: "Prices are soaring here, though they are nowhere near those in Manhattan. A vice president of Juno.com and his wife who are now renting on the Upper East Side are buying the first-ever million-dollar brownstone in Clinton Hill and converting it to a single-family."
The demand has led, not surprisingly, to bidding wars. Richard Steinberg, managing director of Ashforth Warburg, put a single-family house at 161 East 62nd Street on the market last month for $3,150,000. "Within four hours I had three full-price offers," he said. "We went to sealed bids and sold it over the asking price by $150,000." Should the deal fall through, he said he had two backup offers in hand.
Mr. Steinberg is also the representative for Premiere Properties of Manhattan, a company owned by a British investor, Michael Cannon.
"He knew there was a shortage in the New York market of high-end single-family homes, so two years ago he decided to buy multiunit buildings as long as they could be delivered vacant, renovate them and resell them," Mr. Steinberg said. "So far, he has done two, including a building on East 66th Street that he bought for $3,750,000 and sold for $7,250,000."
From the buyer's perspective, the single most critical consideration in the decision to convert a town house that contains four or more units is whether those apartment are occupied and whether they are rent-controlled or rent-stabilized.
Tenants who are not protected by rent control or stabilization can be legally evicted at the end of their leases. To evict a rent-controlled tenant, the owner must obtain an order from the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal verifying the owner's compelling need for the apartment and then must start court proceedings.
Stabilized tenants are protected, too, but Housing Court can authorize evictions at the end of the lease if the apartment is to be occupied by the owner or an immediate member of the family. People age 62 and over or people with disabilities may not be evicted from a stabilized apartment on the grounds of the owner's need for it unless the landlord provides a comparable apartment nearby at the same or lower rent.
With all these conditions standing as potential barriers to the full conversion of a town house, many prospective buyers make it a condition of sale that the building be empty, and many sellers make payments to tenants to move.
Steve Mark, a general contractor who bought a 10,000-square-foot mansion at 8 East 77th Street for himself and his family of six, did that when his bid on the building was accepted. "When we bought it, it had three or four tenants, and our contract was subject to its being vacant," he said. "We gave the seller six months and then could have broken the contract. There was one holdout, so we gave another three months, but they had to pay him $250,000."
H OUSES converted to single-family status by previous owners or ones that can be emptied by the sellers are worth significantly more than those with tenants in residence. Sara Gelbard, a senior vice president of the Corcoran Group who specializes in Greenwich Village, Chelsea and Gramercy Park, recently closed on a house in Chelsea with a duplex apartment and two floor-throughs for $1,750,000, a sum she described as unusually low. "Two doors down there is a house on the market that has been renovated for single-family with an asking price of $2.6 million," she said.
"My recommendation is never to buy anything with the intention of kicking people out," she added. "Offer either to buy them another place or settle with them. You have to be creative."
She gave this example: "Several years ago, I had an owner who bought co-ops for two tenants, relocated them and is allowing them to stay for life, and then he will own the apartments."
Even the wispiest of hints that a building may be for sale is likely to strike fear in the hearts of tenants.
"We are getting more calls all the time over the issue of owner occupancy," said Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants & Neighbors Coalition. "We are seeing more and more eviction cases being brought against tenants in rent-regulated apartments in smaller buildings. Some of those times it's because landlords want to occupy the entire building and other times because they simply want to charge market rents."
Mr. McKee would like to see the laws amended so that rent-stabilized tenants would have the stronger protections rent-controlled tenants have, and he favors limiting the number of apartments a landlord can take over. "That would make people safe in their own homes," he said. "There are cases when the owners act in good faith and other times when they use occupancy as a ruse. They simply have a relative live there for a few months."
Although empty buildings fetch higher prices, there are still some owners who want -- or need -- the income generated from tenants to help carry the mortgage or provide a sense of security. And some brokers, Paul Massey, the president of Massey Knakal Realty Services, among them, contend that "buying such a building is absolutely worth it."
"If you value a building with a stabilized tenant in it and you put a value on the same building were it to be empty, there is a huge leap in value that allows you to pay the tenant," he said. "If there are three or four tenants, you get more of a break."
To illustrate: "The average multiple-unit dwelling in the city sells for about $200 a square foot," he said, "and the average single-family residence for $500 to $1,300 a square foot."
When San Orr, an investment banker, and his wife, Sarah, an owner of Babybox.com, a Web site that sells baby gifts, began looking for a town house last year in the Park Slope and Fort Greene, they considered renting out part of whatever they bought for the income it would generate.
"Then we decided not to, because we found a house where we didn't need the rental income," said Mr. Orr. He would not divulge the price he paid for the house, which is in Fort Greene. "We have two dogs, and we are expecting a baby in August," he added, "and we wanted not to have to worry about people coming and going. We also felt that we would best be able to restore the initial character of the building in its entirety rather than just using one apartment."
Once a building is empty, the process of transforming it into a single-family residence can take a year or more.
"Though in some ways it is more difficult to do a house than an apartment," said Mr. Mark, who has been the contractor on several town houses and is now doing his own, "logistically it is easier. You don't have to have the plans approved by the co-op board or the building's architect, only by the city. You can work 10 hours a day, not 5."
The scope of the project helps, too. "In any renovation, the more you do, the easier it is," he said. "Trying to make new work blend into existing conditions is the most difficult. If you totally gut a place, it may cost more and take more time, but it is less difficult."
But one buyer's difficulty may be another buyer's nightmare. Whenever he hears a building described as having "good bones," Warren Pearl, a contractor who has been renovating town houses in Manhattan for 30 years, becomes suspicious.
"Clients and architects say that all the time," he said, "and what they don't realize is that they are all wrecks, simply because they were converted a long time ago, probably with improperly done structural modifications to accommodate all those kitchens and bathrooms."
Mr. Pearl estimates a renovation will cost 50 percent of the purchase price. "If you pay $6 million, it will cost approximately $3 million," he said. "In terms of square footage, high-end residential jobs are about $300 to $400 per square foot."
Renovating town houses in New York City presents unique challenges. "You have problems here you don't see anywhere else in the country," Mr. Pearl said. "You have attached houses and sometimes one wall is not attached. Manhattan is filled with underground streams, which is why buildings often lean, and there are flooding problems people aren't even aware of."
Among the more serious flaws he encounters are joists damaged by walls, plumbing and electric lines added when the house was converted to apartments, and water damage from inadequately caulked bathtubs and leaky radiators and roofs. "People don't understand the scope and extent of work that is necessary," he said.
That certainly proved true for a woman who moved into a house on the East Side with her husband and three children in February. It was not until the building had been gutted during a year of construction work that they were told that the joists -- the beams that hold up floors and ceilings -- were collapsing.
"The most important thing I learned from the experience was to remain calm when the surprises come," said the woman, who spoke about her experiences only on condition that her name not be used. "The biggest thing for me was to tackle the problem of the day, and every day there were new problems, electrical, plumbing, joists. If you don't like dealing with problems, this is not for you."
M ICHAEL HOURIHAN, a former tax lawyer who is now commercial real estate developer, has converted two brownstones in Manhattan. He is still recovering from a structural surprise. "I usually live in the houses myself for a while before selling them, but my most recent one I ended up selling quicker than I had anticipated," he said.
Last spring, Mr. Hourihan bought a house on East 69th Street that had been built in the 1870's and converted to a rooming house in the 1930's. Gutted by fire about 30 years ago, it was rebuilt into a four-family residence. When he bought it, Mr. Hourihan intended to carve out a duplex for himself, retain two rental apartments to carry the mortgage and then take over the whole building for his own use in a few years.
"In the process of doing cosmetic renovations in the rental space, we discovered structural flaws that were a result of the renovation after the fire, stuff even an architect and engineer who came through couldn't see," he said.
The necessary repairs would have been so extensive, he said, that "once I had to do that level of rip-out, I decided it would be too costly to put in kitchens and bathrooms for the apartments only to rip them out in a few years when I wanted to change it to a single-family," he said. Instead, he skipped right to the final renovation.
"I moved in for a short while, but it didn't make sense to be paying the heavy mortgage, so I put it on the market around Thanksgiving, and it will close on April 25." He bought the building for $1.4 million, he said, and spent $350,000 in renovations that would have cost far more had he not been in the business. He is selling it for $2.7 million.
By comparison, the house the Orrs bought in Brooklyn needed relatively little repair. Since it only contained one rental apartment, whose kitchen and bathroom they have already removed, they did not have to gut it. "It was renovated with new electrical and plumbing systems in the late 1970's, so the renovation is mainly to change it from a two-family to a one-family house rather than major structural changes," Ms. Orr said.
They took down a 25-foot wall that had been put up to keep the stairway private and are installing 10-inch steel beams to prevent floors from sagging.
Meanwhile, the woman who is renovating the East Side town house is moving into the home stretch, picking out knobs, putting up house numbers at the front door, installing lighting fixtures.
The unexpected crises are now a memory. "I thought my house would be nice, but I never thought it would be this beautiful," she said. "It's great having a basement for storage, having a place to put bills, having a basketball net in the backyard, being able to open the door and just walking outside without going into an elevator."
But there is one break she has yet to make. "You definitely miss the handyman," she said. "So I have hired the handyman from my old building to come in one Sunday a month."

HEADLINE: For Expatriate Families, A Home Away From Home;
Foreign Enclaves Dot the Landscape as County Attracts Temporary Residents

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
IT is a glorious spring morning, the daffodils standing at attention outside Bernice Woodbury's white Colonial on one of Scarsdale's prettiest streets. Inside are nine women, babies and toddlers in tow, eating bagels and swapping shopping tips and vacation ideas. But in one important way this is not a typical Westchester play group: the happy chatter has the long, flat accent of Australia, with a sprinkle of New Zealand and Scotland.
"This is a chance to get out and have a talk and a cup of tea," said Carolyn Broughan, an Australian mother of three who lives with her husband, Patrick, in nearby Edgemont. "You leave all your family and friends at home, and it can get lonely." 
 They call themselves expatriates -- well-to-do Germans, Japanese, Australians, French and other foreign nationals who have found their way to Westchester after being transferred by their companies to New York City.
For Americans familiar with Ernest Hemingway, the term "expatriate" conjures up images of youthful decadence. But the county's expatriate community has nothing in common with the dissolute and aimless characters in "The Sun Also Rises."
In many ways, the expatriates of Westchester, who live side by side with Americans 2in some of the county's most desirable towns and villages, have blended so seamlessly into suburban life -- with mothers shuttling children from play dates to practices -- that it is easy to miss them.
But their numbers have been growing, along with the global economy. And as foreign families struggle to adapt to a new culture for an average of three to five years while preserving a bit of their own, they are adding a multinational effervescence to the county, with certain towns acting as magnets for particular nationalities.
Snapping in the wind high above German School New York in White Plains are the American, Austrian, German and Swiss flags. The new Auray Cheese Shop in Larchmont, where the French-American School of New York is situated, offers 80 French cheeses along with crusty baguettes, truffle oil and French chocolates. ("We realized there was a huge French community here, and nobody was doing cheese," said Dale Saffir, who owns the shop with her husband, Warren Reid.) Japanese produce and packaged foods fill the aisles of Meidi-Ya, a Japanese market in Hartsdale, while the Japanese-owned Parisienne bakery next door sells traditional buns filled with sweet red-bean paste.
"Everything has gotten very international," said Ruth Chizzini, director of relocation for Julia B. Fee, a real estate agency with offices in Rye, Larchmont and Scarsdale. "We're getting a lot of people from London, Switzerland, France, Germany and Singapore. They're always interested in the schools, and they like to be close to the city if they can."
Indeed, lower Westchester, where a number of towns are increasingly identified with one or more nationalities, is beginning to resemble a map of the world. Sometimes, a family wants to be near a foreign school. Other times, a company will steer employees to particular suburbs where they may even own houses, as a couple of Australian banks do in Scarsdale. Then there is the snowball effect, in which couples gravitate toward towns that already have hefty numbers of their compatriots.
The French have congregated in Larchmont as well as in nearby Mamaroneck and New Rochelle (a city that, coincidentally, was settled by French Huguenots in the late 1600's). The Germans have overwhelmingly chosen White Plains as their temporary hometown, but they can also be found in Rye, Scarsdale and Mamaroneck. Australians, New Zealanders and Brazilians prefer Scarsdale and Rye, in that order. And the Japanese, whose Westchester presence has shrunk in recent years because of the faltering Japanese economy, are still enamored of Scarsdale, although they also look for houses and apartments in Rye, Harrison, Hartsdale and Eastchester.
Scarsdale, in fact, is famous in Japan, standing for quality schools and housing.
"It's a brand name, and the Japanese like brand goods and brand names," said Kuniko Katz, a Japanese expatriate who raised a family in Scarsdale after marrying an American social studies teacher years ago. Last year, Mrs. Katz, who has tried to bridge the gap between the two cultures, founded Japan America Community Outreach, a nonprofit organization, which helps Japanese expatriates become acclimated to American society while introducing Westchester residents to Japanese life.
Wherever they are, expatriates tend to live in impressive homes in costly neighborhoods, the result of generous housing allowances that can hit $8,000 a month and up. (One exception of late are the Japanese who are being sent over in less senior positions, with smaller allowances.) "You've got to be paid a premium to uproot your family, and expatriates are compensated well enough that they tend to live in nice places," said Joseph C. Snyder, president of the American Australian Association, a business and social organization in Manhattan.
Most expatriates prefer to rent rather than buy, since they are here for a relatively short time. The trick, however, is finding a house to rent in an overheated real estate market. "Everybody wants to sell, and you're the odd one out," said Brigitte Marquardt, who heads a newcomer's club for German-speaking expatriates. Although the County Planning Department does not have numbers to document the presence of expatriates, real estate agents and officials of foreign schools report an increase in numbers among several nationalities.
Some expatriates, like Patrick Croze of Larchmont, who arrived in New York from France on business in 1983, find life in Westchester County so pleasant that they end up staying. "I was transferred here for three years," he said, "and I'm still here."
Mr. Croze, 53, is now the director of finance for the French-American School of New York, a bilingual, bicultural private school with 620 students on two campuses -- in Larchmont and Mamaroneck -- and a waiting list of 120. In 1992, Mr. Croze became an American citizen. Twice a year, he and his family return to France to visit friends and family who often question his decision to become a Yankee.
"I tell them it's good to have one foot on each side," he said. "I find life here very easy. Everything is ordered and clean and extremely safe. In Europe, there is the idea that people here are always killing each other. But New York is safer than Paris."
Of course, it doesn't hurt that French culture in the Larchmont area has evolved to the point that there is a French newcomer's club (with activities almost daily and not only for newcomers), a French theater group, a French bakery and even a doctor who speaks French fluently. In fact, one reason so many French people "stick around" Larchmont, Mr. Croze said, is to be near Dr. Philip Heinegg, an American family practitioner who studied medicine in France and is married to a French woman.
"It's one thing to communicate in a foreign language when you're doing business," said Dr. Heinegg, whose practice in Larchmont treats 300 French patients. "But when there is something wrong with you physically or emotionally you need to talk about it in your mother tongue."
For women, the expatriate experience can be especially tough. All are torn from friends and family, and many leave behind careers as well. Once in the United States, only the husbands qualify for work visas. Friendships with Americans can be elusive, and husbands typically work long hours and travel frequently on business.
The expatriate social organizations are a crucial outlet. Members of the German newcomer's club have visited the Lower East Side Tenement Museum in Manhattan and toured historic mansions in the Hudson Valley. The French Welcome Service, which puts out a newsletter four times a year, organizes crafts projects, bridge games, morning jogs, cooking classes, book discussions and play groups for its members.
There is some intermingling between nationalities, too. Though largely Australian, the Scarsdale play group, which meets every other week, also includes women from New Zealand, the Netherlands, England, Scotland and Germany.
But even more valuable than the formal networks, expatriates say, are the loose circles of friends that function like surrogate families. Jacque Yates, an Australian mother of two in Scarsdale, said she recently sent her baby sitter to the home of a neighbor, another Australian, who needed someone to watch her children while she went to the doctor.
"You bend over backward because everybody's in the same boat," Mrs. Yates said. "We don't have mothers and relatives here, so we help each other out at the drop of a hat."
Perhaps nothing provides so strong a reminder of home as food, and expatriates are expert at tracking down authentic providers. Karl Ehmer Quality Meats, with three stores in Westchester, and Atlantic Meat Market in Norwalk are must stops for self-respecting Germans in search of classic German sausage.
For Mr. Croze, the Frenchman, a stroll down Arthur Avenue in the Bronx, the popular street of Italian food markets, satisfies a certain longing. "It's like shopping in Europe," he said. "There are all these little shops, and you can speak Italian to the people."
At times it can seem as if expatriates have built parallel societies for themselves, between the socializing and the schools (there is a Japanese elementary school in Greenwich and a Japanese high school in Purchase). But many foreign nationals say they relish the chance to experience American culture firsthand. And it is not only the children who want to pass for an American.
Ian M. Phillips, executive vice president and general manager of the Americas for the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, who lives in Scarsdale, said one of his greatest goals was to be able to use telephone voice-recognition systems successfully, which so far have been tripped up by his New Zealand accent. "I'm absolutely sure that some day I'll get that down pat," he said. "Another three years."
Even the German School in White Plains, which receives funds from the German, Austrian and Swiss governments, takes pride in its American attributes, from its softball program to multi-ethnic food.
"Our cafeteria is run by a French caterer, the cook is Italian and all the service aides are South American," Wolfgang Ditscheid, the principal, said. "When you go through our school corridors, you hear our kids speak English."
Befriending Americans, at least for the adults, is sometimes difficult, however. Many Americans in Westchester, expatriates say, are too busy for their existing friends to take on new friends who will eventually leave. A language barrier can make relations harder still.
Mrs. Katz, the cultural go-between for the Japanese, is adamant that Japanese women reach out to American women. The sharing of Japanese rituals, in her mind, is a perfect opening.
In March, she organized a Japanese Festival at the Eastchester Library, with 15 Japanese women demonstrating the art of the tea ceremony, calligraphy, flower arranging and origami for 60 American women and children. In May, Mrs. Katz's organization, Japan America Community Outreach, plans a series of similar demonstrations at the Scarsdale Historical Society.
In the early 1990's, tensions flared in Scarsdale after a sharp influx of Japanese families there; one magazine article spoke ominously of "The Japanning of Scarsdale."
"They were coming one after another in the school system, and it was very hard for the teachers and the community members," Mrs. Katz said. "All of a sudden there were Japanese everywhere. But then people got used to it, and the Japanese also started to leave one by one."
As she loaded daikon, bamboo shoots and green tea into her cart at Meidi-Ya, Tsuru N. Hiroshima, a Japanese expatriate who lives with her husband, Koji, in Hartsdale, agreed that newcomers needed to make the first move. Recently, she showed some fellow members of the Scarsdale Golf Club different ways to prepare tofu. "You have to sell yourself if you are in a foreign country," Mrs. Hiroshima said. "You can't wait for people to come to you."
Regardless of nationality, most expatriates appear to like American life more than they dislike it. Yes, there are mild irritations along with profound qualms: American dependence on the automobile, capital punishment, puritanical views, to name a few.
But expatriates also gush about American politeness. They rave about Westchester County's open space and New York City's cultural riches. They admire the community involvement of residents. And they cannot get over the weather: one expatriate likened Westchester's light to that of Tuscany. There is, they say, a lot to miss.
"It will be hard," said Kirsten Thoma-Cerny, a German lawyer who is returning with her family to Frankfurt this summer after seven years in Harrison. "We got accustomed very much to this country. The Americans make it easy."
 
Helping to Make The Living Easier
 
The economics of being an expatriate can be fairly attractive. Many families receive generous housing allowances, which rise along with an executive's corporate rank. Companies often pick up the tab, too, for private schools, furniture and trips home to visit family and friends.
 
What follows is a snapshot of the financial package given to one Australian family in Scarsdale. The couple, who have two children, agreed to describe the perks of living abroad on the condition that their names not be used.
 
Despite his company's largesse, the executive said his family's life style here was not lavish. "We're living in a similar standard to how we would in Australia," he said. "But everything is more expensive here." While his salary is paid in Australian dollars, the stipends for housing and other costs are paid in American dollars.
 
HOUSING ALLOWANCE: The family gets $7,000 a month to spend on rental housing, a sum that nets a choice selection of homes, even in Scarsdale. But house rentals are scarce. "We looked for six or seven weeks," the executive said of the family's search throughout the county. "We looked at seven houses a day and by the afternoon, the houses were gone."
 
SCHOOLS: While some companies pay tuition for private schools, the Australian family is on its own. But the ample housing allowance enables them to live in one of Westchester County's finest school districts, and, of course, there is no language barrier.
 
FURNITURE RENTAL: When they arrived, the couple went to a furniture showroom and picked out an instant interior for their three-bedroom house, from sofas and beds to rugs and lamps. The company pays the $600 a month it costs to rent the furniture.
 
UTILITIES: The company throws in another $600 a month to cover the family's utility expenses, which include phone, gas heat and electricity.
 
HOME LEAVE: Once a year, the company flies the family back to Australia. The cost of the round-trip, business-class fares is $15,000.
 LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
In Princeton, Housing Prices Eclipse Their SAT's

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
In the Princeton real estate market, pleading cannot hurt. When David Campbell and Amanda Rose saw a house they wanted a few weeks ago, listed at $239,000, they enclosed in their sealed bid a letter and a picture of their year-old daughter.
They won the competition, with an offer of $250,000, after months of watching prices rise and preparing to pounce. "It was clear that if waited we might not get this house," Ms. Rose said, "and there might not be any other house." 
 And so another house departed the superheated housing market here, where the general rule these days is that if you see anything advertised, it has already been sold. Real estate agents and buyers describe bidding wars -- four or five offers is not uncommon -- with mortgage contingencies scratched. Their best guesses are that prices have risen by a third since last summer.
"We're hotter than any other market in New Jersey," said Catherine McCool, the manager of the Gloria Nilson real estate office in Princeton. Ms. McCool measures the heat by the number of buyers lined up; she estimates that the traffic in her office has quintupled in three or four years.
Peter Blicher, president of the Central Jersey Builders Association, measures the heat by the multiple-listings book for Mercer County.
Searching for a ruler during a telephone interview, Mr. Blicher said: "A year ago it was probably two inches thick. It's now less than an inch."
To be sure, Princeton is not the only frenzied market. While the median price of existing homes across the state has been roughly in line with the inflation rate -- the New Jersey Association of Realtors reported an increase to $166,800 last year from $162,400 in 1998 -- there are plenty of hot spots.
Timothy Richards, president-elect of the Realtors association, said prices were shooting up in pockets of Bergen, Monmouth, Morris and Essex counties, too. "The baby boomers are out there buying their buns off," Mr. Richards said.
In Princeton, as in most places, the lower and middle ranges is where the pain is, said Robin L. Wallack, a broker with Nilson.
But here, "middle range" means $400,000 to $700,000. Ms. Wallack said it had probably been a year since she heard of anything under $100,000, and the current listings, slim as they are, show a healthy bulge over $1 million.
"That's about the going rate for bigger houses near the university," Ms. Wallack said as she pointed out some recently sold properties. One of them, a well-kept ranch house on a half-acre, brought more than $500,000. It is now back on the market, offered by a builder with plans to demolish it and build a new one for $1.3 million.
"I've seen a lot of comings and goings," she said, "but I've never seen a market like this, ever."
And a million dollars cannot buy most of the new houses rising in northwestern Princeton Township, a kind of woodsy frontier where a few dozen buildable lots have been carved out. Of the few remaining, a four-acre parcel off Drakes Corner Road is listed at $639,000; a four-acre lot closer to town is listed at $795,000.
"Lots in the Princeton area have probably gone up $100,000 in the last six months," said Mr. Blicher, whose company, Westrum-Pennington Properties, is finishing a development in Hopewell Township where prices start in the$600,000's. "I have to look anywhere in the state just to find property to build on."
Tom Vogt, a molecular biology professor, said he and his wife were "awestruck" by the prices but bought a one-acre lot in Princeton Township last year for $350,000 -- and then watched prices rise around them. Now they are designing a house while living in their university apartment, though Mr. Vogt acknowledges that like everyone else in Princeton he is unable to stop watching the market.
"It's gotten to the point where people are ringing doorbells, saying, 'I'd buy your house if you'd sell it,' " he said. He mentioned a street in his neighborhood where houses that sold for $500,000 two years ago were bringing $780,000. "Friends of ours there were delighted to hear us regale them with stories about prices," he added.
For Ms. Rose, a graduate student at Rutgers, and Mr. Campbell, who teaches at the College of Staten Island, buying was a quick march -- though their transaction was a little slow by Princeton standards. "We started looking on a Thursday," Ms. Rose said. "My husband saw the house Friday, I saw it Saturday, on Monday morning we put in a bid, and on Tuesday it was accepted."
Debbie and Ed Soffen claimed their new house within a day -- a day they had begun with no intention of buying anything.
The Soffens, both doctors, have lived in Princeton for nine years, and wanting to stay in their neighborhood, bought a small house on a large lot two years ago with a rather leisurely plan to replace the house with a bigger one.
As of a month ago, they were working with an architect to design the new house when they received a call: a house on Carnegie Lake, where they had always wanted to live, was going on the market. When they saw it, they decided to buy before they walked out the door.
"When I was trying to describe the house to the insurance company, I couldn't quite remember," Mr. Soffen said. "They were asking, 'Well, what's it made of? What are the floors made of?' I hadn't been in it long enough."
Within two weeks, their first house was sold. They plan to list the second soon. "We wanted to do it one at a time to keep it a little sane," Ms. Soffen said.
At real estate agencies, "agents used to check the computer once a day," said Anne Kearns, manager of the Prudential Fox & Roach office in Princeton. "Now we're checking every hour, every half-hour."
Even if the stock market falters, real estate experts say, the corporate expansions and the local start-ups under way around Princeton seem to dictate a longer life for the longest and strongest market ever.
Mr. Blicher, predicting that new construction could not ease a statewide housing shortage any time soon, added that prices were shooting up especially fast here "because Princeton is just so desirable."
And there will always be a Princeton. For decades, the town has generated stories of the quest for a place in the right ZIP code (that would be 08540 or 08542) and even waiting lists for a post office box within. And in the current issue of Town Topics, a long, loving ad for a $575,000 ranch house end with a common consolation prize: "In Lawrence Township, with a Princeton address."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL;
Seeking a Line in the Sand

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: PORT ELIZABETH

 BODY:
The traffic is already thickening in this tiny old town, and by the end of the month the weekends will deliver thousands of Philadelphians from the Route 55 freeway to the traffic jam snaking up Route 47 from the shore. The backup starts here, in Cumberland County.
While the beaches boom, South Jersey political leaders are trying to raise from the dead a plan that environmentalists find all but incredible: the extension of Route 55 through the marshy plains between Port Elizabeth and the Garden State Parkway. 
 "Where 47 comes down it's horrendous," said State Senator James S. Cafiero, Republican of North Wildwood. "People can't back out of their driveways."
Three months ago, the Senate passed a nonbinding resolution urging the state Department of Transportation, which had turned aside the proposal for decades, to complete the highway. Shortly afterward, the board of the South Jersey Transportation Planning Organization, the agency charged with reviewing projects in the region, endorsed the Senate resolution.
Environmental advocates are fighting back. They maintain that a 20-mile freeway would destroy some of the state's most ecologically fragile land and mar the beauty that draws tourists, all in the cause of easing congestion that lasts perhaps 300 hours a year.
"This summer we'll be proactive, while we have this audience of three-quarters of a million people," said Douglas Jewell, a real estate broker in Swainton who is a leader of Concerned Citizens of Cape May County, an environmental group.
The proposal is also opposed by the Sierra Club, the New Jersey Audubon Society and other groups that say it would undermine the anti-sprawl objectives of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan.
Jeff Tittel, president of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, said he was skeptical of the Whitman Administration's assurances that the state has no plans to extend Route 55. Mr. Tittel cited several highway projects that had appeared suddenly on the Department of Transportations project list.
"If it gets political momentum, the next thing you know, it's getting approval," Mr. Tittel said.
James Weinstein, the state transportation commissioner, acknowledged that the Senate resolution was "absolutely" significant. "When a project has the support of the Legislature," he said, "it raises it to a different level."
But Mr. Weinstein said the department had no plan beyond improving existing roads. "The reality is that the environmental challenges are substantial," Mr. Weinstein said.
A feasibility study in 1993 mapped out a likely route for the new road but did not endorse the project, in part because 40 percent of the highway would cross wetlands. The study then placed the cost at $423 million to $483 million -- a price tag that environmental advocates say would now approach $1 billion.
Still, both sides regard the renewed call to extend the highway as a test of the administration's resolve.
The Senate resolution "should not have an effect on a governor committed to smart growth and the state plan," said Bill Neil, the director of conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society.
But Senator Cafiero, who sponsored the resolution, along with the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said it expressed the legislature's frustration with decades of delay. "I came to the legislature in 1968, and that project was on the board then," Senator Cafiero said. "It becomes more costly as time goes on. If enough pressure can be brought to bear, whatever plans they have can be diverted or amended a little bit."
The environmental obstacles are huge. Half of the new road would lie within the pinelands. It would need approval from the Pinelands Commission, which has already registered its reservations, the Army Corps of Engineers and state and federal environmental agencies.
Those problems were cited in a 1998 report by the South Jersey Transportation Planning Organization, which evaluated many alternatives for alleviating shore traffic both from the Garden State Parkway and Route 55, which begins in Gloucester County. The report concluded that the project "would face extreme environmental problems" and "would also be very costly."
But now, said Timothy G. Chelius, the agency's director, the project "is at the top of this organization's list."
The Route 55 plan is just one thread in a larger debate over economic development in the southern counties.
"To the power brokers there, they are an underdeveloped area that wants what the rest of the state has," Mr. Neil said.
Senator Cafiero agrees. "You can't expect us to keep all these open fields and green spaces while depriving us of the ratables that reasonable construction would allow," he said. "We can't be the windows on the world."
Mr. Jewell said that elected officials were responding to development interests, which contribute heavily to their campaigns, and that the vast majority of residents opposed further building in the county.
"We just want to preserve a way of life," he said. "If we want to be Atlantic County or Asbury Park, we can do that, too."
But some residents do support an extended Route 55. "There are a sizable number of people in South Jersey who are opposed, for want of a better phrase, to anything happening," said Brian Reynolds, a year-round Avalon resident.
Mr. Reynolds, who wrote to the transportation planning organization on behalf of a homeowners group, said in an interview that "on Route 55 on a summer Saturday morning you could have a backup four or five miles long before you get to 47."
Another concern, he said, was evacuating the islands in the event of a hurricane threat, particularly since parts of Route 47 are susceptible to flooding.
On Route 47, Yvonne Glauner, who runs Two Pines Country Gifts in a shop behind her parents' farmhouse, said most people considered the traffic a nuisance, but not one to be solved by a new four-lane highway. "To do all that and disrupt the wildlife and people's homes for three months of the year doesn't make sense," she said.
Ms. Glauner said it would not matter much to her business if shore-bound traffic was diverted. In the bumper-to-bumper stream on Friday nights and Saturdays, she said, few pull off for gift shopping.

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
A Forgotten Threat: Free Trade in Population

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN their determination to derail the forces of globalization -- a process in which dastardly capitalists provide employment to impoverished people all over the world -- protesters in Washington focused recently on a pair of plump targets, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Yet they directed none of their ire at the Washington headquarters of another notorious agent of globalization, the Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
 Of course, the I.N.S. is not really responsible for America's decision to tolerate consistently high levels of legal and illegal immigration, or for the nation's indifference to the age, training or skill level of most of the immigrants it admits.
But the protesters seemed mainly to want a symbol. So why assail global trade (the importing of goods) but ignore immigration (the importing of people)? After all, economists across the political spectrum agree that the growing volume of world trade yields economic, social and even geopolitical benefits to Americans and foreigners alike, making the world more peaceful and more affluent. There is no such consensus on current immigration policy.
Many of the protesters claimed to be environmentalists. Surely the arrival of large numbers of immigrants, who will soon begin consuming land, fuel and other resources at gargantuan American levels, is an environmental issue.
Other protesters profess a concern for American jobs. Yet unemployment in this country is negligible.
The real problem for American workers is that immigration keeps increasing the supply of labor, seriously suppressing low-end wages. George J. Borjas, a Harvard professor of public policy specializing in immigration, calls this "an astonishing transfer of wealth from the poorest people in the country, who are disproportionately minorities, to the richest."
John Micklethwait and Adrian Woolridge, in their exhaustive new book about globalization, "A Future Perfect" (Crown Business Books) state flatly that "immigration has a much more direct impact on American wages than trade does."
What's more, immigration holds down wages in exactly the kinds of low-skill jobs that are not easy to shift overseas -- the only ones, in other words, that are likely to remain available in the long run to the poorest Americans. Many of the poor -- often immigrants themselves -- generally take a much dimmer view of high immigration rates than does the latte-and-S.U.V. crowd, which mainly sees cheap child care and great new ethnic restaurants.
Certainly, immigration has played a role in the declining fortunes of organized labor. Consider the drywallers of Southern California. In the 1970's, installing gypsum wallboard there was highly paid union work. But at the end of that decade, contractors began using nonunion Mexican immigrants, many of them from a single village. By the early 1980's, union drywallers had been completely displaced, and wages had plummeted.
Eventually, after a struggle, the immigrant drywallers formed their own union and won raises, but their pay remains far below what their predecessors earned -- perhaps because there are more immigrants waiting to take their places.
In the rhetoric of its opponents, global capitalism has a prominent failing: income inequality. But in the United States, that inequality is almost certainly exacerbated by immigration; indeed, it is becoming common again for the bourgeoisie to employ servants, though no one uses the term in polite company.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve and bete noire of anticapitalists everywhere, recently called for more immigration of skilled workers. Software companies, of course, love that idea. They want more immigrant programmers, even though there is no great shortage of homegrown software labor, at least according to Norman Matloff, a computer scientist at the University of California at Davis who also studies immigration. There is only a shortage, he says of cheap software labor.
IT would be more logical for foes of globalization to also oppose immigration, but such a stance is, of course, politically incorrect. While supporting both free trade and immigration may be more consistent, I'm not sure it is any more right. If we are to continue reaping the benefits of globalization, we must do more to help those who suffer the heaviest cost -- America's working poor, who should, at the least, receive decent pay and health insurance for their labors. The nation is unlikely to make much headway on this or many other important fronts (like income inequality, suburban sprawl or social cohesion) until we reassess which people, and how many of them, can enter the country. In the past, big influxes have often been followed by long periods of digestion in which fewer newcomers were admitted.
The time may be right for another such breather.
