LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS;
Eugenie Diserio and Bill Buttenwieser

BYLINE: By LOIS SMITH BRADY 

 BODY:
AS the founder of Astronet.com, an astrology Web site, Eugenie Diserio will gladly, even proudly, tell you that until recently she experienced plenty of setbacks, broken hearts, horrific blind dates, cars that broke down and unemployment. To her, life is about cycles -- caused by moons and planets moving in and out of one's celestial house -- and at 45 she's been through plenty of them.
In her 30's, she went through a wild, glamorous, sleepless cycle as the lead singer of a New Wave dance band in Manhattan, the Model Citizens. Then, in 1989, she quit performing, had a child and moved to Woodstock, N.Y., where she baked bread, wore Birkenstocks and drove a Saab with nearly 200,000 miles on it. "That was her Mother Earth time," said Dorette Sacripanti, a friend. 
 In 1992, after breaking up with a boyfriend, she returned to her hometown, New Canaan, Conn., moving into an apartment above her parents' garage. She arrived with no money, no job, her son (Jake, now 11) and a broken heart. "She was really up a creek without a paddle," said her mother, Roseanne Diserio.
Eventually, she got a 9-to-5 corporate job just for the health benefits, but hated it. "I thought, 'God, I'm not supposed to be this generic person,' " she said. When she was fired in 1994, she began a project everyone thought her wackiest yet: she created Astronet.com, which now includes daily horoscopes, astrological charts for couples and an advice column for the lovelorn, Ask Genie. (She's Genie.)
As she built Astronet, which went online in 1995, the only men in her life were Jake and Sam, her overweight mutt. "I was a total single mom," she said. "Sometimes, I'd get depressed and Jake would say: 'Oh, Mom, you're not alone. You have me.' "
Then, in the fall of 1997, she met Bill Buttenwieser, a corporate pilot who is now 43. "We were introduced by my sister, who had been my sole dinner partner up until then," Ms. Diserio said. "Bill was recently separated and at a very low moment. My sister told him: 'You should really meet Eugenie. She's nice and she deals with a lot of people with problems.' So we met, and he unloaded."
Ms. Diserio got his birth date that night and checked him out astrologically. (She's a Libra; he's a Taurus.) "We had a lot of compatibilities in our charts," she said. "So I thought, 'Oh, I'll give this guy a chance.' " As it turned out, the pilot and the astrologer had much in common. Both had been through failed relationships; both were parents (he has three daughters); both knew the stars well, albeit from different perspectives. She describes him as a punctual, orderly and poetic pilot who comes back from work and talks about the spectacular thunderstorms or shooting stars he saw that night.
He said he began falling in love with Ms. Diserio right from the start: "The first time I shook her hand it was like static electricity. There was really a power between us."
Now that her "struggling days" seem over, when people ask Ms. Diserio for advice, she's like a personal trainer. "I get really tough on people," she said. "I try to empower women, because there was a point in my life when I was so unempowered. You have to be very, very proactive. You have to make a good life."
The couple were married in Darien, Conn., on April 29, a day she chose after consulting her charts. The wedding was at the Woodway Country Club, where she used to play tennis in a black leather jacket in her Model Citizens era. This time she wore a conservative white gown with her hair in a bun. Jake gave her away and cried more than anyone. (From happiness, he said.)
Now, Ms. Diserio hopes she's entering a stable, financially secure, suburban, domestic cycle. (Last year, Hearst New Media acquired Astronet for a price in the seven figures, and she now drives a "Big Benz," as she calls it.) She and Mr. Buttenwieser are shopping for a house in New Canaan and want to have children of their own. "I'm kind of a nester," she said. "I was always moving. Now, I'm going to find a home and stay awhile."

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE;
Snapshots in Scent

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
I STARTED wearing Chanel No. 5 because of Catherine Deneuve. To my teenage eyes she was the epitome of French style and classic beauty, and I figured that if I wore it, too -- bell-bottoms aside -- I would somehow acquire that same je ne sais quoi. In Scarsdale.
I had my dalliances along the way. There was Charlie (Shelly Hack's appeal was somehow not eternal) and Chloe, even Fracas for a minute, but in the end it was always Chanel. Those dreaded women at Bloomingdale's who aim their atomizers and fire get nowhere with me. 
 But after 25 years, even I was bored, so when I read that Sarah Horowitz was taking appointments for her Fragrance Journey, I called. "The fragrance equivalent of rebirthing," the notice read, "Horowitz coaxes forth scent-related memories and then blends you a scent with emotional meaning."
Ms. Horowitz is based in Malibu, but she road-trips regularly to New York and London; it turns out she has 1,200 clients. Though it sounded kind of kooky, I found the prospect somehow intriguing -- like having a shrink and a personal shopper rolled into one.
While customization has proved popular recently in everything from suits to ice cream, it is taking off in the top tiers of the fragrance industry. Creed, the very upscale European fragrance house, whose perfumer is the sixth-generation Oliver Creed, offers custom scents ($20,000 for Mr. Creed himself to oversee a process that takes six months). There are also Creed master blenders at Barneys New York, Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus, who can blend five or six of the existing 100 Creed scents for customers in an hour, for the more affordable fee of $400 to $1,000.
On the West Coast there are a growing number of fragrance boutiques like Lather in Pasadena and Homebody in Los Angeles that blend custom scents for clients like K. D. Lang. As Mary Lavo, the merchandising manager in charge of cosmetics for Barneys, says, the custom-scent trend is not sweeping huge numbers because of the time (and money) the process requires -- like couture versus ready-to-wear. Historically, fragrance was an exclusive privilege of royalty and the very rich, until the late 1800's, when the common folk got in on the act. So, it's not surprising that with the economy soaring now, the very rich have once again realized they no longer have to smell like even the moderately rich.
While the custom-scent trend has not broken through to the masses, some online sites plan to offer the service to users, via questionnaire. (Reflect.com was the only one I found promising that personalized scents "will be available soon.") Ms. Horowitz and some other professionals in the fragrance business are skeptical of this sort of venture, however, since body chemistry plays such an important part in determining a scent.
She settled down to determine mine in my apartment, breaking her "no house calls rule," because her New York schedule was so jammed she could see me only on her day off. (She usually sets up shop in a hotel suite; appointments can be made by calling 310-317-6858.)
The Fragrance Journey costs $255 for a 90-minute session and includes a quarter-ounce French-cut bottle of the perfume she creates with you. (Perfect Perfumes, her ready-to-wear line, as she calls it, is sold in New York at the Bigelow Pharmacy in Greenwich Village.)
Ms. Horowitz travels with a fragrance organ, a large case containing 120 bottles of fragrances and essential oils. As she set up her apparatus and put some New Age music on the tape player, I learned that she grew up on Long Island and graduated from Emerson College in Boston, where she discovered her interest in scent while working for Essence, a store on Newbury Street, now defunct. She has apprenticed at Belmay, a perfume house in the Los Angeles area, and has spent the last 12 years combining her love of scent with her love of psychology.
"My passion is to incorporate emotional and physical history into the blending of fragrance," she said. "I love listening to people and seeing what we can put together." The results have included everything from separate daytime and nighttime scents to a custom-made bridal scent that the bridegroom doesn't smell until the wedding day. "After that, you only wear it on anniversaries or special occasions," she said. "It's Pavlovian. You're impregnating the oil with your memory."
Ms. Horowitz started the session by telling me, "You will have to name the fragrance you give to yourself," which she would then print up on labels for my future orders. She has a lab assistant who translates her handwritten formulas into sprays, bath gels and body lotions.
She gave a brief history of fragrance, noting that the Egyptians made cones out of beeswax and tallow, laid blossoms on them and wore them on their heads. As the heat of the sun melted them, the scented fat ran down their faces. Yum yum.
"This is one of the oldest art forms," she said. "You are receiving the highest gift you can give yourself, a fragrance based on your experiences and what you love."
Then her questions started. What were my favorite foods? Favorite color? What were my scent memories of my mother? Do I love citrus? Not especially. How about sweet? Even less.
Yes, I do like the ocean, better than the mountains. I like roses and grass and violets. I especially like the way some people smell like soap, so clean and straight from the shower.
As I spoke, she pulled bottles from her case and grouped them on the table, moving them around as if they were chess pieces. She gave me a Parmesan cheese shaker filled with coffee beans and instructed me to inhale periodically; it works as a palate cleanser for the nose.
"Perfume is built like music is," she said. "The base note, middle and top. The base supports the scent, like the percussion, the middle is the bouquet of fragrance and the top note is the most pungent and pulls you into the rest. It's like the strings."
During the first round of inhaling her bottles, she told me what each scent was and had me tell her whether I loved it, hated it or wasn't sure. What followed was a series of childhood memories, instantaneous snapshots of the oddest assortment of people and places: my Aunt Marcia's bathroom, the soap in my underwear drawer in junior high school, a hotel room in Puerto Rico.
Sweet pea smelled like camp. Cassis smelled like Chanel No. 5. Basil smelled like dinner and didn't interest me at all. As a matter of fact, I disliked most scents.
"There's no wrong answer here," Ms. Horowitz said encouragingly. "It's all about you, and I know how to balance it."
During the second round of inhaling she instructed me to keep my eyes closed. "When they're open you have a mental association with what you perceive the scent to be," she said. "With your eyes closed, you go on your gut. I watch your facial expressions and see where the emphasis should be when I blend."
I ended up with six ingredients for her to mix with her long plastic eyedroppers: Oriental musk, rose, sweet pea, African violet, gardenia and cassis. "It has a garden feel, and the cassis makes it very sophisticated," she said, putting it on my arm. I smelled it and winced. It was way too sweet.
She nodded. "Your skin brings the rose up," she said. "It depends on body chemistry. Certain people pull up certain notes faster."
She kept adjusting, adding one drop at a time from skinnier glass eyedroppers to different areas of my arms and hands. She ran her nose up and down the skin, sniffing, like a puppy. I started to feel that my choices were wrong, but she kept mixing until suddenly I smiled. Yes.
"It reminds me of something," I told her. "Something good."
She smiled. "You," she said.
After she had packed up and gone, I showered, dressed and put on my new perfume, as I did the day after and the day after that. I tried not to notice, but it was still too sweet. The spray she had made was better, less concentrated, but still not right. One night I went back to Chanel No. 5, which surprisingly, smelled thin and chemical by comparison.
I called Ms. Horowitz. "This happens about 10 percent of the time," she said apologetically. "My goal is to have you love this, so I'm going to rework it based on the formula and send you some samples in the mail."
She wasn't completely surprised by my reaction, she added. "My impressions of you," she said, "were that you are extremely thorough and very specific. Yet, there is a little contradiction. You said you didn't like sweet things, but when you smelled them, you liked them."
She hesitated. "If you don't mind my saying so, you do a lot of thinking in your line of work and I think you don't want to be perceived as too sweet."
She was probably right. But she had overcompensated for me a bit too much.
After I hung up, I realized I still hadn't named my scent. I could wait, of course, until the revised version came back. But one night, at the movies, the name came to me. I had caught a whiff of myself, and it was fragrant, familiar, even comforting. Not to mention decidedly imperfect.
"Mine."

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE;
Patients Can Burn Cash, Too

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
ASK people how money is wasted in the health care system, and their tone of voice undergoes an interesting change.
Doctors huff and puff about the squadrons of workers they have had to hire to meet the paperwork demands of managed care. Patients complain about the $60 they shell out for three-minute appointments during which doctors seem to do little more than blink at them. Insurance companies bemoan unnecessary tests. 
 In fact, there are many quantifiable ways in which millions of health care dollars go up in smoke each year. Patients are complicit in the process, though they do not always know it. Doctors, insurance companies and policy experts each have a laundry list of ways that patients aid and abet waste, sometimes at the peril of their own health. Here are some of the problems they cite.
 
UNNEEDED ANTIBIOTICS -- In rare agreement, doctors, insurers and scientists all say there is widespread, wasteful misuse of antibiotics. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta estimates that roughly 50 million unneeded prescriptions for antibiotics are dispensed each year.
Why? Doctors say patients -- especially those who were up all night with a miserable child -- dislike going home empty-handed. Others demand the most expensive types of antibiotics even when they are not appropriate. And some doctors feel that while an antibiotic may not help a situation, it won't hurt, either.
That attitude deeply concerns the C.D.C., which has seen a rapid increase in antibiotic-resistant infections, including those of the ear, urinary tract and respiratory system, in part because of antibiotic misuse.
"I think the average person can help by understanding that antibiotics offer no benefit for colds and flu and viruses," said Dr. David M. Bell, who works on antibiotic resistance issues at the C.D.C. "They should not be disappointed when the doctor does not prescribe them, and they should not demand them."
 
PREVENTIVE SCREENINGS -- In theory, screenings are great, because finding and treating illnesses in early stages tends to be less expensive and more successful. But many people are screened for diseases they are at no real risk of contracting.
Colon cancer experts, for example, generally recommend waiting until the age of 50 to begin screening for the disease unless it runs in the family or a relative has developed it at 55 or younger. But the once-distasteful colonoscopy has been promoted into something of a rage among people who do not really need it, these experts say, eclipsing cheaper tests that may be more appropriate.
"Katie Couric showing that the colonoscopy is a tolerable and accurate screening test is a good thing," said James E. Allison, a gastroenterologist at San Francisco General Hospital and investigator for Kaiser Permanente, a West Coast health maintenance organization. "But the message should not be that average-risk people Katie's age should get a colonoscopy."
Others who do not need the procedure are the very elderly who have been screened in the past; those with terminal illnesses, though 30 percent of primary care doctors refer such patients for the test anyway; and people who have had a benign polyp removed in the last five years, since there is only a remote chance it will come back, Dr. Allison said, citing studies by respected cancer centers.
Looking at screenings more broadly, many experts say that far too many people get M.R.I. scans for lower back pain, and that unnecessary surgery and invasive tests often follow. A New England Journal of Medicine study from the mid-1990's found that as many as 85 percent of patients with lower back pain could not be given a definitive diagnosis.
 
OVER-THE-COUNTER PRODUCTS -- Every doctor and managed-care executive has an example in this area. (Their views are their own, so manufacturers, save the angry letters.) Dr. Jack Swanson, a pediatrician in Ames, Iowa, and the chairman of the American Academy of Pediatrics' committee on practice and ambulatory medicine, does not much care for vitamins for healthy children.
"Most pediatricians don't think healthy children need extra vitamins, even the ones that are picky eaters," Dr. Swanson said. He also derides food additives for children with disabilities. "I think parents see these things advertised and think they are important to use," he said.
Oddly, no one mentioned the mental-health cost of reading really tacky magazines in the doctor's waiting room. But the patient's role in that, of course, is elective.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
In aSearch for Hot Wheels, Buyers Hit a Dead End

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
AS Robert Forester watched his dealer pull up in a black Chrysler PT Cruiser to take him for a test drive, he decided on the spot that the retro-looking small van would join his family's fleet.
"I got in that PT Cruiser and fell in love," said Mr. Forester, who works for a printing and stationery business in Henderson, Tex., 150 miles east of Dallas. 
 But two months after he ordered a red one with automatic transmission and tinted moonroof for his mother, Jean, it still has not arrived. In fact, it has not even been built, and Chrysler representatives could not tell him when it would be.
With auto sales booming along with the economy, consumers who want the hottest vehicles are struggling to find the unfindable, which this spring includes eye-catchers like the PT Cruiser and the Toyota MR2 Spyder sports car, the highly rated Honda Odyssey minivan, and luxury vehicles like the BMW X5 sport utility and Mercedes S-Class sedans. Orders like Mr. Forester's go on waiting lists and languish for months.
In some areas, it can be impossible even to find a vehicle to inspect in the showroom, because dealers are selling every one that comes in. Honda dealers on Long Island are telling customers who want to test-drive an Odyssey that they must first order one, put down a deposit, and then wait for it to arrive.
In response, many consumers find that they must alter their tactics, searching by phone over wide areas for dealerships that have a car on the lot. A growing number of people are turning to the Internet, combing dealer sites, omnibus shopping sites like Autobytel and Microsoft's Carpoint, and even auction sites like eBay for leads.
Tracking down a hot car is one thing; taking title is another. Joel Manby, a former executive with Saab and Saturn who is now president of Greenlight.com, a car-buying site, estimated that half of all buyers use the Internet to research or find vehicles, but that only one in 20 concludes a deal online.
THE Internet also tends to lengthen the lines at the dealers who have hot cars on hand. Corky Jones, Internet sales manager for Covington Pike Chrysler in Memphis, said his dealership had 103 orders for PT Cruisers from people as far away as Ohio, Illinois and Texas. In one hour on Wednesday, six people came into the showroom to see the vehicle, with its vaguely 1930's front end; they were told that new orders would be filled in December.
Mr. Jones likened the demand to the frenzy last year over Volkswagen's New Beetle, which remains in short supply in some parts of the country. But he is enjoying the clamor. "Just once in your life, you want to sell something that is so popular you have people lining up for it," he said. "It's fantastic."
On the wall in Covington Pike's showroom is an ever-lengthening list of buyers who have put down $500 deposits. James Alexander, a mechanic from Mason, Tenn., who went on the list in February, just got his PT. "It's a joy to drive," Mr. Alexander said.
Despite having no bargaining leverage on such a hot vehicle, Mr. Alexander got his for the sticker price, about $20,000 with options, because Covington Pike has decided not to charge a premium. "That wouldn't be fair to the customer," Mr. Jones said.
But other dealers feel differently. Last week, anyone willing to pay $24,999 -- $5,000 above list -- could drive home that day in the dark blue PT Cruiser on the showroom floor at Village Chrysler-Jeep in Royal Oak, Mich. Village's new-car sales manager, Jeff Radke, said it had been bought used with a few hundred miles on the odometer; his waiting list for new ones numbers 60.
And the dealership is not guaranteeing what the final price will be on those, he said, leaving open the possibility that it will tack on a premium if demand stays strong. And if customers balk? "If they don't want it, they can cancel," he said. "It's up to them."
Some dealers are looking to maximize profits on scarce vehicles by auctioning them online. Blouin Truck Center of Augusta, Me., posted a dark red PT Cruiser on eBay last week, seeking an opening bid of $19,990, or $2,400 above list. "It's a variation on what the market will bear," said Mike Linkenbach, the dealership's manager. "This is a unique vehicle. This isn't like a Dodge Neon that they build every day."
Steve Rossi, vice president for global communications at DaimlerChrysler, said such markups were isolated. "You've heard a handful of stories," he said. "What you haven't heard are the 10,000 positive experiences, people who went through the process, placed an order and got their vehicles." Chrysler dealers delivered 8,325 PT Cruisers in April, he said, and have about 79,000 more on order.
IN introducing the X5, its first sport utility, in December, BMW found itself in the catbird seat. Jack Pitney, a spokesman, said, "We're in an enviable position where demand far outweighs supply."
Too far, in fact. The first year's production is sold out, and dealers are not yet allowed to take orders for 2001 models. For now, the only way to get one is to buy it used; an X5 with 4,700 miles was on eBay last week at a minimum bid of $49,100, just $800 below its base price when new.
So, too, with Toyota's new MR2, a two-seat sports car whose production was limited to generate buzz with consumers: all 7,425 available this year are spoken for, the company said. And at Betten Imports in Grand Rapids, Mich., the back-order time for the latest Mercedes S-Class cars, which start at around $80,000, is up to a year.
The Odyssey has no such cachet; its attractions are Honda's reputation for quality and raves in the consumer press. Joseph Phillippi, automotive analyst at PaineWebber, observed, "It's a Honda -- enough said."
Introduced more than a year ago, the Odyssey is still scarce, even though Honda is making as many as it can. "Most dealers only have one or two," said Michael Luckey, an automotive consultant who shopped for an Odyssey in Pompton Plains, N.J. Mr. Manby of Greenlight.com, which matches potential buyers with 1,000 participating dealers, said it "is tough to find anywhere."
Perhaps the toughest of all, for now, is BMW's Z8 sports car, featured in "The World Is Not Enough," last year's James Bond thriller. The car went on sale only last Monday, but all 400 to be sold in the United States have already been allotted to buyers who ordered them up to a year ago, when the Z8 began appearing in European car magazines. An Internet search last week found none on auction sites.
In such cases, "the advice I can give any customer is basically, 'Get to your dealer early,' " said Steven Sturm, vice president for marketing at Toyota.
What will be the next hot car? Analysts mention the Audi TT Roadster and the new Thunderbird that Ford is planning for next spring. Jeff Leckta, Internet Services Manager at Betten Imports, cites the convertible New Beetle. Though Volkswagen told dealers not to expect the car until the fall of 2001, he said, "I already have orders."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS;
Couple of Homeboys With the Gentrification Blues

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LEDUFF 

 BODY:
Fort Greene, Brooklyn, has always been home to a black middle class, but the Ave belonged to the broke and the bus drivers. The playground belonged to the tough kids like Chulo, who wear flannel and sneakers and whiskers.
That was before the Change. The Caucasian invasion, they call it; before the police and the block associations, the bars, cafes and the artistic bubbleheads. They and their money took over. 
 The Ave, as it is known to locals, is the block bounded by DeKalb, Lafayette and Carlton Avenues and Adelphi Street. In the middle is a playground. Along the perimeter are the new bars and the brownstones. Rows and rows of beautiful brownstones. One stop from Manhattan.
Gentrification doesn't just happen, said Chulo, 21, whose given name is Eric J. Melendez. These new people have to be helped, and he was one who helped them. Now he regrets it.
A couple of Europeans opened cafes on the Ave not long ago, and Chulo was attracted to them. They were something different, and good-looking women went there. He now works hustling plates at a French joint called Chez Oskar. He keeps the neighborhood kids off the owner's back and out of her till. He makes $300 a week. He spends evenings at the bar. He now sees possibilities beyond the streets.
"They been good to me," Chulo said. "I been good to them."
But things have gone too far, as far as Chulo's concerned. There is a South African restaurant on the Ave named Madiba, owned by a white man. A few weeks ago, according to Chulo, some white South Africans started a ruckus there with the black employees and left, leaving a racial stink the air. "It bugged me out," Chulo said the other afternoon at Madiba over a beer. "I thought this was still Brooklyn."
His story is Brooklyn to the bone. His mother died young. His father is locked away. He bounced around in foster homes until he was adopted. He was 14 when his second mother died, 14 when his second father died and 14 when he moved into the playground on the Ave.
The park became his home, the bench his mattress, the boys there his family. He drifted from $6-an-hour jobs to street-corner hustling until the white people came with a job and he got an apartment.
It hasn't worked out so well for the others, Chulo said, shading his eyes as he sat on one of Madiba's outside tables. Last week, Chulo said, he watched the light go out in a second-floor apartment on the Ave and saw a friend come down the stairs with the last of his possessions.
"I guess you ain't coming back here no more for real?" Chulo asked.
"Ain't no one to come back to," answered the friend, W. P.
The young men sat in the U-Haul, under the street lamp, drinking Corona and smoking menthols.
W.P. was moving to East New York, a neighborhood of vacant lots and cheaper rents and a growing number of economic outcasts from Fort Greene. The landlord had raised W.P.'s rent again. The liquor store closed for the same reason, and W.P. can't afford the drinks in the new bars.
"Man, what happened to the old neighborhood?" W.P. asked. He said it as if he'd been sneaked up on in the dark and beaten with a wet pillow.
"Not even a good grocery no more," Chulo said. CHARLIE LEDUFF

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Not Just Surviving, but Thriving

BYLINE: By LESLIE BERGER 

 BODY:
MAYBE Jay Pearsall harbors some sort of death wish. He has, after all, been steeped in murder and mayhem for more than 10 years as the proprietor of Murder Ink, the Upper West Side mystery bookstore.
But the wholesome-looking Mr. Pearsall, who just opened a second store selling new and used books, insists he isn't suicidal, just hooked on a business that can be as intensely personal and satisfying as, well, a crime of passion. 
 "I could make more money in an easier way dealing rare books out of my apartment," he said. "But there's something, you know, in my blood to collect these books and turn them around."
Like Murder Ink, the two-month-old Ivy's Books and Curiosities is brimming with charm, uncommon titles and advice aplenty from a well-read staff. The two shops are connected on Broadway, between 92nd and 93rd Streets, and each has its share of antiques and friendly nuzzles from Gus, Mr. Pearsall's wirehaired pointing griffon. So far, he said, "No one has expressed anything but glee about having something other than another mediocre restaurant or Godiva chocolate."
By pumping profits from Murder Ink into a new store just 10 blocks north of Barnes & Noble, Mr. Pearsall has taken a big risk. But it seems to be one that other independent booksellers are taking, too, despite a shellacking over the last several years from Barnes & Noble, Borders and Amazon.com.
The decline in independent bookstores, from a nationwide peak of 5,400 in the early 1990's to 3,200 today, has tapered off during the last two years, according to the American Booksellers Association. Although the association does not break out separate figures for New York City, there is anecdotal evidence to suggest that indies are cautiously reopening their doors to readers starved for face-to-face contact.
Only 76 independent bookstores remain in all five boroughs, according to an association Web site (www.bookweb.org), and many of those are part of museums and other cultural centers. But for every lost icon like Endicott Booksellers, Watson's and Burlington, there is an Ivy's, a Crawford-Doyle and a Posman's, according to Carl Lennertz, a marketing consultant at the association's headquarters in Tarrytown, N.Y.
Shakespeare & Co., whose flagship store at Broadway and 81st Street closed after Barnes & Noble opened a block away, has not only re-emerged on the Upper East Side (near Hunter College), but is also becoming a small chain of its own. After regaining a foothold at Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, Shakespeare has opened branches near Baruch College (in the East 20's), near Wall Street, in Greenwich Village and, most recently, in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
"Any new retailing phenomenon runs out of gas after a while," Mr. Lennertz said. "It's one thing to buy a discounted best seller, and it's another to go in and ask, 'What should my book club read?' "
Personal service is clearly the strength of independent mainstays like the Corner Bookstore, at Madison Avenue and 93rd Street since 1978. On a recent Saturday, pink and red carnations brightened the shop's windows while loyal customers politely vied for space at the cash register.
Carol Vanderkloot, a publicist, snapped up several children's classics for her niece's sixth birthday while Kent Lombard, a perfume chemist, and his wife, Randy, an interior designer, bought "The Horse and His Boy" by C. S. Lewis for their 7-year-old son, Hunter.
When "The Horse and His Boy," the third volume in the Chronicles of Narnia, wasn't readily available recently, the store's workers advised not skipping ahead.
"They didn't press us for another sale, but ordered it for us and called as soon as it came in," said Ms. Lombard, adding, "I don't mind paying a little more money for the service."
The Corner Bookstore's staying power may also stem from the fact that the proprietor, Lenny Golay, and her husband, Ray Sherman, own the four-story building where it is situated (and where they live). Two years ago, the couple opened a second store, the Lenox Hill Bookstore, on Lexington Avenue between 72nd and 73rd Streets.
Commercial rents have put a lot of stores out of business, said Fern Jaffe, who has owned Paperbacks Plus in the Riverdale section of the Bronx for three decades. Her core customers, Ms. Jaffe said, are neighborhood residents who shop along Riverdale Avenue, have known her for years and are now buying books for their children and grandchildren. "The money we're making today is based on a capital investment of old money," she said.
FINANCIAL independence also gave rise about five years ago to Crawford-Doyle, at Madison and 81st Street, whose chatty co-owner, John Doyle, is a retired I.B.M. executive and an avid reader.
"It's really not an economic enterprise anymore," Mr. Doyle said of the book business. "It's a labor of love."
The store grossed just under $1 million last year and barely broke even, Mr. Doyle said. But as he sees it, his staff gets decent wages and he and his wife, Judy Crawford, are able to dine with authors and chat with celebrity walk-ins like Emma Thompson.
Less secure but just as passionate are the operators of Nkiru, a Brooklyn landmark that has specialized in African-American literature since 1976. Talib Kweli Greene and Dante Smith, a hip-hop duo known as Black Star, bought the bookstore in 1998 with the advance from their first album. But competition, plus a $3,000 monthly rent, proved too much for them. The shop, on St. Mark's Avenue in Park Slope, was recently revamped into a nonprofit education and cultural center.
"You just can't rely on walk-ins," said Dr. Brenda M. Greene, Mr. Greene's mother, who now runs the center. Dr. Greene also heads the department of languages, literature and philosophy at Medgar Evers College. Current plans for Nkiru include an expanded selection of multicultural literature, writing seminars and weekend hip-hop performances.
Clearly, establishing a niche is critical. PosmanBooks, which started out as a purveyor of college textbooks, has successfully expanded into the general retail market while clinging to its collegiate roots and finding specialized markets.
Maxene Posman, the president of PosmanBooks, said that the family had doubled its business in the last few years. Though the company still specializes in college bookstores, Posman's three general trade stores have also carved out their own niches. The Grand Central store, for example, offers a wide range of management-training books for employees of nearby corporations.
Most independent bookstores also have Web sites or are developing them. But several booksellers said they had little expectation of reaping much profit on the Net and were going high tech mainly to support www.booksense.com, a Web site that is part of the booksellers association's national campaign to help its members compete online.
Mr. Pearsall, for one, clearly prefers selling books in person, and the intimacy of his stores may be hard to resist. But even his most appreciative customers go high tech and low-rent once in a while.
"I love the feel of this store," said Erin Moriarty, a reporter for "48 Hours," who was prowling for a new mystery recently at Murder Ink.
"How could you not? But I also love the mix of books and people at Barnes & Noble, and I also order books online. I'm an equal opportunist."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Expectations, Over the Rainbow

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT is fair to say that technology investors have high expectations about the future growth of companies in their portfolios. But I bet that those companies have almost no chance of meeting those optimistic expectations.
Why am I so downbeat? It all comes down to the issue of whether huge growth rates can be sustained. 
 Consider a star of the new economy, Cisco Systems. Sure, its gear is essential to the growth of the Internet. But it is unlikely that Cisco will perform well enough over the next five years to satisfy the earnings expectations that I believe are implied by its current price-to-earnings multiple of 188.
To gauge those expectations, we first need to calculate how much Cisco's earnings are likely to grow over the next five years.
If Cisco follows the typical pattern of growth companies, its multiple will drop as it grows and matures. So assume that five years from now, Cisco's P/E will be 50 -- still well above the market's long-term historical average of about 15.
Next we need to postulate the company's stock performance. Cisco's stock has climbed 105 percent, annualized, over the last five years. So, to be conservative, we will guess that it will grow just 22 percent a year -- still double the stock market's long-term average.
Given these cautious assumptions, Cisco's stock will be at $183 in May 2005, up from $67.5625 on Friday. And many investors would be happy to get that kind of return.
But here is the rub: Cisco's earnings will have to grow by nearly 60 percent a year, on average, over the next five years to meet those expectations. And if we assume that Cisco's P/E is below 50 in 2005, or that its price is higher than $183, the requisite earnings growth rate will have to be even higher. To put this in perspective, consider that the earnings growth rate of the median technology company has been just 13 percent, annualized, over the last five decades.
So if you buy Cisco today, expecting that it will hit $183 in five years, you are making an implicit bet that its earnings will grow five times faster than those of the average technology company. And new research suggests that the odds of that are very low.
Josef Lakonishok and Louis K. D. Chan, finance professors at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, studied nearly every technology stock from 1951 to 1999. In particular, they sought companies whose earnings growth rates were consistently above the median of all publicly traded companies.
They found that over periods of five years or more, just 4.7 percent of companies, on average, had earnings growth that beat the median during all years of the period. The number is statistically insignificant because, assuming that earnings growth was random, 3.3 percent of the companies would have beaten the median each year in any case.
Then the professors loosened up a bit, and searched for technology companies whose earnings growth rates exceeded the median in four out of five years. The results were almost identical. Their conclusion: Sustaining consistent, above-average earnings growth over five years is so rare as to approach statistical insignificance.
Of course, the professors were looking only for those technology companies that would beat the median earnings growth rate. The analysis of Cisco suggests that investors are betting, in effect, that the company will beat the median earnings growth rate by a factor of five.
I DO not mean to pick on Cisco. It is unlikely that any company's earnings can grow 60 percent a year for the next five years.
But analysts are forecasting such growth for many companies. According to First Call/Thomson Financial, nearly 280 of the nearly 6,200 companies it tracks have consensus five-year projected earnings growth rates of 60 percent or more, annualized.
Some people say earnings don't matter in the new economy. But the professors foresaw that argument: They reached nearly identical results when they looked at sales growth rather than earnings growth.

LENGTH: 2336 words

HEADLINE: Florists Fling Bouquets For Money, Not Love

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

 BODY:
AN unsuspecting woman received a bouquet of flowers recently at her Fifth Avenue home. Set in a silver-plated urn, the $350 arrangement was lush with romantic pink roses, Italian poppies, deep-purple sweet peas, calla lilies and a card that read, "We'd be a good match."
Her secret admirer? A floral designer named David Beahm, whose intentions were not particularly romantic. The object of his attentions is a member of the organizing committee for a fall fund-raising gala for the Metropolitan Opera, with the unofficial position of flower chairwoman: she picks the florist who picks the flowers. 
 The unsolicited arrangement was "a courting bouquet," Mr. Beahm explained. He sent it in hopes of winning the account to provide flowers for a party that annually attracts some of New York's richest and swellest, names like Kissinger, Kravis and Bass. (He didn't want to reveal the woman's name, out of fear that his competitors would court her as well.)
Mr. Beahm sends up to five courting bouquets a week this time of year, with a retail value of $250 to $400 each, to women all over the city who are immersed in the charity social circuit and are selecting the decor for fall benefits. Doing flowers for the $1,000-a-plate dinners can make the career of an ambitious florist. Centerpieces that provoke oohs and ahhs among the guests can lead to contracts to provide arrangements at extravagant society weddings and Park Avenue dinner parties, and to fill the floral needs of hostesses like Carroll Petrie, who spends up to $20,000 a week in the summer filling her Southampton house with Casablanca lilies and white mixed blooms.
The "flower chairs" and those who advise them are the keys to this lucrative business, and they are courted in ways that go well beyond sending a free bouquet. Four florists discussed how, to win these women's favor, they provide flowers at discounts of 50 to 75 percent for the private needs of some of the city's wealthiest and most socially active hostesses. The largesse includes fresh flowers sent weekly to the women's homes, bouquets that they send to friends as thank-yous for dinner invitations and reductions of tens of thousands of dollars from the going price for their daughters' weddings.
The deep discounts are little known outside the world of the ultrasocial. "It's simply the way most of my friends keep fresh flowers in their houses year round," said Arlene Dahl, an actress who can be seen at many a Park Avenue dinner party. "It's like buying wholesale."
Ms. Dahl, who chooses the decor for the Oscar party for New York members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and for annual galas by the Pearl S. Buck Foundation and the New York Cancer Society, said that at this time of year, her apartment is abloom with courting bouquets. She considers it an innocuous form of petty bribery, she said, adding, "It's in the course of business."
She has not chosen florists for public events as a result of price breaks for her personal flowers, she said, but she knows others who do. In general, women who receive personal discounts say they see nothing unethical in choosing a florist for a public fund-raiser and receiving discounts for one's personal use.
The practice is related to the quiet but widespread convention that allows some of New York's best-dressed, most socially visible women, who are often most able to pay full price, to receive clothes free from designers, or have their homes furnished at a deep discount. "Doing an apartment for free or at 'a special price' is the only way for some newcomers to get the caliber of clients on their roster," said Mario Buatta, the interior decorator. "These women kind of sponsor you."
Polly Onet, a party planner with wide experience among the beau monde, agreed. "That's New York," she said. "Look at the girls we know who get all these cut-rate designer clothes, and they are loaded and they don't pay a dime, for clothes or jewelry. We see them every night, and they don't even dry-clean the clothes before they bring them back to the designer, and the designer doesn't care -- he is just happy that they are wearing the clothes."
Sharyn Mann, another object of Mr. Beahm's attention, is a well-connected social figure with homes in Manhattan and Quogue, N.Y., which she likes to keep well appointed with fresh blooms. "Flowers are your calling card," she said. "They represent you and your taste. Flowers are like angels blessing the room."
One day recently, Ms. Mann was showing Mr. Beahm pictures of a 28-acre island she and her husband, Stephen, an investment banker, had bought in Vero Beach, Fla. Sitting on the down-filled damask couch in the family room of her Fifth Avenue duplex, Ms. Mann said, "David is going to see the property before my husband." (Mr. Mann had approved the purchase sight unseen.) She turned to Mr. Beahm to say, "We must go to Vero Beach soon." Mr. Beahm agreed. With a blush on his cheeks and glee in his voice, he said, "I already have ideas of what we're going to do."
Mr. Beahm had that week filled Ms. Mann's living room overlooking Central Park with more than $600 worth of Kwanzan cherry blossoms and lilacs, at no cost. Ms. Mann, who was chairwoman of the Food Allergy Ball at the Plaza in December, hired him to do the flowers for the 70 tables at the event, which raised more than $2.2 million for charity. Ms. Mann introduced him to Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Valerie Zilkha, Fe Fendi, Iris Love and CeCe Kieselstein-Cord.
"My head was spinning with all the contacts," he said.
"If you make the right people happy and then meet the right people, that hopefully is going to make the discount worthwhile," he added. By the same logic, he said he did the gala flowers for $20,000, with the cost covered by an anonymous sponsor, though the job was really worth more than $80,000.
Ms. Mann said it is natural for an up-and-coming florist to offer a discounted fee for a high-profile assignment like her gala. "He was just starting, unknown in New York, so it was understood if he was good to me, I in turn would be good to him by introducing him to everyone I know," she said. "I purposefully looked for someone just starting. Other people who are established and well known don't try that hard."
As for the flowers he provides for little or nothing for her apartment, she denied using her position with the gala for personal gain. "I have never asked for anything personally," she said. "Whatever David charges, we pay the bill." Even if that bill is sometimes nothing.
Another charity woman, who receives about $300 worth of peonies and roses for her home each week, paying only about $100, also defended the practice. "Look, what's wrong with receiving discounted flowers at home?" she said, sipping a cocktail during a "tailgate party" at the New York Auto Show to benefit the East Side Settlement House last month. This woman is not a flower chairwoman, but she has many prominent friends. "We are giving these boys a big opportunity," she said, "and you know, important people come to my home and see what they do."
In fact, many florists say they refuse to court socialites, either with the occasional sample floral display or with more valuable long-term discounts. "I know it goes on," said Helena Lehane, a floral designer who places arrangements every week in the homes of several Upper East Side billionaires. "I think integrity has something to do with it. I have preferred over my career not to court."
Those who do court justify it as good business sense. Gaige Clark, a co-owner of Spruce, whose clients include the model Amber Valletta and the actress Julianne Moore, said, "I do give special discounts to special clients."
"Doing business with them has helped our name get out there, considering who they are sending their flowers to: people in fashion, people in the film industry," Ms. Clark said.
Some florists never have to weigh the ethical or economic issues, because they are already so busy they don't have to offer discounts. Two designers, Robert Isabell and Philip Baloun, have long had a near duopoly on society parties and benefits, and both deny courting clients with personal discounts. In fact, hostesses sometimes grumble about their high prices. Donna Harvey, a senior account manager at George Trescher Associates, which organizes charity fund-raisers, said it was hard to stay within a budget when planning a party with one of the top-tier florists.
"They are very talented, but many times we have to look elsewhere for someone who is eager for the business," she said.
Lauren Veronis, another socialite involved in the charity world, is heavily courted by up-and-coming florists. "If you get a nod from Lauren Veronis, you're in for the long haul," one florist said.
Ms. Veronis, who was chairwoman this spring of a gala celebrating the 30th anniversary of Zubin Mehta's directorship of the Israel Philharmonic and a buffet dinner at the Four Seasons for the Irvington Institute for Immunological Research, is flattered by the sentiment. For both events, Ms. Veronis broke with the florist she has long favored, Mr. Isabell. "We used Robert for years, and he was wonderful," she said. "But it was time to move on and give the up-and-coming a chance."
For both events she chose David Tutera, a party planner in Mamaroneck, N.Y., who, she said, has not given her any discounts for personal flowers.
"The understanding always is when they do a big charity that there is no budget for the party," she said. "We want all of our proceeds to go to the basic research, so we're delighted to provide the audience for their work to give them big exposure. But in return they have to work below cost."
Mr. Tutera, whose clients include Clarissa Bronfman, several Tisch family members and Iris Cantor, said: "I don't exactly give them financial discounts. I give them more attention and hand-holding. Personally, I'm totally with them every step of the way and I make sure they get the best flowers.
"I know in the long run what I will receive if I give them a lot of attention. I know who is on their guest list. The secret to being successful in the society world in New York is all word of mouth, and I know what they can do for me if I give them a better product for a little less."
Another up-and-coming florist who does give Ms. Veronis a price break is Lisa Marie McWilliams, who said she provides flowers for the Veronis homes in New York and Southampton more than 40 times a year, for 40 percent less than the going rate. Ms. McWilliams said she was so grateful for the exposure her work receives because she is Ms. Veronis's florist that she would not think of charging more. Moreover, it is her way of repaying Ms. Veronis for encouraging her to leave a previous employer and go into business on her own. "I owe so much to her," said Ms. McWilliams, who has not handled any of the charity accounts Ms. Veronis oversees, but hopes to in the future.
Ms. Veronis said she had never asked Ms. McWilliams for a discount, and seemed unaware she was receiving one. "Whenever I use anyone personally, I have never received a reduction or asked for one," she said. "It would be inappropriate to expect something like that."
The hand-holding that florists provide is no small thing on the social circuit. Like fashion designers, interior designers and even some hairstylists, florists have gone from being members of a service class to escorts and dinner-party guests in some of the swankest company. At a gala for the Horticultural Society of New York on Tuesday, where the city's new and old society converged around 40 tables set with flowers by 48 designers, Suzette de Marigny Smith, a chairwoman of the event, described "the very special relationship" some people have with florists.
"They have to be little geniuses," she said. "They have to know more about you than your dressmaker and your interior decorator and your caterer."
Ms. de Marigny Smith, who was wearing a Sander Witlin gold lame dress with hand-painted irises and waving a gold wand, said some of the florists "are very amusing and attractive people, and they are good conversationalists, and they're just fun to have at parties -- like flowers."
Another coveted assignment for floral designers is the society wedding. Some admit that they are willing to offer huge discounts on jobs worth tens of thousands of dollars to have their work seen at its most extravagant by the right crowd.
Joanne de Guardiola, an interior designer who is a player in prominent charities like the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and the New York Botanical Garden (she is fashion chairwoman of the garden's June gala), could have hired a name-brand florist for the wedding of her stepdaughter, Jeanne de Guardiola, next month. Instead, she is using Ms. McWilliams.
"This could be very big for me," Ms. McWilliams said. "There will be a lot of important people there who could very well recommend me for the next step, the charity parties." She said she would charge the family $50,000 to $75,000, less than half what a comparable job for another wedding would cost.
Ms. McWilliams, who speaks to Joanne de Guardiola every week, is planning a white and cobalt theme with lots of peonies for the wedding, which will be in Southampton and will be attended by 400.
Like many florists in her position, she must weigh how long she can continue in business without making a profit on some of her biggest jobs.
For Mr. Beahm, who said he lived hand to mouth despite consorting with the rich and powerful, the flower business is a dicey one indeed. "Personally, they'll spend as little as they can get away with," he said, referring to the women who ask him to send bouquets to friends as thank-yous for a dinner party or to mark a birthday. "The minimum I'll let someone get away with paying is $50, and yet they'll get a $250 bouquet. It's killing me. I have to remind these ladies all the time that I'm not the charity."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Away From the Glare, Dow Corning Recovers Its Footing

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Mich.

 BODY:
GARY E. ANDERSON knows what most people think of when they hear the name Dow Corning: breast implants, and nothing else. And if Mr. Anderson, Dow Corning's chief executive, were an irritable kind of fellow, that would irk him mightily.
After all, Dow Corning makes 10,000 products for more than 30,000 customers, and it never derived more than 1 percent of its sales from breast implants. These days, operating earnings are growing robustly. 
 Yet the impact of implant-related class-action suits has kept Dow Corning operating under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws since 1995. And because Dow Corning is owned by the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc., not directly by shareholders, and because it sells no consumer products, neither the business press nor securities analysts have paid much attention to the company's recovery.
But irritability is not Mr. Anderson's style. A soft-spoken, easygoing man who does not wait for Fridays to dress casually, he patiently discusses the implant issue when asked.
No, Dow did not lose customers, suppliers or employees when the implant debacle hit. Yes, he stands by subsequent studies that absolve silicone from blame in autoimmune and other diseases. Yes, he had hoped that Dow Corning would have emerged from bankruptcy by now, but no, it probably will not for another couple of years.
Only after answering such questions does Mr. Anderson turn to the subject that really makes his juices flow: Dow Corning's mainstay silicone business.
"We sell something to every SIC code," Mr. Anderson said, referring to a common classification system for industries.
SMALL wonder. Silicones are remarkably inert materials; they do not conduct electricity, they are resistant to heat and cold, and they don't react with most chemicals. They are thus ideal insulators, protectants and additives.
Dow Corning routinely pumps about 8 percent of sales into research -- a high percentage for a materials company -- and its roster of patents and products keeps swelling. Its silicones add a soft, nongreasy feel to skin lotions and help shampoos leave behind high-gloss hair. They provide leak-proof seals for automobile engines and coatings for air bags.
The company just introduced a new line of silicone adhesives and protective sealants that make it possible to reduce the size of computer chips without risk that they will short out. The latest PlayStation from Sony already uses the chips, and Dow Corning executives predict that the semiconductor market, now accounting for about 2 percent of sales, will bring as much as 15 percent of sales and 20 percent of profits by 2004.
The specter of huge settlements over the breast implant issue keeps Dow Corning in bankruptcy. But as Siegfried Haberer, a 30-year Dow Corning veteran and now its executive vice president, said, "I haven't seen major impact from the bankruptcy on our business in the last five years, and I don't think I'll see it in the next five."
Dow Corning's fiscal health -- not to mention a study last year that seemed to clear breast implants in health problems -- infuriates its legal antagonists. Sybil Niden Goldrich, co-founder of the Command Trust Network, which distributes silicone implant information, and a self-described "silicone breast implant survivor," has long been critical of the scientific studies of implants. "It seems unfair that you can do business as usual under the protection of bankruptcy," she said.
IN one sense, the same factors that have kept Dow Corning's rebound a secret have given it a certain immunity to public anger. Started in 1943 by Dow Chemical and Corning, it has never had to contend with skittish shareholders. And because its customers are other businesses, its sales have not been affected by any emotional backlash. "The guy ordering silicone sealants isn't thinking of negative public relations," said J. Jeffrey Cianci, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read.
Mr. Anderson said customers have rallied round him. "I got tons of reassuring calls from customers and suppliers," he said. "You could tell they were thinking, 'There but for the grace of God go I.' "
There has been no mass flight of employees; in fact, the list has grown with newcomers -- including many women.
"Of course I'm sympathetic to the women who've gone through this," said Denise L. Wiggins, who joined as global marketing communications manager in 1997. "But during the interviews, I got the sense of a company with high integrity and a solid base of employees. The breast implant situation just wasn't top of mind for me."
That "situation" has given Dow Corning a rough financial ride, though. Before its bankruptcy filing, the company took nearly $2 billion in pretax charges to reflect its liability under an industrywide settlement agreement. As of Dec. 31, 1999, Dow Corning was named in 25,000 pending lawsuits.
To make matters worse, the Asian economic meltdown sent Dow Corning's sales and profits into a nosedive in 1998. Its revenues have been stuck at around $2.6 billion for the last three years.
Still, last year the company was back to $220 million in operating income -- a nice rebound from the $831 million operating loss in 1998. And net income was back to $109.7 million, a lot better than the net loss of $598 million in 1998.
"If Dow Corning were publicly traded, it would be one of the better-regarded specialty chemical companies on the street," said Mark Gulley, an analyst with Banc of America Securities.
Dow Corning's parents have offered not just sympathy, but empathy. Dow Chemical, after all, went through its own tumult when dioxin, a byproduct of its defoliant Agent Orange, was branded a health hazard.
"We told them, get some high-level people to focus on the implant issue, and let everyone else focus on the rest of the business," said William S. Stavropoulos, chief executive of Dow Chemical. In fact, in 1992 Keith McKennon, a Dow Chemical executive who had coordinated much of Dow's public response to the Agent Orange litigation, joined Dow Corning as interim chief executive. One of the first things he did was to plead the company's case on "Larry King Live."
Both Dow Chemical and Corning emphatically deny persistent rumors that Corning is losing interest in the venture and that Dow will buy its share. "Dow Corning has focused all of its energies on one field of science, and we're enjoying the fruits of that, so why mess with it?" Mr. Stavropoulos said.
Corning, meanwhile, has moved heavily into fiber optics, an area that makes great use of silicone coatings. Thus, Dow Corning's products "are in high demand in many of the same growth markets Corning is pursuing," said Keith Horn, technical director of organic materials in Corning's science and technology group.
But one high-growth industry is conspicuously absent from Dow Corning's to-do list. The company is soured, perhaps forever, on medical applications, which in 1990 represented 7 percent of sales. Dow Corning sold its line of implants for knees, hips and the like soon after the first breast implant suits, and has scuttled research into synthetic skin, eye fluids and artificial eyes.
"We could have continued the evolution toward a bionic person, so society has lost out," Mr. Anderson said. "But until trial lawyers are reined in, and we get better laws, it's just not worth the aggravation of making anything that goes into the body."

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
A Lost Generation Seeks Its Due

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
DURING a lunch last month with Ann A. Fishman, a marketing consultant on generational issues, I had the eerie feeling that she had been reading my resume -- or my mind.
She was talking about the characteristics of the so-called silent generation -- people too young to have struggled through much of the Great Depression and fought in World War II, but too old to be baby boomers. The "silents," less numerous than the generations they are sandwiched between, are often overlooked by advertisers and other purveyors of popular culture who are obsessed with appealing to teenagers, young adults, boomers or the elderly. 
 This goes a long way toward explaining why I can surf through scores of cable channels and find so little to watch. It also tells me why a movie I like runs in theaters for only about 15 minutes, or why only one or two copies of it are stocked at the video store.
"The G.I. generation gets attention, and rightly so, because of its role in World War II; the boomers get attention because of their numbers," said Ms. Fishman, who is president of the Generational-Targeted Marketing Corporation, based in New Orleans. "History has forced the silents, members of a transitional generation, to be overlooked."
Members of the silent generation are now in their mid-50's to mid-70's. A total of 49 million of them were born, compared with 79 million boomers (who would now be in their early 40's to mid-50's) and 63 million of the G.I. generation (now in their mid-70's to late 90's), according to "Generations: The History of America's Future, 1584 to 2069," by William Strauss and Neil Howe (William Morrow, 1991).
Ms. Fishman, who has also served as a fellow with the Senate Special Committee on Aging, is careful to note that not everyone in a generational group is alike, but they do tend to share certain characteristics. "The G.I. generation, for instance, is a generation of doers who believe the good life has to be earned," she said. "Baby boomers tend to be self-absorbed and rebellious against authority; they were the main force in the antiwar movement in the Vietnam era. Silents have always done the right things. They did what their parents told them. They are reliable and show up for work on time. Silents tend to be helpers and teachers, and their generation has produced most of the great civil rights leaders -- but not a president."
AS the silents age, many are beginning to panic, because they have never had a great adventure. They were not called on to save the world, as the G.I. generation was, and they have not been as wrapped up in satisfying themselves as the boomers have been.
"They think they are due," Ms. Fishman said. "They want more of a taste of life. Many see it as now or never."
That now-or-never feeling is one reason that many workers in their late 50's and early 60's are choosing to retire early and to proceed on their own terms -- perhaps in other work -- in what some experts call a second middle age, made possible partly by advances in medicine and healthier lifestyles. And, thanks to the long economic boom, many of them can afford it.
Joe Taylor, who will be 56 next month, retired last May from a career as a school psychologist in Corydon, Ind., to start a woodworking business in his home.
"I didn't do this for the money," Mr. Taylor said. "I was tired of what I had been doing and wanted to do something more creative. I find woodwork satisfying. People enjoy what I make."
Mr. Taylor is keenly aware of the role that history can play in shaping generations. When he was in college in the early 1960's, he used a student deferment to avoid being drafted and sent to Vietnam. "I regret that to this day," he said. "I missed my war."
People like Mr. Taylor should serve as a wake-up call to corporations and other employers who often overlook silent-generation workers. Ms. Fishman contends that unless companies move aggressively to retain the silents, they risk losing valuable workers who are at the peak of their expertise.
"They also risk losing valuable mentors who help them retain younger workers," she said. "The Generation Xers, whom companies complain they can't keep, get along much better with the silents than with boomers. Gen Xers like being mentored because it gives them a sense of family, which many are lacking. So silents are not only the top performers in the workplace, they are a key to retaining younger workers."
One way to keep silents on the job, she suggested, is to offer work schedules that allow blocks of time off -- perhaps three or four months a year -- for adventure or self-fulfillment.
Mr. Taylor likes that idea. "If my school had offered me something like that," he said, "presumably at a reduced salary, I would have stayed on."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: John Montgomery;
Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company Portfolio

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
ON Sunday mornings, John Montgomery plays the flute with a folk-rock group at St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church in Houston. On Tuesday evenings, he rehearses for three hours with the group's vocalists and other musicians. "We could really use a drummer," he complains.
A former research engineer at M.I.T., Mr. Montgomery, who is 44, sees his music as complementary to the computer-based calculations he uses to pick stocks for the $42 million Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company Portfolio. "Math is the underlying language of music," he said. 
 The Ultra-Small fund has turned in some sweet results, returning 23.3 percent a year, annualized, for the three years through April 30, versus 8.2 percent for its peers in the small value category, according to Morningstar Inc., and 15.2 percent for the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks.
Mr. Montgomery came to money management by an unlikely route. In 1985, he joined the Houston transit system as a senior budget analyst and during his off-hours developed computer models to manage his investments. He said that in 1990 and 1991, his last years there, his investment earnings far exceeded his modest salary. In 1993, he started Bridgeway Capital Management, which now manages a total of $135 million in four actively managed funds, two index funds and a dozen private accounts.
Mr. Montgomery's background in budgeting leads him to run his firm economically. The firm does not advertise, for example. And because Mr. Montgomery does not allow personal trading by his firm's seven employees, Bridgeway has no need for a compliance officer to monitor their investments.
Moreover, by negotiating with brokerage firms, he has trimmed the average commission the fund pays to just a penny a share. The average such expense is 6 cents.
MANAGERS of successful small-cap stock funds generally face a problem: their funds are flooded with cash, forcing them to buy bigger stocks. In Mr. Montgomery's view, a small-cap fund is easily managed as long as its total assets do not exceed the average market capitalization of the stocks it owns. So he closed the fund to new investors in June 1998, when assets reached $27.5 million; he plans to shut it to all new investments, including those by existing shareholders, when assets hit $55 million, the fund's current average market capitalization.
That market cap is still far smaller than that of the typical small-cap fund. Mr. Montgomery focuses his search for stocks on the smallest 10 percent of issues on the New York Stock Exchange, but also picks from among 2,000 very small stocks in an index created by the Center for Research in Securities Prices, which tracks the smallest stocks traded on the Big Board, the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq.
In choosing stocks, Mr. Montgomery never visits companies or meets with their management. Instead, he uses five proprietary computer models, the details of which he is loathe to discuss.
He does say, however, that four of the models review fundamental data like per-share earnings growth and cash flow; the fifth analyzes technical factors like trading volume and relative price appreciation. Each model is used to pick a list of 10 stocks; the names sometimes overlap.
"We're a black box shop," he said in a slight Texas drawl. "We put the data in and the computer cranks it out."
The portfolio is filled with cheap stocks: its typical price-to-earnings ratio is in the low to mid-teens, though its three-year earnings growth rate averages 36 percent a year.
Mr. Montgomery runs the technical model monthly. Three of the fundamental screens highlight value-oriented stocks and are run weekly. The fourth, which looks for attractive growth stocks, is run daily.
The fund owns about 160 stocks, giving it a degree of diversification that dampens the inherent risks of investing in the smallest stocks, he said. Typically, he sells stocks when they no longer meet his models' criteria, or when the models produce better candidates.
AMONG the stocks he likes is Team America, a Worthington, Ohio, company that provides payroll, retirement plan management and other human resources services to business. Its per-share earnings, cash flow and sales have been strong, he said, but the company's share price is "dirt cheap," in part because of an acquisition-related charge taken last year.
As the company moves forward, Mr. Montgomery said, the share price could double in the next 12 months. He bought shares in May 1999 at $4.78; they closed at $4.50 on Friday, 16 times his 2000 earnings estimate of 28 cents a share.
Another favorite is the Howell Corporation, an integrated oil and gas company in Houston. "Oil prices are way up, and its stock price is dead in the water," he said. But because its cash flow was $3 a share last year, he said, "you could earn your price back with cash flow alone in less than three years."
Mr. Montgomery, who bought shares last July at $6.50, predicts three-year earnings growth of 15 percent a year, on average. The shares closed Friday at $7.1875, or 4.5 times his earnings estimate of $1.60 a share this year.
He also likes Lifemark, a health maintenance organization in Phoenix. "The industry as a whole is cheap," he said, "but this company is doing great."
He noted that the company has doubled its annual per-share earnings for three consecutive years. Wall Street expects earnings growth to average 30 percent a year for the next five years.
He bought shares in October 1998 at $4.375; it closed Friday at $4, or 6 times analysts' consensus earnings of 65 cents a share for the fiscal year ending in May 2001.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
The Case Against Retail Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
SPEND, spend and then spend some more. Americans have always liked to shop. But over the last couple of years, consumers in this country have been buying at an unprecedented rate.
With all that stuff flying off the shelves, you would think that retailing stocks would be in great shape. From the start of 1998 until the end of 1999, that assessment would have been correct: the S. & P. retail stores index nearly doubled. 
 But since then the group has been a bust. The index is down 15 percent this year.
A good chunk of that decline began on Wednesday, when a team of analysts at Goldman Sachs cut its ratings on many retailing stocks. George Strachan, a Goldman vice president, was in the group that issued the report. He took time last week to talk about why he has turned cautious. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Since so many stocks were involved in this downgrade, your shift in opinion seems based on macro environment factors. Is that the case?
 
A. Yes, this is a macro call. It is not based on what the companies are doing today, and the fundamentals still look pretty good.
We look at a number of leading indicators that power spending growth. One is real wage growth, which peaked in April 1998 at 3.4 percent, and has now decelerated to 1.3 percent.
The second is housing turnover, which also peaked in the spring of 1998 at a growth rate of 16.1 percent. Currently it is declining at a 7.6 percent annual rate. That means fewer and fewer new and existing homes are being sold, even though the level of activity is still very high.
The third factor we look at is installment credit, which is growing at the same rate it did a year ago.
With personal consumption spending growing at somewhere between 5 percent and 6 percent and all these indicators heading south, we felt we would probably see a deceleration in retail sales growth in the second half of the year. That's why we cut our ratings.
Q. Could you give some insight into the anatomy of your decision?
 
A. Well, there were six people involved in this call. We have been watching these indicators for a year and a half.
I may have let the decision to downgrade these stocks slide a little bit because of the market, and because from an absolute perspective real wage growth at 2 percent was not so bad. But it is lower now, and we decided it was now more appropriate to be cautious.
 
Q. The Federal Reserve has been raising short-term rates, and is likely to raise them some more. Was that a factor?
A. We don't see much, if any, correlation between change in the federal funds rate and changes in real personal consumption expenditure. If I am on my way to Wal-Mart and I hear the Fed has raised the funds rate, the information doesn't change my behavior a bit. We are six months into a rising rate environment and spending hasn't slowed a whit.
Q. How much of a slowdown do you see?
 
A. We think we will see a deceleration in the growth of personal consumption expenditures from about 5.7 percent currently to around 4 percent. Now, 4 percent is a pretty decent level of growth. In an expansion you normally see personal consumption growth average about 3 percent. So that deceleration may not be enough to satisfy the Fed.
 
Q. And yet since the start of the year the stocks have been weak. Are retailing stocks projecting a slowdown in the economy?
 
A. I wouldn't say retailing stocks have been leading indicators of economic slowdowns.
We had an early cyclical move in the stocks in early 1991, and then they underperformed for a couple of years. What has made retailing interesting in this cycle has been the rise in personal consumption alongside the problems in Asia, which slowed exports and industrial production. That generated a late cycle rally. Everyone wanted to own Wal-Mart, for example, because it had little Asian exposure. The growth names had a marvelous late cycle move, which is uncharacteristic.
 
Q. What other retailers are growth stocks?
 
A. In addition to Wal-Mart, Costco, Target Stores and Kohl's are the pure growth stocks in my sector. Tiffany is another growth stock, but I don't cover it.
A lot of these stocks have outperformed the market by as much as 80 percent over the last two years. And I think these five stocks will continue to provide market leadership. They still have tremendous growth opportunities in front of them.
 
Q. Which are you less enthusiastic about?
 
A. We cut our ratings on Federated Department Stores, May Department Stores, Neiman-Marcus, Abercrombie & Fitch, TJX and Ross Stores to market performer from market outperformer.
