HEADLINE: Mbeki Details Quest to Grasp South Africa's AIDS Disaster

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 6

 BODY:
For months, President Thabo Mbeki says, he pored through medical journals, consulted with scientists and struggled to understand the epidemiology of the AIDS epidemic that is ravaging his country.
"The problem was so big that I personally felt that I wanted to understand this matter better," Mr. Mbeki said today as he addressed an advisory panel of international AIDS researchers here. 
 "I'm reading all these complicated things, language I don't understand," he said. "So I pile through lots and lots of research documentation. I've got dictionaries all around me in case there are words that are difficult to understand. I phone the minister of health and ask her what does this word mean and she explains."
In this strikingly personal speech, Mr. Mbeki offered his first detailed explanation of how he came to consult with two Americans who argue that H.I.V. does not cause AIDS. The decision, which became public two months ago, quickly touched off a firestorm of criticism.
Leading scientists have criticized him for wasting time on discredited theories while South Africa is suffering one of the highest H.I.V. infection rates in the world. Some researchers have called for a boycott of an international AIDS conference that is scheduled to be held here in July.
And as prominent American newspapers published editorials last month condemning his stance, some government officials here began to fear that the issue would overshadow Mr. Mbeki's first state visit to the United States, set for May 20, a visit that some had hoped would focus on South Africa's blossoming economy.
Today, Mr. Mbeki said that he and his ministers know that the human immunodeficiency virus causes AIDS. He said he reached out to the Americans when he discovered how differently the disease appeared in sub-Saharan Africa as compared with the United States and Europe.
According to the United Nations AIDS program, two types of H.I.V. are currently recognized, and the most common, H.I.V.-1, has 10 genetically distinct subtypes.
Subtype B, which is most commonly transmitted through homosexual contact and intravenous drug use, is primarily found in the Americas, Europe, Australia, Japan and the Caribbean. Subtype C, most often found in South Africa and India, seems to be more infectious with a higher potential for heterosexual transmission, the United Nations says.
When he could not find satisfying explanations for such differences, Mr. Mbeki said, he began exploring the work of researchers who believe that poverty and malnutrition are likely causes of the disease in Africa.
"We were looking for an answer because all of the information that has been communicated says in reality that we are faced with a catastrophe," Mr. Mbeki explained in his speech at the Sheraton Hotel here. "And you can't respond to a catastrophe merely by saying, 'I will do what is routine.' "
Mr. Mbeki refused to dismiss the work of the American researchers David Rasnick, a biochemist, and Peter Duesberg, a professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at the University of California at Berkeley.
Both men are included in the government's 33-member advisory panel, which met today for the first time and will advise Mr. Mbeki on the cause and best treatments for AIDS. The panel is evenly split between those who believe H.I.V. causes AIDS, including Luc Montagnier of the Pasteur Institute in Paris, whose research team discovered the virus -- and those who do not.
As Mr. Mbeki described his efforts to understand H.I.V., which has infected more than 3 million people in this country of 44 million, he portrayed an intensely driven, hands-on leader who is reluctant to leave critical decision-making to others.
Tom Lodge, a professor of political science at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, said: "In one way, of course, it's an admirable indication of an extremely conscientious and intelligent chief executive. But I think he's also a compulsive interferer. There is a medical establishment. You leave, as it were, to the experts certain things that require expertise."
Similar criticisms come from doctors in the medical community here, on this and other aspects of policy.
In March, government officials scrambled to explain how $6.2 million of the country's $17 million AIDS budget went unspent last year. And last year, Mr. Mbeki stunned health experts by questioning the safety of the standard anti-AIDS drug AZT. The government has decided not to distributed the drug in public hospitals here, even though the National Institutes of Health in the United States has determined that the benefits of the drug far outweigh the potential side effects.

HEADLINE: New Questions On Drug Plans As Costs Soar

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Americans took home some 2.8 billion prescriptions last year, obtaining some of the newest, most heavily advertised and most expensive drugs. They bought many of those medications as members of managed care drug plans run by pharmacy benefit managers, companies that arrange discounts from retail drugstores and often operate mail-order pharmacies on behalf of employer health plans.
Now the pharmacy benefit management companies, or P.B.M.'s, which handle drug benefits for 200 million Americans, are being assigned an important role in widely discussed proposals to add a drug benefit to Medicare. 
 Supporters of a Medicare drug benefit, including President Clinton, believe that the pharmacy benefit managers could obtain discounts from pharmacists and rebates from drugmakers for all Medicare beneficiaries, just as they are expected to do for employer health plans and Medicare health maintenance organizations. The managers, sponsors suggest, would help rein in the costs of the new Medicare program.
But pharmacy benefit managers are coming under increasing scrutiny. Justice Department officials are investigating possible illegal kickbacks. Pending lawsuits contend that some pharmacy benefit managers have violated their duty to act in the best interest of patients. State regulators are weighing concerns about the absence of oversight of the industry.
At Senate Finance Committee hearings in March on the Medicare proposals, the General Accounting Office questioned whether pharmacy benefit managers would be able to control costs under government disclosure requirements. And health care experts say that even for private companies, drug benefit managers have not been able to put a lid on surging costs.
"P.B.M.'s or no P.B.M.'s, it does not have much effect on the growth trend in pharmaceutical expenses," said Henry Aaron, a health care economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington.
The drug benefit managers do perform valuable services. They handle billions of automated transactions, checking plan members' eligibility online and eliminating mountains of paperwork. They also monitor the drug-buying behavior of individuals, helping people avoid dangerous drug combinations. And for an extra fee from the health plan, they will remind people with serious health problems to follow their doctors' orders.
But though nearly three in four Americans are in drug plans, by the industry's count, national spending on drugs is growing three times as fast as overall health care spending, which itself rose about 6 percent in 1999. Employers' health care expenses were a big factor in the 4.3 percent rise in labor costs in the year ended in March, the biggest increase since the early 1990's. Drug expenditures will double in five years to $200 billion and rise to $300 billion by 2010 if the current pace continues, said C. Daniel Mullins, a pharmaceutical economist at the University of Maryland.
Pharmacy benefit managers say they can slow the pace for health plans that are willing to place tight limits on members' drug choices. Drug costs, they add, would rise even faster without their industry's efforts.
"A third of the increases is from increased utilization," or more people using more drugs, said Judith Cahill, executive director of the Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy, an industry-supported professional group of pharmacists. "A third is from new, improved products, and a third is from plain old vanilla inflation in the cost of products."
Employers are feeling the cost pressures. "The largest component in employers' health costs is not in-patient care, not out-patient care or doctors' office visits or X-rays; it is prescription drugs," said Raymond Brusca, vice president for benefits at the Black & Decker Corporation.
Many health plans have raised premiums and shifted a larger portion of the price of a prescription to employees and their families. Others, mindful of union concerns and competition for employees in a tight labor market, have swallowed hard and absorbed the increases.
General Motors was one of the first big employers to hire a pharmacy benefit management company, in the 1980's. G.M. spent $762 million on drugs in its self-insured plans last year, up nearly 13 percent from 1998. The company recently hired a doctor of pharmacy to work with the P.B.M. to try to tame these costs.
Rob Moroni, the company's assistant director of health plans, said G.M. expected a cost increase of about 20 percent this year, fueled by large numbers of older retirees covered by the company's plan. Elderly people typically take three times as many drugs as people under 65.
After several mergers last year, the pharmacy benefit management market is largely controlled by the three largest concerns. Merck-Medco, PCS Health Systems and Express Scripts say they have three-quarters of the country's P.B.M. business.
Efforts by those companies and by the other pharmacy benefit managers to control costs have largely been stymied. The savings from discounts that pharmacy benefit managers get from drugstores are reduced by manufacturers' price increases and swept away by intense customer demand for advertised drugs, which are typically more expensive than alternative products. Drugmakers spent $1.9 billion on consumer advertising last year, according to Scott-Levin, a research firm in Newtown, Pa. And sales of prescription drugs rose 18 percent, compared with 1998 sales, according to IMS Health Inc., a market research firm in Westport, Conn.
Industry experts say the pharmacy benefit managers, which typically charge employers up to 50 cents for each transaction as well as other fees, have strong incentives to increase the use of drugs.
"With an increase in utilization, the P.B.M.'s get more money," said Debbie Stern, vice president of Rxperts Managed Care Consulting, a drug consulting firm in Irvine, Calif.
What is more, drugmakers promote new and highly competitive -- often more expensive -- products by giving the pharmacy benefit managers rebates based on sales. (The rebates may or may not be shared with employers.) That system, critics say, encourages P.B.M.'s to choose higher priced drugs.
"I haven't seen anybody giving rebates on generics," the lowest-priced drugs, said Patricia Wilson, a pharmaceuticals consultant based in Rosemont, Pa.
The transaction fees that employers pay for the billions of prescriptions filled each year mount up. But Barrett Toan, chief executive of Express Scripts, said these fees merely "cover expenses to process those claims." He said his customers were reluctant to authorize harsh limits on drug benefits that might antagonize their employees at a time of low unemployment.
At the heart of the pharmacy benefit management business is a list, or formulary, of preferred drugs. The employee or health plan member has a lower copayment on these products, an incentive to choose them. In theory, the preferred drugs -- which include many generic versions of drugs that have lost patent protection -- are as good as or better than any in their class as well as the most cost-effective.
But lawsuits filed on behalf of drug plan members over the last three years in Federal courts in several states argue that sponsors of managed care drug plans are violating their fiduciary duty to act in the best interest of patients rather than for company profits, as required by the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act, or Erisa. Several of the suits have been filed against Merck-Medco, a unit of Merck & Company, and at least one is against PCS, which is owned by the Rite-Aid Corporation.
Spokesmen for PCS and Merck-Medco said the lawsuits were without merit.
"We believe we have a long history of developing plans and programs that are designed to benefit plan sponsors and plan members, with the ultimate goal of saving money for those plan sponsors and plan members," said John Bloomfield, a spokesman for Merck-Medco.
Some critics have raised questions about how much pharmacy benefit managers really save employer health plans. These companies typically offer large employers discounts of 12 percent to 15 percent, which come out of the retail pharmacy's pocket. The discounts are subtracted from manufacturers' posted average wholesale prices. But those prices may be inflated. "They are not an average, not wholesale and not a price, other than what employers pay," Ms. Wilson, the pharmaceuticals consultant, said.
While a customer waits at the drug counter, a computer screen displays the terms of her insurance: the discount from list price, a dispensing fee of $2.50 or so for the pharmacist, the customer's other prescriptions and recent purchases, and her copayment. The health plan typically gets an electronic bill for most of the charge.
The drugmakers' prices are flexible, depending on the buyer. "They set a price that they think they can get away with," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University.
New drugs are frequently introduced, and some are priced 20 or 30 times as much as older treatments for the same illnesses. Drug prices increased 5.2 percent in the 12 months ended in March, while the cost of medical care including drugs rose only 3.9 percent and overall consumer prices were up 3.7 percent, according to the Labor Department.
Richard T. Clark, president of Merck-Medco, said health plans -- employers and their workers -- pay prices that are "15 percent lower on average" than people without insurance.
Still, because the pharmacy benefit managers and the drugmakers can keep their price decisions well out of public view, questions continue to arise. The National Association of State Insurance Commissioners is considering whether to recommend legislation to regulate the industry. Kathleen Sibelius, the Kansas insurance commissioner, said there was "a growing concern about the monopoly of control by pharmacy benefit managers who currently are not under a regulatory umbrella, are not licensed or reviewed."
"They aren't screened in any way, but they may have a significant impact on access to prescription drugs and costs associated with that access," she added.
William J. Scanlon, director of health financing issues at the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, advised the Senate Finance Committee in March that if the drug benefit managers' role in Medicare was expanded, the pharmacy managers would have to give up the secrecy that now cloaks their pricing deals.
The Justice Department has subpoenaed records of PCS and Merck-Medco, the two biggest pharmacy benefit management companies, in an inquiry over the fiduciary duty to drug plan members and whether certain types of payments to the industry involve kickbacks. No charges have been filed. Both companies said they comply with the laws and were cooperating with the investigation.
Jim Sheehan, chief of the civil division in the United States Attorney's office in Philadelphia, who is heading the Justice Department inquiry, said there was "a tension" between the benefits that pharmacy benefit managers provide and "where they make their money." He added, "The efficiencies in the business are in the claims processing and the mail order services; the money is in the rebates."
Chris Jennings, a White House adviser on health policy, said the administration's Medicare proposal would include requirements to enhance the quality of service to Medicare enrollees. The plan, he said, was built on "taking the best private practices and avoiding the worst."

HEADLINE: Running for Office? The President Has Some Ideas

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
President Clinton has become a crucial behind-the-scenes player in the 2000 campaign, serving as a tactical adviser for House, Senate and gubernatorial candidates around the country.
Although the spotlight has shifted to Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton, prominent Democrats portray Mr. Clinton's role as that of an enormously valuable Strategist in Chief. They describe him as a sponge for absorbing political statistics -- a skill that is all the more enhanced because he has run twice in all 435 Congressional districts. And he willingly brings his well-honed political instincts to bear while exerting the power of the presidency to elect Democrats. 
 Mr. Clinton has been seeking election or re-election since 1974, when he was defeated in a race for Congress. And the president's closest advisers say that although he is no longer running himself, his passion for electoral politics has never receded. They also cite another, more personal, reason for Mr. Clinton's deep involvement: he wants to burnish his own legacy with the election of Mr. Gore to succeed him, the installation of Mrs. Clinton as senator from New York and the return of the House to Democratic control.
"The guy can't live without a campaign in his life," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. "Life is a campaign for him. He needs a campaign to keep him going. This guy is not going to go into an igloo and freeze away. He can't help but advise."
Politicians and historians say they have never known of a president so deeply immersed in politics -- or a White House that, even during a lame-duck period, was so focused on polls and electoral considerations.
The president is particularly engrossed in the first lady's race, and to a lesser degree in Mr. Gore's. But his involvement in campaigns from coast to coast is extraordinary.
Mr. Clinton is much more than a fund-raiser in these campaigns, even as he has collected millions of dollars for House and Senate candidates. He offers candidates pointers on television and radio advertising scripts. He played a significant role in urging some prospects to run in the first place, and he often schedules trips and policy announcements with an eye to helping specific contenders.
This portrait of Mr. Clinton has been gleaned from interviews with more than two dozen candidates and strategists, as well as lawmakers on Capitol Hill and officials at the White House and at the Democratic National Committee. Joe Lockhart, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, turned down a request to interview the president; some of Mr. Clinton's advisers said they were worried that it would seem unpresidential for him to discuss his activities openly.
"He's the ultimate junkie," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. "He has the best walking knowledge of anybody in American politics."
Referring to Representative Ron Klink's drive to oust Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Mr. Torricelli said: "Last night he called me about the Klink race. He said he was convinced Klink could beat Santorum. He said, 'I want to do something in Philadelphia to bring our base in for Klink. I know he can carry western Pennsylvania, but he may have trouble consolidating the base in the east.' "
The president's network of contacts is vast because he has stumped in more than half the Congressional districts, his advisers say.
Mr. Klink said that he telephoned the White House after he won his primary in April and Mr. Clinton "took my call immediately."
"It's not just lip service," Mr. Klink said. "He's really focused on this race. He can open doors with other individuals by telling them that this race is very meaningful to him."
Sometimes Mr. Clinton calls candidates on the telephone. More often, he grabs them to talk politics during his travels or at the White House.
Craig Smith, a former Clinton political director, said he was at the White House recently to watch an Arkansas Razorbacks basketball game. At halftime, Mr. Smith said, the president cornered a group of his guests and held forth about the Democrats' presidential prospects in several states.
He suggested that Mr. Gore not write off North Carolina in November, even though Mr. Clinton lost the state twice. If the Gore campaign takes that advice, it may cause the Bush campaign to rethink its own electoral tactics.
"He came over and said, 'How do you think the math is working?' " Mr. Smith said. "He said, 'I think North Carolina looks good.' " But Mr. Smith said he cautioned Mr. Clinton that the Democrats should think twice about pumping resources into the state.
"I told him that state broke my heart -- twice," Mr. Smith said. "But he said, 'I think we've got a shot.' "
Others who have talked politics with Mr. Clinton said he was preoccupied with the need for Democrats to win the loyalty of Hispanic voters. They said he had even spoken in detail about the importance of married Protestants. And, they said, he was particularly intrigued by contests in Michigan, New Jersey and Florida, where Mr. Gore has been pressing his campaign amid the tumult over the administration's handling of the Elian Gonzalez case.
"Clinton is obsessed with Florida," the case of the Cuban boy "and how it impacts," Mr. Torricelli said.
Mr. Clinton still convenes political meetings twice a month or so in the ornate Yellow Oval Room in the White House family quarters. The sessions are not as pressing as they were when they were held weekly before the 1996 campaign, and the group of participants, which often numbers close to two dozen, is usually larger than the more exclusive club of the past. Mr. Gore does not attend anymore.
Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton assembles his top aides, some cabinet secretaries and others to hash over how Democrats are performing and to look for ways to use his presidency to help candidates.
At the start of the sessions, Mark Penn, a presidential pollster, reviews the latest surveys on an overhead projector. The discussion that follows is freewheeling, with Mr. Clinton -- who often chews on an unlighted cigar -- sounding at times like a political operative.
"He is a full-time campaign manager at these meetings," one participant said. "The entire meetings are discussions of how this would be good for Al or for the first lady and how he can help the legacy. Clinton is constantly saying, 'This would help Al.' "
Participants at the group's most recent meeting, in April, recalled that Mr. Clinton said he wanted to accept invitations to speak at college graduations in areas with high concentrations of minorities, like Shiprock, N.M., where he thought his appearance would help spur interest in Mr. Gore's campaign.
A favorite pastime of the group is mocking Republicans in Congress, particularly when they do something that hurts them in the polls.
James Carville, an architect of Mr. Clinton's victory in 1992, said of the president: "If he calls me it would be to chat about Gore and Hillary. But I've had him tell me ideas for brochures in Senate races. He's a rare combination of somebody who's got the brains and the gut."
Joe Andrew, the national chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said he was dazzled by the president's knowledge of one Congressional district in Indiana, Mr. Andrew's home state. "He said the Eighth Congressional District is one that goes back and forth -- the bloody Eighth," Mr. Andrew said. "He knew that the southern part of the district was more conservative than the northern part. But he knew that in the southern part there had been tremendous growth because of a Toyota plant that opened there. And he knew of the Whirlpool plant in the northern part that had closed."
Michael J. Lapolla, the manager of Union County, N.J., who is seeking a House seat, said he ran into the president at a White House Christmas party last year. "As soon as he found out what I was running for, he said he liked our chances and he knew just about everything about the district," Mr. Lapolla said.
Mike Honda, a state assemblyman from San Jose, Calif., said Mr. Clinton helped persuade him to run for an open Congressional seat this year.
Mr. Clinton has taken a particular interest in the campaign of Representative Rush D. Holt of New Jersey, a freshman in a tight race. "His knowledge of New Jersey politics, and about my race in particular, is astounding," Mr. Holt said.
Bill Nelson, the state insurance commissioner in Florida, who is running for the Senate, said Mr. Clinton went out of his way to praise him at a dinner of Floridians in Washington last November -- a move that he said helped considerably in persuading Democrats to take a serious look at his prospects. "The President stands up in front of all these distinguished Floridians and proceeded to say very kind things about me," he said.
Mr. Clinton is particularly involved in Mrs. Clinton's Senate campaign. One participant at a meeting with Mrs. Clinton's advisers said it was the president's idea that he not utter a word at his wife's official announcement of her candidacy in February.
"When the issue came up of whether he would speak at Hillary's announcement, he weighed in and said, 'No,' " the participant said. "He said, 'I don't think that's right. This is her day.' There were plenty of people arguing the other way because it seemed unnatural for him not to speak. But it was a good judgment."
Despite Mr. Clinton's interest in his wife's race, Mr. Torricelli said the president does not fully grasp the unusual assortment of parties on the ballot in New York. "He knows New York politically less than a lot of the other states," Mr. Torricelli said. "He doesn't quite understand the mix of all those lines." Referring to Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, he said, "He calls Schumer and gets his opinion and calls me and plays off where we might differ."
While in past years some candidates have urged Mr. Clinton to stay clear of their districts, most of those interviewed said they were grateful for the president's wisdom and did not view him as an unwelcome meddler. "He's not a Mr. Buttinski," Mr. Carville said.
Yet some candidates were not so willing to bow before Mr. Clinton's expertise, perhaps out of fear that they might appear too close to the president. "I've been in elective office over 20 years in Michigan," said Representative Debbie Stabenow, who is running for Senate and campaigned with the president this week. "I know my state very well."
Asked how often he takes advice from Mr. Clinton, Tony Coelho, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, said: "I'm not going to go there."

HEADLINE: Mayor and Mrs. Clinton Woo Liberal Party

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday returned to what has been a solid source of support throughout his political career -- the Liberal Party, and its leader, Raymond B. Harding -- and asked for the party's backing as he sets his sights on the United States Senate. But Hillary Rodham Clinton also appeared before the same group, arguing that her views were more in touch with the Liberal ideology than were those of the Republican mayor.
Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton each spent an hour in private at a Manhattan hotel with the policy committee of the Liberal Party, the first step in the party's move toward choosing its nominee by June 6. This usually barely noticed rite for candidates in New York drew a bustle of attention yesterday, evidenced by a lineup of cameras and security officers, reflecting the state and national political implications that have become attached to the decision by Mr. Harding's party. 
 "This is not my first time being interviewed by the Liberal Party," Mr. Giuliani said as soon as he left the meeting, grinning as he noted his longstanding ties with one of the smaller parties that his advisers believe could provide the winning margin in this election. When a reporter asked if he considered Mr. Harding a close adviser, Mr. Giuliani responded: "I consider Ray Harding to be more than a close adviser. I consider him a close personal friend."
Mrs. Clinton pointed to the same friendship in remarks that seemed to lower expectations on her chances of winning the support of a party that almost invariably backs the Democratic candidate in statewide elections. "I'm well aware of the mayor's relationship with Mr. Harding and the party," she said. "But I came today to ask for their consideration, based on the issues that I'm talking about in this campaign and what I would do in the Senate."
As Mrs. Clinton knows, the only time a Democrat running for statewide office won without the cross-endorsement of the Liberal Party occurred in a Court of Appeals race in the 1970's, when judges to the state's highest court were still elected. Mr. Giuliani's aides noted this fact in a handout they distributed to reporters just before Mrs. Clinton left the committee meeting to talk with reporters.
The Liberal Party has helped Mr. Giuliani's electoral success as mayor, not so much because of the relatively few votes he drew on the Liberal line, but because the party's support has allowed him to blur his ideological designation, making it more comfortable for some Democrats to vote for him.
Mr. Harding was able to steer the endorsement to Mr. Giuliani with relatively little difficulty during his three races for mayor. But this high-visibility Senate race has presented the party with a particularly complicated choice. And it has put Mr. Harding in the position of choosing between the potential future of the 55-year-old party and his loyalty to a man who is a close friend and a source of jobs for his family and party.
In an unusual display of public dissension, some Liberal Party members have said in recent days that they would oppose backing Mr. Giuliani, saying it would be a betrayal of the party's philosophy to send another Republican to the Senate. And if Mr. Harding backs Mr. Giuliani, he risks losing a presidential candidate: Mrs. Clinton's aides have been pushing Vice President Al Gore to decline the Liberal Party line if the party backs Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Gore's aides said yesterday that he might accede to Mrs. Clinton's request. They said he would put off the decision as long as possible, giving him time to assess whether he needs the Liberal Party to win in New York (right now, his aides think he does not), as well as to see whether Mr. Giuliani stays in the race.
Peter Ragone, a spokesman for Mr. Gore's campaign, said that the vice president was now beginning a closer look at the thicket of independent parties in New York, and that he would "consider the endorsement" of any party that shared his views. However, Mr. Ragone added, "the vice president is a strong supporter of Hillary Clinton, and our campaign will do everything we can to elect her the next senator from New York."
Several of Mr. Harding's friends have tried to convince him that the Liberal Party's standing might be permanently damaged if it supports Mr. Giuliani and he defeats Mrs. Clinton this fall. And the advantage that Mr. Harding now enjoys by having Mr. Giuliani in City Hall ends in a year even if the mayor loses, because he will not be allowed to run for a third consecutive term.
Mr. Harding has told friends that he will delay a decision as long as possible, in no small part to see whether Mr. Giuliani stays in the race. The mayor learned recently that he has prostate cancer and has said his medical condition would determine whether he stayed in the race.
The Liberal Party endorsement has been important to Mr. Giuliani's political success to date, but he may be taking some risks in aggressively seeking its support in this race. For one thing, taking the Liberal Party line means giving up the Conservative Party line, said the Conservative Party chairman, Michael Long, who said it was ideologically dishonest for one candidate to run on both lines. The Conservative Party historically has been as critical to statewide Republican candidates as the Liberal has been to Democrats.
"What he did today -- with Hillary, no less -- they both went and knelt at the altar of Ray Harding, who in fact gave us Bella Abzug, John Lindsay and Mario Cuomo," Mr. Long said. "That sends a clear signal to the world that he wants to run with Al Gore, he wants to keep the Liberal tradition, and I don't know who the real Giuliani is."
In addition, running as the Liberal candidate is likely to complicate Mr. Giuliani's efforts to portray Mrs. Clinton as a liberal. That has been the thrust of his fund-raising appeals, and statewide Republican candidates have, for a decade, routinely attacked their Democratic opponents as liberal.
When Mr. Giuliani was asked yesterday whether he considered Mrs. Clinton a liberal, he demurred. "I think it would be overly simplistic to put labels on people," he said. "I think you can say somebody is a liberal on something and moderate on something else and conservative on something else."
Turning the question to himself, Mr. Giuliani said: "I think about me, they would say, he's conservative on economic matters, he's conservative on law and order. But he's moderate, and possibly even liberal, on social issues. It would depend on the part of the country you're in. In New York City, I'm often seen as very conservative. I travel south and west, I'm seen as very liberal. I like that, actually."
Mr. Harding greeted Mrs. Clinton politely when she arrived at the meeting at the Intercontinental Hotel, but, one participant said, asked no questions, sitting quietly in the back of a room that was thick with cigarette smoke.
Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton share positions in their support of abortion rights, gay rights and gun control, as Mr. Harding noted after the meeting. But Mrs. Clinton pointed out some differences between them on issues of concern to Liberals, including her opposition to Mr. Giuliani's school voucher program, and her criticism of the large tax cuts being advocated by Republicans in Washington.
Asked her view of what the Liberal Party stood for, she responded: "Based on what I know of it and what I've read about it, it stands for a sort of positive, progressive tradition in New York politics, and the kind of issues we've talked about. Very strong support for public education. Strong support for child care and working families. Strong support for a minimum wage increase."

HEADLINE: Long Island City Journal;
An Oasis for Fishermen And Riverside Dreamers

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
The blackened iron gantries once dominated this stretch of Long Island City like mechanical giants, their massive and clanking framework lifting railroad freight cars onto river barges like rocks into a sand pail. Manhattan, like a cool sister, obliviously hummed to its own rhythm across the short span of river.
The gantries stand silent now, looming more like towering Tonka toys over what has become a post industrial confection. Two years ago, this two-acre site along the East River was turned into a contemplative playground, into a polished cobblestone plaza, into a wood-and-steel temple for sun addicts and stargazers. 
 But shhhhh. Manhattan still sits across the river, and still is oblivious.
In a city of dwindling secrets, of binocular-toting tourists and space-deprived residents, Gantry Plaza State Park has so far remained an obscure pearl.
This is something that pleases many people in Long Island City and the surrounding communities of Maspeth and Astoria in Queens and Greenpoint in Brooklyn.
"We were afraid it would be commercial, with hot dog vendors, and really gaudy," said Jonathon Chin, who lives about four blocks away and watched the construction of the park with some trepidation.
Mr. Chin, 29, an unemployed waiter, was poring intently over the employment section of the paper, his situation made a bit more bearable by his sun-washed environs.
Some park users say they feel they can extend their arms and almost caress the skyscrapers of Manhattan. But Rebecca Ochner, a 10-year-old on spring break, had something else on her mind. She was sitting at a futuristic-looking circular stainless steel picnic bar, her favorite perch, seeking inspiration for a book she is writing on magic.
"I'm thinking about what Manhattan looked like without all the skyscrapers," Rebecca said.
A Greenpoint resident, she often tags along to the park with her mother's boyfriend, Frank Zito. He comes for the fishing.
"The park makes an artistic statement," said Mr. Zito, a committed angler, examining his bait. "It's functional with style."
On the pier designated for fishing, there is a large free-form steel table with fresh running water for cleaning the catch of the day and a wavy wooden bench that is several yards long.
Throughout the park, bethabara wood, which is plantation grown and imported from Indonesia, is used. It is not a wood that can be easily carved, but "Jose & Sarah" and "Aleandro y Johanna" have managed to leave their monikers on the wooden chaise longues.
On rock-filled paths, there are stone seats and tables that recall the Stone Age. And there are five stainless steel tables for playing chess or checkers. There is no formal garden; instead, native plants and grasses are interspersed throughout.
On one of the other three piers sat Mariaelena Gutierrez, 23, a marketing associate at a publishing house that recently moved from Manhattan to the neighborhood. She came for a lunch break, a tuna sandwich topped off with chocolate candy.
"You don't expect much from the area," she said. "But this is a pleasant surprise."
Her friend, Tracy Tumminello, also 23, a publishing associate eating with Ms. Gutierrez, was decidedly more enthusiastic. "You can't get views of Manhattan like this even in Manhattan," she said.
The park was once home to a deserted waterfront train yard and the resting place of broken televisions, ruptured mattresses and rusting cars. Gantry Plaza, which has so far cost $13 million, is Phase 1 of a planned 19-acre, $60 million park. It will stretch along a one-and-a-quarter-mile span of riverbank.
"It's a 21st-century culture of play that we are all about," said Thomas Balsley of Thomas Balsley Associates, who, along with Sowinski Sullivan Architects and Lee Weintraub, designed the plaza. "It was important that the design be a reflection of the future while being respectful of its past."
For visitors like Anthony Roberson, an unemployed Vietnam veteran, the serenity is enough.
"Here, you don't have the weight of civilization on you," said Mr. Roberson, who sat at the far end of the fish-cleaning table listening to jazz.
Across the water sat Manhattan, still oblivious.

HEADLINE: Small Provider Sees Gain in Cable TV Fight

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
The dispute between the Walt Disney Company and Time Warner Cable that blacked out ABC television for about 1.8 million New Yorkers on Monday and Tuesday provided an unexpected business opportunity to a small telecommunications company based in New Jersey.
The company, Residential Communications Networks, is one of the few alternatives to Time Warner Cable in New York City, where competition for the television industry has long been limited by the high costs of building alternative systems and the reception problems that tall buildings pose for satellite providers. 
 "As you can imagine, our telephones have been ringing off their hooks, from people who want to switch their cable service," David C. McCourt, the chairman and chief executive of RCN, said in an interview last week.
Mr. McCourt, said that people started calling his company, whose services include cable and satellite, in the hours after Time Warner removed WABC in a dispute with the broadcast station's parent company, Disney, over retransmission fees at 12:01 a.m. Monday.
Mr. McCourt contended that the blackout would never have happened if Time Warner faced real competition in New York City.
New Yorkers get cable service from Time Warner or Cablevision, depending on where they live. The two companies do not directly compete in any area.
Except for the much smaller Liberty Cable in Manhattan, the two companies used to be the only licensed cable providers in New York City, operating as government-sanctioned monopolies. But the passage of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 permitted some competition and removed some regulatory controls.
And while Time Warner and Disney have come up with an agreement -- at least until the new July 15 negotiations deadline -- and the cable provider has offered a two-day rebate for its subscribers, the ABC blackout has spawned new concern about a lack of real competition in the cable industry.
Chris Meyer, executive director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, acknowledged cable companies "have gotten a free ride from groups like mine," but added, "those days are over, with prices going up and this active war on consumers."He and other consumer advocates said they feared the potential dominance of the companies, if cable lines become the popular conduit for television, Internet and cable services.
Companies like RCN were seen as the potential competitors that would bring down cable prices and spur more innovation after the passage of the Telecommunications Act. But that has been slow to happen, government officials acknowledged and consumer advocates said.
Mark Cooper, the executive director of the Consumer Federation, a Washington advocacy group, said that "given the economics of splitting the cable market," possible competitors are "just not interested in coming into New York or any other major metropolitan area with high costs."
In many other parts of the country satellite television has emerged as a competitor to cable service. However, in Manhattan and many parts of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, densely packed and tall buildings interfere with satellite television signals.
RCN appears to have found a way around both the infrastructure and building interference problems. From 1991 to 1996, Time Warner and Liberty Cable waged a David-and-Goliath battle for cable-television customers in Manhattan. By 1996, despite a strategy that focused on large apartment buildings in affluent neighborhoods, Liberty was only able to sign up just 34,000 customers.
In 1996, RCN acquired Liberty's network and began putting satellite dishes on other buildings where interference is not an issue.
RCN officials hope to use the Liberty system as a foundation for their own citywide network. They hope to get around the high cost of building their own network by using Liberty's existing system and bundling services together, including cable, telephone and Internet offerings. In this way, company officials said, RCN would be able to use the same infrastructure to take a share of each of those markets. Company officials would not comment on the number of its subscribers in New York.
But industry analysts said that RCN has taken a path that will have serious limitations. For example, in seeking to sell the most profit-yielding telecommunications package, RCN may find itself restricted to upper-income areas, where people often have telephone, cable and Internet access, and tend to spend a lot on telecommunications.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Real Clemens May Have Arrived

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
Roger Clemens pumped his last fastball of a gorgeous yet draining day, a high heater that roared by Rich Amaral for the final out in the seventh inning and caused most of the 54,350 fans at Yankee Stadium to rise and cheer. Clemens exhaled and trudged ever so slowly to the dugout, pulling his glove off, wiping the sweat off his forehead and ending a quality day of work.
The Yankees have seen these dalliances with excellence before from Clemens, so they want to stay cautiously optimistic. They have seen Clemens look like the remarkably effective pitcher he was in a 3-1 victory over the Orioles yesterday. They have seen Clemens dominate for a few starts, only to have that consistency fade. 
 So that is why they wait and wonder if Clemens is finally comfortable with throwing mostly four-seam fastballs and comfortable with being himself. This is merely two straight victories for the new and improved Clemens, who was really being the old and competent Clemens while notching his 250th career victory, but it is enough to have the Yankees hoping that maybe he can be superb all season.
"Roger has always been a power pitcher and, once he gets hot, he stays hot," David Cone said. "Once he gets his confidence, he can reel off 10 in a row. He's starting to look like that pitcher again."
If Cone is right, the Yankees, who have won six straight games, will be relieved and ecstatic. Clemens has often puzzled them since joining the team last year, sometimes pitching like a five-time Cy Young award winner and sometimes pitching like a 37-year-old who has lost confidence in his repertory. But Clemens has returned to his roots, relying on his fastball, and the results have been stunning.
Clemens used an economical 99 pitches yesterday while allowing one run on four hits in seven innings, with five strikeouts and two walks. Those numbers almost mirror the one run and seven hits he allowed while beating the Blue Jays, 7-1, last Sunday. The revival is easy to explain: focus on the fastball.
"He's throwing more fastballs and more fastballs for strikes," catcher Jorge Posada said. "He's locating better and he's getting ahead of hitters. He's not making it harder on himself. He's making it easier on himself."
Posada could not explain why Clemens ever abandoned his best pitch in tight situations.
But, when Manager Joe Torre was asked how important it was for Clemens to continue to depend on the fastball, he was so eager to answer the question that he almost did not wait until it was asked. Torre has long wanted Clemens to be the pitcher who throws 95 miles an hour to barge through sticky situations.
"It's huge that you don't forget you have the thing, even though they know it's coming," Torre said. "A lot of pitchers don't want to throw a particular pitch because the hitter is looking for it, but his fastball is different.
"You can look for it, but he has so much movement and command of it that he doesn't give them many good pitches to hit."
Wearing a Tennessee Titans T-shirt and chugging a sports drink afterward, Clemens was reticent about the 250 victories and the back-to-back victories that have been fueled by his fastball.
Clemens expects to win, so he does not offer much enthusiasm after he does. "It's not ho-hum," Clemens said. "I'll concentrate on my next start and get ready. I'm pleased that the work I've done has paid off. It makes it easier to get up tomorrow and start all over again."
Virtually every time Clemens encountered some danger against the Orioles, he used a fastball to rescue him. Four of his five strikeouts came on fastballs, and the other came on a split-finger fastball. He walked the leadoff batters in the first and second innings, but retired three in a row each time.
Posada bashed a run-scoring double off the left-center-field fence in the second off Pat Rapp, and Shane Spencer had a sacrifice fly in the fourth to give Clemens a 2-0 lead. The Orioles cut it to 2-1 on back-to-back two-out doubles in the fifth before Clemens struck out Mike Bordick on a 1-2 fastball. Albert Belle roped a one-out double in the sixth, but Clemens used fastballs to retire Harold Baines and Cal Ripken Jr. on groundouts. Again, Torre smiled.
"He knows what works for him," Torre said. "I think it's just a matter of putting into practice his approach and knowing that it works."
Clemens said 300 victories "seems a long way off" since it would surely take him until at least the 2002 season, and he claimed that he had not remembered he had won his 250th until Mariano Rivera, who earned his 11th save, gave him the baseball. Cone doubted the veracity of Clemens's claim and lifted his eyebrows while talking about the milestone.
"He should appreciate it," Cone said. "It's a significant number. He's a sure-fire Hall of Famer. The next 50 are going to be tough. If anyone can do it, he can do it."
 
INSIDE PITCH
Second baseman CHUCK KNOBLAUCH (sprained left wrist) will take batting practice today, and he said he might play tomorrow.

HEADLINE: April 30-May 6;
The Economy, Still Bullish

 BODY:
The unemployment rate dropped below 4 percent last month for the first time in 30 years, the United States Labor Department reported as tens of thousands of census takers and restaurant and temporary workers entered a booming economy.
The new numbers -- 341,000 new jobs and a 3.9 percent unemployment rate -- offered no evidence that the nine-year-old expansion might be ending or even weakening in reaction to the Federal Reserve's efforts to slow the economy by raising interest rates. 
 Wall Street reacted as if it had little to fear. Even though many analysts expect that the Fed will raise the rates at its May 16 meeting by as much as half a percentage point, the market shrugged it off and registered healthy gains Friday.

HEADLINE: INSIDE/OUT;
Custom-Built Wine Cellars a Sign of the Times

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
FRED TREGASKIS, who builds wine cellars for a living, said he remembers when city restaurants were the sum total of his clientele. That was in the early 1990's. Now Mr. Tregaskis, of West Cornwall, Conn., is more likely to find work at private homes in Westchester and Fairfield County.
The owner of New England Wine Cellars, Mr. Tregaskis said he built about 40 cellars last year, his biggest year ever. "Cellars have become the rage in new construction," he said. "I've built several cellars in nice homes where the client wasn't an avid wine collector, but felt their home wasn't complete unless it had a wine cellar." 
 Cellars can come with wide-screen televisions, spiral staircases and antique decorative knickknacks.
"They want hand-forged hardware on their door and old-fashioned lighting," Mr. Tregaskis said. "They also often want a medieval Italian look: 'Tuscany.' I hear that word all the time."
As demand for fine wine rises, with a record $18.1 billion worth of wine sold in the United States in 1999, having a place at home to store it safely has become a priority.
Adam Strum, chairman of the Wine Enthusiast, a wine-accessory catalog company in Hawthorne, said sales of its custom-built cellars, which start at about $5,000 for a remodeled closet, rose to 397 last year from 234 in 1998. In the first quarter of this year, he said demand is more than double what it was at this time last year. Christine Hawley of Manhattan, who has designed cellars in Westchester and the Hamptons, said the strong economy has a lot to do with it.
"The economy has been so good, people already have as many cars as they can drive, as many homes as they can go to," Ms. Hawley said. "One thing people haven't experienced is the newest pleasure left, which is wine cellars."
Not long ago, a wine cellar was thought of as a rack under the basement stairs. But today the trend is more in line with Joe O'Connor's 3,000-bottle home cellar in Briarcliff Manor, which Mr. Tregaskis is building.
"We want it to be a room where you can actually have dinner," said Mr. O'Connor, who would not say how much his cellar would cost. "We were very excited to build our house four years ago, but this is something that I'm far more excited about."
Paul Wyatt, a designer who runs the Fine Wine Rack and Cellar Company in San Carlos, Calif., which provides supplies for cellars around the country, said the New York City metropolitan region is one of six regions in the United States where the cellar market is strongest.
"Volume is going up every year," he said. "Periodically, I get so busy I can't see straight, so I raise my prices and volume goes up again."
Evan Goldenberg of Design Build Consultants in Greenwich attributed the strong demand to the rise in the stock market. One of his clients, Tony Bosco of North Salem, is a managing director at Morgan Stanley.
"I got interested in wine through entertaining," Mr. Bosco said. "With the Wall Street career, we would have parties with very fine wines. There would be people there who would go to tastings with professional writers, the kind of people who drank from unmarked bottles and guessed what wine it was."
Now Mr. Bosco is selling his house, and he sees the cellar as a feature more people in the stock-market business have come to expect. "People who have weekend or country homes here, more and more you hear about it," he said.
David Pedowitz, an investment banker who lives in Bedford, is already on his second cellar, with a 5,000-bottle capacity and a $75,000 price tag. He said he has been a wine collector for years.
"'The investment advisory business is tense and nerve racking," he said. "You find people in this business looking for releases from that tension. For me, it's wine, whiskey and cigars.'
In addition to storing his wine at an optimal temperature of 55 degrees, Mr. Pedowitz's cellar, when completed, will include a spiral staircase, a 10-by-13-foot tasting room, a special stand-up rack for his collection of single-malt scotches, mahogany doors and a burglar alarm and a temperature alarm.
Some higher-end clients want elaborate cabinets instead of racks for their bottles, creating an effect that Mr. Goldenberg likens to "a library for wine."
He said his projects tend to be expensive largely because he works with sophisticated refrigeration equipment with temperature-sensitive alarm systems and low-voltage electronic controls.
"Things really started to pick up in 1996," he said. "Projects had been in the $25,000-to-$35,000 range. Then they quickly graduated to the $45,000-to-$55,000 range. I'd have clients call me to say they moved and needed a new wine cellar. I'd have other clients tell me they ran out of space and needed another wine cellar."
While a cellar can be a way to explore a deeply personal passion, for others, it is a smart investment.
"They're a very hot item now," said David Ogilvy, who owns a real estate concern in Greenwich. "What sells houses are things like condition and master bedrooms, but a wine cellar is a really nice piece of cake."
Ms. Hawley said she believed that wine collecting is about more than drinking or investing. It can provide entre into a world where one becomes a "connoisseur of life."
"When you start building a cellar, a lot of things change in your life," she said. "You think about going to wine countries for vacations. You start going to wine auctions. Your friends change, because you're more focused on people who love wine. Your diet changes, because you want food that goes with your wine. It's like having a baby. I see people get so energized and focused."

HEADLINE: Why Speculate?

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle covers economics for The Times.

 BODY:

IRRATIONAL EXUBERANCE
 By Robert J. Shiller.
 296 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
 Princeton University Press. $27.95. 
 We should know better. The greatest stock market boom in history takes place despite all that we have learned about the herd psychology that whips us into buying stocks with such enthusiasm. Never before have so many Americans been so well informed about the propensity of market bubbles to burst, evaporating their wealth before their eyes. And yet people persist -- even after what happened in April -- gambling that a "new economy," more robust and productive than any in the past, will justify the high level of stock prices. Or is it that people know in their hearts that the market is dangerously high, but, caught up in the national mood, they cannot bring themselves to quit?
No one has explored the strange behavior of the American investor in the 1990's with more authority, or better timing, than Robert J. Shiller, a Yale University economist who laces economics with big doses of psychology in his new book, "Irrational Exuberance." That is a departure in his profession. Most economists assume that people are rational and fully informed, and that their stock investments reflect a realistic assessment of the economy. The roller-coaster, less than rational price swings in April undercut that assumption, and so does Shiller.
A chart on Page 8 haunts a reader. It is a single, nervous line, like the tracing on a seismograph, that records the price-earnings ratio for a representative group of stocks back to 1881. The line represents share prices in relation to profits for a number of companies. The ratio goes up when stock prices rise faster than profits. There are peaks in 1901, 1929 and 1966, the high points of the previous booms. These are followed by long, often precipitous declines, each lasting a decade or more before the line finally climbs up toward the next boom. The latest upturn began in the early 1980's and took off in the 90's. The line is still climbing, almost vertically -- already far above the three previous peaks. Research in economics, psychology, demography, sociology and history, Shiller writes, suggests that "the present stock market displays the classic features of a speculative bubble: a situation in which temporarily high prices are sustained largely by investors' enthusiasm rather than by consistent estimation of real value."
What set off this speculation and what feeds it? Shiller ranges widely in his explanations, laying them out in the first 168 pages in easy-to-read, sometimes passionate prose. The last three chapters bog down in a discussion of the proper value of stocks -- only an economist could love it -- and in Shiller's solutions, which have to be taken on faith. (He would draw steam out of the stock market by creating new markets in other items.) But those first 168 pages are must reading for anyone with savings invested in stocks. Just internalizing Shiller's explanations of why we speculate is probably the best antidote of all.
He notes that profits have indeed been strong in the 90's and that growth has coincided with the blossoming of Internet technology, creating the impression that the two are linked. Triumphalism also plays a role. The collapse of the Soviet Union and the greater prosperity in America than in Europe and Japan reinforce confidence in American capitalism, and in the stock market.
Cultural changes are important, particularly the growing public reverence for wealthy business people, the promotion of gambling (which "suppresses natural inhibitions against taking risks") and the erosion among workers of loyalty to their employers. "By pursuing speculative investments," Shiller says, "people in effect create for themselves a second job -- one where they are, at last, their own boss."
Wall Street analysts encourage speculation. The most optimistic are also the most successful, and recommendations to sell become rare. The growth of mutual funds and the spread of self-financed pension plans keep people focused on stocks. So does the endless stream of financial news on all-day television programs. "Such enhanced business reporting," Shiller writes, "leads to increased demand for stocks, just as advertisements for a consumer product make people more familiar with the product, remind them of the option to buy and ultimately motivate them to buy."
The list goes on. Low inflation raises confidence in the stock market, an "illusion" that leaves out the role of interest rates in determining the real value of stocks. But Shiller, whose findings are based in part on his own surveys of investors, is at his best in describing the group pressures and herd behavior that sustain investment -- the amplification mechanism," as he calls it. People are prodded into the market, for example, by the constant suggestion of "the moral superiority of those who invested well" and the ego-diminishing envy stirred by hearing that others have earned more in the market than they have in salary. "The emotional state of investors when they decide on their investments is no doubt one of the most important factors causing the bull market," Shiller asserts.
THE Ponzi effect heads his list. As stock prices rise, people talk endlessly of their windfalls and new investors are drawn in. Each new injection of money pushes up stock prices, creating more happy campers whose stories draw in more investors. Overconfidence fuels the process, which Shiller calls a "naturally occurring Ponzi scheme." It unwinds when something scares the investors, and then the feedback effect works in reverse: negative stories pull down the market.
Like other writers before him -- most recently Edward Chancellor, in his very anecdotal "Devil Take the Hindmost: A History of Financial Speculation" (1999) -- Shiller notes that the behavior of today is a replica of that in previous booms, even including the popular notion that a price drop is a buying opportunity, a rationalization also touted in 1929.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, coined the phrase that became the title of Shiller's book. Greenspan has since backed away, suggesting that the rising market may reflect rational investments in an ever more productive and profitable corporate America. But how can investors be thought of as rational and dispassionate when they so often ignore the social and psychological forces shaping their behavior? 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Identity;
American Dreaming

BYLINE: By Richard Powers; Richard Powers is the author of "Plowing the Dark," a novel, which will be published in June.

 BODY:
Of all our national traits, I find it the most singular, the most astonishing, the most appalling and heartbreaking, and the one that most sets us apart from the rest of the self-describing world. Is it possible in America to be pretty much who you want to be? More of us think so than believe in life after death.
Almost all of us, in fact. Of the next 10 people who you meet, 8.5 will bear a faith in their unlimited opportunity. The ability to become a ballerina, physicist, holder of patents, teacher of poetry, real estate mogul, pro basketball player, senator, ambassador, president or even a TV-show host. Pretty much whoever you want to be. A third of everyone in line at the supermarket will be dreaming of fame -- recording contracts, movie offers -- and the great majority of those will consider such dreams realizable. We live in a vast, affirming Levittown, on a double lot between Walter Mitty and Gordon Gekko, our desperation quiet to mute, our belief in boundless opportunity raucous. 
 Ever since the sudden eruption of this continent, European Americans have lived on the edge of an open frontier. Screw things up back East, and you can always light out for the territories. The fact that 85 percent of Americans still feel they have no limits suggests that, even centuries on, the frontier remains untapped and open for homesteading.
Pretty much who you want to be: five seconds of reflection exposes the equally limitless absurdity. Do 8.5 of the next 10 people you meet have a badger's chance at a dog show of becoming a brain surgeon or socializing in Hyannisport? But then, perhaps, they never wanted to. Perhaps, in America, everyone is already pretty much who they want to be, or at least happy in their infinite fallbacks. This is the secret flip side to the American dream: our embrace of endless opportunity may clothe an equally happy acceptance of the most normative social control. In America, you wouldn't want to be what you pretty much couldn't be. In the language of the marketplace -- our true, infinite frontier -- who says you can't have it all? Just don't ask what all may be.
Three years after Frederick Jackson Turner gave his famous lecture, "The Significance of the Frontier in American History," and two years after Edward Stratemeyer (of Hardy Boys and Tom Swift fame) published the first volume in his "Bound to Succeed" series, W. E. B. DuBois began the groundbreaking study, "The Philadelphia Negro." In it, DuBois wrote: "The humblest white employee knows that the better he does his work the more chance there is for him to rise in the business. The black employee knows that the better he does his work the longer he may do it." What an American wants to become has forever depended on who he is allowed to be.
Since the dream of unlimited self-realization has survived slavery and segregation, perhaps I shouldn't be shocked that 85 percent of us still assert it only eight years after one of the worst race riots in American history. But then almost half of us believe that race plays "not much role" in who we are, including three-quarters of African-Americans polled. Hispanic believers slightly outnumber whites.
Nor does economic class much trouble our belief in universal attainment. While 90 percent of people making more than $75,000 assert their unlimited potential, even people making $30,000 or less still sign on at the rate of 82 percent. Those of us who are not winning even the financial part of the race want to believe that our children still might.
The market keeps building us new room to believe, ever more American territories to light out for. Kept in reserve by God and rising up from the filled-in map, the infant Internet promises endless new vistas for self-creation. In this newfound America, everyone can register her own domain name. As gold rushes go, the Information Age threatens to leave the Gilded Age in the pyrite dust. Microsoft alone has produced as many as 5,000 millionaires.
Belief in the digital boom's democracy has, in some ways, democratized it. Almost half of Americans now own stock -- up from 14 percent in 1980. A staggering increase in paper worth has led to an even more staggering sense of paper opportunity. But in the race to be all we can be, consumer debt is mushrooming without any limits of its own. Personal bankruptcies have quadrupled over the last decade, neatly pacing the Dow. We're not afraid of losing all we have. But we're terrified of losing a chance to have it all.
Perhaps for this reason more than a third of us sometimes lament that our lives did not turn out as we wished. A third have visited therapists. Half know someone who has tried to commit suicide. Half of us think we don't get enough credit for what we do. We seem to be free to be everything we want -- except content.
For possibility and contentment may be sworn enemies. Pure potential and its despair combine to create the ideal late-capitalist perpetual-motion engine, with self-realization powering the drive train. So long as we believe there is no ceiling, there will be no end to the effort we'll expend on the way to self-making. Be all you can be. Go for the gusto. Such cheerleading cloaks the sharpest spurs ever invented. For in this country, if you don't become all that you pretty much want, you've only your own indolence to blame.
Discount these grumblings as the duty of a writer. Horatio Alger and the Stratemeyer Syndicate aside, American novelists from Hawthorne through DeLillo have forever made a living by waking America from its dream. Writers, to become pretty much what they want to be, often feel the need to leave the land of endless opportunity. Baldwin, Wright and DuBois (for reasons that almost half of those polled dismiss), Stein (the majority of respondents oppose same-sex marriages), James, Wharton, Hemingway: endless potential drove them away, to realize themselves elsewhere.
But also pardon this returnee's confession. However I would answer the question, I, too, imagine that I might have become, in some hypothetical America, anything I cared enough to be. Something in me carries around this stamp of citizenship.
In America, de Tocqueville said, with only a tincture of French tannic acid, "No natural boundary seems to be set to the effort of man; and in his eyes what is not yet done, is only what he has not yet attempted to do."
Under the burden of becoming anything we hope, between the dream of realization and our waking reality, we've created the most mercilessly productive country on earth. In believing that only the attempt stands between us and what's not yet done, we Americans, for better and for worse, will, in time, do pretty much everything we want, and then some.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Victoria Scully, Mar-Jan Ostrowski

 BODY:
Victoria Rae Scully, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis A. Scully of New York, was married yesterday to Mar-Jan Ostrowski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Czeslaw Ostrowski of Bellows Falls, Vt. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend performed the ceremony at St. James's Episcopal Church in New York.
Mrs. Ostrowski, 34, is the marketing and public relations manager in the New York office of Platinum Guild International, a trade association for precious metals mines. She graduated from American University. Her father is an investment adviser in New York. Her mother, Rae M. Scully, is the nurse at the Brearley School in New York. 
 Mr. Ostrowski, 47, is the manager for a project to fight hepatitis C in Cairo, run jointly by the University of Maryland at Baltimore and the Agency for International Development. He graduated from the University of Maryland, where he has completed course work for a Ph.D. in Middle Eastern affairs.
The bridegroom's mother, Leonarda Y. Ostrowski, is a volunteer translator for Polish and Russian patients at the Cheshire Medical Center in Keene, N.H. His father retired as a machinist and mechanical engineer in Keene.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Supermarket Stocks, in the Bargain Aisle

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER

 BODY:
SUDDENLY, the long-suffering supermarket sector seems an attractive place for investors to shop. Those seeking safety in a turbulent market have already begun to pile into what analysts perceive as the highest-quality supermarket stock, Safeway. Despite the pounding of retail stocks last week, its shares are up 20.3 percent so far this year; other grocery stocks have also shown gains of late.
Money managers and analysts say some of these companies -- including Safeway -- may still be good bets, particularly for investors willing to take a longer-term approach. 
 Last year, the Standard & Poor's retail food chain stores index of five supermarket stocks fell 26 percent, versus a 20 percent gain in the S.& P. 500, as investors fled value stocks in general and low-margin retailers in particular. This year has been a different story: the S.& P. retail food chain index is up 5.3 percent, compared with a loss of 2.5 percent for the S.& P. 500. But Lisa Cartwright, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, estimates that the group is still trading at a 40 percent discount to the S.& P. 500, based on current price-to-earnings multiples.
The chains themselves have joined the buying spree. Last month, the nation's two largest grocery chains, Kroger and Albertson's, announced plans to buy back $750 million and $500 million of their shares, respectively.
The attraction in a time of tumult is obvious. In the past, grocery stocks have held up well during market downturns and recessions, so the stocks are seen as good defensive plays. The industry is likely to continue consolidating, many analysts say, creating greater economies of scale and fattening what have long been razor-thin net margins of 3 percent or less.
"This sector has good earnings growth and it's trading at close to its 20-year lows in terms of valuation," said Mark Husson, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "Food retailing stocks are stable and solid. They have good earnings potential and the valuations are very cheap."
Of course, there are risks. If the stocks are to stay attractive, analysts say, earnings per share need to grow in the range of 16 to 18 percent -- a level last achieved in 1997.
While many analysts expect some of the companies to reach that rate in 2000, they disagree on which ones will do so. Last year earnings per share for the five stocks grew just 14 percent, on average.
Then there is the threat posed by Wal-Mart Stores, which has been rapidly pushing into the grocery business with its Supercenter outlets. Wal-Mart Supercenters combine a large grocery store with the traditional Wal-Mart discounted general merchandise in vast stores of between 100,000 and 200,000 square feet. The company is introducing the Supercenters at a rapid pace: there were 739 as of March 31, compared with 582 a year earlier.
Among the large chains, Kroger, of Cincinnati, faces the biggest risk from Wal-Mart because of geographical overlap: Wal-Mart operates Supercenters in about half of Kroger's 15 largest markets. So far, Kroger is holding its own, according to analysts. Indeed, Joseph A. Pichler, the chief executive, told analysts in a conference call two months ago that Kroger had increased its market share in five of the seven markets where it competes head-to-head with Wal-Mart.
"What you're finding is that Wal-Mart is consolidating the business, but that Kroger is still able to compete effectively," said George Thompson, an analyst at Prudential Securities. Mr. Thompson said Kroger should have no problem achieving earnings-per-share growth in the 16 to 18 percent range going forward.
He has a strong buy on the stock and a 52-week price target of $32; the shares now trade at $19.5625, or 14.5 times analysts' 2000 earnings estimate of $1.35 a share.
MASU MULLICK, co-manager of the Neuberger Berman Partners fund, says Kroger presents an interesting risk-reward story because of its $13.5 billion acquisition last May of Fred Meyer, a supermarket chain based in Portland, Ore., that nearly doubled Kroger's size.
"It's a combination of a terrific opportunity and a terrific challenge," said Mr. Mullick, who had about 2.5 percent of the fund invested in Kroger on March 31.
Others say the merger has made it more difficult for Kroger to focus on its Internet strategy. Though Internet grocers are struggling to turn profits, some analysts worry that traditional brick-and-mortar chains will eventually feel some impact.
Over the last month, Safeway has invested in Groceryworks.com, an online grocer in Dallas, while Royal Ahold, the Netherlands-based operator of Stop & Shop and Giant Food Stores, has invested in another, Peapod of Skokie, Ill.
"The Internet is clearly going to be a channel, even if the model has not yet been figured out," Ms. Cartwright said. "But it's important to have a strategy."
DESPITE the run-up in Safeway's stock, it remains the favorite of some analysts, largely because the company has avoided the big acquisitions that Kroger and Albertson's have made.
Safeway, which is based in Pleasanton, Calif., and operates more than 1,600 stores, is often cited as having a strong management team.
"They don't have have the integration risk that Kroger has" as a result of its merger, said Deborah Weinswig, an analyst at Bear Stearns. Her 52-week price target for the stock is $65; the shares closed on Friday at $43, or 19 times analysts' earnings estimates of $2.23 a share for this year.
For its part, Albertson's, based in Boise, Idaho, is not encountering major problems in its merger with American Stores, completed last June, but analysts said it still has to prove that it can handle increased competition from Wal-Mart.
Ms. Cartwright has a hold on the stock and a 12-month price target of $35. It now trades at $32.1875, or 12 times analysts' 2000 earnings estimates of $2.68 a share.
