HEADLINE: The World;
Sometimes, National Security Says It All

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TEN years after recapturing the Continent, Dwight D. Eisenhower calculated that the lessons of D-Day could be usefully applied in persuading Congress to lace the land with highways. His administration dreamed up the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways and argued that these roads were not only about economic development, they were about national security.
"In case of atomic attack on our key cities," he wrote in 1955, "the road net must permit quick evacuation of target areas, mobilization of defense forces and maintenance of every essential economic function." 
 Half a century later, the highways he built can barely handle a 5 p.m. crush of commuters in their S.U.V.'s, much less a panicky evacuation of the capital. But if he were alive today, the old five-star might smile to hear the latest Clinton White House strategy. The president and his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, have taken up a mantra that granting permanent "normal" trading status to China isn't just about profit opportunities, it's also about national security. At the same time, the administration has labeled the AIDS crisis in Africa a threat to national security, and Vice President Al Gore has raised similar fears with his "new security agenda," which includes global warming.
Without question there is a case to be made that economic chaos, disease and climatic upheaval can all trigger political nastiness. So all of this new labeling raises a question: Just when does a big problem turn into a national security threat?
On trade with China, the Clinton administration argument is that granting normal trade status would reassure the Chinese that America isn't trying to hem them in.
"From a national security point of view, it would in my view be a very, very unwise and precarious move to say that the United States doesn't care whether they're part of the world community or not," President Clinton told an insurance group last week, a theme he repeated nightly as he tried to win over 40 or so legislators who were still undecided about the China bill.
Only days before, the White House was arguing that the spread of AIDS in Africa would lead to economic collapse, political instability and civil wars that might eventually require American intervention.
"I'm not saying that we have a short list of national security threats and East Timor is now off and AIDS is on it," Mr. Berger said in an interview. But strife has many origins, he said: "If it creates instability, chaos, conflict and war, that has national security implications."
Mr. Gore, meanwhile, used a foreign policy speech last weekend to argue for the need for "forward engagement" (presumably a Gore-ism for trying to think ahead). He ticked off -- in no particular order of priority -- pandemics, economic inequality, global warming and the digital divide as potential security problems that had to be nipped in the bud.
In Mr. Gore's case, the political calculation is obvious: he is trying to portray his opponent, George W. Bush, as a man caught in what he termed a cold-war mindset that sees national security only in the most conventional terms.
But it is still unclear whether the new Democratic relabeling of issues is just shrewd political marketing -- to Democrats who don't like trade deals, and to Republicans who don't care for foreign aid, particularly when it involves AIDS -- or a truly new agenda for an age of new global threats.
It is hard to tell. As the Clinton presidency winds down, the definition of national security threats has gotten ever fuzzier. Even some senior members of the administration worry privately that the White House regularly overplays its hand and should reserve the national security argument for events tightly linked to the prospect of the United States becoming involved in conflict. "There's a significant risk of crying wolf," one of the president's top security advisers concedes. "This isn't Sputnik," he added, in another allusion to the Eisenhower years, when appeals for education funds could be based on fears that the Russians were well ahead in the race to build the first I.C.B.M.'s.
Clearly there is a strong moral argument for helping the destitute ravaged by AIDS, in Africa or elsewhere. And no doubt the disease could lead to political instability. But so can poverty, and the 1.3 billion people who live on less than a dollar a day trigger meetings at the World Bank these days, not in the Situation Room.
Advisers to Mr. Bush, eager to portray the current occupants of the White House as long on butter and short on guns, carry the argument one step further: by making the list of security threats too long, they argue, the Clinton administration risks taking its eye off more imminent threats. Or as Paul Wolfowitz, dean of the school of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University and one of those advisers, wrote recently, AIDS in Africa and the environment are serious problems, but calling them national security threats carries "the implication that conventional security is no longer something we need to worry much about."
But this is also an administration repeatedly stung by the criticism that its foreign policy has been a series of belated reactions, rather than the product of any global strategy. So Americans may be ready to welcome anything resembling preparation for new crises, as long as it differentiates between real security threats, potential threats and social work. And it is possible -- though hardly certain -- that after a decade of unchallenged power and prosperity, Americans are ready to think about their national security in broader terms.
A decade ago, any serious official who argued that admitting Communist China into a Western trade regime might change China's political culture would have been laughed out of the National Security Council. Today, even some Republicans sound a lot like Bill Clinton when it comes to talking about the benefits of exposing China to a Western-designed legal system or fueling the spread of the Internet. "China's emergence as a world power is a classic security issue," said Richard Armitage, who has served several Republican presidents, "and if getting them into the world trading system makes them more restrained, a better actor, then I'm for it."
Mr. Clinton's most potent argument may be the one he hasn't made in public, chiefly to avoid offending two of America's closest allies. In the first half of the 20th century, Germany and Japan lashed out in large part because they felt the world was constraining not only their military might, but their ability to manufacture and export. Any global system that reduces trade barriers, the theory goes, also deflates some of those pressures.
But non-economic forces also cause wars, and it is a mistake, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers acknowledges, to "overemphasize the link between economic forces and future conflict." Perhaps that is why Mr. Clinton and Mr. Berger last week opened a new front in the China argument. Rather than argue the economic and political benefits of getting China into the tent, they made the case that keeping it out would court disaster -- that insulting China would strengthen the hand of the People's Liberation Army in its battle over China's direction with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, the leader of China's move to a market economy. But if the Chinese economy opens too quickly -- forcing tens or hundreds of millions of workers in inefficient state-owned enterprises out of work -- Mr. Zhu could be blamed for that, too.
Whatever one thinks of the logic, Mr. Clinton's national security case for letting China into the World Trade Organization seems to be winning some converts. "The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has an answer to the economic arguments about this deal," one undecided congressman -- who asked not to be named -- said last week. "But they don't have any answers on the security side." On the other hand, the effort to reclassify AIDS seems to have fallen flat. No one in either party is talking about reallocating the trillions saved by the Soviet Union's fall on international AIDS programs, or any other foreign aid.
But China trade may be different. Eisenhower's highway system is now crumbling, and members of Congress want it fixed. A few who are on the fence about China have suggested that the place to fix the Interstate System is in their districts before Election Day. That might make them more amenable to the Clinton view of national security.

But the main point of his comment was, "When people are prosperous and hopeful, they don't look for men on horseback."

HEADLINE: Next Up, Making Adriaen's Landing Work

BYLINE: By NICOLE ITANO 

 BODY:
THE state government agreed last week to invest more than half a billion dollars in Adriaen's Landing, an ambitious plan to develop Hartford's waterfront that many people hope will ignite an economic revival in the state's struggling capital city.
Hartford, which has the highest unemployment in the state and the lowest per capita income, is trying to capitalize on the experience of other cities such as Baltimore and Cleveland, which have worked to revitalize their downtowns through public investment in sports complexes, convention centers and retail districts. 
 While the state's decision to put $529 million into this project has been lauded as a turning point for downtown Hartford, almost everyone involved with the project agreed that the long-term success of the project will require more than just sticking a new hotel and convention center into the downtown. Supporters hope the project will be a catalyst for further economic development and help turn around the city's image. For that to happen, however, the project must be successfully integrated into the surrounding city and coordinated with other urban revitalization projects.
"This is not a magic bullet for the city," Representative David McClusky said. "The city has a lot to prove. Not only does it have to get this project right so that it doesn't become another Constitution Plaza or Hartford Civic Center, it has to get its act together on other issues such as education and social services."
All together, Adriaen's Landing will cost an estimated $771 million culled from a combination of public and private sources. The state will raise most of its share from bonds. The project will include the construction of a convention center, a 700-room hotel, entertainment and retail space and upper-income housing targeted at young professionals on a 33-acre patch of land near the Hartford waterfront, as well as a $90 million football stadium in East Hartford for the University of Connecticut.
The House of Representatives passed the bill authorizing state funding for the project on Tuesday and Gov. John G. Rowland, who has put his political weight behind Adriaen's Landing from the beginning, signed it into law less than an hour later.
Mr. Rowland's rapid action on the funding bill is illustrative of the unusual coalition that has united behind this project. While the bill faced sharp criticism from some members, it passed easily in both the House and Senate with strong support from both parties.
Public investment in projects like Adriaen's Landing, which are intended to draw people downtown and attract private investment, have become popular methods of urban renewal in cities that have been losing population and jobs to the suburbs.
"These kinds of projects can be very symbolic and very important and significant in making those other kinds of investments take place," said John Melcher, associate state director at Michigan State University's Center for Urban Affairs Community and Economic Development Program. "Downtowns by and large have had a traditional role of being the centers of commerce and financial centers for communities."
Mr. Melcher said a city's image could affect the reputation of the surrounding region, influencing investment decisions and people's decision to move into the area. Much of that image, he said, is based on the perceived vibrancy of the downtown area.
Mr. Melcher cautioned, however, that downtown redevelopment projects must be accompanied by other initiatives to fix schools, support community organizations and provide affordable housing.
"That isn't in and of itself a solution to many of the problems that face our urban cores," he said. "Healthy downtowns and poor neighborhoods make you no more successful than healthy neighborhoods and poor downtowns."
Opponents of the project, who were few in number but vocal with their objections, question whether Adriaen's Landing is even a good place to start revitalizing Hartford. While the project may gentrify the city's center, they argued, it would leave the surrounding neighborhoods mired in poverty.
"A project like this has never, ever, anywhere in the United States, been a catalyst for turning around a distressed city," said Representative Jefferson Davis, an opponent of the bill. "We're going to find ourselves in five years with the convention center done and a city that is still segregated both economically and racially."
Mr. Davis said the Baltimore harbor project, which supporters of Adriaen's Landing and similar projects point to as a classic success redevelopment story, failed to help the poorest residents and improved only a few square miles of the city.
David Rusk, a specialist on urban issues and author of "Inside Games/Outside Games," said that the success of a project like Adriaen's Landing depends largely on whether one is looking at the downtown or the surrounding city. While Adriaen's Landing may turn the downtown into a tourist attraction and popular residential area for young professionals, he said he doubted that any positive economic effect would spill over into the surrounding neighborhoods. Hartford's biggest problems, he said, are its poverty and segregation.
"This initiative is not going to affect that picture," Mr. Rusk said. "That situation is the primary burden that the city of Hartford must deal with."
While Adriaen's Landing has attracted a great deal of attention, city and state officials said it is only one part of the Hartford revitalization effort.
"Adriaen's Landing tends to get a lot of the attention because it's the biggest development project," said Dean Pagani, a spokesman for the governor. "Millions of dollars have been spent in the neighborhood trying to create new business, trying to create safer hosing conditions near Trinity College. It's a process that is taking place throughout the city."
The Capital City Economic Development Authority, a quasi-public agency charged with overseeing Adriaen's Landing and other state-funded redevelopment projects in Hartford, is also working to bring more housing downtown, revitalize the ailing Hartford Civic Center, and bring more parking to the downtown area.
The Riverfront Recapture Project has been working to reconnect the downtown to the water by creating a network of public recreation facilities.
The success of Adriaen's Landing will depend largely on integrating these various projects and connecting them to the rest of the city through transportation and education initiatives, those involved in the project said.
"This is only the end of the beginning," said Brendon Fox, executive director of the Capital City Economic Development Authority.

HEADLINE: Where 'Separate but Equal' Still Rules

BYLINE: By Ward Connerly; Ward Connerly is the chairman of the American Civil Rights Institute and the author of "Creating Equal: My Fight Against Race Preferences."

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
If you're looking for one of the last bastions of segregation in America today, you are likely to find it at your local bookstore. I learned to my surprise and consternation last week that a customer looking for a specific book may need to identify and be conscious of the race of the author in order to locate it. Or the customer will need to presume that the subject matter is an issue of importance only to readers of a specific race.
As a recently published author, I stopped by a prominent bookstore in Washington a few days ago to autograph its stock of my new book, which recounts the story of my advocacy against racial preferences. First I looked in the "New Arrivals" section. It was not there. Nor was it in "Politics & Government" or "Biography & Autobiography." 
 When I asked a store employee to check to see if the book had been ordered, the manager recognized me as the author and helpfully explained that the book had been shelved under "African-American Interest." When I asked why he had placed the book in that section, he said he had done so as a "service to the community."
The "service" to the African-American "community" is in reality a great disservice to the general book-buying public. And for those authors like me who find themselves consigned to the redlined literary ghetto, it represents discrimination of the most insidious type.
One of the great joys of bookstore shopping is serendipity, the unplanned discovery of a book one hadn't known existed. Most of my book purchases over the years have been the result of such chance encounters, and I know that I am not alone. Publishers, after all, work hard to design attractive dust jackets to encourage impulse buying.
But for black authors -- or any authors who write about race issues -- the "special section" approach rules out the serendipitous purchase. Only those book buyers who self-consciously identify with the "black community" are likely to head for the "African-American Interest" shelves.
What about other readers who may be interested in the subjects we're writing about? If they browse in "Performing Arts," will they find the new biography of David Geffen, but not Sidney Poitier's memoir? If they check the shelves in "American History," will they see Tom Brokaw's books on the World War II generation but not Michael Eric Dyson's controversial reinterpretation of the life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.?
The shelving of their books in a special section deprives black authors or "race" authors of significant sales opportunities, putting them at a competitive disadvantage compared with authors whose books are not ghettoized.
But the economic harm pales in contrast to the intellectual and cultural damage caused by the bookstores' version of racial profiling. They have fallen into the trap of thinking that a writer's skin color is a reliable guide to judging the contents of his or her books. My book, like those by other writers who happen to be black, is meant for readers of any race interested in the subjects and controversies I address. By relying on a blatant stereotype -- that blacks are the only ones interested in the history, culture and politics of black people -- the bookstores marginalize some writers and limit their ability to reach out to a broader audience and to share common bonds and values.
If bookstores are truly interested in performing a "service to the community," they should make an active effort to integrate black writers, and writers of other ethnic and racial groups, into the general mainstream of the publishing world, and to allow books to rise and fall on their literary and intellectual merits -- not on their supposed narrow appeal to racial pride.
"Separate but equal" did blacks no favors in schools or on public transportation; it does us no favors in bookstores, either.

HEADLINE: Terrorism's Real Locale

BYLINE: By Ali Abunimah; Ali Abunimah is vice president of the Arab American Action Network.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Global terrorism has a new face: its practitioners are less the well-organized, state-sponsored groups of old and increasingly part of "far-flung and loosely structured webs of terror." So said Secretary of State Madeleine Albright last week as she released a report on global terrorism.
The report also had two other major conclusions: that there has been a shift from politically motivated terrorism to a brand driven by religion and ideology, and that the primary terrorist threats to the United States emanate from the Middle East and South Asia. 
 All of this may seem like conventional wisdom, but a closer look at the government's own data reveals a reality at odds with it. And policies built on flawed conclusions could do more harm than good.
Contrary to popular perceptions, most terrorist attacks against American targets do not emanate from the Middle East or South Asia. Of the 169 specifically anti-American attacks on foreign soil in 1999, 96 were in Latin America, 30 were in Western Europe (many of these committed by groups opposed to the war in Kosovo), nine in the countries of the former Soviet Union and 16 in Africa. Only 11 were in the Middle East, and just 6 in Asia. The proportions have been similar since at least 1996.
Much of the terrorism in Latin America, which includes bombings and kidnappings, is committed in Colombia and Peru by leftist rebels and right-wing paramilitary groups. American citizens and commercial interests have been attacked partly for ransom money to help finance insurgencies and partly to undermine national economies.
But these groups, which commit most of the attacks against Americans and their property abroad, get less attention than groups with Arab or Muslim orientations.
In the Middle East and South Asia, the terrorist attacks against Americans that do take place usually arise from a perception that the United States has taken sides in local political conflicts, like those between Turkey's government and the Kurds or between Israel and the Palestinians. Most terrorism in South Asia is linked to conflicts in Kashmir and Sri Lanka. The United States continues to list some countries in these regions -- most notably Iran, Iraq, Libya and Syria -- as "state sponsors" of terrorism, but acknowledges that they are generally far less active today than in the past.
We must not be complacent about terrorism and should continue trying to identify dangerous groups. But we must also be conscious of overreacting to a phenomenon that typically claims fewer American lives in a year than domestic handgun violence claims in a single day.
Arab-Americans and Muslims living in the United States have too often borne the brunt of government suspicion and media stereotyping. After many in the media rushed to blame Middle Eastern terror groups for the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995 -- erroneously, as they soon learned -- several Arab-American groups reported an increase in hate crimes and harassment. Last December, there were reports of increased and sometimes abusive scrutiny of Arab-American travelers after the State Department linked a threat of terrorism around New Year's Day with the Muslim holy month of Ramadan, without giving any specific grounds for such a connection.
Arabs and Muslims, almost exclusively among immigrant groups, have also been subjected to the use of secret evidence in deportation proceedings -- which, in opposition to American traditions of open justice, has been legal since 1996.
The cruelest paradox is that many of the people suspected of having connections to terrorism actually came to America to escape conflict and injustice in their homelands and could be important allies in the most effective long-term antiterrorist strategy of all: improving relations with their home countries and bringing just solutions to conflicts there. The worst thing the United States could do on the home front is to make them, and the American public, feel that these people are strangers who bring danger to this country, rather than would-be citizens who strengthen it.

HEADLINE: Challenges Lure New Workers

 BODY:
The newest crop of workers may be less concerned than had been thought on the high salaries and stock options.
In a survey to be released today by WetFeet.com, an online recruiting and career site, 869 undergraduate and graduate students from more than 50 colleges and universities around the country were asked to rank their priorities in making career decisions. 
 Challenging work topped the list of important factors. It was followed closely by solid "training for future work." Third in ranking came "good colleagues/boss." Salary was fourth. Stock option packages fell to the bottom, along with "ability to dress casually" and "no weekend work."
"Even in today's economy, where it seems everyone is going after the Internet gold rush, people are looking at their career decisions very carefully and are weighing other factors as more important than salary and stock options in their career decision," said Stephen Pollock, president of WetFeet.com.
Mr. Pollock said he found the results particularly striking because the survey was in February and March, when the stock market was still flying high.
"Even before the recent volatility in the stock market, students show they're very thoughtful about their career choices," Mr. Pollock said.
WetFeet.com, based in San Francisco, hired Q & A Research, a research firm in Novato, Calif., to conduct the online survey. Survey participants were drawn from users of the WetFeet.com site as well as other career and educational Web sites.

HEADLINE: An Absence at Auction Time;
Former Sotheby's Official Is in Limbo Instead of in the Spotlight

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL and RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
In other times, this would have been Diana D. Brooks's moment.
On the eve of the multimillion-dollar spring auctions of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's in New York, it was always Ms. Brooks's striking presence and booming voice that predominated. 
 As the auction house's president and chief executive, she cropped up on "Charlie Rose" or "Today," talking up the forthcoming sales. She greeted the thousands of visitors who thronged Sotheby's York Avenue galleries to view the art coming up for auction. Ms. Brooks, six feet tall with distinctive curly blond hair, presided over cocktail parties, dinners and brunches in the United States and abroad for Sotheby's big-money collectors. When the selling began, sometimes she even wielded the auction gavel herself.
But as experts finish preparing for the two weeks of auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's that begin tonight -- hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of art will change hands -- there is an uncomfortable silence on York Avenue. Ms. Brooks, who had become something of a celebrity in the 13 years since Sotheby's made her the first woman to head an auction house, resigned under fire on Feb. 21, along with A. Alfred Taubman, the company's chairman and its biggest shareholder, in connection with a federal antitrust investigation. Allegations center on whether the two colluded with their counterparts at Christie's, Sotheby's archrival, in setting the commissions charged to buyers and sellers. Between them Sotheby's and Christie's dominate the multibillion-dollar auction market.
The prospect of financial ruin or even prison has taken a toll on Ms. Brooks and her family, friends and associates say. "She is extraordinarily upset and terrified about the consequences," one friend said, speaking on condition of anonymity. She recently cut her hair short and straightened it to be less recognizable. But the friend also described her as resilient and physically fit, still devoted to morning runs of several miles.
Except for one visit to Sotheby's since her resignation -- several hours that employees described as painful in their awkwardness -- Ms. Brooks, 49, has kept to herself, spending considerable time at her mother's house in Hobe Sound, Fla., but returning periodically to a luxury apartment on the East Side of Manhattan and a Connecticut home.
She and her husband, Michael C. Brooks, a venture capitalist, recently bought a house in Jupiter, Fla.; Florida protects homes from seizure in bankruptcy proceedings. The week she resigned from Sotheby's, the couple put their 7,262-square-foot Colonial house in Greenwich, Conn., on the market for $4 million, along with an additional two-acre plot for $1.5 million. They also own a residence in Lawrence, on Long Island.
Ms. Brooks turned away numerous requests for interviews, made through one of her lawyers, Stephen E. Kaufman, and Sotheby's chief spokeswoman, Diana Phillips.
Ms. Phillips, a longtime confidante of Ms. Brooks, said that they had spoken from time to time since Ms. Brooks's resignation and that "she sounded fine."
As Ms. Brooks's lawyers maneuver to negotiate a settlement with the Justice Department, her life is in limbo. If charged and found guilty, she could be heavily fined and sentenced to up to three years in prison. But the Justice Department could still determine that the evidence is insufficient to warrant prosecution, or it might offer her lenience or even immunity in exchange for her testimony.
People close to the case said she was prepared to testify that Mr. Taubman had directed her to meet with her counterpart at Christie's, Christopher M. Davidge, to discuss price-fixing arrangements. But they said she would give such testimony only in exchange for favorable treatment from prosecutors. Such a statement would support one made by Mr. Davidge, who has told the government that a former chairman of Christie's, Sir Anthony Tennant, devised the price-fixing scheme in meetings with Mr. Taubman and then instructed Mr. Davidge to carry it out on behalf of Christie's.
Christie's turned over documentation from Mr. Davidge to the government and has received immunity dependent on its continued cooperation.
Through their lawyers Mr. Taubman and Sir Anthony have disputed the accounts and denied any wrongdoing. The chief Justice Department antitrust prosecutor in New York, John J. Greene, has consistently declined to discuss the case.
Life at Sotheby's is not going on entirely without Ms. Brooks. Although she is no longer a company officer -- she and Mr. Taubman are now listed only as board members in Sotheby's catalogs, and even those references will soon disappear as neither is standing for re-election -- she remains on her full salary of $600,000, people close to her said.
William F. Ruprecht, Sotheby's new chief executive, who joined the company in 1980, confirmed only that she was still getting paid for helping with what he called the transition. Art dealers say that she has been calling their clients, hoping to win business for Sotheby's.
So big was her role at Sotheby's that it was impossible for her simply to walk away, officials at the company say. It was Ms. Brooks who shaped relationships with the company's most important clients, often pre-empting other Sotheby's specialists. It was Ms. Brooks who brokered every important deal, whether for a highly valuable Picasso or for a giant canary diamond. "She's a very smart, innovative thinker," said George Goldner, chairman of the department of prints and drawings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who negotiated complicated deals with Sotheby's while curator of paintings and drawings at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles. "She was not restricted by the boring ways most people buy and sell art."
Collectors and dealers say they do not believe the Justice Department investigation will hamper a serious collector who covets a Monet or a Matisse. But in an auction world governed by the "three D's" -- death, divorce and debt -- the robust economy is such that collectors who don't have to part with their artworks are holding on to them. Since no big collectors died this past winter, experts at both Sotheby's and Christie's were left to scramble for property. Ms. Brooks was Sotheby's most powerful business getter.
The first daughter of a family of six children, Ms. Brooks was brought up comfortably on the North Shore of Long Island. She once said she remembered her father, Martin, telling her she could do anything her two older brothers did.
"I believed him," she said years ago. "When I was 8, I announced I wanted to go to Yale." She graduated from Yale in 1972.
The man she would marry, Mr. Brooks, was also a Yale graduate. Their eldest child, a daughter, graduated from Yale last year.
Her father controlled the only private water company covering a part of New York City, the Jamaica Water Company. After he died in 1977, Ms. Brooks's brother, Andrew, took over the company, then called Jamaica Water Properties, and through rapid acquisitions built it into the nation's largest computer reseller, a multibillion-dollar public company renamed JWP Inc.
Ms. Brooks later joined the board of JWP but left before December 1993, when the company collapsed in bankruptcy and litigation charging fraud in bookkeeping. JWP later re-emerged as the Emcor Group. A lawsuit by insurance companies seeking to recover $148 million from Ernst & Young, JWP's accounting firm, was recently reinstated by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York. Ms. Brooks was not a defendant in the actions.
Ms. Brooks got to Sotheby's by accident. In 1979, while taking a leave from Citibank, where she was a lending officer, to spend more time with her infant daughter, she was told by a friend that Sotheby's was looking for a business person. She was hired part time as director of financial planning and soon assumed the job full time.
For four years Ms. Brooks, who is known to her friends and colleagues as Dede (pronounced DEE-Dee), concentrated on the business side of the company. Then she moved into a more administrative position. That was in 1982, when the company's profits were down and its staff bloated. Through buyouts and pink slips, Ms. Brooks reduced the staff by 90. The move earned her praise from some outside financial analysts, but some inside the company called her "the hatchet woman."
As a boss Ms. Brooks was known for putting a premium on the company's profitability and seeking out new business opportunities, for instance, using the Internet and offering clients insurance. She stressed that the company's future depended on reaching beyond the traditional deep-pocketed buyer.
But her management style lacked subtlety and got mixed reviews. "Dede is an extremely smart person, effective in putting teams together in every imaginable project and creative in bringing people together, often outside their regular expertise," her successor, Mr. Ruprecht, said. "We had a full and frank relationship with each other, and 'warm' needs to get added to that."
But some colleagues and former Sotheby's employees, who signed confidentiality agreements in exchange for lucrative financial settlements but who agreed to speak on condition of anonymity, said she displayed a temper and willfulness, sometimes directed even at Mr. Taubman, the chairman, who himself is strong willed.
"Nothing happened without her knowledge or say-so," said one former employee. "She micromanaged everything."
But Mr. Ruprecht made light of such accounts, saying, "She deconstructed some things and put them back together." He called her "a conciliator and provocateur, as any boss needs to be," adding, "We worked all the time in concert -- not all the time."
From the beginning, despite occasional frictions, Ms. Brooks won the support and respect of Mr. Taubman. "I think they worked closely with each other for a long period of time," Mr. Ruprecht said.
In 1990 she was elected to the board of the Yale Corporation, on which she still serves. She and her husband have contributed generously to the university.
She was asked to leave another board, however, that of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, after she resigned at Sotheby's.
She supports various charities, including a juvenile outreach program in Baltimore that she and two friends started after Ms. Brooks's godson, a 19-year-old high school student, committed suicide two years ago. A sportswoman who runs nearly every day and was known to have whipped male employees on company golf outings, Ms. Brooks frequently spends vacations tackling challenging pursuits like helicopter skiing.
Her competitive side was just as visible in the office. When the company arranged with Amazon.com last year to create a new Web site called Sothebys.Amazon.com, which sells collectibles online, Ms. Brooks was all over the airwaves once more. The company has poured tens of millions of dollars into that site and a sister one, and once more Ms. Brooks was not only Sotheby's champion, but also its personification. Promotions for the Amazon venture featured a picture of Jeff Bezos, chairman and founder of Amazon, and Ms. Brooks posed together in a gilt frame.
That was only last summer, but in many ways it was a long time ago.

Royal KPN Reopens Talks On Mobile Phone Venture
Royal KPN returned to the bargaining table with another potential partner, NTT DoCoMo of Japan, just days after KPN called off merger talks with Telefonica of Spain.
Royal KPN, the largest telephone operator in the Netherlands, and DoCoMo, the mobile operations of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, have been negotiating in fits and starts for over a month now. They are hoping to reach an agreement that could include an alliance between the two companies' mobile telephone operations. Page C12. 

Israeli Cabinet Passes Tax Measure
Israel's cabinet voted to overhaul the country's tax system for the first time in a quarter century, backing a finance ministry proposal for lower income tax rates balanced by new levies on inheritances, foreign earnings and capital gains. C14.
 
Hyundai Announces 'World Car' Deal
Hyundai Motor said it had agreed to take part in an alliance with Mitsubishi Motors and DaimlerChrysler to build a one-liter "world car" with commercial production set for 2002. But DaimlerChrysler denied that it had agreed to take part in the venture. C10.
 
Time Warner's Big Gamble
Time Warner's decision to block the ABC television network in 3.5 million homes last Monday will surely be a prominent chapter in public relations history. In just 39 hours -- the time it took for it to restore the ABC signal -- Time Warner managed to anger many of its customers, rile local and national politicians, , draw the ire of the Federal Communications Commission, and upset what had looked like smooth sailing on the way to approval of its merger with America Online. C20.
 
Cisco's Younger, Smaller Rivals
Cisco is the undisputed leader in Internet communications equipment and the No. 1 company in market value. But in the new economy, few titans remain astride their industry for long, and several newer communications equipment companies have Cisco in their sights. C4.
 
'Millionaire' Enters 'E.R.' Zone
With a week of celebrity contestants, ABC had already found a new way to use "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" to hammer its competitors in a sweeps month. But last Thursday the network managed to pile on some additional torment for NBC: ABC quietly let the Thursday edition of "Millionaire" run eight minutes long, just enough to blunt the start of NBC's strongest series, "E.R." ABC beat "E.R." in its first half-hour, something no regularly scheduled ABC show had done in the seven-year run of the hit medical drama. C20.
 
A Top Inspired by Buckminster Fuller
Kurt Przybilla's childhood jungle gym inspired a lifelong fascination with Buckminster Fuller, the architect and futuristic thinker who invented the geodesic dome, and that led to Mr. Przybilla's newly patented invention, which he describes as an omnidirectional top. He says that his tops can help children develop an intuitive understanding of physics or chemistry in much the same way that an understanding of geometry can grow out of playing with blocks. Patents. C8.
 
Unilever's Shampoo Campaign
Unilever -- a company known for its household and personal care products -- is planning a multimillion-dollar advertising extravaganza for a shampoo line. The British-Dutch conglomerate is staking millions in production costs and more than $40 million in media buys to promote the two-year-old ThermaSilk shampoo, conditioner and hair care line. The campaign goes on the air on network television today. Advertising. C18.

HEADLINE: Falling Euro, a Unity Currency, Instead Bolsters Dollar and Pound

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 7

 BODY:
The pink roses with dashes of peach were popular on a sunny spring afternoon at the downtown farmers' market.
But for anyone thinking in terms of dollars, what was more striking was the price for a dozen: 7.2 German marks, or $3.31. Not long ago, they would have cost almost $5. 
 Fresh-cut flowers have long been a bargain here, but something else is at work now as well: The euro, Europe's fledgling single currency, has plunged 24 percent since its debut on Jan. 4, 1999.
The euro was supposed to unify the economies of 11 European countries and be a symbol of stability to rival the dollar, the yen and even the British pound. The idea was to be a European champion just as Airbus aircraft took on Boeing.
But so far it has been a boon to the very currencies with which it was supposed to compete. Now Americans brandishing dollars or Britons spending pounds are finding bargains from Amsterdam to Vienna.
On Friday, in an extraordinary statement for a central banker, the president of the European Central Bank, who is to the euro what Alan Greenspan is to the dollar, all but apologized for its descent, saying it could "undermine the perception of the euro as a stable currency."
He and and another top official hinted, for the first time, that the bank might reverse its policy and try to raise the value of the euro by going into currency markets and using its reserve of dollars to buy euros.
Thanks to the euro, the price of a McDonald's Big Mac costs less in Germany than in the United States. French wines, Belgian beers and Italian shoes are all bargains when priced in dollars.
Euro bills and coins are not yet in circulation, but local currencies like the German mark and French franc are locked to the euro's value and controlled by the European Central Bank, in Frankfurt. That means that euro weakness matters little for Germans buying goods with marks or Italians with lire.
"As long as I don't go on vacation in the United States, it doesn't bother me," said Dagmar Hofmann, a rose cultivator who brings her flowers into Frankfurt every Friday.
But it means that the euro is suffering a crisis of confidence. Since its debut as the official monetary measure of Europe, used mostly by banks, corporations and stock markets, it has fallen from $1.17 to below $1 last year and to just 89 cents last week.
The decline has mystified analysts, mortified politicians, alarmed central bankers and reignited suspicions among those who never liked the idea of giving up their currencies.
"I believe we will have to pay dearly for the euro," said Rainer Forster, a 37-year-old electrician. "The British haven't joined yet, and now it turns out that was pretty clever."
Wim Duisenberg, the central bank president, said in his written statement on Friday, "The euro's exchange rate has given rise to questions from European citizens who are concerned about the value of their currency." The implication that the bank might intervene cheered euro speculators, and the currency's value rose slightly against the dollar later in the day.
"I understand their concerns, since a persistently lower euro exchange rate might ultimately lead to higher prices in the shops," he added.
The vice president of the bank, Christian Noyer, was blunter, saying that intervention in the markets was "a tool in our hand," and that "we may use it."
For now, though, some Europeans have felt almost cheated. "There is a general feeling of unfairness," the French newspaper Le Monde said in an editorial. "Does the United States deserve such a strong currency? The dollar's superstar status demonstrates how well Washington is able to steer the international financial community into overlooking the weaknesses of the American economy."
Europe is hardly in an economic crisis. The euro countries are growing at a rate of about 3.4 percent this year, the fastest clip in years, and not that bad compared with the 4.5 percent expected for the United States. While inflation is lower than in the United States, unemployment is still high at 9.6 percent. American unemployment was 3.9 percent last month.
Nor are volatile exchange rates anything new. But the fallout from the euro's plunge is getting serious. It has greatly strengthened the position of opponents in Britain, which will make it more difficult for Britain to adopt the currency.
Partly in response, conservative German politicians demanded last week that Greece be barred from adopting the euro for several years. The European Commission recommended on Wednesday that Greece be allowed to join. But when the euro dropped to a low of 88.9 cents on Thursday, the Bavarian governor, Edmund Stoiber, blamed the decline in part on the news about Greece.
The economic consequences are beginning as well. With import prices higher, inflation in the euro zone reached 2.1 percent in March.
By making European goods cheaper in American dollars, the euro has fueled a boom in European exports, and that has propelled German economic growth, which is expected to more than double from last year.
But the euro has also created a deep economic wedge between Britain and the Continent. The pound has risen just as sharply against the euro as the dollar, with devastating results for British manufacturers.
Thanks to the strong pound, British products are now expensive in continental Europe, and Britain is being flooded with low-priced imports from the Continent.
Exchange rate problems were one reason for catastrophic losses at Rover, the British maker of four-wheel-drive vehicles that Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. bought and tried to export to Europe and is now desperately trying to sell.
Jaguar, the luxury auto maker, has absorbed what amounts to a double-digit price decline in Germany to keep from losing market share. So some Jaguar models in Germany cost less than in Britain.
British consumers, furious, have started a campaign called "Rip-Off Britain" to put pressure on companies that charge more for products in Britain than on the Continent.
But the big debate is about the reasons for the decline, which has confounded economists.
The most common explanation is that the American economy's remarkable boom has been an unprecedented magnet for money.
One common criticism of the euro-zone economies is that they have not yet deregulated their labor markets and reduced taxes.
Others point to conflicting signals from the European Central Bank. "I admit that we have not always been equally successful in communicating our policy intentions to the public," Sirkka Haemaelaeinen, a member of the bank's executive board, conceded in a speech last week.
The problems may go deeper. Economists note that the bank has been following a surprisingly loose monetary policy.
Not only are interest rates substantially lower in Europe than in the United States, but the supply of money has also consistently expanded faster than the central bank's own targets, hurting the euro's value.
So far, ordinary citizens have remained fairly relaxed. Even many Germans, who treated the mark with almost religious reverence, seem patient.
"The euro's image is pretty bad right now, but I think it has been bad-mouthed," said Severin Fiebon, a 27-year-old bank worker in Frankfurt. "The euro is still very young."
Gerhard Bocke, a retired teacher here, said he has lived through big swings before. "The exchange rate between the dollar and mark has changed so often," Mr. Bocke said on Thursday. "It goes up, then it goes down. I don't really care about it as long as I don't travel to America."

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Women's Sports Foundation Expands Mission Beyond Opening Doors

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., May 7

 BODY:
Female athletes, coaches, administrators, educators and entrepreneurs gathered here this weekend to celebrate their accomplishments and to prepare for the challenges ahead.
In assessing the state of women in sports, those attending the 14th annual conference of the Women's Sports Foundation agreed that there were more opportunities for women since Title IX of the 1972 Educational Amendments banned sex discrimination in federally funded school programs. Now, in a stance that reflects the influence of the foundation and its constituency, the group wants to focus less on getting in and more on moving up. 
 "Initially the primary function was opening doors of opportunity," said Donna Lopiano, the executive director of the foundation. "Now, it's exploiting the participation of women in sports in an economic sense, gaining access to assets, program expansion and addressing the continuing problem of girls being discouraged from sports."
That sentiment was echoed in the theme of the conference: Brave New World of Women's Sports. For the 350 who registered for the three-day event at the Long Island Marriott, it was a chance to exchange information and ideas, network and develop strategy to fulfill the potential that women have in athletics.
It provided a setting for the kind of informal debate many women had not engaged in since their college days, on topics as disparate as the feasibility of a 24-hour women's sports channel and the notion that news media images have increasingly portrayed female athletes as sex objects.
During a panel discussion on women of color in sport, Krista Ford, the only African-American woman on the United States bobsledding team, talked about the trials and tribulations that come with being "a first and only."
"There's no diversity in winter sports," said Ford, who also competes in bodybuilding. "In bobsledding, there are no women on member boards. It's all good old boys."
Ford said she had grown weary from the constant battles, but vowed to continue the fight "so other kids won't have to go through the hell we've had to endure as pioneers."
Established in 1974 by Billie Jean King, the foundation has emerged as a leader and advocate for women's sports. From May 1974 to May 1999, the foundation awarded more than $5 million in grants and scholarships to girls' sports programs, elite athletes in training and other leaders in women's sports. It annually responds to more than 100,000 requests for information on issues ranging from pregnancy and exercise to coed sports, and assists more than 700 students, parents and coaches a year on gender equity issues.
To ensure its place in the future, the foundation has begun to change the way it reaches its audience. Last year it created a Web site, www.womenssportsfoundation.org.
"Women's sports has been somewhat prevented from educating the next generation," Lopiano said, noting that because men are still largely in decision-making roles in athletics, women do not have equal access to young athletes. "We had to find a way to leap over the more traditional communication systems of getting to kids through teachers in the schools and go directly to the teens by using teen media vehicles: television and the Web. The Web is the most cost effective."
Another measure of the foundation's clout was found in the mix of corporate sponsorships for this year's convention. Although there were female-oriented sponsors like Tampax and Sports Illustrated for Women, big donors also came from the finance, apparel and telecommunications industries. Among them: Merrill Lynch, Mervyn's of California and America Online.
Karin Lofstrom traveled here from Ottawa, where she runs an on-line company for women's sports products.
"We don't have an organization like the Women's Sports Foundation in Canada," she said. "It's so exciting to be here with these women, who are helping to change the role women play in sports not only in America but throughout the world."

HEADLINE: Serving Self While Serving Others

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
J. T. Houk, the impresario behind one of the nation's largest charities, is no stranger to controversy.
The Internal Revenue Service once tried to revoke his organization's tax-exempt status. Last year, Congress and the I.R.S. put a stop to a charitable giving strategy promoted aggressively by Mr. Houk that critics said benefited donors more than recipients. 
 Now Mr. Houk is facing a challenge to what he claims is the cornerstone of his brand of philanthropy: finding ways to have donors and volunteers pay themselves for their charitable deeds.
Rejecting the notion that anyone ought to perform a charitable service for free, Mr. Houk derides what he calls the "charity poverty syndrome." He acknowledges that some people make exceptional volunteers, but says, "Volunteers give you dregs, not dynamite," especially as fundraisers. "You get what you pay for."
Donors who entrust money instead to his Falls Church, Va., charity, known as the National Heritage Foundation, set up individual accounts that mimic foundations at a fraction of the cost. In turn, they are eligible for immediate tax deductions for their gifts and are encouraged to use the money in their accounts to pay salaries and expenses for themselves and their families.
Donors need not worry about the low pay charities offer, says the pitch on the foundation's Web site, "We would strive to bring your salary up to private industry standards."
But many in the charitable world bridle at the notion that people have any business paying themselves to carry out their charitable impulses.
"It's like paying the Girl Scouts to sell cookies," said Jack Shakely, president of the California Community Foundation, which is one of many competing charities that also offer "donor advised" funds, which allow donors to set up individualized accounts with funds earmarked for charity.
The California Community Foundation bars donors from paying themselves or family members. "It's not illegal, but it just doesn't pass the 60-second smell test," Mr. Shakely said.
The National Heritage Foundation, however, is far less restrictive, one reason why at last count tens of millions of dollars from some 4,000 foundations had been set aside for charity under its auspices. How much of that money will ever go to worthwhile causes is far from clear.
Administrative and marketing fees payable to National Heritage, some of which are split with financial advisers who bring in the funds, come right off the top. Then there are also the many families who dip into their National Heritage accounts to pay themselves salaries or defray expenses.
Dr. W. John Martin of Rosemead, Calif., set up his charity to fund research on viruses that no university or government agency would underwrite.
Robert and Cynthia Fleming of Poulsbo, Wash., used some of the money they gave to National Heritage to send their son to Mexico for three years, calling it missionary work. While the Flemings could have tried to create their own foundation, it would have been "very time consuming and expensive," said Ms. Fleming, who heard Mr. Houk's spiel on radio and was persuaded.
Jerome T. Barrett of Falls Church, Va., heard about National Heritage from a colleague. What he finds most appealing was foundation officials' willingness to look after many of the details of running a charity. "They take care of the money, and they will defend you in court" if a donor runs afoul of I.R.S. rules, Mr. Barrett said.
He uses his charity, Friends of FMCS History Foundation, to sponsor research on a book he is writing on the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, where he once worked. His foundation no longer has enough assets to allow him to dole himself a salary, but it covers the rent on his office.
While Mr. Houk says the National Heritage Foundation ultimately controls where every dollar under its management goes, many of his competitors want Congress to outlaw use of such accounts to siphon money to donors and their families. The effort to curb this practice was reported last Friday in The Wall Street Journal. The Clinton administration has proposed going further: restricting the gifts these funds can make to charities registered with the Internal Revenue Service. That would preclude donors from giving to foreign charities and needy individuals.
Mr. Houk makes no bones about favoring old-fashioned entrepreneurship as a way to invigorate the nation's charities. Accustomed to being the focus of regulatory ire, Mr. Houk, a former Fullbright scholar who boasts a law degree, an M.B.A. and a Ph.D., refuses to back down even at the risk of further scrutiny by the I.R.S. and sharp public criticism. "The envelope needs pushing," he said.
If that makes him something of a maverick, so be it. "All progress is created, in my opinion, by skewed personalities," he said. "The champion is not an average guy."
Quick to rely on biblical sources to support his views about paying volunteers, he claims the National Heritage Foundation has the potential to revolutionize churches, schools and other charities. But he is convinced that competing charities, the government and the media are conspiring to put an end to his efforts.
Born in Dayton, Ohio, Mr. Houk, who is known as Dock, describes himself as coming from a wealthy background. He said his family was connected with the Mead Corporation, the giant paper company. He claims to have given nearly all of his inheritance to charities except for some property he kept for his wife and some small mutual fund accounts for his grandchildren.
After graduating from Brown University, he spent a year in Finland on a Fullbright scholarship, where he earned an M.B.A. Later, he added two other advanced degrees before working for the government researching the impact of international aid.
In 1968, dismayed by the government's actions to crack down on private charities, Mr. Houk created the National Heritage Foundation in anticipation of the 1969 Tax Reform Act, which took aim at perceived abuses by corporations and individuals whose charitable activities were said to be more for their benefit than that of others. "I didn't like the 1969 tax act," Mr. Houk said. "I thought it might cauterize charitable giving."
Mr. Houk was also busy on other fronts: creating what he claims was the first socially conscious mutual fund and teaching in the economic and business department of Liberty University, the college founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell.
By the early 1980's, the National Heritage Foundation was coming under increased scrutiny by the I.R.S., which can revoke a charity's tax-exempt status for some offenses. The service brought a case in 1982, alleging that the charity was really a group of private foundations, which would be subject to different requirements, and that it offered significant private benefit to financial planners who promoted it.
Mr. Houk's organization, which by then had ousted him at the insistence of a big donor and had changed its name to National Foundation Inc., won the case in 1987.
He got going again in 1994, forming a new group that he again called the National Heritage Foundation. It invoked many of the same principles about the evils of big government, attracting many powerful supporters. For instance, Bruce R. Hopkins, a prominent Kansas City charity lawyer, wrote the forward to Mr. Houk's book, "The Coming Charitable Revolution," in which he lauded Mr. Houk's vision of a grassroots brand of philanthropy. That said, Mr. Hopkins said in an interview he never meant to provide Mr. Houk's organization with a blanket endorsement.
There also remains significant enthusiasm for Mr. Houk's creativity at motivating people to give among people who work with donors.
"The big issue is charitable entrepreneurship, and how far you can push that," said C. Dennis Brislawn, a trusts and estate lawyer in Kirkland, Wash., whose clients have set up foundations at National Heritage. "Dock Houk is one of the champions to push the limits."
Besides getting a cut of the fees levied on donors' accounts, financial planners who generate a lot of business for National Heritage have also been rewarded occasionally by having foundations set up in their own names at National Heritage's expense. Planners may also use foundations to pay themselves for raising funds for charity.
What Mr. Houk and his organization get out of all this is open for debate.
In 1998, when people were enthusiastic about a plan to buy so-called split-dollar life insurance policies at his urging, National Heritage took in $128 million in revenue, its tax returns show. The split-dollar life insurance scheme, in which donors' gifts to a charity were used to buy life insurance policies naming both the charity and donors' heirs as beneficiaries, was outlawed last year, and Mr. Houk says National Heritage's revenues fell to about $61 million in 1999, information that is not yet available on the tax returns. Some donors who took his advice and bought split-dollar life insurance policies that have backfired are mulling lawsuits, although it is not clear that Mr. Houk would be the target of such actions.
Even in a banner year like 1998, only $3 million was disbursed to outside charities, the tax returns show. Another $3 million covered other program expenses like honorariums and publicity, and nearly $60 million was used to buy insurance policies and other investment products used to build endowments. And information on how much donors are paying themselves cannot be gleaned from the tax returns.
The charity's 1998 tax return makes no mention at all of Mr. Houk's own pay package and does not list Mr. Houk as one of its top officers, omissions that Mr. Houk acknowledged were an error, especially when the organization's letterhead refers to him as its executive director and chief executive officer.
Mr. Houk says he makes about $6 an hour, roughly $12,000 a year or so, in keeping with his sense that he does not need the money. He does, however, allow the organization to pick up some of his expenses, like frequent travel to the West Palm Beach area, where he maintains a modest office.
Having installed his wife, son and daughter-in-law in top positions at National Heritage, he allowed them as a group to make about $166,000 in 1998 salaries, according to the tax returns.
At an airport lounge in West Palm Beach last Friday, Mr. Houk said he did not understand why he was such a target for regulators, who he said were paying undue attention to him.
"We're probably more socially responsible than the average bear," Mr. Houk said defiantly. He says he could easily spend his days playing tennis and enjoying life, but there is little sign of surrender. "We're not going to quit fighting," Mr. Houk said.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Numbers Hint at Change in Voting Rules

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The latest numbers offered a stunning contradiction: a 3.9 percent unemployment rate, the lowest in 30 years, and two major national polls showing Gov. George W. Bush of Texas leading Vice President Al Gore by 5 percentage points.
To put that contrast in perspective, the last time a president's party lost the White House in good times was 1920. And even then, the country was recovering from the double-digit inflation of World War I. 
 So why isn't the booming economy blowing Mr. Bush away? Have the rules changed?
Perhaps.
First, the economy has stayed strong so long that most people are not worrying about it. Peter D. Hart, a Democratic pollster, said, "It doesn't sit there as a major worry that people talk about." Robert Teeter, a Republican pollster who collaborates with Mr. Hart on the NBC News/ Wall Street Journal poll, said one reason for Bush support among older people was that "only about 6 percent of the old people have economic worries."
Second, Mr. Gore does not get credit for the way things are. Polls show the public gives it to President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
That may be reasonable enough, but Mr. Gore's own weakness as a candidate compounds that problem. After all, Mr. Gore is campaigning on a promise to keep the same economic policies Mr. Clinton has followed, while Mr. Bush's central campaign message is that he wants a very big tax cut.
But the NBC/Journal poll showed that only 27 percent of voters thought Mr. Gore was very likely or fairly likely to pursue policies that would keep the economy strong, compared to 32 percent who said that of Mr. Bush. (Both of them enjoyed less credence than they did in December, when 36 percent had confidence in Mr. Gore and 43 percent in Mr. Bush.)
The NBC/Journal poll had Mr. Bush ahead, 46 percent to 41 percent. A Gallup Poll for CNN and USA Today had the Bush lead at 49 to 44. Both polls were taken the last weekend of April, and the margin of sampling error for the NBC/Journal survey was plus or minus three percentage points, one less than for the Gallup Poll.
Mr. Gore has simply not capitalized on winning his party's nomination more easily than Mr. Bush won his or achieving quickly the party unity and support from Bill Bradley that Mr. Bush is still seeking from Senator John McCain.
Mr. Teeter said the data in the NBC/Journal poll explained it. "Gore is not a very good candidate," he said. "He is not a very likable candidate." Mr. Teeter argued that Mr. Gore's frequent attacks on Mr. Bush ran the risk "of looking like the guy who is out of his time," out of step with an optimistic country.
Though Mr. Teeter agreed that a strong economy was a major factor in retaining a president or his party, he said the most "likable" candidate had won most postwar elections. The clearest exception was 1968, when a losing war, civic turmoil and rising inflation helped Richard M. Nixon edge out Hubert H. Humphrey. In 1976, Mr. Teeter said, both Jimmy Carter and President Gerald Ford seemed likable.
Still, these are early days. When the nomination contests ended in March, public interest in the campaign plummeted, and surveys by the Vanishing Voter project of the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University show that knowledge about the candidates has also declined.
There is no question that the Gore message in the summer and fall will emphasize continuity and accuse Mr. Bush of risking prosperity for a needless tax cut. Comparisons with the last Republican administration are inevitable, but will have special bite because the phrase "Bush recession" will surely be used.
Mr. Hart, while conceding Mr. Gore's weak standing, cited a focus group he conducted last Tuesday in a Philadelphia suburb as offering hope for Mr. Gore. Everyone in the group of 12, whether he or she favored Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore, "wanted the same policies," he said. "They didn't want to tinker with the economy."
"Al Gore is sitting on a gusher," Mr. Hart said, if he can find a way to identify himself with the voters' desire for continuity.
The best evidence that it is not too late for Mr. Gore comes from a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken in May 1988. That was the last time a vice president ran to succeed a popular president in an economic boom. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis led Vice President George Bush, 49 percent to 39 percent. It did not last.

HEADLINE: China Trying to Crack Down On Vocal Liberal Intellectuals

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 7

 BODY:
China's leaders are trying to rein in a growing and increasingly assertive liberal intellectual movement, criticizing prominent academics and authors in speeches, forbidding newspapers from running their articles and punishing or shutting down publishers who have brought out their work.
In recent years, unofficial and quasi-official outlets for liberal political ideas have multiplied rapidly in China -- on the Internet, in informal discussion groups, in magazines and books that result from collaborations between independent editors and state publishers. At a time of rapid economic and social change, China's leaders clearly view this trend as a threat to their political power. 
 Despite his Western-leaning economics, President Jiang Zemin has in the last year constantly reiterated the importance of standing fast by Communist ideology in a China overrun with dot-com start-ups. In the last few months, those admonitions have led to a series of punitive actions against writers perceived as straying too far in a liberal or reformist direction.
"It's a very tense time," said a prominent professor, who like others would speak only if not identified. "President Jiang is very unhappy with some things that friends have written. He wants to undertake some ideological cleansing."
In a country where economic reforms have spawned greater pluralism in ideas and the means to express them, it is impossible to mount a concerted old-style Communist Party campaign, academics here say. But the scattershot attacks have been many and varied, and do have short term consequences, at least.
In a speech in Guangdong province, Mr. Jiang himself directly criticized a much-revered retired official of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Li Shenzhi, for an Internet essay.
The editorial offices of the Reform Publishing House in Beijing have been shut down for bringing out "The Secret Scriptures of Officialdom," a book that obliquely describes the back-stabbing and bribery required to attain public office.
Liu Juning, a political scientist who has written about the need for political reform, was fired from his job at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, and editors at the state-owned Commercial Publishers had to write self-criticisms for publishing his book.
High-level officials have canceled the scheduled publication of the second volume of the official "History of the Chinese Communist Party, covering 1949-82, saying the final draft was too critical of the party's past errors. Gong Yuzhi, one of the book's chief editors, has retired as deputy head of the Central Party School, in part as a result.
Editors at two lively, independent newspapers, Southern Weekend and Shopping Guide, have been replaced. And editors at a popular newspaper have been criticized for reporting that several employees of the United States Central Intelligence Agency were disciplined for the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade a year ago -- a fact not reported in the state-controlled media.
"It is evident that Jiang Zemin feels that the intellectual community has become too brazen," said a newspaper commentator, who also would not be identified. "Everyone is aware of the spirit of Jiang Zemin's speeches. And even if they don't agree, they know if they don't act, they're putting themselves in danger."
Chinese liberals say the timing of the intense criticisms, after years of stuttering but slowly expanding intellectual freedom, is probably related to Communist Party politics.
They say China's leaders are nervous about the liberalizing forces that could be unleashed by China's expected entry into the World Trade Organization, as early as this year. They add that Mr. Zemin's tenure as president and party leader will probably end in the next few years and that he is trying to burnish his image to maintain some role for himself in the future. That means turning down the volume of critics.
Overall, the campaign has had a clear dampening effect: China's growing stable of liberal intellectuals -- in universities, government research institutes, the media and publishing -- are lying low. For instance, more than half a dozen people who last year would have been happy to be quoted by name, refused to be identified in this article.
But most remain confident that the current tightening on intellectual life will pass. And in the China of today, threats from the central authorities have diminished influence. Bookstores are still filled with provocative books. And people fired from government institutes can now often find a way to make a living in the expanding private sector.
"I can continue to do my work, but it will be more difficult," said Mr. Liu, the political scientist who was fired. "Now, for example, I think it will be very difficult to publish articles or books in the major media. And, perhaps, students will not be able to invite me to lecture at universities."
The government's surprising face-off with Mr. Li -- by far the mosttalked-about event in the crackdown -- shows both the government's determination to curb liberal voices, and also how far some essayists have gone.
A one-time aide to Zhou Enlai, the late Prime Minister, Mr. Li had been considered nearly untouchable, until he was berated by Mr. Jiang in a speech this year to Communist Party cadres. The criticisms were deleted from published versions of the lecture, Chinese journalists said.
Mr. Li, who is in his late 70's and will probably suffer no immediate effects from Mr. Jiang's speech, has long issued muted criticisms of the government, generally concerning the 1988 military suppression of pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square. But his recent essay was considerably more explicit, mocking last year's lavish celebration of 50 years of Communist rule.
"Hitler is dead, Stalin is dead; there can't be that many countries left that strive for this vision of grandeur," he wrote. "My own guess is perhaps only Kim Jong Il's Korea would embrace it."
His essay was widely circulated in intellectual circles -- on paper and by e-mail. It was ultimately posted on the Internet, though not by Mr. Li himself, his friends say. That is when it came to the attention of government officials.
Although liberal academics say senior officials have also directly criticized a few other longtime reformers, including the economist Mao Yushi, the tightened policy has generally trickled down by more circuitous routes.
In the last year, Mr. Jiang has insisted that all officials rededicate themselves to Communist ideology through his "Three Stresses" campaign ("Politics, Study, Probity"), and some have clearly heeded the call.
In early March, the central government's News and Publications bureau called publishers to a conference just outside Beijing to deliver Mr. Jiang's admonitions, specifically criticizing two publishing houses.
Although all publishing in China is theoretically owned and controlled by the state, most publishers these days collaborate with independent, for-profit book editors, generally by selling them a government license to print a particular book. This widespread practice, which started as a way to raise money for cash-strapped state publishers, has opened up the industry to a broad spectrum of politically sensitive topics, since the actual editing is no longer done by government employees.
At the conference, state publishers were told that Mr. Jiang wanted to curb the practice and were instructed to review all books they had brought out since 1997 to see if they contained attacks on the leadership.
"Suddenly, all of the publishers totally withdrew, without exception," said an independent editor. "Now they've started coming back, but very slowly, and the book has to be totally secure and unprovocative."
The tightening has surprised many Chinese who had hoped that the government would open publishing and generally relax security, once the 50th anniversary celebrations were over last fall. And in a throwback to old-style Communist campaigns, trouble for individuals has often been heralded by an article in an obscure journal or a letter to the editor.
Mr. Liu's firing from the Academy of Social Sciences grew out of an indignant letter from a graduate student at Beijing University who had heard him speak. The letter, printed in Guangming Daily, a party newspaper aimed at intellectuals, was addressed to the academy and also to the president.
Still, even as Chinese intellectuals bemoan the current climate, they feel more inconvenienced than terrified by the government's wrath.
"The methods are pretty much the same as in Deng Xiaoping's and even Mao's time," the professor said. "What's different is that nobody pays attention anymore. The effect is very limited. Intellectuals don't feel that much pressure. And ordinary people don't pay much attention or sympathize with the authors."
He predicted that the current effort would peter out within a year because "no one approves of this kind of criticism anymore." And the graduate student who caused the dismissal of Mr. Liu would probably have trouble getting a university job in the future, he said.
And even as some authors complained that publishers had put their books on hold, strong liberal voices were cropping up here and there -- in some very unlikely places.
The current edition of "Reading Room," a monthly journal published under the auspices of the Hunan Province News and Publication Bureau -- the provincial censorship organ -- features two long, somewhat daring essays. One advocates more aggressive economic reform. The second explores the often prickly relationship between writers and politics.
"In China, winning and consolidating state power was the main objective of all revolutionary work, and publishing, as a part of it, was no exception," Li Xianzhi wrote in this second essay. "The longstanding precepts of 'class struggle' and 'ideological dictatorship' destroyed people's ideas of rule of law, that is, their ideas of freedom."
